PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1964 Code, as supplemented through August 13, 1990, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city commission. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1964 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Numbering System 
    The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of Chapter 4 is 4-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 3-1 and 3-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 3-1.5. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 12 and 13, it will be designated as Chapter 12.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. 
Indexes 
    The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the appropriate page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised sheets are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Roger D. Merriam, Supervising Editor, and Ronald K. McLaughlin, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to City Attorney Geoffrey B. Dobson, City Clerk Paula B. Owens and the city staff for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida  
ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 92-04 
An Ordinance Adopting the Code of the City of St. Augustine, 1992 Edition, as Prima Facie Evidence of the Ordinances of the City of St. Augustine, General and Permanent, as Therein Specified; Adopting Chapter 1 of the Code of the City of St. Augustine, 1992 Edition, as Positive Law of the City of St. Augustine; and Providing an Effective Date. 
Be it Enacted by the People of the City of St. Augustine, Florida: 
    Section 1. The matters set forth in the Code of the City of St. Augustine, 1992 Edition, shall, together with the then current supplements, if any, establish prima facie the Ordinances of the City of St. Augustine, general and permanent in their nature, in force on September 23, 1991, or the effective date of the most recent ordinance included within such supplements, if any. In the event of conflict between ordinances as enrolled on the records of the City Clerk and the provisions of the Code of the City of St. Augustine and supplements, if any, the provisions of such enrolled ordinances shall control; provided, however, that whenever any provision of such Code shall have been enacted into positive law, the text thereof shall be accepted as the official text of such ordinances. 
    Section 2. That Chapter 1 of the Code of the City of St. Augustine, 1992 Edition, be, and the same is hereby, adopted as positive law. 
    Section 3. That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
    Section 4. This Ordinance shall take effect immediately. 
    Passed this 24th day of February, A.D., 1992. 
/s/   
      Tracy W. Upchurch 
      Mayor-Commissioner   ATTEST: 
/s/   
      Paula B. Owens 
      City Clerk

PART I - CHARTER LAWS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The City of St. Augustine was originally incorporated by the Territorial Acts of 1822, pages 86, 87. Since that incorporation it was reincorporated in 1824, 1889, 1915, 1921, 1923 and 1925, when the present Charter, Chapter 11148, was enacted. 
Part I of the Code is made up of the Charter Laws of the City as amended or supplemented. 
The editors in compiling the existing charter laws have in many instances moved sections into more significant article headings. Except as stated, no material within the sections has been disturbed and appears here as recorded in the official journal in the Secretary of State's office. The section, subsection and paragraph numbering and lettering of this compilation of the Charter and amendments have been supplied by the editors, as well as catchlines and article headings. The true identification of each section as to its chapter and section number appears in parentheses at the end of each section. All sections that are no longer effective have been superseded or that consist of mere legislative dicta have been omitted. All words, phrases, corrections, etc., other than placement of statutory references in a uniform style supplied by the editors in the actual body of any section are placed in brackets, or are noted in editor's notes. Obvious misspellings have been corrected without notation. 
A comparative table immediately following the Charter compilation shows the disposition of each section herein. 

ARTICLE I. - TRANSITION; CORPORATE LIMITS 

Sec. 1.01. - Short title. 
    This Act shall be known as the "Charter of the City of St. Augustine, Florida," and in all subsequent amendments thereto, it will be sufficient to refer to this Act as the "Charter of the City of St. Augustine, Florida." 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 221) 
Sec. 1.02. - Existing municipality abolished. 
Editor's note- Section 1.02 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 1. It has been deleted as obsolete. 
Sec. 1.03. - New municipality created. 
    The inhabitants of the City of St. Augustine, Florida as its limits are hereinafter established shall continue to be a body politic and corporate to be known and designated as the "City of St. Augustine, Florida," and as such shall have perpetual succession. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 5) 
Sec. 1.04. - Rights and liabilities of old municipality vested in new. 
    The title, rights and ownership of property, uncollected taxes, dues, claims, judgments, decrees and choses in action, held or owned by the municipality of St. Augustine shall pass to and be vested in the municipal corporation organized under this Act to succeed the municipality abolished. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 2) 
Sec. 1.05. - Obligations not to be impaired. 
Editor's note- Section 1.05 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 1. It has been deleted as obsolete. 
Sec. 1.06. - Officers to continue in office; ordinances unimpaired. 
Editor's note- Section 1.06 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 4. It has been deleted as obsolete. 
Sec. 1.07. - Liens not impaired by act. 
Editor's note- Section 1.07 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 4. It has been deleted as obsolete. 
Sec. 1.08. - Boundaries. 
    The boundaries within which shall be comprehended and included the territory of the City of St. Augustine, Florida shall be as follows: 
(a)  Beginning at the southeast post of the west abutment of the North River Bridge, in the City of St. Augustine, Florida, and running thence 
(b)  South 32° 0' East 7,280 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits on the south shore of the St. Augustine Inlet, in the subdivision known as Davis Shores, thence 
(c)  Following the south shore of St. Augustine Inlet in a southerly direction 8,040.5 feet to a concrete monument marked city limits set at the southeast corner of lot 4, section 21, township 7 south, range 30 east, thence 
(d)  South 65° west 10,480 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits set on the southwest point of the San Sebastian River at its connection with the Matanzas River, thence 
(e)  North 54° 45' west 3,680 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits, set on the south point of Gonzales Creek at its connection with the San Sebastian River, thence 
(f)  Northerly and following the west shore of the San Sebastian River 3,200 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits set at the southeast corner of tract No. 3 of the M. Solano grant, section 49, township 7 south, range 30 east, thence 
(g)  South 56° 15' west 1,760 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits set at the west angle of Arapahoe Street, thence 
(h)  North 79° 45' west 1,560 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits, set 150 feet west of the Dixie Highway on the south side of Hancock Street, thence 
(i)  North 3° 0' west 1,800 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits set at a point 150 feet south of Anderson Street and 150 feet west of the Dixie Highway, thence 
(j)  South 86° west 1,360 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits, set at a point 150 feet west of Whitney Street, thence 
(k)  North 3° 0' west 3,600 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits, set 150 feet west of Whitney Street at the first angle to left in Whitney Street, thence 
(l)  North 8° 45' west 4,165 feet, more or less, to the center line of Ravenswood Drive and 150 feet west of Whitney Street, thence 
(m)  North 81° 15' east along the center line of Ravenswood Drive 3,680 feet, more or less, to the west shore of the San Sebastian River, thence 
(n)  Northerly following the west shore of the San Sebastian River 5,915 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits, set on the west shore of the San Sebastian River, thence 
(o)  North 27° 0' west 3,760 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits at the township line between townships 6 and 7, south range 30 east, thence 
(p)  East along the township line 2,000 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits, set on the west side of the Dixie Highway, thence 
(q)  South 27° 0' east to the south side of Poinciana Avenue, thence 
(r)  Easterly along the south side of Poinciana Avenue to a concrete monument marked city limits at its intersection with the township line between townships 6 and 7, south range 30 east, thence 
(s)  East along the township line to a concrete monument marked city limits which is 2,880 feet east from its intersection with the south line of Poinciana Avenue, thence 
(t)  South 23° 30' east 7,200 feet, more or less, to a concrete monument marked city limits, at the south line of the causeway (or extension of May Street) leading to the North River Bridge, thence 
(u)  Following the south and east side of the causeway to the North River Bridge (or the extension of May Street) to the place of beginning, and containing 11.3 square miles, more or less. (Excepting the right-of-way of road 4 through the M. Solano grant, section 49, township 7 south, range 30 east.), and 
(v)  All that portion of lots 6 through 11, inclusive, block 5, Rothschild's Addition, according to the map or plat thereof recorded in map book 3, page 133, public records, St. Johns County, Florida, outside the above-described limits of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(w)  A parcel of land in section 40, township 7 south, range 30 east, St. Johns County, Florida, more fully described as follows: Commencing at the intersection of the center line of Arapaho Avenue with the north line of a 30-foot street which runs easterly to San Sebastian River, said 30-foot street being the former north boundary of Diesel Boat Plant; thence south 52° 45' west, on the southwesterly extension of said north line of 30-foot street, 17.76 feet to the point of beginning at the southeast corner of the herein described parcel of land on the southwest line of Arapaho Avenue; thence continuing south 52° 45' west, on said extension of the north line of 30-foot width street, 545.17 feet; thence north 12° 29' 15? west, on the east right-of-way line of U.S. Highway No. 1, a distance of 200 feet; thence south 63° 34' 58? east 25.65 feet to the center line of a vacated road, said vacated road being 20 feet in width and being known as the road to Bettes Cottage; thence north 52° 23' 45? east 10.31 feet to the east line of said road to Bettes Cottage at the southwest corner of land described in deed book 231, page 123, public records of said county; thence continuing north 52° 23' 45? east, on the south line of said land described in deed book 231, page 123, and the south line of land described in deed book 231, page 532, a distance of 337.90 feet; thence south 69° 35' 45? east, on the southwest line of Arapaho Avenue, 190.30 feet to the point of beginning, containing 1.68 acres, more or less. 
(x)  Lots 4 and 5 and Lots 12 and 13, Block 5, Rothschild's Subdivision. 
(y)  That part of government lot 8, section 21, township 7 south, range 30 east and that part of the north 600 feet of government lots 1 and 2, section 29, township 7 south, range 30 east, lying above the mean high-water line of the Matanzas River not hereinabove included within the City Limits of the City of St. Augustine, Florida.

M., and being described in the United States Land Office Survey of 1850, and also all the lands formed by the sea since said survey, lying east of said lands and between the north boundary line prolonged of said southeast quarter section 21 and the south boundary line prolonged of said section 27. 
(aa)  Lots 2, 3, 14 and 15, Rothschild's Subdivision. 
(bb)  Lots 1 and 16, Rothschild's Subdivision.

Sec. 1.09. - Property excluded to pay pro rata share of debts. 
Editor's note- Section 1.09 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1933) ch. 16659, § 3. It has been deleted as preempted by F.S. § 171.022. See also F.S. §§ 171.052, 171.061. 
Sec. 1.10. - City may furnish water to excluded property. 
    The City of St. Augustine, Florida is hereby vested with authority to furnish water to any of the excluded lands, real property and territory, and to make rules and regulations for its use and the price to be paid for said water. Nothing in this Act shall be construed to divest the said city of its title or ownership of any property of said city in said excluded land, real property or territory. 
(Laws of Fla. (1933) ch. 16659, § 4)

Sec. 1.15. - State land granted to city. 
    The State of Florida hereby grants to the City of St. Augustine, in fee simple absolute, all lands and river bottoms owned or held by the State of Florida, in trust or otherwise and lying and being within the corporate limits of said City of St. Augustine. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 9)

ARTICLE II. - CITY COMMISSION AND CITY EMPLOYEES 

Sec. 2.01. - Composition; qualifications of members; terms of office; manner of election. 
    The city commission of the City of St. Augustine, Florida shall consist of five (5) members and who shall be qualified electors of said city, with one of the commissioners to be designated as mayor in accordance with this charter. Each commissioner shall be elected at large in the manner hereinafter provided. Commencing with the general election to be held in November, 1992, three (3) commissioners shall be elected, the candidate receiving the highest number of votes cast for Seat One to serve for a term of four (4) years; the candidate receiving the highest number of votes cast for Seat Two to serve for a term of four (4) years; and the candidate receiving the highest number of votes cast for Seat Three to serve for a term of two (2) years, and thereafter, commencing with the general election to be held in November, 1994, three (3) commissioners shall be elected. The candidate receiving the highest number of votes cast for Seat Four to serve for a term of four (4) years, the candidate receiving the highest number of votes for Seat Five to serve for a term of four (4) years, the candidate receiving the highest number of votes cast for Seat Three, designated as the mayor/commissioner seat, to serve for a term of two (2) years. Thereafter in general elections to be held in November of each even numbered year, successful candidates for Seats One, Two, Four and Five shall be elected for a term of four (4) years and the successful candidate for Seat Three receiving the highest number of votes shall be elected for a term of two (2) years." 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 8; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 2; Laws of Fla. (1955) ch. 31217, §§ 1, 2; Laws of Fla. ch. 67-1975, § 8; Ord. No. 87-17, § 1, 4-13-87; Ord. No. 90-05, § 1, 3-12-90; Ord. No. 06-17, § 1, 8-14-06) 
Cross reference- Election of member of city commission as mayor, § 5.03. 
Sec. 2.02. - Powers generally; members to judge own elections, etc.; forfeiture of office on conviction of crime. 
    The city commission shall constitute the governing body of the city, with powers as hereafter provided, to pass ordinances, adopt resolutions and appoint an administrative officer to be known as the city manager and to exercise all other powers hereinbefore or hereafter provided. A quorum of the city commission shall consist of three commissioners, but a less number may adjourn from day to day to compel the attendance of absent members in such manner and under such penalties as may be prescribed by ordinance and no legislative action on the part of the city commission shall be valid unless concurred in by a three-fifths vote of all the members of the city commission. The city commission shall be the judge of the election and the qualifications of its own members subject to review by the courts. Any member of the commission who shall be convicted of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude while in office shall forfeit his office. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 8; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 2) 
Editor's note- The last sentence has been altered to read as shown. It appears to be amendable by ordinance. See AGO 073-25. 
Sec. 2.03. - Members of the city commission to be residents and electors; dual office-holding prohibition and ethics laws. 
    Members of the commission of the City of St. Augustine, shall be residents of the city, and the members of the commission shall have the qualifications of electors therein. The prohibition against dual office-holding and the regulation of public ethics shall be as required pursuant to Florida law. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 12; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 3; Laws of Fla. (1955) ch. 31220, § 1; Ord. No. 18-05, § 1, 2-22-18) 
Sec. 2.04. - Public officers and employees to comply with State of Florida Code of Ethics. 
    Reporting individuals, as defined and interpreted consistent with Florida law, shall comply with the State of Florida's financial and gift disclosure regulations. All public officers and employees shall comply with the State of Florida's code of ethics, including, but not limited to, prohibitions on gifts intended to influence official decision-making. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 15; Ord. No. 18-13, § 1, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 2.05. - Forfeiture of office by commissioner losing qualifications. 
    Any commissioner who shall cease to possess any of the qualifications required under the six [four] preceding sections [§§ 2.01-2.04] shall forthwith forfeit his office. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 16) 
Editor's note- As to the term "six preceding sections," two of the original six (6) sections have since been repealed. 
Sec. 2.06. - Vacancies. 
    Any vacancy in the city commission shall be filled until the next municipal election by vote of the remaining members of the commission; provided, that if such vacancy is not filled within ten days after it shall have occurred, appointment to fill the existing vacancy shall be made by the Governor. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 17) 
Editor's note- The last clause of the above section has been deleted as superseded by F.S. § 100.361(8). See also F.S. § 100.361(4), (9). 
Cross reference- General provisions relating to elections, Art. VI. 
Sec. 2.07. - Group insurance of city employees-Authorized. 
    The City of St. Augustine, Florida is hereby authorized and empowered to provide for life, health, accident, hospitalization, surgical, and annuity insurance, or all or any such insurance for its employees and officers, excluding members of the city commission, upon a group insurance plan and to that end to enter into agreements with insurance companies to provide such insurance. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 61-2737, § 1) 
Sec. 2.08. - Same-Payment of premiums by city. 
    The City of St. Augustine, Florida is hereby authorized and empowered to pay all or any portion of the premiums for such group insurance from the general fund of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 61-2737, § 2) 
Sec. 2.09. - Same-Deductions from salaries. 
    Upon the request in writing of any employee or officer, the director of financial services, is hereby authorized and empowered to deduct from the wages of such employee or officer, periodically, any premium or any portion of premium for such insurance which such employee or officer has agreed to pay, and to pay or remit the same to the Insurance Company issuing such group insurance. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 61-2737, § 3) 
Sec. 2.10. - Annual Christmas bonus. 
    The City of St. Augustine, Florida, is hereby authorized and empowered to pay, by resolution, to each of its officers and employees a Christmas bonus less all necessary deductions. That such bonus shall be in addition to and in no manner in lieu of any other regular compensation paid to such officer and employee. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 59-1787, § 1; Ord. No. 379-A, § 1, 12-17-73) 
Sec. 2.11. - Removal of city official; hearing. 
    That in the event of the removal of any paid official of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, appointed by the city commission of said city, after having served for a period of thirty days such official, upon request within three days thereafter, shall be entitled to a public hearing within fifteen days after said removal, and the final removal thereof shall not be effective until after such public hearing. 
(Laws of Fla. (1955) ch. 31223, § 1) 
Secs. 2.12-2.17. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POWERS AND DUTIES 

Sec. 3.01. - General state laws. 
    All general laws of the state applicable to municipal corporations, now or which may hereafter be enacted, and which are not in conflict with the provisions of this charter or with the ordinances and resolutions hereafter enacted by the city commission, shall be applicable to this city; provided, however, that nothing contained in this charter shall be construed as limiting the power of the city commission to enact any ordinance or resolution not in conflict with the constitution of the state or with the express provisions of this charter. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 219) 
Sec. 3.02. - General powers. 
    The City of St. Augustine, Florida, by and through its city commission, shall have and is hereby granted the right, power and privilege: 
(a)  Taxes. To levy taxes and assessments. 
(b)  Public works. To control, perform and furnish all public services including the services of a civil or other engineer for the purpose of obtaining data, estimates, plans and specifications for proposed or contemplated public works or improvements except as otherwise herein provided. 
(c)  Acquisition of lands. To acquire by purchase, gift, devise, bequest, donation, lease or condemnation any real or personal property or any estate, right, easement or interest therein, situate within or without the corporate limits of the City of St. Augustine for any of the uses, purposes and needs of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, and upon the acquisition of same to hold, use, manage, maintain, control, sell, lease, donate, exchange, mortgage, pledge or otherwise dispose of and encumber the same. 
(d)  Lands, buildings, water, eminent domain. To maintain and further public improvements and works of all kinds, including municipal and other public buildings, armories, markets, toll bridges, airports and all buildings and other structures necessary or appropriate for the use of the city, and to acquire by condemnation proceedings or otherwise any and all lands, riparian or otherwise, and other rights and easements necessary for such public works and improvements; to purchase, hire, construct, own, maintain, operate or lease works for supplying the city and its inhabitants with water; to acquire in any lawful manner in any county of the State of Florida, or without said state, such water, lands and land under water as may be deemed necessary for the purpose of providing an adequate water supply for said city and for the piping of said water from such land or lands under water herein authorized to be acquired, wheresoever situate, to the said City of St. Augustine for constructing and erecting necessary dams, pumping stations and any and all other works in connection therewith; to make all reasonable rules and regulations for promoting the purity of its water supply wheresoever situate, and for protecting the same from pollution; and for this purpose to exercise full police powers over all lands comprised within the limits of the watershed territory tributary to such water supply wherever such land may be located in the State of Florida; to impose and enforce adequate penalties for the violation of any such rules and regulations; and to prevent by injunction any pollution or threatened pollution of such water supply, and any and all acts likely or considered likely, to impair the purity thereof; and for the purpose of acquiring lands or materials for any such use, to exercise within the State of Florida, all powers of eminent domain. For any of the purposes aforesaid, the said City of St. Augustine, by and through its city commission, shall have the right, power and authority to acquire by condemnation, purchase or otherwise, any estate or interest in such lands, or any of them, or any right of easement therein, reserving to the owner or owners thereof such rights or easements as may be prescribed in the ordinance providing for such condemnation or purchase of any lands or interest therein. The city may sell or supply to persons, firms or industries residing or located without the city limits any surplus of water it may have over and above the amount required to adequately supply its own inhabitants. 
(e)  Wharves, bridges. To establish, build, construct, maintain and operate public lands, public wharves, docks and toll bridges within the city; and to acquire by condemnation or other lawful manner all lands, riparian and other rights, approaches and easements necessary for the purposes aforesaid; to lay and collect reasonable duties or wharfage fees on vessels or boats using any such landings, wharves or docks; to assess and collect tolls from and upon any municipally owned toll bridge or bridges of the city and to fix the rate of such tolls and to provide for the application of the revenues derived from such tolls to any municipal purpose or purposes; to dredge or to deepen the harbor or rivers, or any branch or portion thereof, within the limits of said city; to prescribe and enforce reasonable rates and regulations for the protection and use of its said properties. 
(f)  Aircraft regulations. To license and regulate all and every manner and kind of air vessels operated over the city; and to stipulate the height at, and the manner in which said air vessels may be operated above the area included in the city limits, and to license and register the pilots thereof; to establish and maintain and equip municipal airports, and to regulate the use thereof and to prescribe and collect fees or tolls for the use thereof. 
(g)  Plats, fills, conveyances. To develop by filling, platting, bulkheading, reclaiming, dredging, subdividing or otherwise improving as may be prescribed by the city commission for the health, comfort, convenience and amusement of the inhabitants of said city, all lands acquired by the said city, by purchase or otherwise, and lying and being within the corporate limits of said city as hereinbefore set forth; such development may be carried on under contract with persons, firms or corporations or otherwise as the city commission may deem wise; and in the furtherance of such development of all land acquired by said city, by purchase or otherwise, the said city commission shall have the right and power to make, execute and deliver good and sufficient deeds of conveyance under such restrictions as may be prescribed by the city commission to persons, firms or corporations for private purposes, and to receive and accept money or other valuable considerations, the kind and amount to be fixed by said city commission, in payment for the conveyance of such lands; provided, however, that all moneys derived from the sale of such lands, after the costs of such development have been paid, shall be used in the building of municipal wharves, docks and terminals, yacht basins, piers, parkways, golf links and suitable buildings to be operated in connection therewith, sanitation and for the furtherance of commerce and navigation. 
(h)  Historical sites. It is hereby declared and enacted that the preservation, restoration and maintenance of the City of St. Augustine's ancient landmarks, sites, buildings, remains and other property of historical or antiquarian interest, of scenic beauty, recreational or scientific utility, remarkable phenomena or other unusual features is a public use for the observation, education, health, pleasure, benefit and general welfare of its citizens. 
(i)  Underground wiring-Buildings; zoning. The City of St. Augustine, by and through its city commission, be and it is hereby authorized and empowered by its zoning ordinances to define the terms "residence," "place of residence," "business," "place of business," "business, residential," "historical park," "parking," "scenic and boulevard areas and districts"; to limit, regulate, control or prohibit the erection or construction of any pole, object or thing for carrying, holding or maintaining any overhead wires; to limit and regulate the location, or require the placing underground, of all overhead wires within the boundaries of the City of St. Augustine, Florida; to prohibit, regulate and control the construction, erection, maintenance and use of any and all signs, billboards or displays of any nature over and upon the streets of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, and over and upon the property of any individual, person, firm, corporation or association situated within the corporate limits of the City of St. Augustine, Florida; to regulate, control and limit the architectural design, kind of material, height, size and location of buildings and structures hereafter erected; and to regulate and control the use and alteration of present buildings and structures and those to be hereafter erected and constructed; to require the alteration and razing of present buildings or structures or portions thereof which are in conflict with the zoning ordinance or ordinances of the City of St. Augustine, Florida; to regulate, control and determine the area of yards, courts and other open spaces, and to create and establish, regulate and control business, residential, historical, park, parking, scenic, boulevard and other similar areas and districts and combinations thereof, and to prescribe for each such area and district the business, trades and industries that shall be excluded or allowed and regulated therein. Such regulations shall be designed to promote the public health, safety from fire and other damages, preserve and maintain ancient landmarks, buildings, remains, sites and other property of historical or antiquarian interest, of scenic beauty, recreational and scientific utility for the education, pleasure, benefit and general welfare of the inhabitants of the City of St. Augustine, and their property, and shall be made with reasonable consideration, among other things taking into consideration the location of the districts, its peculiar suitability for particular trade or industrial uses, historical, scenic, recreational, scientific and educational value and the conservation of property and enhancement of property values in such districts and the direction and general supervision of building development in accord with a well considered and duly adopted plan; the grant of specific powers in relation to the regulation of buildings and the location of business, trades and industries shall not be dependent upon any state law. 
(j)  Traffic. The City of St. Augustine, Florida, by and through its city commission, be and it is hereby granted full power and authority by ordinance or ordinances to regulate and control all traffic of any nature whatsoever, and prohibit where necessary the use of motor vehicles, over, upon and in its streets, roads, parks, parking areas and boulevards; and to regulate and control the width, height and weight of any kind of any and all motor or other vehicles; to establish terminals for passenger and freight motor lines and when so designated said passenger and freight lines shall take on and discharge their passengers and freight at only such designated terminals. 
(k)  Underground wiring. The City of St. Augustine, Florida, by and through its city commission, be and it is hereby granted the power and authority to regulate, control or prohibit by ordinance the erection or construction of any pole, object or thing for carrying, holding or maintaining any overhead wires, and of the stringing of any wires on any pole, object or thing within the incorporated limits of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, and to compel by legal action all individuals, firms, associations or corporations owning or maintaining overhead wires on poles or other objects or things within the limits of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, to place said wires underground and to raze the poles, objects or things on which they are now strung. 
(l)  Signs and advertising-City streets. The City of St. Augustine, Florida, by and through its city commission, be and it is hereby further granted full power and authority by ordinance or ordinances to prohibit, regulate and control the construction, erection, maintenance and use of any and all signs, billboards, or displays of any nature over and upon the streets of the City of St. Augustine. 
(m)  Same-Private property. The City of St. Augustine, Florida, by and through its city commission, be and it is hereby further granted full power and authority by ordinance or ordinances to prohibit, regulate and control the construction, erection, maintenance and use of any and all signs, billboards or displays of any nature over and upon the property of any individual, person, firm, corporation or association situated within the corporate limits of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(n)  Eminent domain. The City of St. Augustine, Florida, by and through its city commission, be and it is hereby granted the power of eminent domain, upon payment of just compensation, to take the fee title to property or any right, easement or interest therein less than the fee as may be necessary for the preservation, restoration and maintenance of its ancient landmarks, sites, buildings and other property of historical or antiquarian interest, of scenic beauty, recreational or scientific utility, remarkable phenomena or other unusual feature, for the elimination of signs, billboards or similar mediums of display, for the relocation, or the placement of overhead wires underground, and for the relocating of the razing of the poles, objects or things upon which said wires are strung, within the corporate limits of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(o)  Acquisition of property. The City of St. Augustine, Florida, by and through its city commission, be and it is hereby authorized and empowered to receive, accept and acquire by gift, devise, bequest, donation, purchase, lease, condemnation or otherwise historical landmarks, sites, remains, buildings, monuments, cemeteries or other antiquarian interest or value, scenic beauty, scientific interest, recreational utility, remarkable phenomena or other unusual features, books, manuscripts and other personal property of historical value, relics, as well as money for the purchase and maintenance of same, and to hold, control, own and use the same and provide for the restoration, care and preservation of the same; and in the same manner to receive, accept and acquire any property immediately contiguous to and adjoining any such real estate which is necessary for any such educational, scientific or historical purpose or for the accommodation of the public in visiting such historical site, object or place, or which is essential to the carrying out of the intent and purpose for which the park, preserve, site or memorial was created; the City of St. Augustine, by and through its city commission, be and it is hereby specifically authorized and empowered to hold, use, manage, control, sell, lease, donate, exchange, mortgage, pledge or otherwise dispose of any such property or any part thereof, upon such terms and conditions as may be prescribed by the city commission of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, whether the said property was acquired by gift, devise, bequest, donation, purchase, lease, condemnation or otherwise. 
(p)  City may act as trustee. The City of St. Augustine, Florida, by and through its city commission or other governing head, be and it is hereby granted the power and authority to act as trustee for any money and property, real or personal, which may be placed by gift, devise, bequest, donation or otherwise in its hands for the use and benefit of said city, and/or for the use, observation, education, health, benefit, pleasure and general welfare of the citizens of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, and/or for the restoration, preservation and maintenance of ancient or historical landmarks, sites, cemeteries, graves, military works, monuments, locations, remains, buildings and other property or objects of historical or antiquarian interest or value, scenic beauty, scientific interest, recreational utility, remarkable phenomena or other unusual features of the City of St. Augustine, and to bind the said city, its commissioners or other governing head, in the acceptance thereof, and to any and all conditions attached to such gift, bequest, devise or donation; that such money and property shall not be subject to or held liable for any claim, indebtedness, judgment, mortgage or lien which has been or may be obtained by any person, firm, corporation or association against the City of St. Augustine, Florida; that the said property or money coming into the hands of said city in trust shall be held and used only for the purposes for which the said property or money is placed in its hands in trust, and that all such money and property shall be inviolate and not subject to any action at law or equity against the said City of St. Augustine, Florida, for any of its said obligations. 
(q)  General law. The enumeration of the particular powers herein shall not be construed or held to be exclusive, but in addition to the powers enumerated herein, implied thereby or appropriate to the exercise thereof, the City of St. Augustine, Florida, shall have, and may exercise thereof all other powers which are conferred upon cities by the general laws of which, under the constitution and laws of Florida, it is and would be competent for this section expressly to enumerate. 
(r)  Codification of ordinances. The City of St. Augustine, Florida, shall have the power, and is hereby authorized, by and through its city commission, at any time, to appoint some person or persons and authorize him or them to arrange and codify the ordinances of said city and to publish such codification in an appropriate volume which shall become the laws of said city upon the adoption by ordinance duly passed by the city commission; and provided further, that in the exercise of the power by said commission to adopt said codification, it shall not be necessary to publish said codification, but the publication of the ordinance adopting the same shall be sufficient to make the codification of such ordinances binding as the laws of said city. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 7; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 1; Laws of Fla. (1937) ch. 18873, § 1; Laws of Fla. (1947) ch. 24859, § 1) 
Editor's note- Former subsection (i) (pertaining to zoning) has been deleted as preempted by F.S. § 163.3161 et seq. 
Sec. 3.03. - Powers as to zoning. 
Editor's note- Section 3.03 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1937) ch. 18873, § 2. It has been deleted as obsolete. 
Sec. 3.04. - City may operate municipal bus line. 
    An additional power is hereby granted to the city commission and the City of St. Augustine, Florida, to wit: The City of St. Augustine, Florida shall have the power and authority to buy, purchase and sell, to lease and mortgage, and to maintain and operate a municipal bus, or bus line for the carrying of passengers and freight within the city limits of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. (1931) ch. 15500, § 6) 
Sec. 3.05. - Commission to exercise all powers not delegated; administrative service to be dealt with through city manager. 
    All powers of the city except such as are vested in the jurisdiction of the municipal court and except as otherwise provided by this charter or by the constitution of the state, are hereby vested in the city commission; and, except as otherwise provided by this charter, or by the constitution of the state, the city commission may, by ordinance or resolution, prescribe the manner in which any power of the city shall be exercised. Neither the commission nor any of its members shall dictate the appointment of any person to office or employment by the city manager or in any manner prevent the city manager from exercising his own judgement in selecting the personnel of his administration. The commission and its members shall deal with the administrative service solely through the city manager and neither the commission nor any member thereof shall give orders to, nor make requests of any of the subordinates of the city manager, either publicly or privately. Provided, however, nothing herein shall be taken or construed as a criminal violation or to prohibit the commission or any member thereof from making requests for information only from any of the subordinates of the city manager or the city's administrative service. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 11; Ord. No. 88-56, § 1, 9-26-88) 
Editor's note- References in the above section to the municipal court are obsolete. See Fla. Const. art. V, § 20(d)(4). 
Sec. 3.06. - Authority to provide fire protection and other services beyond limits. 
    The City of St. Augustine, Florida, is hereby authorized and empowered to provide fire protection and other governmental services beyond the corporate limits of said City and to enter into contracts for such purposes. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 61-2736, § 1) 
Sec. 3.07. - Authority to promote and publicize city. 
(a)  The city commission of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, is hereby authorized and empowered to use such means and media as said commission deems advisable to publicize and make known the advantages, facilities, resources, products, attractions and attributes of the City of St. Augustine, Florida; to promote the said city as a site for conventions and gatherings of all kinds; to create a favorable climate of opinion concerning the said city; and to cooperate with any and all other governmental agencies in accomplishing these purposes. These are hereby declared to be valid municipal and public purposes. 
(b)  The city commission of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, is hereby authorized and empowered to pay the expenses of such activities and the cost of carrying out the purposes of this act out of general municipal funds. Said payment may be made without regard to whether the expense or cost is incurred within or without the limits of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(c)  It is the intention of the legislature that the authority granted in this act shall be cumulative and that funds expended hereunder shall be in addition to all other expenditures authorized by law. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-2158, §§ 1-3) 
Secs. 3.08-3.12. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXECUTIVE AND ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICERS 
DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4.01. - In whom power vested. 
    The executive and administrative powers of the city, not herein otherwise provided for, shall be vested in and exercised by the following officers and departments: 
    A city attorney, a municipal judge, and three departments as follows: Department of public safety and welfare and public works, department of records and taxation and department of finance. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 35) 
Editor's note- References in the above section to a municipal judge are obsolete. See Fla. Const. art. V, § 20(d)(4). 
Sec. 4.02. - Investigation of departments, officers; process; procedure. 
    The city commission, or any committee thereof, the city manager or any advisory board appointed by the city commission for such purposes, shall have power at any time to cause the affairs of any department or the conduct of any officer or employee to be investigated and for such purpose shall have power to compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of books, papers and other evidence, and for that purpose may issue subpoenas or attachments which shall be signed by the president or chairman of the body or by the officer making the investigation, and shall be served by any officer authorized by law to serve such process. The authority making such investigation shall have power to cause the testimony to be given under oath, such oath to be administered by some officer having authority under the law of the state to administer oaths; and shall also have power to punish as for contempt any person refusing to testify to any fact within his knowledge, or produce any book or papers under his control relating to the matter under investigation. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 218) 
Sec. 4.03. - Oath of officers. 
Editor's note- Section 4.03 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 184. It assumed ordinance status pursuant to F.S. ch. 166 and has been transferred into the Code of Ordinances. 
Sec. 4.04. - Present officers to continue in office. 
Editor's note- Section 4.04 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 186. It has been deleted as obsolete. 
Sec. 4.05. - Removal of city official; hearings. 
    In the event of the removal of any paid official of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, appointed by the city commission of said city, after having served for a period of thirty days, such official, upon request within three days thereafter, shall be entitled to a public hearing within fifteen days after said removal, and the final removal thereof shall not be effective until after such public hearing. 
(Laws of Fla. (1955) ch. 31223, § 1) 
Sec. 4.06. - Tort actions against city. 
Editor's note- Section 4.06 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1955) ch. 31221, § 1. It has been deleted as superseded by F.S. § 768.28(5). 
DIVISION 2. - COMPENSATION OF OFFICERS 

Sec. 4.07. - Salaries fixed by commission; salaries fixed by city manager; to be uniform; where reported; disposition of fees and moneys. 
    The commission shall fix by ordinance the salary or compensation of the city attorney, municipal judge, the heads of the departments, members of the police and fire forces and members of boards. The city manager shall fix the number and compensation of all other officers and employees. All such salaries and rates of pay with dates of employment and discharge shall be immediately reported to the director of financial services. All fees and moneys received or collected by officers and employees shall be immediately paid over to the director of financial services on the date of their receipt. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 183) 
Editor's note- The third sentence of the above section has been deleted pursuant to city instructions. References to the municipal judge are obsolete. See Fla. Const. art. V, § 20(d)(4). 
Sec. 4.07-1. - Salary of commissioners. 
Editor's note- Section 4.07-1 was derived from Ord. No. 76-41, § 1, 11-8-76; Ord. No. 77-12, § 1, 5-9-77; Ord. No. 79-19, § 1, 5-14-79; Ord. No. 79-43, § 1, 10-8-79; Ord. No. 82-36, § 1, 12-27-82. The section has been transferred to the Code of Ordinances. See AGO 075-223. 
Sec. 4.08. - Bond of officers, etc. 
    The city commission or city manager in fixing the salary of any officer, clerk, or employee shall determine whether or not such officer, clerk or employee shall give bond, and the amount thereof, which bond shall be procured from a regularly accredited surety company authorized to do business under the laws of Florida, the premiums on such bonds to be paid by the city. All such bonds shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 185) 
Editor's note- Pursuant to city instructions, "finance director" has been changed to "clerk" in the last sentence. 
DIVISION 3. - MAYOR 

Sec. 4.09. - Election; powers and duties. 
    The commissioner elected to Seat Three shall serve as mayor and shall preside at all meetings of the commission and perform such other duties consistent with his office as may be imposed by it, and he shall have a voice and vote in the proceedings of the commission but no veto power. He may use the title of mayor in any case in which the execution of legal instruments of writing or other necessity arising from the general laws of the state so requires, but this shall not be considered as conferring upon him the administrative or judicial functions of a mayor under the general laws of the state. He shall be recognized as the official head of the city by the courts for the purpose of serving civil processes by the government in the exercise of military law and for all ceremonial purposes. He may take command of the police and govern the city by proclamation during times of grave public danger or emergency. The powers and duties of the mayor shall be such as are conferred upon him by the city commission in pursuance of the provisions of this Charter and no others. In the absence of the mayor, the other members of the city commission shall select one of their number to perform his duties. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 19; Ord. No. 82-40, § 1, 5-4-83; Ord. No. 06-17, § 2, 8-14-06) 
Editor's note- Substitute for Ord. No. 82-40, adopted May 4, 1983, was approved at referendum held May 1983. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY MANAGER 

Sec. 4.10. - Appointment; qualifications; temporary manager during absence, etc. 
    The city commission shall appoint a city manager who shall be the administrative head of the municipal government under the direction and supervision of the city commission, and he shall hold office at the pleasure of the city commission. He shall be chosen solely on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications, without regard to his political belief, and he need not be a resident of the city or state at the time of his appointment. During the absence or disability of the city manager, the city commission may designate some properly qualified person to temporarily execute the functions of the office. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 31) 
Cross reference- City manager to have exclusive authority in the employment of city employees, § 3.05. 
Sec. 4.11. - Compensation. 
Editor's note- Section 4.11 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 32 and Laws of Fla. (1931) ch. 15500, § 1. It assumed ordinance statutes pursuant to F.S. ch. 166 and has been deleted as not needed. 
Sec. 4.12. - Term of office. 
    The city manager of the City of St. Augustine, Florida shall serve at the pleasure of the city commission. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 33; Laws of Fla. (1931) ch. 15500, § 2) 
Sec. 4.13. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The city manager shall be responsible to the city commission for the proper administration of all affairs of the city and to that end, his powers are and they shall be: 
(a)  To see that the laws and ordinances are enforced; 
(b)  Except as hereinafter specifically provided, to appoint and remove all subordinate officers and employees of the city; all appointments to be made upon merit and fitness alone; 
(c)  To exercise control and direct supervision over all departments and divisions of the municipal government under this charter, or which may hereafter be created by the city commission; 
(d)  To see that all terms and conditions imposed in favor of the city or its inhabitants in any public utility franchise are faithfully kept and performed; and upon knowledge of any violation thereof, to call the same to the attention of the city attorney whose duty it is hereby made to take such legal steps as may be necessary to enforce the same; 
(e)  To attend all meetings of the city commission and of its committees, with right to take part in the discussion, but without having a vote; 
(f)  To recommend to the commission for adoption such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient in the interest of the city; 
(g)  To keep the city commission fully advised as to the financial conditions and needs of the city and to submit for its consideration an annual budget; 
(h)  To perform such other duties as may be prescribed under this charter or as may be required of him by ordinance or resolution of the city commission; and 
(i)  The city manager of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, or his designee, shall be the purchasing agent of said city by whom all purchases of supplies shall be made; and he shall approve all vouchers for the payment of same. In the capacity of purchasing agent he shall also conduct all sales of personal property which has become necessary or unfit for the city's use. Competitive formal bids should be solicited for any single item which exceeds the purchase cost of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00); provided, however, that when such formal bids have been received on public works construction contracts to be let by the city and they are in excess of the estimated construction costs as prepared by independent engineers or architects on behalf of the city then, and in that event, the city manager may, subject to approval of the city commission, negotiate the terms and conditions of such construction contracts with any qualified contractor, whether low bidder or otherwise, so as to bring the cost of the proposed contract within the engineers' and/or architects' estimate or the amount of money available to the city for such contract. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 34; Laws of Fla. (1955) ch. 31226, § 1; Ord. No. 82-38, § 1, 11-22-82; Ord. No. 90-34, § 1, 12-10-90) 
Editor's note- The last sentence of the above section has been transferred to the Code of Ordinances. 
Cross reference- Duty of the city manager in the preparation of the annual city budget, § 14.02; expenditures other than salaries in excess of $1000 shall be made by competition, § 14.10. 
Sec. 4.14. - To be head of various departments. 
    The city manager, as the administrative officer of the city shall be the head of each department provided for under this charter and shall be responsible for its successful and businesslike operation. He shall be the active head of the department of public safety and welfare, which department shall have cognizance of all matters making for the welfare of the community such as the control of its charitable and correctional institutions, and the management and supervision of all public improvements, works and undertakings of the city except as otherwise specifically provided for under this charter. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 52) 
Sec. 4.15. - Appointment of health officer; duties. 
Editor's note- Section 4.15 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 53. While it is a part of the charter, it has been deleted as obsolete. 
Sec. 4.16. - Additional duties. 
    The city manager shall manage and control all city owned public utilities operated and managed by the municipality, and the office of the city manager shall be charged with the management and operation of all public works and the regulation by ordinances of the city commission of all charitable and correctional institutions and agencies of the city, enforce all laws, ordinances and regulations relative to the preservation and promotion of public health; shall manage or inspect water, lighting, heating, power and transportation enterprises of the city; shall manage and control the use, construction, improvement, repair and maintenance of all recreational facilities of the city, including parks, playgrounds and public gymnasiums, bathhouses and social centers; he shall manage and supervise all public improvements, works and undertakings of the city, except as otherwise provided in this charter; he shall have charge of the construction, improvement, repair and maintenance of streets, sidewalks, alleys, lanes, bridges, viaducts, aqueducts, public highways, sewers, drains, ditches, culverts, streams, watercourses, and all public buildings; he shall manage and control market houses, crematories, sewerage disposal plants and farms, and he shall enforce all the obligations of privately owned or operated public utilities which are enforceable by the city; he shall have charge of the making and preservation of all surveys, maps, plans, drawings and estimates for such public work; the cleaning, sprinkling and lighting of streets and public places; the collection and disposal of wastes; the preservation of tools and appliances belonging to the city and pertaining to the functions of its several departments. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 58) 
Sec. 4.17. - Assistant city manager. 
(a)  There shall be an assistant city manager who shall be appointed by and serve during the pleasure of the city manager. The appointment shall be effective upon confirmation by the city commission. 
(b)  The assistant city manager shall, in the absence of the city manager, perform the duties of the city manager as provided by the Charter and Ordinances of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 73-608, §§ 1, 2) 
Editor's note- Ch. 73-608, §§ 1, 2, amended the Charter but did not specify the manner thereof, hence inclusion herein as § 4.17(a) and (b) was at the discretion of the editor. 
DIVISION 5. - CITY ATTORNEY 

Sec. 4.18. - Qualifications. 
    The city attorney shall be a lawyer of at least five years' experience admitted to and having authority to practice in all courts of the state. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 38) 
Cross reference- Ordinances to be voted on by the electors of the city to be first submitted to and approved by the city attorney, § 5.21. 
Sec. 4.19. - Special duties. 
    The city commission shall appoint a city attorney who shall act as the legal adviser to, and attorney and counselor for, the municipality and all of its officers in matters relating to their official duties. He shall prepare all contracts, bonds and other instruments in writing in which the municipality is concerned and shall endorse on each his approval of the form and correctness thereof and no contract with the municipality shall take effect until his approval is so endorsed thereon. He shall prosecute and defend for and in behalf of the city all complaints, suits and controversies in which the city is a party. He shall furnish the city commission, the city manager, the head of any department or any officer or board not included in any department his opinion on any question of law relating to their respective powers and duties. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 36) 
Editor's note- The next to last sentence has been modified so as to delete a reference to the city attorney prosecuting in municipal court, as municipal courts have been abolished. See Fla. Const. art. V, § 20(d)(4). 
Sec. 4.20. - Additional duties. 
    In addition to the duties specifically imposed under the preceding section he shall perform such other professional duties as may be required of him by ordinance or resolution of the city commission or as are prescribed for city attorneys under the general law of the state and which are not inconsistent with this charter and with any ordinance or resolution which may be passed by the city commission. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 37) 
DIVISION 6. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 4.21. - Appointment; duties generally. 
    There shall be a city clerk who shall be appointed by and serve during the pleasure of the city commissioners and who, under the supervision of the city manager, shall be director of the department of records. He shall attend all meetings of the city commission and shall keep a journal of its proceedings, the correctness of which proceedings as entered in such journal shall be certified to after each meeting by his signature and by the signature of the presiding officer of the city commission. He shall be the custodian of the seal of the city and of all records and papers of a general character pertaining to the affairs of a municipality. He shall attest to the signature of the mayor-commissioner on all contracts and other documents requiring such attestation. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 59; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 7; Ord. No. 75-17, § 1, 8-11-75; Ord. No. 84-12, § 1, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 4.22. - Additional duties. 
    In addition to the duties specifically imposed under this Charter, the city clerk shall perform such other duties as may be required of him by ordinance or resolution of the city commission, as well as such as may be required by the city manager or of city clerks by the general laws of the state applicable to municipalities and not inconsistent with this Charter or with any ordinance or resolution passed by the city commission. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 60; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 8; Ord. No. 84-12, § 1, 4-23-84) 
Secs. 4.23-4.31. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- As previously constituted, div. 6 pertained to the director of financial services, and §§ 4.23-4.31 contained provisions relating to the director's duties regarding expenditures, audits, etc. These duties are now performed by the director of financial services, whose duties were provided for in div. 7. Sections 4.23-4.31 were formerly derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, §§ 61-68, 70, and Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 9. 
DIVISION 7. - DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL SERVICES[2]
