Secs. 4.42, 4.43. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- At an election held on December 6, 1936, the electors adopted the provisions contained in former F.S. ch. 174 relative to civil service for police and firemen in cities and towns of one hundred twenty-five thousand population, or less. 

Sec. 4.44. - Composition; powers and duties generally of fire chief. 
    The fire force of the City of St. Augustine shall consist of a chief, who shall be a fire warden, and as many subordinate professional officers, professional firemen and employees, employed on a full time basis, as the city commission shall by ordinance determine is reasonably required to afford fire protection to the city. In determining the level of fire protection to be afforded, the city commission shall consider the recommendations of the Insurance Service Organization, the National Fire Protection Association, the fire chief, the city manager and the level of service afforded cities of a comparable size. The fire chief shall have exclusive control of the stationing and transfer of all firemen and other officers and employees constituting the fire force, subject to such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by city manager or by ordinance of the city; he shall have exclusive management and control of such officers and employees as may be employed in the administration of the affairs of his force. In case of riot, conflagration or like emergency, the city manager may appoint additional firemen for temporary service. The fire chief shall have, subject to the remaining portions of this charter, the right to suspend any officer or employee of the fire force because of incompetency, neglect of duty, drunkenness, failure to obey orders given by proper authority or for any other just or reasonable cause and shall immediately report the fact of such suspension to the city manager for final action. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 57; Ord. No. 88-43, § 1, 8-8-88) 
Sec. 4.45. - Authorized working hours; exceptions. 
    No member of the fire department of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, shall regularly be required to remain on duty more than one hundred forty-four hours in any two consecutive calendar weeks; provided, however, that all members of the fire department of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, shall be subject to call in the event of a general fire alarm during the time when a fire emergency so requires; and provided, further, that nothing herein contained shall be construed to repeal any provision of any law or ordinance of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, allowing vacations to members of the fire department of the said city. 
(Laws of Fla. (1949) ch. 26190, § 1) 
Sec. 4.46. - Same-Inapplicability of certain state law. 
Editor's note- Section 4.46 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1949) ch. 26190, § 2. It has been deleted as obsolete. 
DIVISION 10. - ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 4.47. - Appointment; powers and duties; compensation. 
Editor's note- Section 4.47 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 84. It has been deleted per instructions of the city. 
DIVISION 11. - RESERVED 
Editor's note- Division 11, §§ 4.48-4.50, relating to the board of adjustment, derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 88, and Laws of Fla. (1937) ch. 16657, § 1, was repealed by Ord. No. 84-12, § 4, 4-23-84. 

Secs. 4.48-4.50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES 

Sec. 4.51. - Appointment; composition; terms; powers and duties. 
    The city commission may, by ordinance or resolution, appoint a board of trustees, to be composed of three members, who shall be citizens of said city, one trustee shall be appointed for one year, one for two years, and one for three years, and shall hold office until their successors are appointed and qualified. The said trustees shall take charge of, manage, conduct and exercise all the powers necessary for the reclamation and filling in of all marsh or submerged lands acquired by said city, by purchase or otherwise, to sell and convey such reclaimed lands upon such terms, conditions and restrictions as the said trustees deem best for the interest, benefit, welfare, comfort, pleasure and convenience of the citizens of said city, and to that end are hereby authorized to do and perform any and all acts necessary. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 151) 
Editor's note- A freeholder requirement in the first sentence has been deleted as unconstitutional. See Harper v. Virginia Board of Elections, 483 U.S. 663 (1963). 
ARTICLE V. - MEETINGS, ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS 
DIVISION 1. - MEETINGS 

Sec. 5.01. - Meetings, records, etc., to be public; rules and order of business; journal. 
    All meetings of the city commission and of the committees thereof shall be public and any citizen shall have access to the minutes and records thereof at all reasonable times. The commission shall determine its own rules and order of business and shall keep a journal of its proceedings. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 21) 
Sec. 5.02. - Regular meetings. 
    At 7:30 p.m. on the first Monday in December, 1988, and thereafter at 7:30 p.m. on the first Monday in December following each regular municipal election, the city commission shall meet at the usual place for holding the meetings of the legislative body of the city, at which time the newly elected commissioners shall assume the duties of office. Thereafter, the city commission shall meet at such time as may be prescribed by ordinance or resolution, except that it shall meet regularly not less than once each month, unless such meeting is impracticable due to a federal, state, or local declaration of a state of emergency. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 20; Laws of Fla. (1951) ch. 27856, § 1; Ord. No. 87-17, § 2, 4-13-87; Ord. No. 18-14, § 1, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 5.03. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 5.03 derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 18 was repealed by Ord. No. 82-40, § 2, 5-4-83. The office of mayor is now subject to election by the voters, pursuant to § 4.09 of this Charter. 
Sec. 5.04. - Special meetings. 
    The city commission, or the city manager, may call special or emergency meetings of the commission upon at least twelve (12) hours' written notice. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 21; Ord. No. 18-14, § 2, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 5.05. - Absence from meetings. 
    Absence from four consecutive regular meetings of the commission shall operate to vacate the seat of a member, unless such absence is excused by the commission by resolution setting forth the fact of such excuse, duly entered upon journal. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 22) 
Secs. 5.06-5.11. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS 

Sec. 5.12. - [Definitions; form; reading; publication; emergency measures; effective date; recordation.] 
Editor's note- Section 5.12 was derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 57-1777, § 1; Ord. No. 372-A, § 1, 10-8-73; Ord. No. 76-33, §§ 1, 2, 9-13-76; Ord. No. 78-1, § 1, 1-23-78. It had assumed ordinance status pursuant to F.S. ch. 166 and has been deleted as inconsistent with F.S. § 166.041. 
Secs. 5.13-5.15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 372-A, § 2, 4-8-73, repealed former §§ 5.13-5.15, pertaining to the procedures for enacting ordinances and resolutions, which were derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, §§ 25, 26, 30; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, §§ 4, 5; Laws of Fla. (1953) ch. 29484, § 1; and Laws of Fla. ch. 61-2738, § 1. 
Sec. 5.16. - Ordinances submitted by petition of voters-Requirements; procedure. 
    Any proposed ordinances, including ordinances for the repeal or amendment of ordinances then in effect, may be submitted to the city commission by petition signed by at least twenty per cent of the total number of registered voters in the municipality. All petitions circulated with respect to any proposed ordinances shall be uniform in character, shall contain the proposed ordinance in full, and shall have printed or written thereon the names and addresses of at least five electors who shall be officially regarded as filing the petition and shall constitute a committee of the petitioners for the purpose hereinafter named. Each signer of the petition shall sign his name in ink or indelible pencil and shall place on the petition, opposite his name, the date of his signature and his place of residence by voting precinct or ward and by street and number. The signatures to any such petition need not all be appended to one paper, but to each such paper there shall be attached an affidavit by the circulator thereof, stating the number of signers to such part of the petition and that each signature appended to the paper is the genuine signature of the person whose name it purports to be, and that it was made in the presence of the affiant and on the date indicated. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 197) 
Sec. 5.17. - Same-Petition to be filed with clerk; submission to commission. 
    All papers comprising a petition shall be assembled and filed with the city clerk as one (1) instrument within ninety (90) days of the date of the first signature thereon, and, when so filed, the clerk shall submit the same to the city commission at its next regular meeting and provision shall be made for public hearings upon the proposed ordinance. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 198; Ord. No. 84-12, § 5, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 5.18. - Same-Consideration by commission; election may be held if rejected; new petition required. 
    The city commission shall at once proceed to consider such petition and shall take final action thereon within thirty days after the date of submission. If the city commission rejects the proposed ordinance, or passes it in a different form from that set forth in the petition, or fails to act finally upon it within the time stated, the committee of the petitioners, by written demand filed with the city clerk, may require that the proposed ordinance be submitted to a vote of the electors in its original form, if, with or prior to such demand, a petition for such election signed after the final action or inaction of the city commission is filed with such city clerk bearing additional signatures of five (5) per cent of the electors of the city, none of whom were signers of the first petition. The city clerk shall forthwith cause notice of the filing of such demand and petition to be published in some newspaper of general circulation in the city, and shall also, within five (5) days, certify to the city commission the proposed ordinance, stating whether or not a special election is demanded in the petition, the percentage of registered voters who signed the two (2) petitions in the aggregate, and the date on which he published the notice last mentioned. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 199; Ord. No. 84-12, § 6, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 5.19. - Same-When election after rejection by commission may be held. 
    If an election is to be held not more than two (2) months nor less than thirty (30) days after the publication of such notice by the city clerk, such proposed ordinance shall be submitted to a vote of the electors at such election. If no election is to be held within the time aforesaid, the city commission shall provide for submitting the proposed ordinance to the electors at a special election to be held not later than forty-five (45) days and not earlier than thirty (30) days after the publication of the first notice, if the petitions for such ordinances and the petition for such election so demand, and if the signers of the two (2) petitions amount in the aggregate to at least twenty-five (25) per cent of the registered voters of the city; otherwise the same shall be submitted at the next regular or special municipal election. At least ten (10) days before any such election, the city clerk shall cause such ordinance to be published. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 200; Ord. No. 84-12, § 6, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 5.20. - Same-Election ballots; ordinance effective on majority vote of approval. 
    The ballots used when voting upon any such proposed ordinance shall state the title of the ordinance to be voted on and below it the two propositions: "For the ordinance" and "Against the ordinance." 
    Immediately at the left of each proposition there shall be a square in which by making a cross (X) the voter may vote for or against the proposed ordinance. If a majority of the electors voting on any such proposed ordinance shall vote in favor thereof, it shall thereupon become an ordinance of the city. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 201; Ord. No. 84-12, § 6, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 5.21. - Same-Ordinances to be approved by city attorney. 
    Before any ordinance so proposed shall be submitted to the city commission, it shall first be approved as to its form by the city attorney, whose duty it shall be to draft such proposed ordinance in proper legal language if called upon so to do and to render such other service to persons desiring to propose such ordinance as shall be necessary to make the same proper for consideration by the city commission. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 202) 
Cross reference- Qualifications and duties of the city attorney, § 4.21 et seq. 
Sec. 5.22. - Same-Method of amending ordinances passed by electoral vote. 
    No ordinance adopted by an electoral vote can be repealed or amended except by an electoral vote; but an ordinance to repeal or amend any such ordinance may, by resolution of the city commission, be submitted to an electoral vote at any regular election, or at any special municipal election called for some other purpose, provided notice of the intention to do so be published by the city commission not more than sixty days nor less than thirty days prior to such election, in the manner required for the publication of ordinances. If an amendment is so proposed, such notice shall contain the proposed amendment in full. Such submission shall be in the same manner, and the vote shall have the same effect, as in cases of ordinances submitted to an electoral vote by popular petition. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 203) 
Sec. 5.23. - Zoning ordinances; amendments. 
Editor's note- Section 5.23 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1953) ch. 29482, § 1. It has been deleted as superseded by F.S. ch. 166. 
Sec. 5.24. - Effective date of section 5.23. 
Editor's note- Section 5.24 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1953) ch. 29482, § 1. It has been deleted as obsolete. 
Sec. 5.25. - Referendum petition to repeal or amend ordinances-When and where filed; contents. 
    If, at any time within said thirty days, a petition signed by thirty-five per cent of the total number of registered voters in the municipality be filed with the city clerk, requesting that any such ordinance be repealed or amended as stated in the petition, such ordinance shall not become effective until the steps indicated herein shall have been taken. Such petition shall have stated therein the names and addresses of at least five (5) electors as a committee to represent the petitioners. Referendum petitions need not contain the text of the ordinance or ordinances the repeal of which is sought, but shall contain the proposed amendment, if an amendment is demanded, and shall be subject in all other respects to the requirements for petitions submitting proposed ordinances to the city commission. Ballots used in referendum elections shall conform in all other respects to those provided for in section 2.33 [§ 5.20] of this Charter. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 204) 
Editor's note- The first sentence of the above section has been deleted as superseded by § 5.12. 
Sec. 5.26. - Same-Reconsideration by commission; election. 
    The city clerk shall, at its next meeting, present the petition to the city commission, which shall proceed to reconsider the ordinance. If, within thirty (30) days after the filing of such petition, the ordinance be not repealed or amended as requested, the city commission shall provide for submitting the proposed repeal or amendment to a vote of the electors, provided a majority of the committee named in the petition to represent the petitioners shall be [in] writing, filed with the city clerk within twenty (20) days after the expiration of the said thirty (30) days, so required. In so doing the city commission shall be governed by the provisions of section 200 [§ 5.19] of this Charter respecting the time of submission and the manner of voting on ordinances proposed to the city commission by petition; excepting that the question of calling a special election for such purpose shall be determined by the demand and number of signers of the petition requesting the repeal of amendment of such ordinance, which number shall be not less than twenty-five (25) per cent of the registered voters; and excepting, further, that the city commission may call, and fix the time for a special election for such purpose if, in its judgment, the public interest will be prejudiced by delay. If, when submitted to a vote of the electors, such repeal or amendment be approved by a majority of those voting thereon, it shall thereupon go into effect as an ordinance of the city; but if any such amendment is clearly separable from the remainder of the ordinance and does not materially affect the other provisions of such ordinance, all sections of the ordinance except that sought to be amended and those dependent thereon shall take effect as though no referendum of any portion of the ordinance had been demanded. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 205; Ord. No. 84-12, § 6, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 5.27. - Same-Ordinances submitted by initiative petition subject to referendum. 
    Ordinances submitted to the city commission by initiative petition and passed by the city commission without change, or passed in amended form, and not required to be submitted to a vote of the electors by the committee of the petitioners, shall be subject to the referendum in the same manner as other ordinances. If the provisions of two or more ordinances adopted or approved at the same election conflict, the ordinance receiving the highest affirmative vote shall prevail. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 206) 
Sec. 5.28. - Same-Applicable to emergency ordinances. 
    Ordinances passed as emergency measures shall be subject to referendum in like manner as other ordinances, except that they shall go into effect at the time indicated in such ordinances. If, when submitted to a vote of the electors, an emergency measure be not approved by a majority of those voting thereon, it shall be considered repealed as regards any further action thereunder, but such measures so repealed shall be deemed sufficient authority for the payment in accordance with the ordinance of any expenses incurred previous to the referendum vote thereon. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 207) 
Sec. 5.29. - Preliminary steps may be taken before petitioned election is held. 
    In case a petition be filed requiring that a measure passed by the city commission providing for an expenditure of money, a bond issue or a public improvement be submitted to a vote of the electors, all steps preliminary to such actual expenditure, actual issuance of bonds, or actual execution of a contract for such improvement may be taken prior to the election. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 208)

DIVISION 1. - REGISTRATION OF ELECTORS[5]

DIVISION 2. - PRIMARY AND GENERAL ELECTIONS 

Sec. 6.14. - When elections to be held. 
    The primary and general elections for the election of city commissioners of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, shall be as follows: The primary election shall be held on the Tuesday ten (10) weeks prior to the general election, and the general election shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday of November, 2014, and thereafter primary elections shall be held on the Tuesday ten (10) weeks prior to the general election of each even numbered year and the general elections shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of each even numbered year. 
(Laws of Fla. (1955) ch. 31217, § 3; Laws of Fla. ch. 67-1975, § 1; Ord. No. 87-17, § 3, 4-13-87; Ord. No. 12-09, § 1, 7-9-12; Ord. No. 14-02, § 1, 1-27-14) 
Sec. 6.15. - When primary and general elections not necessary. 
    If only one (1) candidate qualifies for a group, a primary and general election for that group shall not be necessary. If only two (2) candidates qualify for a group, then their names only shall be placed on the ballot for that group in the general election and a primary election for that group shall not be necessary. If more than two (2) candidates qualify for a group, a primary election shall be necessary for that group. The names of unopposed candidates shall not appear on the primary or general election ballot. Each unopposed candidate shall be deemed to have voted for himself or herself. 
(Laws of Fla. (1955) ch. 31217, § 4; Laws of Fla. ch. 67-1975, § 7; Laws of Fla. ch. 74-598, § 1; Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 6) 
Sec. 6.16. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- At the direction of the city § 6.16 has been deleted. It was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 187; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 8; Laws of Fla. (1931) ch. 15500, § 7; Laws of Fla. (1949) ch. 26191, § 1; Laws of Fla. (1951) ch. 27856, § 2. It is superseded by § 6.14. 
Sec. 6.17. - Qualifications of voters. 
Editor's note- Section 6.17 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 88; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 79; Laws of Fla. (1931) ch. 15500, § 8; Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 3. It was superseded by F.S. § 166.032, 97.041 and unconstitutional in part (dealing with poll tax). See Harper v. Virginia Board of Elections, 383 U.S. 663 (1963). 
Sec. 6.18. - Arrangements; appointment of chairman of city canvassing board, inspectors and clerk. 
    The city commission shall make necessary arrangements for holding all municipal elections and appoint a canvassing board who shall canvass and declare the results thereof. The canvassing board shall be comprised of the city attorney, the officer before whom the candidate for office qualified, and a member of the city commission who will act as chairman. The chairman of the canvassing board shall be selected from among the members of the city commission by the mayor-commissioner. The chairman of the canvassing board shall not be a candidate with opposition in the election being canvassed nor an active participant in the campaign or candidacy of any candidate with opposition in the election being canvassed. If the chairman of the canvassing board is unable to serve or is disqualified, the mayor-commissioner shall appoint as a substitute another member with the same qualifications. If a substitute member cannot be appointed as provided elsewhere in this subsection, the city commission shall appoint as a substitute member a qualified elector of the city who is not a candidate with opposition in the election being canvassed and who is not an active participant in the campaign or candidacy of any candidate with opposition in the election being canvassed. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 190; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 81; Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 2; Ord. No. 87-17, § 4, 4-13-87; Ord. No. 87-14, § 1, 4-13-87) 
Sec. 6.19. - When polls are open; ascertainment of canvass of returns; declaration of result; certification of election. 
    The results of the voting at all polling places shall be certified by the canvassing board. The chairman of the canvassing board and the city attorney shall transmit such returns to the city commission at a meeting to be held at 12:00 noon on the day following the election. At such meeting, the city commission shall canvass the returns, and the results as shown from such canvass shall be by the city commission declared to be the results of the election. The qualifying officer shall, on or before 12:00 noon, of the second day after the election, furnish a certificate of election to each person shown to have been elected. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 191; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 82; Laws of Fla. (1949) ch. 26191, § 2; Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 4; Ord. No. 84-12, § 7, 4-23-84; Ord. No. 87-17, § 5, 4-13-87; Ord. No. 87-14, § 2, 4-13-87) 
Editor's note- The first sentence of the above section has been deleted as superseded by F.S. § 100.011. 
Sec. 6.20. - Paper ballots. 
    The whole number of paper ballots to be printed for any primary or general municipal election for the nomination or election of candidates for the office of city commissioner shall be divided by the number of such candidates, and the quotient so obtained shall be divided by the number of ballots in each series of ballots to be printed. The names of the candidates shall be arranged in alphabetical order for each group in the first series of ballots printed. The first names shall then be placed last and the next series of ballots printed, and this process shall be repeated until each name shall have been first. These ballots shall then be combined into tablets, or pads, with no two of the same order of name together. The ballots shall in all other respects conform as nearly possible to the form of ballots prescribed by the general election law of the State of Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 192; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 83; Laws of Fla. ch. 67-1975, § 5; Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 5) 
Sec. 6.20.1. - Voting machine ballots. 
    Voting machine ballots shall conform to the form of ballots prescribed by the general election law of the State of Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 7) 
Sec. 6.21. - Nomination of commissioners; petition required; regulations for petitioners; payment of qualification fee; groups. 
    Candidates for the office of city commissioner shall be nominated at a nonpartisan primary election where there are more than two (2) persons nominated for each office to be filled as hereinafter provided. Any person possessing the qualifications set forth in this Charter shall be entitled to have his or her name printed upon the ballot at the primary election by written petition circulated by such candidate or on his or her behalf, signed by at least twenty-five (25) qualified electors of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. Each of said petitioning electors shall in all respects be qualified to vote in the ensuing general election to be held in the City of St. Augustine, Florida. Such written petition shall be filed with the appropriate filing officer no earlier than noon of the 71st day, and no later than noon of the 67th day, before the first primary election or the same will not be recognized. Each petitioner signing said petition shall add after his or her signature, his or her place of residence, including street and number, and voting precinct, and also the date of the signing of said petition. Each petitioner may subscribe to one nominating petition for each office to be filled and no more. All signatures shall be written in ink or indelible pencil or the same shall not be recognized. Each candidate so nominated shall, upon his or her acceptance of such nomination as provided in this Charter, pay to the qualifying officer at the time of qualifying the sum of twenty-five [dollars] ($25.00) as his or her qualification fee. Candidates shall run in three (3) groups designated as Group One, Group Two and Group Three; and each voter may vote for one candidate in each group. The nominating petition of each candidate shall indicate the group in which his or her name is to appear on the ballot; that is to say, whether in Group One, Group Two, or Group Three; and unless so indicated, the petition shall be deemed a nullity. No candidate's name in any primary or general election shall be printed on the ballot if said candidate has notified the officer before whom the candidate qualified in writing, under oath, no later than noon the thirtieth day prior to the primary election, that he or she will not accept the nomination or office for which he or she filed qualification papers. The candidate who has withdrawn as a candidate for one group may qualify as a candidate for a different group, provided he or she complies with all the qualification procedures provided herein. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 193; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 84; Laws of Fla. (1949) ch. 26191, § 1; Laws of Fla. ch. 67-1975, § 6; Laws of Fla. ch. 74-598, § 1; Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 6; Ord. No. 87-17, § 6, 4-13-87; Ord. No. 08-04, § 1, 1-28-08) 
Sec. 6.22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 6.22, requiring candidates to file acceptance with the city auditor and clerk, derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 194, and Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 85, was repealed by Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 8. 
Sec. 6.23. - Primary and general election; when candidate deemed elected; tie votes. 
(a)  In the primary election and in the general election to be held in May, 1969, and in each primary election and in each general election thereafter, the candidates for city commission shall run in three groups designated as Group One, Group Two and Group Three, and each voter may vote for one candidate in each group. In the general election, the successful candidates in Group One and Group Two shall be elected for a full term of four years and the successful candidate in Group Three shall be elected for a full term of two years. 
(b.1)  At the primary election, if a candidate receives a majority of the votes cast in his group, then his or her name shall not be placed on the ballots for that group in the general election. Each unopposed candidate shall be deemed to have voted for himself or herself. In the event that a candidate in any group does not receive a majority of the votes cast in his group, then, subject to the provisions of subsections (b.2) and (b.3) of this section, the names of the candidates placing first and second in that group, and their names only, shall be placed on the ballots for that group in the general election. 
(b.2)  In all primary elections where there is a tie for first place in any group, the names of, and only the names of, the candidates so tying shall be placed on the ballots for that group at the general election. 
(b.3)  In all primary elections where there is a tie for second place in any group and the candidate placing first in that group did not receive a majority of the votes cast in that group, then the names of, and only the names of, the candidates placing first and tying for second in that group shall be placed on the ballots in the general election. 
(c)  In any general election the candidate in each group receiving the highest number of votes, is and shall be deemed, held and declared to be the person elected. In the event there shall be a tie vote in any general election, between two or more persons receiving the highest number of votes in any group, the tie vote shall be decided by lot to be conducted by the city attorney, city manager and city clerk. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 195; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 86; Laws of Fla. ch. 67-1975, §§ 2-4; Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 5) 
Sec. 6.24. - General laws of state to apply. 
    All elections held in the City of St. Augustine shall be conducted, except as otherwise provided under this Act, under the rules and conditions prescribed by law and subject to the general election laws of the State of Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 196; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 87) 
Sec. 6.25. - Charter amendments. 
    Amendments to this Charter may be submitted to the electors of the city by a two-thirds vote of the city commission, and, by petition signed by thirty-five (35) per cent of the electors of the city setting forth any such proposed amendment, shall be submitted by action of the city commission unless such amendments are authorized by the state Municipal Home Rule Powers Act. The ordinance providing for the submission of any such amendment, other than that authorized by the state Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, shall require that it be submitted to the electors at the next regular municipal election if one shall occur not less than sixty (60) days and not more than one hundred twenty (120) days after its passage; otherwise it shall provide for the submission of the amendment at a special election to be called and held within the time aforesaid. 
    If such amendment is approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon, it shall become a part of the Charter at the time fixed therein. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 220; Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 1) 
Sec. 6.26. - Use of voting machines. 
    The city commission of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, may authorize the use of voting machines in any municipal election; providing that the voting procedure, voting machine ballot, and the requirements of voting machines shall be in accordance with the Florida Election Code. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 71-891, § 1) 
Secs. 6.27-6.31. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RECALL OF COMMISSION MEMBERS 

Sec. 6.32. - Petition for recall. 
    Any or all members of the city commission may be removed from office by the electors by following the procedures prescribed by the general election law of the State of Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 209; Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 1) 
Secs. 6.33-6.40. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Laws of Fla. ch. 81-480, § 8 repealed Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, §§ 210-217 and Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 85, from which §§ 6.33-6.40 were derived. 
State Law reference- Municipal recall provisions superseded, F.S. 100.361(10). 
ARTICLE VII. - TAXATION 
DIVISION 1. - ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION OF TAXES 

Sec. 7.01. - Real property defined. 
Editor's note- Section 7.01 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 102; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 22; Laws of Fla. (1937) ch. 18877, § 5. The section has been deleted as being preempted to general law by F.S. § 166.211(2).

Editor's note- Section 7.02 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 108; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 14375, § 23; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 18877, § 6. It has been deleted as preempted to general law by F.S. § 166.211(2).

Sec. 7.04. - Percentage of taxation based on valuation in assessment roll; taxes to be uniform, etc. 
Editor's note- Section 7.04 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 107; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 25; Laws of Fla. (1937) ch. 18877, § 8. It has been deleted as preempted to general law by F.S. § 166.211(2). 
Sec. 7.05. - When taxes assessed.

DIVISION 5. - GASOLINE TAXES 

Sec. 7.75. - Exemption from certain state gasoline tax. 
    The City of St. Augustine, Florida, a municipal corporation, under the laws of the State of Florida, is hereby expressly exempted from the provisions of section thirteen of Senate Bill 155, as now amended, and which was passed by the legislature of the State of Florida, at its 1937 session and which act is known as: "An act imposing an additional tax upon gasoline or other like products of petroleum; providing for reports of sale of such commodities to the comptroller of the State of Florida; providing for the distribution of the moneys derived from such tax, and fixing a penalty for the violation of the provisions of this act; providing that the gasoline inspection laws of the State of Florida shall apply to this act," and the City of St. Augustine, aforesaid, is hereby authorized and empowered to create and fix the amount of gasoline tax levied and collected within the municipality and which said tax shall be independent of any general state revenue law. 
(Laws of Fla. (1937) ch. 18876, § 1) 
Sec. 7.76. - Authority to levy and collect tax. 
    The City of St. Augustine, Florida, a municipal corporation, shall have, and is hereby granted, authorized and empowered, through its city commission, the power and authority to levy and collect a tax upon gasoline sold within the city limits of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. (1937) ch. 18876, § 2) 
Sec. 7.77. - Referendum clause. 
    This Act shall take effect after the approval and acceptance of the provisions hereof shall have been submitted to the qualified electors of the City of St. Augustine, St. Johns County, Florida, at a special election, or at the next ensuing city election. If the majority of all the electors voting at said election shall vote to approve and accept the provisions of this Act, then and in that event this Act shall take effect and be in force from and after the date of canvassing and declaring the result of said election. If the majority of all the electors voting at said election shall vote not to approve and accept the provisions of this Act, then and in that event the provisions of this Act shall not be operative for any purpose; that said election shall be held and canvassed and the result thereof declared in accordance with the laws pertaining to elections in the State of Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. (1937) ch. 18876, § 4) 
Editor's note- No records were found in the city's election files or the minutes of the city commission of an election ever having been held as required by section 7.77 supra.

ARTICLE IX. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 9.01. - Jurisdiction; Anastasia Island. 
    The police jurisdiction granted under this charter shall extend to and be of full force and effect upon Anastasia Island and all existing ordinances and any which may hereafter be enacted dealing with the police powers of the city shall be of force and effect upon such island. Persons violating such ordinances and who may commit breaches of the peace upon the said Anastasia Island shall be subject to arrest by members of the police force of the City of St. Augustine and to trial before the municipal court of said city, just as though the offense had been committed within the actual corporate limits of the said city. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 45) 
Editor's note- References in the above section to a municipal court are obsolete as Ord. No. 371-A, § 1, 9-24-73 abolished the municipal court effective Oct. 1, 1973. 
Sec. 9.01.1. - Hot pursuit within St. Johns County. 
(a)  Any member of the police department of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, is hereby authorized to pursue across the city limits line and arrest where apprehended in St. Johns County, any person suspected of having committed an offense against the ordinances of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, provided the pursuit of such person is continuous after having originated within the corporate limits of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(b)  Any member of the Police Department of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, is authorized to continue a "hot pursuit" beyond the limits of said city to any point in St. Johns County, and arrest upon apprehension any person suspected of violating any ordinance of said city. 
(c)  "Hot pursuit" as herein used, shall be construed to mean pursuit of a person suspected of violating an ordinance of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, said pursuit being within the limits of said city and continuing without interruption beyond the limits of said city to any point within St. Johns County, Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 65-2162, §§ 1-3) 
Sec. 9.02. - Arrests. 
Editor's note- Section 9.02 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 44. It has been deleted as it related to the municipal court, which court was abolished by Ord. No. 371-A, § 1, 9-24-73, effective Oct. 1, 1973. 
Sec. 9.03. - Chief and jail officers to take bond from persons arrested. 
Editor's note- Section 9.03 was derived from Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 46. It assumed ordinance status pursuant to F.S. ch. 166 and has been deleted as obsolete. 
Sec. 9.04. - Composition; chief to control force. 
    The Police Force of the City of St. Augustine shall consist of a chief of police and as many subordinate officers, policemen and employees, employed on a full time basis, as the city commission shall by ordinance determine is reasonably required to enforce the law. The chief of police shall have exclusive control of the stationing and transfer of all patrolmen and other officers and employees constituting the police force, subject to the approval of the city manager and under such rules and regulations as the city commission may prescribe or as may be prescribed by the ordinances of the city. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 54; Ord. No. 88-42, § 1, 8-8-88) 
Sec. 9.05. - Additional policemen during emergencies. 
    In case of riot or other grave emergency and during elections or similar occasions, the city manager may appoint additional patrolmen and officers for temporary service. No person shall act as a special policeman, special detective or other special police officer for any purpose whatsoever, except on written authority of the city manager. Such authority shall be exercised only under the direction and control of the chief of police for a specified time. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 55) 
Sec. 9.06. - Powers and duties generally of chief. 
    The chief of police shall attend all meetings of the city commission and aid in the enforcement of order under the direction of the presiding officer. He shall execute the commands of the city commission and all processes issued by authority thereof which shall be issued to him by the mayor. He shall perform such other duties appropriate to his office as may be imposed upon him by law, the ordinances of the city, and by direction of the city manager, consistent with this Act. He shall have the right to suspend any officer or employee of the police force because of incompetency, neglect of duty, immorality, drunkenness, failure to obey orders given by proper authority or for any other just and reasonable cause and he shall immediately report the fact of such suspension to the city manager for final action. 
(Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 56) 
Editor's note- Language in the third sentence dealing with the chief of police's duties relative to the municipal court have been deleted as Ord. No. 371-A, § 1, 9-24-73 abolished the municipal court effective Oct. 1, 1973. 
Sec. 9.07. - Abandoned or unclaimed property-Sale. 
    The Police Department of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, is hereby authorized to sell at public auction all lost, abandoned or unclaimed property now in its possession or which shall in the future come into its possession, such sales to be held at such time and at such place as shall be determined from time to time. 
(Laws of Fla. (1951) ch. 27860, § 1) 
Sec. 9.08. - Same-To be retained for six months. 
    No property as set forth in the preceding section shall be sold until after the expiration of six months from the time that such lost, abandoned or unclaimed property shall come into the possession of the Police Department of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. (1951) ch. 27860, § 2) 
Sec. 9.09. - Same-Notice of sale. 
    Public notice of the time and place of such sale with a description of the property shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation published in the City of St. Augustine, Florida, ten (10) days prior to the date of such sale, one insertion of such notice of sale being sufficient. 
(Laws of Fla. (1951) ch. 27860, § 3) 
Sec. 9.10. - Same-Disposition of funds from sale. 
    All funds derived from the sale of such lost, abandoned or unclaimed property shall be paid to the St. Augustine Police Benevolent Association, Inc., a corporation not for profit, and be disbursed for the uses and purposes provided by such corporation. 
(Laws of Fla. (1951) ch. 27860, § 4) 
Secs. 9.11, 9.12. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - POLICE OFFICERS RETIREMENT SYSTEM 

Sec. 10.01. - System and fund created. 
(1)  There is hereby created and established: 
(a)  A retirement system for police officers of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, to be known as the "St. Augustine Police Officers Retirement System," by and in which name it shall, pursuant to this Act, transact all of its business and shall have the powers and privileges of a corporation, the same to be a department or instrumentality of such city. 
(b)  A special fund to be known as the "St. Augustine Police Officer's Retirement Fund," said fund to be used for the exclusive benefit of Plan Members and Beneficiaries. Any diversion of fund assets prior to the satisfaction of all liabilities related to the system shall be prohibited. The fund shall be collected, administered and disbursed according to the provisions of this Act. Actuarial deficits, if any, arising in the fund created under this Act shall be the obligation of the City of St. Augustine except as provided herein. 
(2)  The fund and the system hereby created shall be in substitution for the "St. Augustine Police Officers Retirement Fund" and the retirement system thereunder, now and heretofore existing in the City of St. Augustine in pursuance of the provisions of F.S. ch. 185; and said "Police Officers Retirement Fund" and the system thereunder now and heretofore existing in said city under the provisions of said Chapter 185, shall on the effective date of this Act, stand abolished. 
(Ord. No. 99-30, § 1, 10-25-99) 
Sec. 10.02. - Definitions. 
(1)  "Accrued benefit" shall mean the total monthly benefit which shall have been earned by each member for all years of creditable service of said member as follows: 
(a)  A member who terminates city employment with ten (10) or more years of creditable service shall earn a benefit at the rate of two percent (2.0%) of the member's average final salary for each year of creditable service. 
(b)  A member who terminates city employment on or after March 1, 2000 with ten (10) or more years of creditable service may elect a benefit at the rate of two and one-half percent (2.5%) of the member's average final salary for each year of creditable service, subject to the early retirement provisions of Section 10.08(5). 
(c)  A member who terminates city employment after October 1, 2005 with ten (10) or more years of creditable service shall earn a benefit at the rate of three percent (3%) of the member's average final salary for each year of creditable service earned after October 1, 2005. The three percent (3%) multiplier may apply to creditable service earned prior to October 1, 2005, subject to the provisions of Section 10.08 (7). 
(2)  "Accumulated contributions" shall mean the sum of all amounts deducted from the salary of a member and contributed to the fund. 
(3)  "Actuarial equivalent" shall mean a benefit of equivalent value to that which would otherwise have been provided to the member, computed as follows: 
(a)  For benefits payable in the form of a life annuity, a benefit equal to one hundred two (102) percent of that otherwise payable as ten-year certain-and-life annuity if the member is age fifty-five (55) or younger. If the member is older than fifty-five (55), 0.5 percent will be added to the one hundred two (102) percent for each year older, not to exceed one hundred eight (108) percent; 
(b)  For benefits payable in the form of a fifty (50) percent joint-and-survivor annuity, a benefit equal to ninety-four (94) percent of that otherwise payable as a ten-year certain-and-life annuity if the beneficiary is the same age as the member. If the beneficiary is younger than the member, 0.5 percent will be subtracted from the ninety-four (94) percent for each year younger. If the beneficiary is older than the member, 0.5 percent will be added to the ninety-four (94) percent for each year older, not to exceed one hundred (100) percent; 
(c)  For benefits payable in the form of a fifty (50) percent joint-and-last-survivor annuity, a benefit equal to ninety-seven (97) percent of that otherwise payable as a ten-year certain-and-life annuity if the beneficiary is the same age as the member. If the beneficiary is younger than the member, 0.5 percent will be subtracted from the ninety-seven (97) percent for each year younger. If the beneficiary is older than the member, 0.5 percent will be added to the ninety-seven (97) percent for each year older, not to exceed one hundred (100) percent; 
(d)  For benefits payable in the form of a sixty-six and two-thirds (66 2/3 ) percent joint-and-last-survivor annuity, a benefit equal to ninety-three (93) percent of that otherwise payable as a ten-year certain-and-life annuity if the beneficiary is the same age as the member. If the beneficiary is younger than the member, 0.5 percent will be subtracted from the ninety-three (93) percent for each year younger. If the beneficiary is older than the member, 0.5 percent will be added to the ninety-three (93) percent for each year older, not to exceed one hundred (100) percent; 
(e)  For benefits payable in the form of a one hundred (100) percent joint-and-last-survivor annuity, a benefit equal to eighty-seven (87) percent of that otherwise payable as a ten-year certain-and-life annuity if the beneficiary is the same age as the member. If the beneficiary is younger than the member, 0.5 percent will be subtracted from the eighty-seven (87) percent for each year younger. If the beneficiary is older than the member, 0.5 percent will be added to the eighty-seven (87) percent for each year older, not to exceed one hundred (100) percent. 
(f)  For benefits payable in any other form, actuarial equivalence means the same actuarial present value as the normal form of payment on any single measurement date. The determination of the actuarial present value of any form of benefit, including lump sum distributions, shall be based on the RP-2000 static mortality table (h) unisex 50/50 for healthy lives projected to 2010 for healthy members and the RP-2000 static mortality table (d) unisex 50/50 projected to 2010 for disabled members; and an interest discount rate of 8% per annum, compounded annually. This definition may be amended by the city pursuant to the recommendation of the board with the advice of the plan's actuary and the city's actuary, such that the actuarial assumptions are not subject solely to city discretion. 
(4)  "Average final compensation" means one-twelfth of the average annual compensation of the five (5) best years of the last ten (10) years of creditable service prior to retirement, termination or death. 
(5)  "Beneficiary" shall mean any person so designated by a member as provided in section 11 [10.11]. In the event no designation is made the beneficiary of said member shall be his estate. 
(6)  "Board" shall mean the board of trustees as provided in this Act. 
(7)  "City" shall mean the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(8)  " Creditable service" for the purpose of this Act shall mean the total number of years and fractional parts of years of service of any police officer as follows: 
(a)  Periods of service as a police officer with the city prior to October 10, 1953, during which the police officer shall have contributed to this system or any predecessor retirement systems (other than the Federal Social Security System) for police officers of the City of St. Augustine. In determining the aggregate number of years of creditable service of any police officer, periods of absence for service in the Armed Forces after initial employment as a police officer, or any leaves of absence authorized by the city shall be added to the years of service as a police officer with the city, provided that credit for such military leave or authorized leave of absence shall not exceed five (5) years. Creditable service shall be granted to any member who is legally entitled to reemployment under the provisions of the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act, without such member making the contributions required under Section 10.07(2). Otherwise, the aggregate number of years of creditable service shall mean the total number of years and fractional parts of years of service of any police officer, omitting intervening years and fractional parts of years when such police officer is not employed by the city. 
(b)  For members who retire or terminate city employment on or after October 1, 2004, "creditable service" shall also include up to three (3) years of active duty in the U.S. armed forces or full-time employment as a law enforcement officer with another governmental entity prior to employment by the city, purchased by the member in accordance with this paragraph; provided the member has not received and will not receive a benefit from another retirement plan based on such prior employment as a police officer. Such purchased service may not be used for vesting purposes. An eligible member may purchase creditable service under the system for such prior employment by paying into the fund the full actuarial cost of such creditable service, as determined by the plan actuary. Such payment must be made in full prior to entering the DROP or separation from city employment, whichever occurs earlier. In the event full payment is not made prior to such date, the member shall receive only the amount of creditable service, as determined by the actuary, for which the payment made, excluding interest, is the full actuarial cost. A member purchasing such additional creditable service must also pay the full cost of any actuarial calculations required. Payment for the purchase of creditable service pursuant to this paragraph may be made using any one or a combination of the following options: 
1.  Cash lump sum payment. 
2.  Installment payments, plus simple interest at the rate of four (4) percent per annum, deducted from the member's city salary over a period not to exceed five (5) years. 
3.  Direct transfer or rollover of an eligible rollover distribution from a qualified or eligible plan, in accordance with Section 10.14. 
(c)  For members who retire or terminate city employment on or after October 1, 2004, "creditable service" shall also include the years or fractional years that a member performs "Qualified Military Service" including voluntary or involuntary service in the armed forces of the United States as defined in the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act (USERRA) (P.L. 103-353), as amended, or has served in the National Guard or reserve military service of the armed forces of the United States, prior to or while in the employ of the city, purchased by the member in accordance with this paragraph; provided the member has not received and will not receive a benefit from another retirement plan based on such prior service. Such purchased service may not be used for vesting purposes. The member must contribute the full actuarial cost of all such creditable service. Creditable service for National Guard or military reserve service shall be calculated by dividing the total number of official military reserve points by 365 to determine the equivalent years of fractional parts thereof to be credited. The combined total of all creditable service purchased pursuant to this paragraph and paragraph (b) of this subsection shall not exceed three (3) years. Payment for the purchase of National Guard or reserve military service shall be made in the same manner as provided in paragraph (b) of this subsection. 
(d)  This section is intended to satisfy the minimum requirements of USERRA, as may be amended from time to time. To the extent that this section does not meet the minimum requirements of USERRA, the provisions of USERRA shall govern. 
(9)  "Contributions" shall mean the amounts deducted from the salary as a member as provided in section 7 [10.07]. 
(10)  "Disability retirement" shall mean retirement upon the disability retirement rate as provided in section 10 [10.10]. 
(11)  "Fund" shall mean the St. Augustine Police Officers Retirement Fund as provided in this Act. 
(12)  "Member" shall mean any police officer entitled to participate in the system and fund as provided in this Act. 
(13)  "Past service liability" shall mean the liability attributable to all accrued benefits which shall have been earned by members prior to January 1, 1957. 
(14)  "Police officer" means any person who is elected, appointed, or employed full time by any municipality, who is certified or required to be certified as a law enforcement officer in compliance with F.S. § 943.14, who is vested with authority to bear arms and make arrests, and whose primary responsibility is the prevention and detection of crime or the enforcement of the penal, criminal, traffic or highway laws of the state. This definition includes all certified supervisory and command personnel whose duties include, in whole or in part, the supervision, training, guidance and management responsibilities of full-time law enforcement officers, part-time law enforcement officers, or auxiliary law enforcement officers, but does not include part-time law enforcement officers or auxiliary law enforcement officers as the same are defined in F.S. § 943.10(5) and (7), respectively. "Police officer" also shall include a public safety officer who is responsible for performing both police and fire services. 
(15)  "Salary" shall mean the total cash or remuneration paid to a police officer for services rendered during a particular year. It shall include base salary, overtime, special incentive pay, and sick leave or vacation leave taken during the year. Salary shall not include lump-sum checks for leave pay accrued but never taken. Only fifty-two (52) weeks of salary may be credited in any year. For years beginning on and after October 1, 1994, salary in excess of $150,000 shall be disregarded for all purposes of the system. As of October 1 of each calendar year thereafter, the dollar limitation as determined by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue for that calendar year will become effective for that plan year in lieu of the dollar limitation provided in the preceding sentence. For an employee who became a member prior to October 1, 1994, this limitation shall not apply to the extent that salary allowed to be taken into account under the plan would be reduced below the amount allowed to be taken into account under the plan in effect on September 30, 1994. Salary in excess of the limitations set forth in Section 401(a)(17) of the Code as of the first day of the plan year shall be disregarded for any purpose, including employee contributions or any benefit calculations. The annual compensation of each member taken into account in determining benefits or employee contributions for any plan year beginning on or after January 1, 2002, may not exceed $200,000, as adjusted for cost-of-living increases in accordance with Section 401(a)(17)(B) of the Code. 
(16)  "Service retirement" shall mean retirement upon the normal service retirement date or delayed service retirement date, as provided in section 8 [10.08]. 
(17)  "System" shall mean the St. Augustine Police Officers Retirement System created by this Act. 
(18)  "Total current contribution" shall mean the total of all funds contributed for any given calendar year to the St. Augustine Police Officers' Retirement Fund, less the funds contributed that year toward amortizing the unfunded liability at December 31, 1960, (which funds shall in no event be less than three (3) percent of the unfunded liability at December 31, 1960, left unamortized at the end of the preceding calendar year). 
(19)  "Trustee" shall mean any member of the board of trustees as provided in this Act. 
(Ord. No. 99-30, § 1, 10-25-99; Ord. No. 00-05, § 1, 2-28-00; Ord. No. 00-24, § 1, 6-26-00; Ord. No. 04-19, § 1, 10-25-04; Ord. No. 06-02, § 1, 1-23-06; Ord. No. 06-29, § 1, 9-25-06; Ord. No. 10-33, § 1, 10-11-10) 
Sec. 10.03. - Creation and maintenance of the fund. 
    The special fund created by this Act shall consist of moneys and assets derived from the following sources: 
(1)  From moneys and other assets of the "police officers retirement fund" held by the board of trustees of said fund on the effective date of Article X hereof, in pursuance of F.S. ch. 185. The board of trustees of said fund shall take such action as may be required, on the effective date of this Act, to transfer to the trustees of the fund under the system hereby created such moneys and assets. 
(2)  From the net proceeds of the point eighty-five (.85) percent excise or license tax which may be imposed by ordinance of the city upon those casualty insurance companies to the extent and as described and permitted in F.S. § 185.08. 
(3)  Effective October 1, 2005, from a contribution of five and one-half (5.5) percent of the salary of each member, which shall be deducted by the city from each salary payment to the member and paid over to the board. Effective October 1, 1993, the contributions made by each member to the fund shall be designated as city contributions in accordance with Section 414(h) of the Internal Revenue Code, and shall be excluded from the members' gross income for federal income tax purposes. For all other purposes of the system, such contributions shall be considered member contributions. In addition, the city shall make a contribution of one percent of salary of each member which shall be paid over to the board. 
(4)  From the funds of the St. Augustine Police Benevolent Association. At such time as Article X hereof, shall become operative and from time to time thereafter, there shall be transferred from the funds of the St. Augustine Police Benevolent Association such amounts as shall be agreed upon by the officers of said association and the board. 
(5)  From all gifts, bequests and devises when donated for the fund. 
(6)  From accretions to the fund by way of interest on bank deposits or otherwise. 
(7)  From all other sources of income now or hereafter authorized by law for the augmentation of such fund. 
(8)  The city shall contribute to the plan annually an amount which together with the contributions from police officers, the amount derived from the premium tax provided in F.S. § 185.08, and other income sources will be sufficient to meet the normal cost of the plan and to fund the actuarial deficiency over a period of not longer than forty (40) years. The city contributions shall be deposited on at least a quarterly basis. If the required city contributions for any plan year should exceed five (5) percent of the combined salaries of contributing plan members, the cost of living adjustment provided in Section 10.12(10) shall not be accrued until the required city contribution for a subsequent plan year equals five (5) percent or less. 
(9)  The cost shall be determined by an actuarial valuation of the retirement plan which must be made at least every three (3) years commencing from the last actuarial report of the plan pursuant to F.S. § 185.35(1)(h). Such valuation shall be prepared by an enrolled actuary. 
(Ord. No. 99-30, § 1, 10-25-99; Ord. No. 06-02, § 2, 1-23-06) 
Sec. 10.04. - Board of trustees. 
(1)  In the municipality of St. Augustine, Florida, there is hereby created a Board of Trustees of the St. Augustine Police Officers' Retirement Trust Fund, which shall be solely responsible for administering the trust fund. Effective as of the effective date of this Act, and thereafter, the board of trustees shall consist of five (5) members, two (2) of whom, unless otherwise prohibited by law, shall be legal residents of St. Augustine, Florida, who shall be appointed by the St. Augustine City Commission, and two (2) of whom shall be police officers as defined in F.S. § 185.02(1), who shall be elected by a majority of the police officers who are members of such plan. The fifth member shall be chosen by a majority of the previous four (4) members, and such person's name shall be submitted to the St. Augustine City Commission. Upon receipt of the fifth person's name, said city commission shall, as a ministerial duty, appoint such person to the board of trustees as its member. The fifth member shall have the same rights as each of the other four (4) members appointed or elected as herein provided and may succeed himself in office. Each resident member shall serve as trustee for a period of two (2) years, unless sooner replaced by the city commission at whose pleasure he shall serve, and may succeed himself as a trustee. However, the terms of the mayor, or corresponding chief executive officer of the municipality, and the chief of the police department as members of the board of trustees as provided in Laws of Fla. (1953) ch. 28230, as amended, together with any city manager and member of the City Commission of St. Augustine, Florida, as members of the board of trustees shall terminate on the effective date of this Act. Each police officer member shall serve as trustee for a period of two (2) years, unless he sooner leaves the employment of the municipality as a police officer, whereupon the City Commission of St. Augustine, Florida, shall choose his successor in the same manner as an original appointment. Each police officer may succeed himself in office. The board of trustees shall meet at least quarterly each year. Each board of trustees shall be a legal entity with, in addition to other powers and responsibilities contained herein, the power to bring and defend lawsuits of every kind, nature and description. 
(2)  The trustees shall by majority vote elect from its members a chairman and a secretary. The board of trustees may by majority vote also elect from its members a vice chairman. The secretary of the board shall keep a complete minute book of the actions, proceedings, or hearings of the board. The trustees shall not receive any compensation as such, but may receive expenses and per diem as provided by law. 
    The elected trustees shall be elected by the members of the system at an election held in the following manner: 
(a)  By per capita vote of all the members at a meeting of which all members shall be notified in person or by mail five (5) days in advance. Elected trustees shall begin their term of office on the first Monday after election to said office. An election shall be compulsory every year. 
(b)  The first election of the elected trustees shall be held within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this Act. The members of the board of trustees other than the elected trustees shall appoint the judges and clerks for the election of the elected trustees, and shall establish such rules and procedures as may be necessary to conduct the election in an orderly and equitable manner. 
The time for said election shall be set by the two (2) trustees first appointed to the board and thereafter said election shall be held on that date each year, or such date as may be designated by the board. The votes shall be counted immediately following the election and the member receiving the greatest number of votes shall be declared elected. 
(3)  If a vacancy occurs in an elective office of trustee, the vacancy shall be filled within thirty (30) days after the date of the vacancy for the unexpired term in the same manner as the office was previously filled. 
(4)  Each trustee shall, within ten (10) days after his appointment or election, take an oath of office before the city chief accountant or a notary public, that so far as it devolves upon him he will diligently and honestly administer the affairs of the said board, and that he will not knowingly violate or willingly permit to be violated any of the provisions of the law applicable to this system. Such oath shall be subscribed to by the trustee making it and certified by the said city chief accountant or notary public and retained as a permanent record in the files of the board. 
(5)  In addition to its quarterly meetings, the board shall hold special meetings at any time requested by the chairman or any three (3) trustees. The chairman shall designate the time and place of each meeting by written notice to the trustees and members, such notice to be delivered or placed in the mail to said trustees and members at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the convening of said meeting. All meetings of the board shall be open to the members of the system and to the public. 
(6)  Three (3) trustees shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the board. Each trustee shall be entitled to one vote in the meetings of the board. At least three (3) concurring votes shall be necessary for a decision by the board. The board shall have the right to dismiss any elected trustee if, after hearing before the members of the system, it is found that the said trustee has failed to comply with any of the stipulations of Article X hereof, involving moral turpitude as defined by Florida Law. 
(7)  The board of trustees, subject to the limitations of this Act and within the standards and purposes of this Act, shall make such rules and regulations as are necessary for the effective administration of the system and fund created by this Act and for transaction of its business. The board shall keep records of all its proceedings and such records on each member as it may deem necessary and proper in its administration of this Act. Said board shall make investigations concerning the enforcement and effect of this Act and its adopted rules and regulations. It shall make an annual report to the members of the system which shall include a financial report of the receipts, disbursements, assets and liabilities of the fund. 
(8)  The board shall engage such actuarial, legal or other services as shall be required to transact the business of the fund. The compensation of all persons engaged by the board and all expenses necessary for the operation of the system shall be paid by said system at such rates and in such amounts as the board shall agree. 
(9)  The secretary of the board shall execute bonds in such amounts as may from time to time be fixed by the board for the faithful performance of his duties. The board shall establish a system of accounting, and do all things, take all actions, and make all rules and regulations, not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act, that it deems necessary and proper to safeguard the funds placed in its custody and to carry out the provisions of this Act. 
(10)  The secretary of the board shall be the custodian of all records maintained by the board. The secretary shall permit inspection of all records held in his custody by any trustee or member of the system. The secretary shall keep a record of all persons receiving retirement payments under this system, in which it shall be noted the time when the pension begins and when the pension shall cease to be paid. In this record, the secretary shall keep a list of all police officers employed by the City, including the name, address, and dates of employment of each police officer. 
(11)  In the absence of the chairman of the board at any meeting of the trustees the vice chairman shall serve as chairman and in the absence of both the chairman and the vice chairman at any meeting of the trustees, the secretary shall serve as chairman. 
(12)  At least once every three (3) years, the board of trustees, shall retain an independent consultant professional qualified to evaluate the performance of professional money managers. The independent consultant shall make recommendations to the board of trustees regarding the selection of money managers for the next investment term. These recommendations shall be considered by the board of trustees at its next regularly scheduled meeting. The date, time, place, and subject of this meeting shall be advertised in a newspaper of general circulation in the municipality at least ten (10) days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(13)  In connection with the administration of the fund the board of trustees is authorized and empowered to institute proceedings in court and be sued, in the name of the system. 
(Ord. No. 99-30, § 1, 10-25-99; Ord. No. 00-24, § 2, 6-26-00) 
Sec. 10.045. - City attorney to represent board of trustees. 
    The city attorney shall give advice to said board of trustees in all matters pertaining to their duties in the administration of said municipal police officers' retirement trust fund whenever requested; and he shall represent and defend said board as its attorney in all suits and actions at law or in equity that may be brought against it, and bring all suits and actions in its behalf that may be required or determined upon by said board; provided, however, that if the board of trustees so elects, it may employ independent legal counsel at the pension fund's expense for the purposes contained herein, together with such other professional, technical, or other advisers as the board deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. 99-30, § 1, 10-25-99) 
Sec. 10.05. - Management of the funds. 
(1)  The board is solely responsible for administering the trust, and shall be responsible for investing the assets of the system in accordance with this section. The board shall exercise its duties with respect to the system for the exclusive purpose of providing benefits to members and their beneficiaries and defraying the reasonable expenses of administering the system. The board shall exercise its investment authority with the care, skill, prudence and diligence under the circumstances then prevailing that a prudent person in a like capacity and familiar with such matters would use in the conduct of an enterprise with like character and like aims, and by diversifying the investments of the system so as to reduce the risk of large losses, unless under the circumstances it is clearly prudent not to do so. The board shall have full power to hold, purchase, sell, assign, transfer and dispose of any of the securities and investments in which any of the assets of the system have been invested, as well as the proceeds of such investments and any moneys belonging to the fund, in accordance with this section. The board may employ outside investment counsel to advise the board in the making and disposition of investments. 
(2)  The board shall adopt and periodically update a written investment policy in accordance with Section 112.661, Florida Statutes, incorporating the following requirements for specific investments: 
(a)  The board may invest in money market instruments, stocks, corporate bonds, bonds or other obligations of the United States of America, either directly or through pooled or commingled funds. 
(b)  The board may make direct investment in bonds, notes, or obligations of any municipality or political subdivision or any agency or authority of the State of Florida, if the obligations are rated investment grade by at least one nationally recognized rating organization. 
(c)  The board may invest up to fifteen (15) percent of its assets in real estate only through participation in commingled funds or insurance company group annuity separate accounts holding diversified real properties. Insurance companies must be licensed to do business in the State of Florida and commingled funds and insurance companies must be rated investment grade by at least one nationally recognized rating organization. Any commingled or pooled vehicles used by the board should have investment guidelines that are materially consistent with the guidelines herein. 
(d)  The board may invest up to fifteen (15) percent of its assets in mortgage loan securities secured by real property only through participation in commingled funds or insurance company separate accounts holding diversified mortgage securities. Insurance companies must be licensed to do business in the State of Florida and commingled funds and insurance companies must be rated investment grade by at least one nationally recognized rating organization. Any commingled or pooled vehicles used by the board should have investment guidelines that are materially consistent with the guidelines herein. Mortgage securities of commingled funds must be issued by an agency of or enterprise sponsored by the United States Government, including, but not limited to, the Government National Mortgage Association, the Federal National Mortgage Association, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. 
(e)  The board may invest up to five (5) percent of its assets in stock and corporate bonds of any one (1) issuing company either directly or through pooled or commingled funds. 
(f)  The aggregate investment in stock either directly or through pooled or commingled funds shall not exceed seventy (70) percent (at cost) of the assets of the fund. 
(g)  The average credit quality of the fixed income portfolio shall be rated "A" or higher. No more than 15% of the fixed income portfolio may be rated lower than "BBB". The duration of the fixed income portfolio shall remain within 35% of the duration of a market index selected by the board. If there is no index selected, the default index shall be the Lehman Aggregate Bond Index. 
(h)  The board may invest up to twenty-five percent (25%) of the assets of the fund, in corporate obligations and/or securities of a foreign corporation or a foreign commercial entity that are not subject to United States securities laws. United States dollar-denominated securities listed and traded on a United States exchange would not be included in this limitation. 
(3)  The board shall deposit the funds and securities of the city police officers' retirement trust fund in a qualified public depository as defined in section 280.02(26), Florida Statutes, which depository with regard to such funds and securities shall conform to and be bound by all of the provisions of Chapter 280, Florida Statutes. 
(4)  The board may issue drafts upon the city police officers' retirement trust fund pursuant to Article X hereof, and rules and regulations prescribed by the board. All such drafts shall be consecutively numbered, be signed by the chairman and secretary and state upon their faces the purposes for which the drafts are drawn. The city director of financial services shall retain such drafts when paid, as permanent vouchers for disbursements made, and no other money shall otherwise be drawn from the fund. 
(5)  No trustee shall have any interest, direct or indirect, in the gains or profits of any investment made by the board, save insofar as such trustee may be a member or beneficiary of the system. No trustee shall in any manner, directly or indirectly, for himself or as an agent, use the funds or deposits of the system except to make such payments therefrom as are authorized by the board, nor shall any member of the board become an endorser or surety or in any manner an obligor for moneys loaned by or borrowed from the fund. 
(6)  The board shall have the right to purchase an individual annuity from an insurance company, when a member becomes eligible for service retirement, in an amount sufficient to pay the retired member his earned monthly pension of retirement. 
(7)  Notwithstanding any provision of this section to the contrary, the Board shall identify and publicly report any direct or indirect holdings it may have in any scrutinized company, as defined in section 215.473, Florida Statutes, and proceed to sell, redeem, divest, or withdraw all publicly traded securities it may have in that company beginning January 1, 2010. The divestiture of any such security must be completed by September 30, 2010.
