In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the city commission. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "Section _____ of The Code of the City of St. Augustine, Florida is amended to read as follows: ...." The new provisions should then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  If a new section is to be added, the following language may be used: "The Code of the City of St. Augustine, Florida is amended by adding section (or article or chapter) _____, to read as follows: ...." The new section should then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1964, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-8. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  In this section "violation of this Code" means: 
(1)  Doing an acting that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(2)  Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(3)  Failure to perform an act if the failure is declared a misdemeanor or an offense or unlawful by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(b)  In this section "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a city officer or city employee to perform an official duty unless it is provided that failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided, a person convicted of a violation of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days or any combination thereof. With respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate offense. 
(d)  The imposition of a penalty does not prevent revocation or suspension of a license, permit or franchise. 
(e)  Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent equitable relief. 
(f)  The imposition of a penalty does not prevent code enforcement board proceeding or the imposition of a civil fine or civil penalty. 
(Code 1964, § 1-8) 
Sec. 1-9. - Proration of fine and imprisonment. 
    Any person serving a jail sentence in lieu of paying a fine may at any time obtain his release by paying an amount equal to the prorated amount of his fine, plus court costs. The prorated fine is determined by multiplying the number of days remaining unserved by the daily rate of fine. The daily rate of fine is determined by dividing the amount of the original fine by the number of days of the original sentence. It is intended that this section shall apply only to such cases where it is optional with the convicted person to pay either the fine or to serve the jail sentence. 
(Code 1964, § 1-9) 
Sec. 1-10. - Assessment of court costs. 
    The county court in and for the county shall assess two dollars ($2.00) as a court cost against every person convicted for violation of a municipal ordinance of the city committed within the city limits within the territorial jurisdiction of the county court, including violations of the Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law [F.S. ch. 316] previously adopted by the city, and including violations of any offenses previously triable in the municipal court, for law enforcement education expenditures for the city law enforcement officers. In addition, two dollars ($2.00) from every bond estreature or forfeited bail bond related to such penal ordinances shall be assessed for the aforesaid purpose. No such assessment shall be made against any person convicted for a violation of any municipal ordinance related to the parking of vehicles. All such costs collected by the county court in and for the county shall be deposited and disbursed according to law. 
(Code 1964, § 1-10) 
State Law reference- Authority to so provide, F.S. § 943.25. 
Sec. 1-11. - Ordinances not affected by Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city, or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city. 
(2)  Establishing positions, classifying employees and setting salaries or providing employee benefits that is not codified in this Code. 
(3)  Any right of franchise granted by any ordinance to any person. 
(4)  Dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way that is not codified in this Code. 
(5)  Dealing with appropriations or the budget that is not codified in this Code. 
(6)  Levying or imposing taxes not inconsistent with this Code herewith. 
(7)  Rezoning specific property. 
(8)  Published in the charter compilation accompanying this Code. 
(9)  Establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city. 
(10)  Providing for local improvements and assessments taxes therefor. 
(11)  Dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city. 
(12)  Extending or contracting or otherwise relating to the boundaries of the city. 
(13)  Adopted for purposes which have been consummated. 
(14)  Which is temporary, although general in effect. 
(15)  Which is special, although permanent in effect. 
(b)  Such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Sec. 1-12. - Provisions considered as continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this and the following chapters and sections, so far as they are the same as those of ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-13. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance of the city in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - City seal. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted as an official seal of the city that certain coat of arms, a copy of which is appended to the ordinance from which this section derives and as filed with the city clerk. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful, and the city hereby adopts the provisions of Ch. 91-59, Laws of Florida, for any person to utilize any image or impression of the city seal without the consent, in writing, of the city commission, as provided in Ch. 91-59, Laws of Florida, and violation hereof shall be punished as a second degree misdemeanor as provided in Ch. 91-59, Laws of Florida. 
(c)  Any existing seal of the city may continue to be utilized by the city clerk as an official seal of the city. 
(Ord. No. 91-32, §§ 1-3, 12-9-91) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 91-32, §§ 1-3, adopted Dec. 9, 1991, not specifically amendatory of this Code, has been codified as § 2-1 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 2-2-2-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- City commission, § 2.01 et seq.; election of mayor, § 4.09. 
Cross reference- Elections, Ch. 10. 

Sec. 2-26. - Salary of commissioners. 
    Each member of the city commission, other than the mayor-commissioner, shall receive a salary of twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00) per year and the mayor-commissioner shall receive a salary of sixteen thousand dollars ($16,000.00) per year. Each successive year, on October 1, the salaries of each member of the city commission and the mayor-commissioner shall be increased by the average general wage increase for all employees of the city. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 4.07-1; Ord. No. 76-41, § 1, 11-8-76; Ord. No. 77-12, § 1, 5-9-77; Ord. No. 79-19, § 1, 5-14-79; Ord. No. 79-43, § 1, 10-8-79; Ord. No. 82-36, § 1, 12-27-82; Ord. No. 99-08, § 1, 2-22-99; Ord. No. 03-18, § 1, 6-9-03) 
Secs. 2-27-2-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- City officers generally, § 2.01 et seq., § 4.01 et seq.; civil service, § 10.5.01 et seq. 
Cross reference- Pensions and retirement, Ch. 20. 
State Law reference- Public officers and employees generally, F.S. ch. 112. 

Sec. 2-51. - Oath of officers. 
    Every officer of the city shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take and subscribe to an oath or affirmation to be filed and kept in the office of the city clerk; which oath shall be in the form prescribed for state officers by the constitution of the state. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 4.03; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 184) 
State Law reference- Official oath, Fla. Const. art. II, § 5(b). 
Sec. 2-52. - Conflicts of interest. 
(a)  For the purposes of this article, the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section. 
    Conflict of interest means the having of a direct financial interest of any kind in the outcome of any act taken by a person connected with the operation of the city which will aid or benefit that person. 
    Members of any board, commission, council or agency means each and every person appointed by the city commission to any board, commission, council or agency, whether compensated for services or not. 
    Officers and officials; employees means each and every person employed by the city in any capacity. 
(b)  Any individuals referred to in subsection (a) above who shall have a direct financial interest in any matter or transaction affecting the city government shall state the nature of such interest, recordably, at the commencement of such transaction and shall thereafter refrain from all participation therein. 
(c)  Should any such person participate in any such action, that fact alone shall render the matter or transaction voidable by the city commission. 
(d)  Any person found guilty of the willful violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1964, §§ 2-16-2-18; Ord. No. 18-11, § 1, 8-27-18) 
State Law reference- Conflicts of interest and financial disclosure, F.S. § 112.313 et seq. 
Sec. 2-53. - Per diem rates and subsistence allowance for authorized travelers. 
(a)  As used herein all words and phrases shall have the same meaning as provided by general law. 
(b)  In lieu of the per diem rate established by general law, authorized travelers may be allowed subsistence when traveling away from the traveler's official headquarters, i.e., actual expenses for meals, including gratuities, plus actual expenses for lodging at single occupancy rate, such expenses for lodging to be substantiated with paid bills therefor; however, in lieu of reimbursement for such subsistence and lodging the city manager is authorized to cause to be issued by a reputable credit card company upon such terms and conditions as he deems reasonable credit cards to such regularly employed employees of the city, including the city manager, as he shall deem appropriate, to be used by such employee or employees for the sole purpose of paying for such actual expenses for meals, including gratuities, and actual expenses for lodging at single occupancy rates as herein provided; provided that in the event of the use of such credit card all receipts shall be accounted for by the authorized traveler; and provided, further, that in the event of resignation or other departure from city service of such employee, such employee's final pay shall be withheld until the return of any such credit card. 
(c)  The following incidental traveling expenses of the traveler may be reimbursed: 
(1)  Taxi fare, including gratuities. 
(2)  Ferry fares and bridge, road and tunnel tolls. 
(3)  Storage and parking fees, including gratuities. 
(4)  Communication expenses incurred in pursuit of municipal business. 
(5)  Luggage handling and maid service, including gratuities. 
(6)  Convention registration fee while attending a convention or conference which will serve a direct public service with relation to the public agency served by the person attending such meeting. However, any meals and lodging included in the registration fee will be deducted in accordance with the provisions of general law. 
(7)  Actual expenses incurred for meals and gratuities of persons engaged in municipal business with the authorized traveler; however, such expenses of third persons shall be documented by the authorized traveler by providing on his reimbursement voucher the name, affiliation and municipal business discussed with such third person. 
(Code 1964, § 2-5) 
Sec. 2-54. - Filling of vacancies; chief of police or fire chief. 
    At the time of any vacancy for the position of chief of police or fire chief of the city, the civil service board or its examiner, subject to its approval, shall provide examinations and maintain a list of eligibles to appointment of chief of either the police or fire department and shall certify such list to the city manager and such vacancy shall be filled only from such list of eligibles. In the event that the city manager shall determine that no one on the list of eligibles shall be qualified to serve as chief of the fire or police department, then such civil service board shall prepare an additional list of eligibles for certification to the city manager from which such appointment shall be made. 
(Code 1964, § 2-6) 
Secs. 2-55-2-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Civil service board, § 10.5.04. 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxation and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17. 
State Law reference- Municipal finance generally, F.S. § 166.201 et seq.; local government finance, F.S. ch. 218. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-71. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall begin on the first day of October and end on the thirtieth day of September of each year. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 14.01; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 93; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 15) 
State Law reference- Fiscal year, F.S. §§ 166.241, 218.33. 
Sec. 2-72. - Transfer of funds. 
    No transfer of the money or any part thereof from one (1) fund to another fund, or the payment from one (1) fund of expenditures legally payable from another fund shall be lawful except by a duly adopted resolution of the city commission concurred in by not less than a majority of commissioners, and the director of financial services shall not make any transfers of moneys from one (1) fund to another except upon a resolution duly adopted as provided for above. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 14.07; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 97; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 18; Ord. No. 84-12, § 10, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 2-73. - Money drawn from treasury; issuance of warrants. 
    No money shall be drawn from the treasury of the city, nor shall any obligation for the expenditure of money be incurred, except pursuant to the appropriations made by the city commission. No warrant for the payment of any account or claim shall be issued by the director of financial services until such account or claim shall have been approved by the city manager. The director of financial services under the supervision and advice of the city manager shall prescribe the method and forms of accounting in the city, and make all necessary rules and regulations to make such method and forms of accounting effective. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 14.09; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 99; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 19; Ord. No. 84-12, § 10, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 2-74. - City manager authorized to determine fees for administrative services. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized, from time to time, to determine the cost of copying, inspections and other administrative services performed by the city and where no charge is otherwise provided for such services, to promulgate fees in accordance with such costs to be charged for the rendering of such services. Such fees shall become effective thirty (30) days after a copy thereof has been furnished to the city commission unless the city commission shall, by ordinance, provide some other fee or charge for such services or direct that no fee be charged. 
(Code 1964, § 2-3) 
State Law reference- User fees authorized, F.S. § 166.201. 
Sec. 2-75. - Law enforcement trust fund. 
(a)  Created. There is hereby created in the city treasury a special law enforcement trust fund pursuant to the provisions of the Florida Contraband Forfeiture Act into which shall be deposited, from time to time, proceeds from the sale of seized contraband articles such as vessels, motor vehicles, aircraft and other personal property. The funds contained in this special law enforcement trust fund may be expended only upon approval of the city commission and may be used only to defray costs of protracted or complex investigations; provide additional technical equipment or expertise to the police department of the city; provide matching funds to obtain federal grants; or such other law enforcement purposes as the city commission deems appropriate; but in no event shall such funds be utilized to meet normal operating needs. 
(b)  Report. The chief of police shall submit to the city commission a quarterly report specifying for the preceding quarter the type and approximate value of the property received and the amount of any proceeds received. The amounts contained in the trust fund established by subsection (a) hereof shall not be included in the adoption or approval of any budget for the police department. 
(Code 1964, § 2-4) 
State Law reference- Law enforcement trust fund, F.S. § 932.704(3)(a). 
Sec. 2-76. - Road and bridge fund established; purposes; deposit of monies; unexpended monies. 
(a)  There is hereby established a fund to be known and designated as "The Road and Bridge Fund." 
(b)  All monies deposited in the road and bridge fund shall be kept separate and apart from all other municipal funds. Monies from the road and bridge fund shall not be expended for any other purposes than for work on the public roads and bridges in the city; for the payment of the salaries of employees engaged in road and bridge work; for providing the necessary tools, materials, implements and equipment for repairing and maintaining the roads and bridges of the city. 
(c)  The monies to be deposited in the road and bridge fund shall be: 
(1)  All monies received from the board of county commissioners as the city's share of the county levy of taxes for road and bridge purposes in accordance with law. 
(2)  All monies appropriated by the city commission to the road and bridge fund in the city's annual budget. 
(3)  All monies received by the city from state or federal grants or matching funds for the purpose of repairing and maintaining the city's roads, streets and bridges. 
(d)  All unexpended monies in the road and bridge fund at the end of any fiscal year of the city shall be carried over and appropriated to the road and bridge fund in the next ensuing city budget. Such unexpended monies in the road and bridge fund shall not be placed in the general fund or any other fund of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 25-5) 
Sec. 2-77. - Competitive bids. 
    Competitive formal bids should be solicited for any single item which exceeds the purchase cost of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(1964 Charter Laws § 4.13; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 34; Laws of Fla. (1955) ch. 31226, § 1; Ord. No. 82-38, § 1, 11-22-82) 
Sec. 2-78. - Accounting procedure; accounting reports. 
    The accounting procedure established in the office of the director of financial services shall be adequate to provide a record in detail of all transactions affecting the acquisition, custodianship and disposition of value, including cash receipts and disbursements, and such facts shall be so presented in the reports which the director of financial services is required to render periodically, and shall be supported with such summaries and analytical schedules as may be necessary to show in detail the full account of such transactions for each fiscal year, upon the finances of the city and relation to each department of the city government, including district summaries and schedules for each public utility owned and operated. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 4.34; Ord. No. 84-12, § 2, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 2-79. - Determination of indigent status. 
(a)  Application to the clerk. A person seeking relief from payment of administrative fees based upon an inability to pay must apply to the office of the city clerk for a determination of indigent status using the application form provided for that purpose. The application must include, at a minimum, the following financial information: 
(1)  Net income, consisting of total salary and wages, minus deductions required by law, including court-ordered support payments. 
(2)  Other income, including, but not limited to, social security benefits, union funds, veterans' benefits, workers' compensation, other regular support from absent family members, public or private employee pensions, reemployment assistance or unemployment compensation, dividends, interest, rent, trusts, and gifts. 
(3)  Assets, including, but not limited to, cash, savings accounts, bank accounts, stocks, bonds, certificates of deposit, equity in real estate, and equity in a boat or a motor vehicle or in other tangible property. 
(4)  All liabilities and debts. 
(b)  The application must be substantiated by proof of income documentation that verifies the financial information alleged by the applicant. Such documentation, including but not limited to, pay stubs, bank statements, and proof of benefits must be provided for all applicable income information entered on the application. 
(c)  The application must include a signature by the applicant which attests under penalty of perjury to the truthfulness of the information provided. 
(d)  The city clerk shall accept any application and supporting proof of income documentation, including an application that is signed by the applicant and submitted on his or her behalf by a private attorney who is representing the applicant in the applicable matter. 
(e)  Determination by the clerk. The city clerk shall determine whether an applicant seeking such designation is indigent based upon the information provided in the application, supporting proof of income documentation, and the criteria prescribed in this subsection. 
(1)  An applicant, including an applicant who is a minor or an adult tax-dependent person, is indigent if the applicant's income is equal to or below two hundred (200) percent of the then-current federal poverty guidelines prescribed for the size of the household of the applicant as published in the Federal Register by the United States Department of Health and Human Services. 
(2)  There is a presumption that the applicant is not indigent if the applicant owns, or has equity in, any intangible or tangible personal property or real property or the expectancy of an interest in any such property having a net equity value of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or more, excluding the value of the person's homestead and one vehicle having a net value not exceeding five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(f)  Based upon its review, the city clerk shall make one of the following determinations: 
(1)  The applicant is not indigent. 
(2)  The applicant is indigent. 
(g)  If the city clerk determines that the applicant is indigent, the clerk shall immediately issue a certified letter of determination of indigency. 
(h)  The duty of the city clerk in determining whether an applicant is indigent is limited to receiving the application and comparing the information provided in the application to the criteria prescribed in this subsection. The determination of indigent status is a ministerial act of the city clerk and may not be based on further investigation or the exercise of independent judgment by the city clerk. 
(i)  Appeals. The applicant may seek review of the city clerk's determination that the applicant is not indigent by filing a petition to review the city clerk's determination of nonindigent status with the city manager's office within ten (10) days of the determination. The city manager shall make a final determination of indigent status by reviewing the information provided in the application against the criteria prescribed in subsection (d) and by considering any further mitigating factors as presented by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 16-28, § 1, 2-23-17) 
Secs. 2-80-2-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DIRECTOR OF FINANCIAL SERVICES 

Sec. 2-96. - Generally. 
    There shall be a director of financial services who shall be appointed by and serve during the pleasure of the city manager. Under the supervision of the city manager he shall be director of the financial services department. He shall be the custodian of all moneys of the municipality and shall keep and preserve the same in such manner and in such place or places as shall be determined by the city commission. He shall issue all warrants for payment of money by the city and shall keep an accurate account of all taxes and assessments, all moneys due to and of all receipts and disbursements by the city, of all of its assets and liabilities and all of the appropriations made by the city commission. He shall submit to the city manager each month a report covering the next preceding month of receipts and expenditures and of the financial condition of the city. He shall make and keep a list of the outstanding city bonds, to whom issued, for what purpose, when and where payable and the rate of interest they respectively bear. He shall furnish the city manager at any time such reports, data and information as may be necessary to fully inform the latter as to the financial affairs of the city, furnishing him such estimates of the expense of the city government as may be necessary to form the basis of the annual budget and to determine the revenues necessary to be raised each year. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 4.32; Ord. No. 84-12, § 2, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 2-97. - City indebtedness; records of lands subject to city assessment; tax levy. 
    The director of financial services shall keep regular books of account, in which shall be entered all indebtedness of the city and which shall at all times show the financial condition of the city, the amount of bonds, orders, certificates or other evidence of indebtedness which have been redeemed; he shall keep account with all disbursing officers and employees of the city showing the amounts they have received from different sources of revenue and the amount they have disbursed as authorized under the ordinances of the city. The director of financial services shall keep a list of all certificates issued for work or for any other purpose and, before the levy by the city commission of any special tax upon any property in the city or any part thereof. The director of financial services shall furnish to the city manager for the information of the city commission a schedule of all lots or parcels of land which may be subject to the proposed tax or assessment and which it may be necessary to levy on, which such schedule shall be certified by his affidavit and shall be prima facie evidence of the facts stated therein in all cases wherein the validity of such tax or assessment shall come in question. Acting upon such schedule the city commission may, if it deems such special tax or assessment legal and just, cause the same to be levied. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 4.33; Ord. No. 84-12, § 2, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 2-98. - Audit of accounts of officers removed from office; report of indebtedness. 
    Upon the death, resignation, removal or expiration of the term of any officer, the director of financial services shall audit such officer's accounts; and if such officer shall be found to be indebted to the city, the director shall at once give notice thereof through the city manager to the city commission and to the city attorney and the latter shall forthwith proceed to collect the sum of such indebtedness. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 4.35; Ord. No. 84-12, § 2, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 2-99. - Duty to collect interest on investments, etc.; hold bonds, securities, etc. 
    All moneys due as interest upon investments or deposits, except investments or deposits of sinking fund assets, shall be collected by the director of financial services and placed to the credit of the general fund of the city. Any and all bonds and securities taken for investments and deposits shall be held by the director for safekeeping for the benefits of the city. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 4.36; Ord. No. 84-12, § 2, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 2-100. - Collection of city moneys; account. 
    The director of financial services shall receive and collect all moneys belonging to the city including taxes, license moneys, fines and income from all other sources. The director of financial services shall collect all special assessments as provided for under the Charter and Code and keep an accurate account thereof. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 4.37; Ord. No. 84-12, § 2, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 2-101. - Money to be paid on warrants only; exceptions. 
    The director of financial services shall pay out moneys only on warrants countersigned by the city manager, except bonds and interest-bearing coupons, which, when due, may be paid upon presentation, or in case the same are payable in some other place other than the city, the money for their redemption shall be sent to the place of payment. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 4.38; Ord. No. 84-12, § 2, 4-23-84) 
Secs. 2-102-2-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUDGET PREPARATION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Budget preparation generally, F.S. § 200.065. 

Sec. 2-121. - Responsibility of city manager. 
(a)  At such time as required by general law and by the city Charter, the city manager shall prepare and file with the city commission a full and complete budget of all anticipated expenditures for administration and maintenance of the city for the next ensuing fiscal year, giving details as required by the city Charter and general law as to the number and amounts of paid employees and for necessary regular administration and maintenance expenditures and capitol outlays. In the preparation of the tentative budget, the city manager shall first ascertain the estimated revenues and receipts by source anticipated to be available during the ensuing year for which the budget is prepared. Estimated revenues derived from ad valorem taxation shall be based on the estimated rolled back millage as determined by general law. The receipt side of the budget shall set forth all anticipated fund balances to be brought forward at the beginning of the budget year. In the preparation of estimated expenditures, the city manager shall first set forth all amounts required or estimated to be required for fire protection, police protection, solid waste disposal, water utility and sanitary sewer utility. There shall be set aside sufficient estimated receipts to provide for such services, and the moneys thus set aside in the tentative budget shall be used for no other purpose. 
(b)  He shall set forth all amounts required or estimated to be required for accounting, payroll, utility billing and collecting, vehicle maintenance, purchasing and stores and administration. There shall be set aside sufficient estimated receipts to provide for such services, and the moneys thus set aside in the tentative budget shall be used for no other purpose. 
(c)  If there shall be any revenues remaining, he shall set forth all amounts required or estimated to be required for street and drainage maintenance, building and zoning code enforcement, and building and structure maintenance. 
(d)  There shall be budgeted from the remaining tax revenues the following services: Advertising and promotion, historic preservation, parking enforcement, dog control, recreation, parks and yacht pier. 
(Code 1964, § 2-59) 
Sec. 2-122. - Budget to conform to state law. 
    In the preparation of the tentative and final budget, no moneys shall be allocated or budgeted to aid any corporation, association, partnership or person in violation of Fla. Const. art. VII, § 7. 
(Code 1964, § 2-60) 
Sec. 2-123. - City manager to submit budget to commission; information required. 
    Prior to the making of the levy for taxes for each year, the city manager shall prepare and submit to the commission a budget estimate of the necessary and ordinary and of all special and extraordinary expenditures contemplated and the anticipated revenues and receipts of all city departments, divisions, and offices for the ensuing fiscal year. The estimate shall be compiled from detailed information obtained from the several departments, divisions, and offices, on uniform blanks furnished by the city manager. The classification of the estimates shall be as nearly uniform as possible for the main functional divisions of such departments, divisions and offices and these shall give in parallel columns the following information: 
(1)  A detailed estimate of the expenses of conducting each department, division or office. 
(2)  Expenditures for corresponding items for the last two (2) fiscal years. 
(3)  Expenditures for corresponding items for the current fiscal year including adjustment due to transfers between appropriations, plus an estimate of the expenditures necessary to complete the current fiscal year. 
(4)  The value of supplies and material on hand at the date of the preparation of the estimate. 
(5)  Increases or decreases requested compared with corresponding appropriation for the current year, with reasons for such increases or decreases. 
(6)  The total probable income of the city from taxes for the period covered by the estimate. 
(7)  An itemization of anticipated revenues from other sources. 
(8)  The total amount of the outstanding city debt with a schedule of maturities of bond issues and other indebtedness. 
(9)  The amount required for interest on the city debt, for sinking funds and for maturing bonds. 
(10)  Such other information as may be required by the commission. 
(11)  The information and estimate so given and constituting the recommendation of the city manager as to the amounts necessary to be appropriated for the ensuing fiscal year shall be supported with information giving the reasons therefor in such detail as may be necessary to afford the city commission a comprehensive understanding of the needs and requirements of the various divisions of the city government for the ensuing period. 
(12)  The city commission may in its discretion create a special fund which shall be designated as "reserve fund" into which shall be payable all revenues arising from sources other than taxes, license fees, rentals and endowments. In the event such a reserve fund shall be established, the city manager in preparing the budget shall exclude from his estimate of the income of the city, all revenues for the year for which such budget estimate is prepared, which shall be payable to such reserve fund, but he shall include in the budget as available revenue, subject to appropriation, the amount of all moneys in such reserve fund at the commencement of the year for which such budget estimate is prepared. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 14.02; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 94; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 16) 
Sec. 2-124. - Budget estimate to be filed with director of financial services. 
    Copies of the budget estimate of the city manager shall be on file in the office of the director of financial services and open for inspection by the public. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 14.03; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 94; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 16; Ord. No. 84-12, § 10, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 2-125. - Budget estimate to be basis for tax levies and appropriations. 
    The budget estimate of expenditures and revenues shall form the basis for all tax levies and appropriations made by the city commission for the year for which such budget estimate is prepared. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 14.04; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 94; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 16) 
Sec. 2-126. - Budget estimate to show expenditures contemplated; notice and hearing; adoption; certification; disposition of unexpended funds. 
    The estimates herein provided, after being completed, shall be published in summary form one (1) time in a newspaper published in the city; together with a notice to the taxpayers of the city stating the time and place when objections thereto will be heard; such publication and the notice shall be made within one (1) week from the making of such estimates; and at the next regular meeting of the city commission after such publication or at a special meeting of the city commission after such publication or at a special meeting called for the purpose not less than two (2) weeks after such publication. Such estimates and objections, if any, shall be considered and acted upon and as adopted the estimates shall be spread in full upon the minutes of the city commission. The adoption of such estimates by the commission shall give such estimates the force and effect of fixed appropriations and the same shall not be altered or amended, or exceeded, nor shall the expenses estimated under one (1) head be paid out of the estimate for any other expense. The city commission shall certify the total millage to the county property appraiser as soon after the adoption of the budget as possible. All unexpended balances to the credit of any account at the end of the fiscal year shall revert to the fund from which the appropriation was made, but nothing herein shall be construed as prohibiting the reserving in the estimates of a reasonable sum for contingencies and emergencies and the appropriation of any part of such sum so reserved for any expense of the city authorized by law or by the Charter. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 14.06; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 11148, § 95; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 17; Laws of Fla. (1933) ch. 16657, § 2; Laws of Fla. (1937) ch. 18877, § 4; Ord. No. 74-27, § 1, 9-9-74) 
Secs. 2-127-2-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS AND SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Special assessments generally, F.S. ch. 170. 

Sec. 2-146. - Adoption of policies and procedures in purchasing manual; modification approved by resolution. 
    The city commission may adopt policies and procedures to guide the city manager in the execution and oversight of city purchases and contractual obligations for goods and services. The policies and procedures may be combined, formatted and adopted in a purchasing manual. The city commission herein adopts the purchasing manual in existence and use by the city manager at the time of the adoption of this section as the city's purchasing manual. When in the opinion of the city manager it becomes necessary for the efficient operations of the city and the prosecution of any work or improvement under contract to make alteration or modification to the purchasing manual, the city manager may approve such amendments. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 12.01; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 155; Ord. No. 14-07, § 1, 7-14-14) 
Sec. 2-147. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-07, § 1, adopted July 14, 2014, repealed § 2-147, which pertained to aggregate of contracts not to exceed estimates. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 2-148. - Improper contracts void. 
    All contracts, agreements or other obligations entered into, and all ordinances passed or resolutions and orders adopted, contrary to the provisions of the preceding sections, shall be void. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 12.03; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 157) 
Sec. 2-149. - Commission may declare improvements necessary; community notice. 
    The city commission may declare improvements necessary for the public good and direct the city manager to implement said improvements. The city manager will provide reasonable community notice and an opportunity for public comment prior to the commission approving any contractual obligation of city funds to construct a new building or its supporting infrastructure, to initiate a change in the comprehensive plan or a rezoning for a project expending city funds, to enter into a public-private partnership as allowed pursuant to Florida law, or to vacate roads. The community notice provision does not include expenditures of city funds pursuant to an approved capital improvement plan, routine connection to right-of-way or utilities, maintenance or repair or reconstruction of existing city buildings or public infrastructure. Community notice pursuant to this section shall include a notice mailed to the Neighborhood Council of St. Augustine, Inc. or its successor by regular U.S. mail or electronic mail, to any of its officers or registered agents. In addition, the city manager may provide additional courtesy notice and information to the community at large in person, by regular U.S. mail or electronic mail, posting on the city's website or as otherwise provided by the city clerk. Notice pursuant to this section is not intended to be a legal notice, nor should it be relied upon to provide affected party status or standing. If more specific notice is required for any particular government action pursuant to federal, state or local law such notice shall preempt and supersede the general community notice provided herein. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 12.04; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 158; Ord. No. 14-07, § 1, 7-14-14; Ord. No. 14-21, § 1, 11-10-14) 
Sec. 2-150. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-07, § 1, adopted July 14, 2014, repealed § 2-150, which pertained to procedure when assessments are not paid within specified time. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 2-151. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-07, § 1, adopted July 14, 2014, repealed § 2-151, which pertained to assessments for public improvements not to be made until bids for labor and costs are received. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 2-152. - Authority to levy special assessments for local improvements. 
    The city commission shall have power by ordinance or resolution as authorized by state law to provide for the construction, reconstruction, repair and maintenance, by contract or directly by the employment of labor, of all things in the nature of local improvements, and to provide for the payment of any part of the cost of any local improvement by levying and collecting special assessments upon abutting, adjoining, contiguous or other specially benefited property. The amount assessed against any abutting, adjoining, contiguous or other specially benefited property shall not exceed the amount of the estimated benefits accruing to such properties. The city commission may use the authority and method of making local municipal improvements pursuant to Chapter 170, Florida Statutes. The city commission may elect to use the uniform method of collecting non-ad valorem assessments pursuant to Chapter 197, Florida Statutes, or may use any other legally available method of collection. Any existing non-ad valorem assessment imposed by the city commission shall remain in full force and effect and amendments thereto may be authorized pursuant to this section. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 12.09; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 132; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 48; Ord. No. 14-07, § 1, 7-14-14) 
Secs. 2-153-2-165. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-07, § 1, adopted July 14, 2014, repealed §§ 2-153-2-165, which pertained to public improvements and special assessments. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 2-166. - Reassessments. 
    If any special assessment made under this division to defray the whole or part of the cost of any local improvement shall be either in whole or in part annulled, vacated or set aside by the judgment of any court, or if the city commission shall be satisfied that any such assessment is so irregular or defective that the same cannot be enforced and collected, or if the city commission shall have omitted to make such assessment when it might have done so, it is hereby authorized to take all steps to cause a new assessment for the whole or any part of any improvement or against any property benefited by any improvement following as near as may be the provisions of this Act, and in case such second assessment shall be annulled, the city commission may obtain and make other assessments until a valid assessment shall be made. No omission, informality or irregularity in the proceedings or preliminary to the making of any special assessment shall affect the validity of the same, where the assessment roll has been confirmed by the city commission and the assessment roll and the record thereof, kept by the director of financial services, shall be competent and sufficient evidence that the assessment was duly levied and the assessment roll duly made and adopted and that all other proceedings adequate to the adoption of such assessment roll were duly had, taken and performed as required by law. No variance from the directions herein contained as to the form and manner of any of the proceedings shall be held material, unless it is clearly shown that the party objecting was materially injured thereby. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 12.23; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 142; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 58) 
Sec. 2-167. - Owner may pay assessment at any time; no bar to supplementary assessments. 
    Any property owner may pay his assessment in full at any time, and discharge his property from the lien thereof, upon payment of the aggregate amount of all outstanding installments, plus interest thereon at the rate of eight (8) percent per annum to the date when the next installment shall become due, but such payment shall not bar the levy of a supplemental assessment as hereinabove provided upon such property in a proper case. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 12.24; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 143; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 59) 
Sec. 2-168. - Legality of special assessments may be contested within thirty days. 
    For a period of thirty (30) days after the date of the confirmation of any special assessment, any person aggrieved shall have the right to contest the legality thereof, by suit, action, writ or special proceeding, after which time no suit, action, writ or special proceeding in any manner questioning the legality of the special assessment shall lie for any cause whatever. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 12.25; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 144; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 60) 
Sec. 2-169. - Special fund for special assessments. 
    All moneys received on account of any special assessment shall be held by the director of financial services as a special fund for which payment shall be made only on account of the improvement for which such assessment was made unless bonds shall have been issued to pay the cost of construction of such improvement, in which case all moneys received on account of the special assessment levied for said improvement shall be paid into the sinking fund of the city. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 4.39; Ord. No. 84-12, § 2, 4-23-84) 
Sec. 2-170. - Improvement bonds-Issuance authorized; conditions. 
    On or after the adoption of an ordinance ordering the making of an improvement as provided in section 2-149 the city commission may, by ordinance or resolution, issue bonds of the city in an amount not exceeding the estimated cost of the improvement or any part thereof and for the reimbursement of any fund of the city from which any part of such cost has heretofore been paid, but no bonds shall be issued in excess of the actual cost of the improvement unless such bonds shall have been issued before the actual cost of the improvement can be determined. Such bonds may be issued in separate series for the cost of each improvement or in one (1) series for the cost of two (2) or more improvements. Each series of bonds shall mature in annual installments on such date in each year and in such annual amounts as the city commission may by resolution determine, beginning not more than two (2) years from their date, nor extending beyond the life of the improvement as determined in the ordinance authorizing the making of the improvement. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 12.26; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 145; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 61; Ord. No. 14-07, § 1, 7-14-14) 
Sec. 2-171. - Same-Bonds issued on abutting property not previously pledged. 
    In all cases in which assessments have been heretofore made or improvements authorized hereunder for which assessments the city shall hold liens upon the abutting, adjacent, contiguous or benefited property not pledged to the payment of any bonds or other obligations, bonds of the city may be issued as nearly as practicable in the manner provided in this section, to the amount of such unpaid assessments and the proceeds of such bonds shall be used in repaying any fund of the city from which payment was made for the cost of the improvement for which the assessment was levied. If such lien shall be pledged to the payment of outstanding bonds or other obligations, no bonds shall be issued as herein provided unless at or before the issuance thereof the outstanding bonds or other obligations shall have been paid in full with all interest thereon. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 12.27; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 145; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 61) 
Sec. 2-172. - Same-General requirements. 
    It shall not be necessary to submit to the electors of the municipality the proposition of issuing any bonds provided for in this section, nor shall the bonds authorized to be issued by this section be subject to any limitation of indebtedness prescribed by the Charter of the city or by any general or special law of the state, nor shall the bonds authorized to be issued by this section be affected by any irregularity or defect of any character in the proceeding authorizing the making of the improvement or the levy of the assessment therefor. The bonds authorized by this section shall be issued upon the general credit of the city and the proceeds derived from the collection of the special assessments levied for the improvement for which such bonds were issued shall be assets of the city in which the holders of the bonds shall have no claim superior to the claims of other holders of the city's obligations. 
(1964 Charter Laws § 12.28; Laws of Fla. (1925) ch. 11148, § 145; Laws of Fla. (1929) ch. 14375, § 61) 
DIVISION 5. - BONDS FOR ASSISTANCE OF INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 93-34, adopted Sept. 27, 1993, has been included herein at the direction of the city as Div. 5 of this Art. IV and said provisions designated as §§ 2-173-2-189 at the discretion of the editor. 
Charter reference- Bonds generally, § 11.01 et seq. 

Sec. 2-173. - Authority for this division. 
    This division is adopted pursuant to Article 8, Section 2 of the Florida Constitution, Chapter 11148, Laws of Florida, Special Acts of 1925, as amended and supplemented, Chapter 166, Part II, Florida Statutes, and other applicable provisions of law. 
(Ord. No. 93-34, § 1, 9-27-93) 
Sec. 2-174. - Findings and declaration of necessity. 
    It is declared that for the benefit of the people of the city, the increase of their commerce, welfare, and prosperity and the improvement of their health and living conditions, it is essential that this and future generations of youth be given the fullest opportunity to learn and to develop their intellectual and mental capacities; that it is essential that institutions for higher education within the city be provided with appropriate additional means to assist such youth in achieving the required levels of learning and development of their intellectual and mental capacities and that it is the purpose of this division to provide a measure of assistance and an alternate method to enable institutions of higher education in the city to provide facilities and structures which are sorely needed to accomplish the purposes of this division. The necessity in the public interest of the provisions hereinafter enacted is hereby declared as a matter of legislative determination. 
(Ord. No. 93-34, § 2, 9-27-93) 
Sec. 2-175. - Definitions. 
    The following terms, wherever used or referred to in this division shall have the following respective meanings, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
(1)  City means the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(2)  City commission means the city commission of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(3)  Real property includes all lands, including improvements and fixtures thereon, and any property of any nature appurtenant thereto, or used in connection therewith and every estate, interest and right, legal or equitable, therein, including terms for years and liens by way of judgment, mortgage or otherwise and the indebtedness secured by such liens. 
(4)  Project means a structure suitable for use as a dormitory or other housing facility, dining hall, student union, administration building, academic building, library, laboratory, research facility, classroom, athletic facility, health care facility, and maintenance, storage, or utility facility, and other structures or facilities related thereto, or required thereto, or required or useful for the instruction of students, or the conducting of research, or the operation of an institution for higher education, including parking and other facilities or structures, essential or convenient for the orderly conduct of such institution for higher education and shall also include equipment and machinery and other similar items necessary or convenient for the operation of a particular facility or structure in the manner for which its use is intended but shall not include such items as books, fuel, supplies or other items which are customarily deemed to result in a current operating charge. 
(5)  Cost, as applied to a project or any portion thereof financed under the provisions of this division, embraces all or any part of the cost of construction and acquisition of all lands, structures, real or personal property, rights, rights-of-way, franchises, easements and interests acquired or used for a project, the cost of demolishing or removing any buildings or structures on land so acquired, including the cost of acquiring any lands to which such buildings or structures may be removed, the cost of all machinery and equipment, financing charges, interest prior to, during and for a period of thirty (30) months after completion of such construction, provisions for working capital reserves for principal and interest and for extensions, enlargements, additions and improvements, cost of engineering, financial and legal services, plans, specifications, studies, surveys, estimates of cost and of revenues, administrative expenses, expenses necessary or incident to determining the feasibility or practicability of constructing the project and such other expenses as may be necessary or incident to the construction and acquisition of the project, the financing of such construction and acquisition and the placing of the project in operation. 
(6)  Bonds or revenue bonds mean revenue bonds of the city issued under the provisions of this division, including revenue refunding bonds, notwithstanding that the same may be secured by mortgage or the full faith and credit of a participating institution for higher education or any other lawfully pledged security of a participating institution for higher education. 
(7)  Financing agreement means a lease, lease-purchase agreement, lease with an option to purchase, sale or installment sale agreement, whether title passes in whole or in part at any time prior to, at, or after completion of the project, loan agreement, or other agreement forming the basis for the financing under this division, including any agreements, guarantees, or security instruments forming part of or related to providing assurance of payment of the obligations under such financing agreement. 
(8)  Institution for higher education means any educational institution which by virtue of law or charter is an accredited, nonprofit educational institution empowered to provide a program of education beyond the high school level. 
(9)  Participating institution of higher education means an institution for higher education which, pursuant to the provisions of this division, shall undertake the financing and construction or acquisition of a project or shall undertake the refunding or refinancing of obligations or of a mortgage or of advances as provided in and permitted by this division. 
(Ord. No. 93-34, § 3, 9-27-93) 
Sec. 2-176. - General powers. 
    The city commission shall have all of the powers necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions of this division, including, but without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the powers, with respect to any project or projects: 
(1)  To prescribe rules, regulations, and policies in connection with the performance of its functions and duties under this division; 
(2)  To receive, administer and comply with conditions and requirements respecting any gift, grant or donation of any property or money from any sources, whether federal, state or private; 
(3)  To make and execute financing agreements, contracts, deeds and other instruments necessary or convenient in the exercise of the powers and functions of the local agency under this division, including contracts with persons, firms, corporations, federal and state agencies, and other local agencies, which state agencies and other local agencies are hereby authorized to enter into contracts and otherwise cooperate with any local agency to facilitate the financing, construction, leasing or sale of any project; 
(4)  To acquire by purchase, lease, gift or otherwise, or to obtain options for the acquisition of, any property, real or personal, improved or unimproved, for the construction, operation or maintenance of any project; 
(5)  To sell, lease, exchange, transfer or otherwise dispose of, or to grant options for any such purposes with respect to any real or personal property or interest therein; 
(6)  To pledge or assign any money, rents, charges, fees or other revenues and any proceeds derived from sales of property, insurance, or condemnation awards or otherwise received under financing agreements; 
(7)  To issue revenue bonds of the city for the purpose of providing funds to pay all or any part of the cost of any project, and to issue revenue refunding bonds; 
(8)  To construct, acquire, own, repair, maintain, extend, improve, rehabilitate, renovate, furnish and equip projects and to pay all or any part of the costs thereof from the proceeds of bonds of the city or from any contribution, gift, donation or other funds made available to the city for such purpose; 
(9)  To fix, charge and collect rents, fees and charges for the use of any project; and 
(10)  To employ consulting engineers, architects, attorneys, real estate counselors, appraisers and such other consultants and employees as may be required, in the judgment of the city, and to fix and pay their compensation from funds available to the city thereto. 
(11)  To mortgage any project and the site thereof for the benefit of the holders of revenue bonds issued to finance such projects. 
(12)  To make loans to any participating institution for higher education for the cost of a project in accordance with an agreement between the city and the participating institution for higher education; provided no such loan shall exceed the total cost of the project as determined by the participating institution for higher education and approved by the city. 
(13)  To make loans to a participating institution for higher education to refund outstanding obligations, mortgages or advances issued, made or given by such participating institution for higher education for the cost of a project. 
(14)  To do all things necessary or convenient to carry out the purposes of this division. 
(Ord. No. 93-34, § 4, 9-27-93) 
Sec. 2-177. - Criteria and requirements. 
    In undertaking any project pursuant to this division, the city commission shall be guided by and shall observe the following criteria and requirements; however, the determination of the city commission as to compliance with such criteria and requirements shall be final and conclusive: 
(1)  The project, in the determination of the city commission, is appropriate to the needs and circumstances of, and shall make a significant contribution to the economic growth of, the city; shall serve a public purpose by advancing the economic prosperity, the public health or the general welfare of the city and its people as stated in section 2-174 hereof. 
(2)  No financing agreement for a project shall be entered into with a party that is not financially responsible and fully capable and willing to fulfill its obligations under the financing agreement, including the obligations to make payments in the amounts and at the times required; to operate, repair and maintain at its own expense the project; and to serve the purposes of this division and such other responsibilities as may be imposed under the financing agreement. In determining the financial responsibility of such party, consideration shall be given to the party's ratio of current assets to current liabilities; net worth; earning trends; coverage of all fixed charges, the nature of the industry or activity involved; its inherent stability; any guarantee of the obligations by some other financially responsible corporation, firm or person; and other factors determinative of the capability of the party, financially and otherwise, to fulfill its obligations consistently with the purposes of this division. 
(3)  The city will be able to cope satisfactorily with the impact of such project and will be able to provide, or cause to be provided when needed, the public facilities, including utilities and public services, that will be necessary for the construction, operation, repair and maintenance of the project and on account of any increases in population or other circumstances resulting therefrom. 
(4)  Adequate provision shall be made for the operation, repair and maintenance of the project at the expense of the party to such financing agreement and for the payment of principal of and interest on the bonds. 
(5)  The costs to be paid from the proceeds of the bonds shall be costs of a project within the meaning of this division, except for payments included in the purposes for which revenue refunding bonds may be issued under this division. 
(Ord. No. 93-34, § 5, 9-27-93) 
Sec. 2-178. - Financing agreements. 
(a)  No project financed under the provisions of this division shall be operated by the city or any other governmental agency, except that the city may temporarily operate or cause to be operated all or any part of a project to protect its interest therein pending any leasing or sale of such project in accordance with this division. Any such financing agreement may provide, among other provisions, that: 
(1)  The institution for higher education shall at its own expense operate, repair and maintain the project or projects financed thereunder. 
(2)  The amounts payable by the institution for higher education payable under the financing agreement will in the aggregate be not less than an amount sufficient to pay all of the interest, principal and redemption premiums, if any, on the bonds that will be issued by the city to pay the cost of the project or projects. 
(3)  The institution for higher education shall pay all other costs incurred by the city in connection with the financing, construction and administration of the project or projects, except as may be paid out of the proceeds of bonds or otherwise, including, but without being limited to, insurance costs, the cost of administering the bond resolution authorizing the bonds and any trust agreement securing the bonds, and the fees and expenses of trustees, paying agents, attorneys, consultants and others. 
(4)  The term of the financing agreement will terminate not earlier than the date on which all such bonds and all other obligations incurred by the city in connection with the project or projects are paid in full, including interest, principal and redemption premiums, if any, or on which adequate funds for such payment are deposited in trust. 
(5)  The institution for higher education's obligation to make the payments due under the financing agreement shall not be subject to cancellation, termination or abatement by the institution for higher education until such payment of the bonds or provision for such payment, is made. 
(b)  Such financing agreement may contain such additional provisions as in the determination of the city are necessary or convenient to effectuate the purposes of this division, including provisions for extensions of the term and renewals of the financing agreement and vesting in the institution for higher education an option to purchase the project, if the project is leased to the institution for higher education, pursuant to such terms and conditions consistent with this division as are prescribed in the financing agreement; provided that, except as may otherwise be expressly stated in the financing agreement to provide for any contingencies involving the damaging, destruction or condemnation of the project or any substantial portion thereof, any such option to purchase granted to the institution of higher education may not be exercised unless all bonds issued for such project, including all principal, interest, and redemption premiums, if any, and other obligations incurred by the city in connection with such project have been paid in full or sufficient funds have been deposited in trust for such payment; and provided further that the purchase price of such project shall not be less than an amount sufficient to pay in full all of the bonds, including all principal, interest and redemption premiums, if any, issued for the project then outstanding and all other obligations incurred by the city in connection with such project. 
(Ord. No. 93-34, § 6, 9-27-93) 
Sec. 2-179. - Construction of the project. 
    The institution for higher education shall be responsible for constructing the project as provided in the financing agreement and related documentation. 
(Ord. No. 93-34, § 8, 9-27-93) 
Sec. 2-180. - Credit of city, state or political subdivision not pledged. 
(a)  Bonds issued under the provisions of this division shall not be deemed to constitute a debt, liability or obligation of the city or of the state or of any political subdivision thereof, or a pledge of the faith and credit of the city or of the state or of any political subdivision thereof, but shall be payable solely from the revenues provided therefor. Each bond issued under this division shall contain on the face thereof a statement to the effect that the city shall not be obligated to pay the same nor interest thereon except from the revenues and proceeds pledged therefor, and that neither the faith and credit nor the taxing power of the city or of the state or of any political subdivision thereof is pledged to the payment of the principal of or the interest on such bonds. 
(b)  Expenses incurred by the city in carrying out the provisions of this division may be made payable from funds provided pursuant to this division and no liability or obligation shall be incurred by the city hereunder beyond the extent to which moneys shall have been so provided. Any and all moneys advanced on behalf of any project, which are derived from any tax source of the city, shall be repaid from the bond proceeds or from the institution for higher education to the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-34, § 8, 9-27-93) 
Sec. 2-181. - Revenue bonds. 
(a)  The city is authorized from time to time to issue its negotiable revenue bonds for any purpose authorized by this division. In anticipation of the sale of such revenue bonds the city may issue negotiable bond anticipation notes and may renew the same from time to time, but the maximum maturity of any such note, including renewals thereof, shall not exceed five (5) years from the date of issue of the original note. Such notes shall be paid from any revenues of the city available under financing agreements therefor and not otherwise pledged, or from the proceeds of sale of the revenue bonds of the city in anticipation of which they were issued. The notes shall be issued in the same manner as the revenue bonds. Such notes and the resolution or resolutions authorizing the same may contain any provisions, conditions or limitations which a bond resolution of the city may contain. 
(b)  The revenue bonds and notes of every issue shall be payable solely out of revenues received by the city under the financing agreements, subject only to any agreements with the holders of particular revenue bonds or notes pledging any particular revenues. Notwithstanding that revenue bonds and notes may be payable from a special fund, they shall be and be deemed to be for all purposes negotiable instruments, subject only to the provisions of the revenue bonds and notes for registration. 
(c)  The revenue bonds may be issued as serial bonds or as term bonds; or the city, in its discretion, may issue bonds of both types. The revenue bonds shall be authorized by resolution of the city commission and shall bear such date or dates, mature at such time or times from their date or dates as may be determined or provided for by the city commission, bear interest at such rate or rates, be payable at such time or times, be in such denominations, be in such form, either coupon or registered, carry such registration privileges, be executed in such manner, be payable in lawful money of the United States at such place or places, and be subject to such terms of redemption, as such resolution or resolutions may provide. The revenue bonds or notes may be sold at public or private sale for such price or prices as the city commission shall determine. Pending preparation of the definitive bonds, the city may issue interim receipts or certificates which shall be exchanged for such definitive bonds. 
(d)  Any resolution or resolutions authorizing any revenue bonds or any issue of revenue bonds may contain provisions, which shall be a part of the contract with the holders of the revenue bonds to be authorized, as to: 
(1)  Pledging of all or any part of the revenues of a project or any revenue-producing contract or contracts made by the city with any individual, partnership, corporation or association or other body, public or private, to secure the payment of the revenue bonds or of any particular issue of revenue bonds, subject to such agreements with bondholders which may then exist. 
(2)  The rentals, fees and other charges to be charged, and the amounts to be raised in each year thereby, and the use and disposition of the revenues. 
(3)  The setting aside of reserves or sinking funds, and the regulation and disposition thereof. 
(4)  Limitations on the right of the city or its agent to restrict and regulate the use of the project. 
(5)  Limitations on the purpose to which the proceeds of sale of any issue of revenue bonds then or thereafter to be issued may be applied and pledging such proceeds to secure the payment of the revenue bonds or any issue of the revenue bonds. 
(6)  Limitations on the issuance of additional bonds, the terms upon which additional bonds may be issued and secured and the refunding of outstanding bonds. 
(7)  The procedure, if any, by which the terms of any contract with bondholders may be amended or abrogated, the amount of bonds the holders of which must consent thereto, and the manner in which such consent may be given. 
(8)  Limitations on the amount of moneys derived from the project to be expended for operating, administrative or other expenses of the city. 
(9)  The acts or omissions to act which shall constitute a default in the duties of the city to holders of its obligations and providing the rights and remedies of such holders in the event of a default. 
(10)  The mortgaging of a project and the site thereof for the purpose of securing the bondholders. 
(e)  Neither the members of the city commission nor any person executing the revenue bonds or notes shall be liable personally on the revenue bonds or notes or be subject to any personal liability or accountability by reason of the issuance thereof. 
(f)  The city shall have the power, out of any funds available therefor, to purchase its bonds or notes. The city may hold, pledge, cancel or resell such bonds, subject to and in accordance with agreements with bondholders. 
(Ord. No. 93-34, § 9, 9-27-93) 
Sec. 2-182. - Security of bondholders. 
    Any revenue bonds issued under the provision of this division shall be secured by a trust agreement by and between the city and a corporate trustee or trustees, which may be any trust company or bank having the powers of a trust company within or without the state. Such trust agreement or the resolution providing for the issuance of such revenue bonds may pledge or assign the revenues to be received or proceeds of any contract or contracts pledged and may convey or mortgage the project or any portion thereof. Such trust agreement or resolution providing for the issuance of such revenue bonds may contain such provisions for protecting and enforcing the rights and remedies of the bondholders as may be reasonable and proper and not in violation of law, including particularly such provisions as have hereinabove been specifically authorized to be included in any resolution or resolution of the city authorizing revenue bonds thereof. Any bank or trust company incorporated under the laws of this state which may act as depository of the proceeds of bonds or of revenues or other moneys may furnish such indemnifying bonds or pledge such securities as may be required by the city. Any such trust agreement may set forth the rights and remedies of the bondholders and of the trustee or trustees, and may restrict the individual right of action by bondholders. In addition to the foregoing, any such trust agreement or resolution may contain such other provisions as the city commission may deem reasonable and proper for the security of the bondholders. All expenses incurred in carrying out the provisions of such trust agreement or resolution may be treated as a part of the cost of the operation of a project and shall be paid by the institution for higher education. 
(Ord. No. 93-34, § 9A, 9-27-93) 
Sec. 2-183. - Rates, rents, fees and charges. 
(a)  In the event the city acquires ownership of the project pursuant to the provisions of this division or any financing agreement, the city commission is authorized to fix, revise, charge and collect rates, rents, fees and charges for the use of and for the services furnished or to be furnished by each project and to contract with any person, partnership, association or corporation, or other body, public or private, in respect thereof. Such rates, rents, fees and charges shall be fixed and adjusted in respect of the aggregate of rates, rents, fees and charges from such project so as to provide funds sufficient with other revenues, if any: 
(1)  To pay the cost of maintaining, repairing and operating the project and each and every portion thereof, to the extent that the payment of such cost has not otherwise been adequately provided for. 
(2)  To pay the principal of and the interest on outstanding revenue bonds of the city issued in respect of such project as the same shall become due and payable. 
(3)  To create and maintain reserves required or provided for in any resolution authorizing, or trust agreement securing, such revenue bonds of the city. 
    Such rates, rents, fees and charges shall not be subject to supervision or regulation by any department, commission, board, body, bureau or agency of the state other than the city. 
(b)  A sufficient amount of the revenues derived in respect of a project, except such part of such revenues as may be necessary to pay the cost of maintenance, repair and operation and to provide reserves and for renewals, replacements, extensions, enlargements and improvements as may be provided for in the resolution authorizing the issuance of any revenue bonds of the city or in the trust agreement securing the same shall be set aside at such regular intervals as may be provided in such resolution or trust agreement in a sinking or other similar fund which is hereby pledged to, and charged with, the payment of the principal of and the interest on such revenue bonds as the same shall become due, and the redemption price or the purchase price of bonds retired by call or purchase as therein provided. Such pledge shall be valid and binding from the time when the pledge is made; the rates, rents, fees and charges and other revenues or other moneys so pledged and thereafter received by the city shall immediately be subject to the lien of such pledge without any physical delivery thereof or further act, and the lien of any such pledge shall be valid and binding as against all parties having claims of any kind in tort, contract or otherwise against the city, irrespective of whether such parties have notice thereof. Neither the resolution nor any trust agreement by which a pledge is created need be filed or recorded except in the records of the city. 
(c)  The use and disposition of moneys to the credit of such sinking or other similar fund shall be subject to the provisions of the resolution authorizing the issuance of such bonds or of such trust agreement.
