(b)  Every contractor granted a certificate of competency shall be required to maintain, at all times, said insurance. The building official may also deny issuance of, or may suspend, any outstanding building permit where a contractor fails or refuses to provide proof of workers' compensation insurance, public liability insurance, and property damage insurance coverage. 
(c)  In the event of the cancellation of a policy of any contractor, the registration of such contractor shall automatically be revoked. The registration may be reinstated by the city building official once a certificate of insurance has been furnished. 
Sec. 8-708. - Workers' compensation coverage. 
    Any person, business organization, or qualifying agent engaged in the business of contracting in the City of St. Augustine and certified to engage in contracting on a statewide basis, or registered under this chapter shall, as a condition precedent to the issuance or renewal of a registration, provide to the city evidence of workers' compensation coverage pursuant to F.S. Ch. 440. The failure to maintain workers' compensation coverage shall be grounds to revoke, suspend, or deny the issuance or renewal of a registration of the contractor. 
Secs. 8-709-8-712. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-15, § 7, adopted December 10, 2018, repealed §§ 8-709-8-712, which pertained to unlicensed contractor contracts; contractor's bond; journeyman; journeyman to be present at job site. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Chapter 9 - CABLE TELEVISION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 94-37, adopted Oct. 10, 1994, amended former Ch. 9, relative to cable television, in its entirety to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Ch. 9, Arts. I-III derived from Code 1964, §§ 113/4-1-113/4-32.5 and Ord. No. 87-62, adopted Sept. 28, 1987. 
Cross reference- Franchises, Ch. 14; licenses, taxation and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17. 
State Law reference- Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166; local cable television franchises, F.S. § 166.046; trespass and larceny with relation to cable television fixtures, F.S. § 812.14. 

Sec. 9-1.0. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. 
    The words "shall" and "will" are always mandatory, and not merely directive or indicative. 
    The word "may" is permissive and indicative, and not mandatory. 
    Not all of the following terms are used in this chapter [Ordinance No. 94-37]; some are defined to facilitate administration of the franchise; resolve complaints; coordinate PEG and cable operator relationships; and for other institutional and governmental purposes: 
    9-1.1 A-B Switch: A high-isolation switch used to select between two (2) input signal sources, e.g., an off-air antenna and the cable television subscriber drop. 
    9-1.2 Access cablecasting: Services provided by or through a cable television system on its public, educational, local-government, and/or leased channels. 
    9-1.3 Access channels: Dedicated channels providing for nondiscriminatory use of the cable system by the public, government agencies, and educational and other institutions: 
9-1.3.1 Commercial access channels: Channels allocated for carriage of program material provided by persons who lease channels, (and, if necessary, studio or other facilities and/or equipment) from grantee. Programs may carry commercial advertising and announcements. See Section 612 of the Cable Act, 47 USC § 532. 
9-1.3.2 Educational Access Channels: Channels allocated for use by the local educational authorities and institutions, i.e., public and private schools, industrial training centers, community colleges, colleges, universities, and other institutions of learning. 
9-1.3.3 Government Access Channels: Channels allocated for non-commercial use by grantor.; 
9-1.3.4 Public access channels: Channels allocated for free-expression, non-commercial, and nondiscriminatory use by any member or members of the public, at no charge for channel time or equipment use. 
    9-1.4 Activated channels (as compared to Usable activated channels): Those channels engineered at the headend and in the cable distribution system for the provision of services generally available to residential subscribers of the cable system, regardless of whether such services actually are provided, including any channel designated for public, educational or governmental use. 
    9-1.5 Active device: A device or circuit capable of some dynamic function, such as amplification, oscillation, or signal control. Usually requires a power supply for its operation. 
    9-1.6 Addressable: The capability to receive a signal from the headend or hub site in such a way that only the designated receiving-terminal equipment is affected. By this means it is possible to send signals to subscribers and to effect changes in subscribers' level of services remotely. 
    9-1.7 Aerial cable: Outside cable plant that is located above ground on overhead utility poles or other structures. 
    9-1.8 Affiliated person: Any person, corporation, partnership, or other legal entity under common control by or with grantee. Any general partner, joint-venture partner, or other person holding five (5) percent or more of grantee's stock, or any director or officer of grantee. Affiliate Person shall in no event mean grantor, any limited partner of grantee, or any creditor of grantee solely by virtue of its status as a creditor. 
    9-1.9 Alphanumeric: A format consisting of a combination of letters and numbers, usually used: (a) in reference to keyboards permitting communication in such form and/or (b) in reference to channels or programs transmitting information in such form. 
    9-1.10 Aluminum-sheath cable: Coaxial cable constructed with a solid-copper or copper-clad aluminum center conductor, dielectric insulation, and semi-rigid aluminum outer conductor/enclosure. 
    9-1.11 Ambient temperature: The temperature of the medium surrounding subject apparatus and equipment. 
    9-1.12 Amplifier: A piece of equipment containing active devices, used to increase the operating level or power of an input signal, or to change the impedance of or isolate the input signal from the output signal. Used in a cable system's distribution plant (trunk and feeder) to compensate for the effects of attenuation (signal loss) in transmission components (cable, passives, etc.). Also used in headends and processing centers, usually for single channels. 
    9-1.13 Analog: Pertaining to signals in the form of continuously-varying electrical quantities. 
    9-1.14 Analog channel: A communication channel on which the information transmitted can take any value between the limits defined by the dynamic range of the channel. Voice-grade channels are analog channels, as are broadcast video (TV) channels in the form of NTSC-VSB-AM 
    9-1.15 Ancillary services: Video, audio, data, or other transmission services as well as other information sources permitted under the Cable Act which may be provided by grantee, in addition to cable service. 
    9-1.16 Annexed areas: Any areas added to the territorial limits of grantor after the date of the franchise. 
    9-1.17 Antenna: Any structure or device used to collect or radiate electromagnetic waves. 
    9-1.18 Antenna array: A radiating or receiving system composed of several spaced radiators or receiving elements or Antennas. 
    9-1.19 Application: A proposal to construct and operate a cable system within grantor's territorial limits, transfer a franchise, renew a franchise, or modify a franchise. An application includes the initial proposal plus all subsequent amendments or supplements to the proposal, and relevant correspondence. 
    9-1.20 Area outage or major malfunction: An area outage or major malfunction occurs when a section of plant is "down" or damaged, or fails (collectively called "malfunctions"), and five (5) or more subscribers connected to that section of plant report that they are deprived of full cable service as a result of such malfunction(s). 
    9-1.21 Area served by cable system see also homes passed: The term "area served by a cable system" means an area where all homes are actually passed by the cable system and where subscribers can be connected for a standard connection fee. 
    9-1.22 Armored cable: Coaxial cable that can be direct-buried without protective conduit, or used in hazardous applications. For underwater applications, this cable is constructed with a flooding compound applied to the cable's outer conducting sheath followed by a plastic jacket, armor, and another plastic jacket. 
    9-1.23 Attributable interest: For purposes of determining whether a party has an "attributable interest" as used in this subpart, the definitions contained in the notes to § 76.501 of the FCC Rules shall be used, provided, however that: 
(1)  The single majority shareholder provisions of Note 2 (b) to § 76.501 and the limited partner insulation provisions of Note § 76.501 shall not apply; and 
(2)  The provisions of Note 2 (a) to § 76.501 regarding five (5) percent interests shall include all voting or nonvoting stock or limited partnership equity interests of five (5) percent or more. 
    9-1.24 Audio: Relating to sound or its reproduction; used in the transmission or reception of sound 
    9-1.25 Audio signal: The sound signal, amplified and provided as appropriate to speakers or earphones. 
    9-1.26 Aural carrier (Sound carrier): The sound-carrying portion of a composite modulated RF television signal. 
    9-1.27 Bandwidth specified in Mega Hertz (MHz): 
(1)  Channel: A measure of the information carrying capacity of a communication channel. 
(2)  System: The range of usable frequencies that can be carried by a cable television system. 
    9-1.28 Baseband: The band of frequencies occupied by the signal in a carrier wire or radio transmission system before it modulates the carrier frequency to form the transmitted line or radio signal; the band of frequencies occupied by the modulating signal. 
    9-1.29 Basic service tier; basic cable service (see also "Enhanced Basic Service"): The basic service tier shall, at a minimum, include all signals of domestic television broadcast stations provided to any subscriber (except a signal secondarily transmitted by satellite carrier beyond the local service area of such station, regardless of how such signal is ultimately received by the cable system), any public, educational, and governmental programming required by the franchise to be carried on the basic tier, and any additional video programming signals or service added to the basic tier by the cable operator. The rate for this tier can be regulated by the local franchise authority, in accordance with FCC Rules Part 76, Subpart N. 
    9-1.30 Bidirectional: The ability to transmit signals in both directions (upstream and downstream). 
    9-1.31 Bonding: 
(1)  The permanent joining of metallic parts to form an electrically-conductive path which will ensure electrical continuity and the capacity to conduct safely any current likely to be imposed; 
(2)  The interconnection of the CATV cable support strand with a telephone company support strand and/or the power company ground/neutral wire to eliminate ground-potential differences. 
    9-1.32 Bridging amplifier or bridger: An amplifier tapped into the main trunk of the CATV system, providing isolation from the main trunk, having multiple high-level outputs that provide signals to the feeder cables of the distribution system 
    9-1.33 Broadband (synonymous with "wideband"): Capable of delivering multiple channels and/or services to users or subscribers. Generally refers to CATV systems. 
    9-1.34 Broadcast: Over-the-air transmission by a standard FCC-authorized radio or television station, to a multiplicity of commercial or consumer receivers. 
    9-1.35 BTSC: 
(1)  Broadcast Television Systems Committee; 
(2)  The current de facto multichannel television sound (MTS) standard now used in broadcast and CATV. 
    9-1.36 Buried cable: Outside cable plant located underground, without conduit. 
    9-1.37 Business district: Any area zoned for Business, and/or containing Business establishments, whether or not also containing dwelling units. 
    9-1.38 Cable: 
(1)  One or more electrical or optical conductors found within a protective sheath; 
(2)  Also used synonymously with "Cable Television" 
    9-1.39 1984 Cable Act: The Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984. 
    9-1.40 1992 Cable Act: The Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992. 
    9-1.41 Cable compatible or cable ready: Generally refers to TV sets, VCR's, etc., that are designed to allow direct connection to a CATV system without a converter, and to receive cable channels, in addition to broadcast channels. Does not imply capability to receive secure (encoded or scrambled) channels or signals and may not imply compatibility to tune all TV channels provided by a specific CATV System. 
    9-1.42 Cable distribution system or distribution system: That part of the CATV plant, usually coaxial cable and/or fiber-optic cable with associated amplifiers, drops, and other devices, hardware, and accessories, which is used to provide service from an origination point (Hub or Headend) to subscriber's TV sets. 
    9-1.43 Cable programming service: (See "enhanced basic service"). Cable programming service includes any video programming provided to subscribers over a cable system, regardless of service tier, including installation or rental of equipment used for the receipt of such video programming, other than video programming carried on the "Basic service tier" as defined in Section 9-1.29 hereof and other than pay-per-view and pay-per-channel programming. The rate for this tier is regulated by the FCC, Part 76, Subpart N of the FCC Rules. 
    9-1.44 Cable service: Any service provided by a cable system. 
    9-1.45 Cable system or system or CATV system or cable television system (see also "cable television" below): The complete system in a physical sense: the antennas, cables, amplifiers, towers, microwave links, satellite links, and any other conductors, converters, equipment, or facilities and plant designed and constructed for the purpose of receiving or producing, amplifying, storing, processing and distributing audio, video, digital, analog, control, or other forms of electronic or electric signals to and/or from subscribers as herein provided. 
    9-1.46 Cable television, or CATV: A broadband communications technology or service in which multiple television, audio, digital, control, analog, and other electrical signals are transmitted through a cable distribution system to and/or from single or multiple locations. The term also usually encompasses the associated and evolving programming and information resources that have been and are being developed at the local, regional, and national levels and the public and institutional access services that are being developed and used as well. 
    9-1.47 Carrier: An electromagnetic wave of which some characteristic is varied in order to convey information. A radio-frequency or microwave signal upon which data and/or the sound (audio), picture (video), and/or color information in a TV picture is modulated. 
    9-1.48 Carrier to noise ratio, or CNR: In cable television, the ratio of peak carrier power to root mean square (rms) noise power in a 4-MHz television-channel bandwidth. Usually expressed in decibels (dB). Defined by the FCC in conjunction with any technical standards placed on CATV Systems 
    9-1.49 Cascade: The number of devices (such as amplifiers in a cable television system) operated in series so that the output of one device feeds the input of the next. 
    9-1.50 CATV system: See section 9-1.45. 
    9-1.51 CATV Ordinance: This chapter [Ordinance No. 94-37]. 
    9-1.52 Channel: A signal path of specified bandwidth for conveying information. Usually a band of frequencies in the electromagnetic spectrum which is capable of carrying one standard NTSC audio-video-color television signal; an allocated spectrum bandwidth of 6 MHz, usually as specified by a television channel-assignment system. The portion of the channel spectrum used may change, depending on the information carried, the modulation technique used, and the form of compression used, if any. 
    9-1.53 Channel capacity: In a cable television system, the number of channels that can be carried simultaneously on the system. Generally defined in terms of the number of equivalent 6 MHz (television) channels, but may be defined in terms of the overall bandwidth or the number of active video-channels available. 
    9-1.54 Character generator: An alphanumeric text generator, commonly used to display messages on a television set, from a typewriter-like keyboard. May also have graphics capability. 
    9-1.55 Churn: Upgrading, downgrading, or otherwise changing levels of service, including connecting and disconnecting service. See also "Spin." 
    9-1.56 City: The City of St. Augustine, Florida (See also "Grantor"). 
    9-1.57 City commission: The elected governing body of the city. 
    9-1.58 Class I cable television channel: A path in a CATV system for a retransmitted standard broadcast TV channel, and as defined by the FCC Rules, Part 76. 
    9-1.59 Class II cable television channel: Locally-originated clear signals, and as defined by the FCC Rules, Part 76.: A path in a CATV system for a locally-originated TV signal intended for reception by standard broadcast (and cable-ready) TV sets, without the use of decoders or descramblers. 
    9-1.60 Class III Cable television channel: A path in a CATV system for delivering downstream signals to subscriber terminals for other than broadcast-type receivers, and including for control of decoding or descrambling equipment, and as defined by the FCC Rules, Part 76. 
    9-1.61 Class IV cable television channel: A path for non-broadcast, non-TV signals of any type from any subscriber terminal to any other point in the cable TV system, and as defined by the FCC Rules, Part 76. 
    9-1.62 Color signal: Any signal used at any point in a color television system for wholly or partially controlling the chromaticity values of a color television picture. 
    9-1.63 Competing distributors: The term "competing," as used with respect to competing multichannel video programming distributors, means distributors whose actual or proposed service areas overlap. See also "Overbuild." 
    9-1.64 Composite video signal: The complete video signal for TV. It consists of the picture signal and the blanking and syuchronzing signals, and, for color pictures, color synchronizing and color picture (chroma) information. 
    9-1.65 Control or controlling interest: The ownership or voting control of fifty (50) percent or more of the issued outstanding shares of grantee or any parent of grantee; the ability to elect a majority of the board of directors of grantee or any parent of grantee. 
    9-1.66 Converter (converter box): (For Cable TV reception). An engineering term for an electronic device which changes CATV channels to a channel which can be received by the subscribers' television sets by use of an appropriate channel selector, which permits subscribers to view all TV signals paid for and delivered at designated dial locations. See also "Decoder," often an integral part of the converter. 
    9-1.67 Cross-ownership: The ownership or control of two (2) or more kinds of communications services in the same market, e.g., newspapers and television stations, by a single person. 
    9-1.68 CSR or customer service representative: An individual employed by the cable company to answer the telephone, write service and installation orders, answer customers' questions, and perform other customer-service-related activities. 
    9-1.69 Customer service: Providing telephone, written, and in-home assistance to CATV subscribers. 
    9-1.70 dB: See "Decibel." 
    9-1.71 dBmV or deciBel-milliVolt: A unit of measurement referenced to one milliVolt (mV) across an impedance of 75 ohms, which is the characteristic impedance for metallic-cable CATV systems. 
    9-1.72 DeciBel or dB: A unit that expresses the ratio of two (2) levels of power as a logarithmic function: dB=10 Log 10 P 1 /P 2 . 
    9-1.73 Decoder also called "Descrambler": A device, located on or near the subscriber's premises, which descrambles or decodes signals so that they may be viewed or used by the subscriber. Often combined in the same enclosure with and as part of the "converter." 
    9-1.74 Demographics: Statistical breakdown by categories (e.g., age, sex, education, income, etc.) of any defined group or section of the public. 
    9-1.75 Descrambler; see "Decoder": Included generically in a "Converter" or "Converter Box." 
    9-1.76 Digital signals: Signals and information transmitted in the form of individual timed electronic pulses, which have only two (2) states (i.e., on/off 1/0, yes/no, etc.). 
    9-1.77 Distant signal: The signal of a television broadcast station which is extended or received beyond the Grade-B contour (as defined by the FCC Rules, Part 73) of that station, or otherwise as defined by copyright or other applicable rules. 
    9-1.78 Distribution system: See "Cable Distribution System." 
    9-1.79 Down: Inoperable; not functioning as specified. 
    9-1.80 Down time: The period of time during which the CATV system is not providing full service. 
    9-1.81 Downstream transmissions: Signals transmitted in the direction from the head-end toward subscribers or other location(s). 
    9-1.82 Drop: That portion of the cable distribution system which connects the subscriber's television reception equipment to the multi-tap and feeder cable. Includes any ancillary equipment in the subscriber's premises, e.g., matching transformers, converters, ground blocks, etc. 
    9-1.83 Drop cable: The coaxial cable that connects the feeder portion of the distribution system to the subscriber's premises, usually to the ground block. 
    9-1.84 Drop system: Collectively, all drops and associated hardware and devices. That part of the cable distribution system that is connected between the "tap" or "multi-tap" and the subscribers' terminals. 
    9-1.85 Dwelling unit: Any facility used as a domicile or living quarters. See also "Unit." 
    9-1.86 Educational access channel: See section 9-1.3.2 hereof. 
    9-1.87 Educational program: Any program prepared by, on behalf of, or in cooperation with or for any educational institutions, libraries, museums, PTA's or similar organizations of learning. 
    9-1.88 Egress: Leakage of signals from CATV systems. Called "radiation" by the FCC. 
    9-1.89 Emergency override: An emergency communications system which allows messages or announcements to replace she normal picture and/or sound on a CATV system, at the option of a local authority. 
    9-1.90 Emergency power: (Standby power; backup power) Generator or battery back-up to replace primary power during any electrical power failure or outage. 
    9-1.91 Enabling document: An interim document, perhaps called a "Letter of Intent" which will define the conditions under which grantor will execute a franchise of predetermined content with grantee, following completion of rebuild of grantee's cable television system. This document contains all conditions and requirements related to completion and testing the system in-place prior to execution of the franchise. 
    9-1.92 Enhanced basic service: (See "Cable-Programming Services," section 9-1.43 hereof. 
    9-1.93 Facility: The site, including land and buildings, containing all or part of a system or systems of technical apparatus: for example, a headend facility or microwave facility employed for purposes of electronic communications or data processing. 
    9-1.94 Failure: See "Fault." 
    9-1.95 Fault, failure: A condition that results in a functional unit in the system failing to perform in the required manner. 
    9-1.96 FCC: The Federal Communications Commission. 
    9-1.97 Feeder cables (feeder lines): The cables, connected to the trunk cable, from which cable service is tapped off (by multitaps) and distributed to subscribers, through drops. 
    9-1.98 Feeder system: The subsidiary cable system which is supplied by the trunk cable system; includes feeder cables, distribution or extender or line amplifiers, multitaps, fittings, passives, and accessories and hardware. 
    9-1.99 Fiber optics: The technology of modulating and guiding beams of light through hair-thin glass fibers as communications paths. 
    9-1.100 Flooded cable: Cable that has a waterproof self-sealing compound between the metal sheath and the jacket. 
    9-1.101 Franchise: The formal document which authorizes a specific franchisee (grantee or cable operator) to construct, own, and operate a cable TV system pursuant to the terms and conditions of this chapter [Ordinance 94-37]. 
    9-1.102 Franchise authority: Any entity which may grant or revoke a franchise; "grantor." 
    9-1.103 Franchise extension: Any lengthening of the duration of the franchise or of an earlier extension by grantor. An extension involves no changes to the franchise agreement other than the duration thereof. 
    9-1.104 Franchise fee: The fee paid by the cable operator (franchisee) to the franchise authorities in consideration of the use of public rights-of-way and the costs of regulation of the CATV system; handling public complaints and other public matters; and administration of local access activities and this chapter and the franchise. Such fees are not excludable from gross revenues, and are part of grantee's cost of doing business. Reasonable payments made by grantee to reimburse grantor for or to provide access capital equipment and incidental costs shall not be included as part of the franchise fee payment, but shall be considered to be in addition to such franchise fees. 
    9-1.105 Franchise renewal: A process to replace the franchise agreement, if and as extended. A renewal involves, or may involve additions to, deletions from, or modifications of the existing franchise agreement in any matter agreed to by the parties. 
    9-1.106 Franchisee ("grantee"): The person to whom a franchise is granted pursuant to this chapter; any successor to that person in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
    9-1.107 Ghosts: Multiple images in a television picture, usually caused by signal reflections, or by direct pickup (dpu) of off-air signals by the system, or by the subscribers' equipment, i.e., the same signal, delayed or advanced in time. 
    9-1.108 Government access channels: Channels set aside for free local government use. See section 9-1.3.3 hereof. 
    9-1.109 Government center: Any area containing facilities used for any government nonresidential purposes. 
    9-1.110 Grantee (franchisee): The person to whom or to which a franchise is granted pursuant to this chapter; any successor to that person in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, and the franchise. 
    9-1.111 Grantor (city): (The governing body of the City of St Augustine.) Also, when used in regulatory and reporting contexts, "Grantor" shall mean grantor's executive officers and the city commission. 
    9-1.112 Gross receipts; also gross revenues: The total of any and all payments made to or compensation received by grantee, its affiliates, subsidiaries and parents, directly or indirectly, derived from subscriptions, advertising (corporate or local), shopping services, PCS service, PCN's, and any other legal service uses of the cable system as a consequence of the existence of the cable system and the cable operator in the community; provided that such reported receipts shall not include any add-on state or local sales taxes - but shall include the franchise fee itself. Includes all revenues realized by grantee as a result of the existence or presence of grantee's cable system. 
Where a parent receives compensation for use of multiple systems, this revenue is allocated to individual franchises and/or grantees on the basis of the count of all subscribers who receive basic service and who are not delinquent in payments, compared to the total applicable multiple-system basic-subscriber count. 
    9-1.113 Hardware: (1) Pole line hardware: The components that are used to attach aerial cable plant to poles, e.g., strands, suspension clamps, through-bolts, etc.; (2) Collectively, electronic circuits, components, devices, and associated fittings and attachments in the cable system. 
    9-1.114 HDTV: See "High-Definition Television." 
    9-1.115 Head-end; See also "Principal headend": A control center of a cable television system; the electronic processing center through which all common broadcast, cablecast, access, local origination, tape/film play back, character-generator, satellite, and other signals are electronically translated or modified and combined for distribution throughout the entire cable system. 
    9-1.116 Head room: The differences, usually in dB, between (1) optimum design and operating technical standards, and (2) minimum standards which may be established by grantee, customers, or regulatory agencies. 
    9-1.117 High-definition television (HDTV): A very-high-quality television signal. May have resolution more than twice that of today's standard broadcast NTSC TV broadcast signal. 
    9-1.118 Homes passed See also "Area Served by Cable System": Homes which are near enough to the cable distribution system to be connected by a standard drop, i.e., at no additional line-extension charge. 
    9-1.119 Hub: A local-distribution and insertion facility which is supplied with composite signals directly or indirectly from the head-end; which feeds subscribers through a portion of the cable distribution system; and where locally-originated and other special signals may be inserted and upstream signals received, switched, and/or processed. Signals may be supplied by fiber-optics; metallic trunk cable, microwave, radio, tape, special-origination, etc. 
    9-1.120 Incidental expenses: All expenses incurred by grantor directly related to the complete processing of a grantee's application for a franchise including, but not limited to, expert consultant fees, legal fees, printing and publishing costs, public notice costs, ordinance amendment costs, referenda and other election costs. Such expenses are not excludable from gross revenues and are part of grantee's cost of doing business. 
    9-1.121 Industrial area: Any area zoned for Industrial use, and/or containing industrial facilities such as research, manufacturing, retail, engineering, and other related operations. May also contain dwelling units. 
    9-1.122 Ingress: Leakage of signals into a cable television system. 
    9-1.123 Installation charge: A one-time charge for connection of a new cable television subscriber or for addition of a cable tier. 
    9-1.124 Institutional loop: A cable subsystem of dedicated bi-directional channels which carries television, audio, video, analog, control and digital signals between and among government, educational, public, and/or business institutions and other locations as designated. The institutional loop may be a cable, physically separate and distinct from the subscriber cable system, or it may consist of combinations of upstream and downstream channels on the subscriber cable system, usually capable of real-time interactive service. May include provisions for scrambling and de-scrambling signals for limited and controlled reception. 
    9-1.125 Institutional system; See also "Institutional Loop": The network of cables and/or frequencies that connects schools, government agencies, and/or other public organizations to the cable system headend and for interconnection between such institutions. Usually separate from the "Subscriber-Cable System." 
    9-1.126 Interactive: An application where an electronic or RF entry may or will call for a response. 
    9-1.127 Interactive cable system: A cable system with two-way capability installed and with terminals that can communicate with each other in either direction, i.e., upstream and downstream, simultaneously through the cable system. 
    9-1.128 Interconnect: The connection between two (2) or more cable systems, usually bidirectional. 
    9-1.129 Local commercial television station: A local commercial television station is any full power television broadcast station, other than a qualified educational television station licensed and operating on a channel regularly assigned to its community by the commission that, with respect to a particular cable system, is within the same television market as the cable system, except that the term "local commercial television station" does not include: 
(1)  Low power television stations, television translator stations, and passive repeaters which operate pursuant to Part 74 of the FCC rules. 
(2)  A television broadcast station that would be considered a distant signal under the cable compulsory copyright license, if such station does not agree to indemnify the cable operator for any increased copyright liability resulting from carriage on the cable system; or 
(3)  A television broadcast station that does not deliver to the principal headend of a cable system either a signal level of ;minus;45 dBmV for UHF signals or ;minus;49 dBmV for VHF signals at the input terminals of the signal processing equipment, i.e., the input to the first active component of the signal processing equipment relevant to the signal at issue, if such station does not agree to be responsible for the costs of delivering to the cable system a signal of good quality or a baseband video signal. 
    9-1.130 May: is always discretionary. 
    9-1.131 Mile (of Cable Plant): A horizontal distance of one mile (five thousand two hundred eighty (5280) feet), as measured on the surface of the earth, along a line parallel to and at the shortest distance from the cable, within the right-of-way or easement. 
    9-1.132 Multichannel video programming distributor: The term "multichannel video programming distributor" means an entity engaged in the business of making available for purchase, by subscribers or customers, multiple channels of video programming. Such entities include, but are not limited to, a cable operator, a multichannel multipoint distribution (MMDS or wireless cable) service, a direct broadcast satellite service, a television receive only satellite program distributor, and a satellite master antenna television (SMATV) or private-cable system operator, as well as the buying groups or agents of all such entities. 
    9-1.133 Multiple system operator (MSO): A person that operates more than one cable TV system. 
    9-1.134 Multitap: A passive device which splits or taps off sufficient signal to feed one or more cable drops to one or more individual subscribers; a part of the feeder system. 
    9-1.135 Normal business hours: Those hours during which most similar businesses in the community are open to serve customers. In all cases, "normal business hours" for the CATV system also must include some evening hours at least one night per week and/or some weekend hours. 
    9-1.136 Normal Operating Conditions: The term "normal operating conditions" means those service conditions which are within the control of the operator. Those conditions which are not within the control of the cable operator include, but are not limited to, natural disasters, civil disturbances, power outages, telephone network outages, and severe or unusual weather conditions (force majeure). Those conditions which are ordinarily within the control of the cable operator include, but are not limited to, special promotions, pay-per-view events, rate increases, regular peak or seasonal demand periods, and ongoing maintenance or upgrade of the cable system. 
    9-1.137 Off-the-air; also broadcast: Standard broadcast signals provided directly by use of a transmitting antenna system and a multiplicity of receiving antennas. 
    9-1.138 Optical fiber: A hair-thin, flexible thread of glass (silica) used for conducting lightwaves and capable of carrying information bandwidths in the thousands of TV channels. 
    9-1.139 Origination cablecasting: Locally-originated programming carried on the cable system. Can be originated by the cable operator; by local institutions; by those using leased channels; by the public; or by other entities or persons. 
    9-1.140 Outage; malfunction: An equipment or facility failure that results in the loss of satisfactory service on one or more channels. A malfunction or outage is major if it affects five (5) or more subscribers in the same area. 
    9-1.141 Outlet: A CATV connection terminal or wallplate in the building structure which is used for the purpose of connecting a television receiver or other subscriber terminal to the CATV system. 
    9-1.142 Overbuild: To construct and operate a second, competing CATV system to serve an area already served by another CATV system. 
    9-1.143 Parent (when used in reference to grantee): Any person or group of persons holding direct or indirect ownership or control of a majority of the issued and outstanding shares or interests of grantee, in the aggregate; any person holding such ownership or control of grantee or a parent of grantee. 
    9-1.144 Passive device: A device which does not require a power supply to perform its function. Generally refers to a splitter, directional coupler, power-insertion unit, or similar item-as used to divide (multiply outlets) and, or reduce levels of CATV signals. 
    9-1.145 PCS, PCN: Personal communications system, personal communications network. See section 9-1.148 hereof. 
    9-1.146 Penetration (saturation): The percentage of homes where CATV is available that subscribe to CATV (the ratio of subscribers to homes passed in an area). 
    9-1.147 Person: Any individual, proprietorship, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, organization, or other business entity. 
    9-1.148 Personal communications system (PCS); personal communications network (PCN): Provision of telephone, video, data, and other services to individuals through use of cable, microcellular, fiber, and other technologies. 
    9-1.149 Picture signal: That portion of the composite video signal which lies above the blanking level and contains picture brightness (gray scale) information. 
    9-1.150 Plant: Grantee's furniture, office equipment, buildings, tower(s), amplifiers, antennas, processors, lines, cables, wires, tools, test equipment, vehicles, and all other physical equipment and accessories utilized in the operation of the system. 
    9-1.151 Pole attachment right: The right to attach hardware and equipment to poles owned by utility companies or others. 
    9-1.152 Premium service: Optional additional programming provided to subscribers at an additional monthly charge for each channel carrying such programming. 
    9-1.153 Principal headend: 
(1)  The headend, in the case of a cable system with a single headend or, 
(2)  In the case of a cable system with more than one headend, the principal headend designated by the cable operator, except that such designation shall not undermine or evade the requirements of the FCC and this chapter. Usually supplies signals to all hubs, in the system. 
    9-1.154 Proof test: (1) Action undertaken to prove or demonstrate that a system fulfills agreed upon criteria-for example, that the processing of specified input yields specified output; (2) A test to demonstrate that the system meets minimum technical standards. 
    9-1.155 Public access channel: See section 9-1.3.4 hereof. 
    9-1.156 Public notice: An announcement to the community of some planned action by the franchise authority (grantor) or its designate in respect to cable service or the cable television franchise. May be accomplished by bulletin, newspaper, radio or TV broadcast, and/or other means, including announcements on the CATV local origination channel, to insure that all community members can be made aware of the event. 
    9-1.157 Rebuild: To replace a CATV system in its entirety with another system that may provide for a higher level of performance, and usually will provide more channels. 
    9-1.158 Request for proposal (RFP): A formal document issued by a franchising authority and inviting proposals (applications) from prospective operators to submit applications for a franchise. Provides guidelines and requirements that must be met by prospective franchisees. 
    9-1.159 Satellite broadcast programming: Standard broadcast video programming when such programming is retransmitted by satellite and the entity retransmitting such programming is not the broadcaster. 
    9-1.160 Satellite broadcast programming vendor: A fixed-service satellite carrier that provides service pursuant to section 119, Title 17, United States Code, with respect to Satellite Broadcast Programming. 
    9-1.161 Satellite cable programming: Video programming which is transmitted via satellite and which is primarily intended for direct reception by cable operators for their retransmission to cable subscribers. Such term does not include satellite broadcast programming. 
    9-1.162 Satellite cable programming vendor: A person engaged in the production, creation, or wholesale distribution for sale of satellite cable programming, but does not include a satellite broadcast programming vendor. 
    9-1.163 Scramble; encode (scrambler or encoder) : To interfere deliberately with or transpose or invert or otherwise make a signal unintelligible except to authorized terminals. 
    9-1.164 Service area: See "Area Served by Cable System." 
    9-1.165 Service call ratio: The number of problems which require a truck trip to a customer's home, per one hundred (100) subscribers per month; number of "truck rolls" per one hundred (100) subscribers per month. 
    9-1.166 Service interruption: The loss of any signal at one or more subscriber/user locations. 
    9-1.167 Shall: is always mandatory. 
    9-1.168 Signal-to-noise ratio (SNR): The ratio, expressed in decibels, of the peak voltage of the signal of interest to the rms (Root-Mean-Square) voltage of the noise in that frequency band, or as further defined by the FCC. 
    9-1.169 Sound Carrier: See "Aural Carrier." 
    9-1.170 Spin: A term often used to describe and measure subscriber changes (adding or removing) between tiers and/or premium channels, and not including disconnects and/or reconnects. See also "Churn." 
    9-1.171 Standard radio station: A radio (AM or FM) station licensed by the FCC. 
    9-1.172 Standard Television Station: See "Television Station." 
    9-1.173 State of the art: That level of technical performance or capacity or service of plant, for which there is a reasonable market demand and which has been demonstrated by existing cable television system operators and reputable equipment suppliers to be workable in the field at a reasonable level of cost. That level of technical performance or capacity which has been installed and is proven at the time in at least ten (10) other cable systems of comparable or smaller size for a period of at least one (1) year. 
    9-1.174 St. Johns County: The County of St. Johns, Florida. 
    9-1.175 Street: The surface of and the space above and below any public street, road, highway, freeway, lane, path, public way, or place, alley, court, boulevard, parkway, drive or other easement now or hereafter held by grantor for the purpose of public travel, communications, alarm, street lighting, power distribution, or other public use and shall include such other easements or rights-of-way as shall be now held or hereafter held by grantor. 
    9-1.176 Studio: A specially-designed room with associated lighting, switching, control and monitoring facilities, used for the origination of TV programming. Must be capable of producing standard EIA/NTSC signals. 
    9-1.177 Subscriber: Any person legally receiving any of the cable services of grantee. 
    9-1.178 Subscriber cable system: The portion of the cable/fiber distribution system which serves the CATV subscribers. 
    9-1.179 Subscriber drop: See "Drop." 
    9-1.180 Subscriber terminal: The point of CATV signal input to the subscriber-owned equipment (converter, VCR, TV set, radio, etc.). 
    9-1.181 System operator (operator): The person operating the cable television system. 
    9-1.182 Technical standards: System performance requirements established by local, state, and/or federal governments and/or applicable to grantee pursuant to the terms of this chapter and the franchise. See FCC Rules Part 76 Subpart K. 
    9-1.183 Telephone waiting time: The time required for grantee to attend to a call from a waiting subscriber or prospective subscriber. Includes time used for listening to directions, recorded messages or instructions, and any other machine time or waiting time (e.g. for telephone ringing or "hold") by the subscriber. 
    9-1.184 Television channel: (1) The range or band of the radio frequency spectrum assigned by the FCC to a standard VHF or UHF television station; 6 MHz in the U.S. and Canada. (2) The channel number assigned by the FCC and/or the cable operator. 
    9-1.185 Television station; television broadcast station: Any television broadcast station operating on a channel regularly assigned to its community by § 73.606 of the FCC rules, and any television broadcast station licensed by a foreign government: Provided however, that a television broadcast station licensed by a foreign government shall not be entitled to assert a claim to carriage, program exclusivity, or retransmission consent authorization pursuant to Subpart D or F of Part 76 of the FCC rules, but may otherwise be carried on any service tier if such is consistent with the rules. 
    9-1.186 Territorial limits: Grantor's geographical limits, as of the date of execution of the franchise. 
    9-1.187 Tier (tiered service): Any group of channels or programs, priced separately as an initial or additional offering by a CATV system. A single channel (e.g., HBO) can be a tier, as is Basic Service, and as is so-called "a la carte" Basic Service. 
    9-1.188 Total households: The sum of all dwelling units in the territorial limits. 
    9-1.189 Transfer: The disposal, directly or indirectly, voluntarily or involuntarily, by any method, including gift, assignment, sale, merger, consolidation, acquisition, bankruptcy, receivership, or otherwise, of the ownership or control of grantee, the physical-system plant, or the franchise, in whole or in part. 
    9-1.190 Trunk or trunkline: The primary cable subsystem leading from the headend of the cable TV system to the various points where feeders or feeder lines are tapped off to distribute signals to drops. Can be (a) metallic or (b) glass fiber. 
    9-1.191 Two-way activation: The condition existing when the amplifiers and other technical components of the system have the requisite equipment in place to pass video, audio, voice, analog, and/or data signals upstream and downstream simultaneously. 
    9-1.192 Two-way capability: The condition existing when the amplifiers and other technical components of the cable system have been designed and installed to be easily upgraded to activate two-way transmission of information over the cable system, i.e., if all that is required for two-way activation is the insertion and alignment of additional standard plug-in modules into the amplifiers. 
    9-1.193 Upgrade: (1) The addition, by a subscriber, of a premium program or other service or product to the existing level of CATV service provided to that subscriber; (2) A major improvement to the cable system that usually includes a major increase in number of channels available and/or a major improvement in performance. This usually includes replacing some or all active components (e.g., modules), passive components, some cable, etc. An upgrade utilizes major parts of the original system; a rebuild does not. 
    9-1.194 Unit: A building or facility occupied by one or more persons as a dwelling or such business, professional, or institutional entities as shall subscribe to cable television. 
    9-1.195 Upstream: In the direction from any designed point in the system toward the hub or head-end. 
    9-1.196 Upstream transmissions: Signals traveling in the direction from origination points in the cable system toward a head-end or hub, i.e., in the opposite direction from subscriber channels. 
    9-1.197 Usable activated channels, See also "Activated Channels": (1) Those activated channels of a cable system, except those channels whose use for the distribution of broadcast signals would conflict with technical and safety regulations (See Part 76 Subpart K of the FCC rules). (2) Channels which are available for immediate use without system modification. 
    9-1.198 Vertical wiring: Multiple-outlet internal wiring in a multiple-dwelling or multiple-use building. May include amplifiers. Does not normally include internal wiring on a subscriber's premises (these are drops). Vertical wiring is considered to be part of the cable television plant, as compared to subscriber drop plant. 
    9-1.199 Video: Visual electronic information; a picture signal. 
    9-1.200 Video signal: The base-band monochrome video or picture signal, amplified as appropriate and provided to a monitor, for combination with the "Synchronization Signal" and, as applicable, the "chroma signal". 
    9-1.201 Will: Is always mandatory; a commitment. 
    9-1.202 Other definitions: Any term defined in FCC and/or other applicable government rules and regulations as of the effective date of the franchise, but not included in the foregoing list, shall be incorporated herein by reference as if set forth in full, and shall be defined as it appears in such rules and/or regulations. If not so defined, or not defined herein, words and terms shall be given their ordinary and usual meanings as defined in standard reference works. 
    9-1.203 Precedence: In the event of conflict between any of the definitions herein and any definitions contained in any applicable state-government, FCC, or federal-government statutes, such state, FCC and federal-government definitions shall take first precedence. The definitions herein shall take next precedence. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 9-2.0. - Grant of authority. 
    9-2.1 Unlawful to operate without a franchise. It shall be unlawful to commence or engage in the construction, operation or maintenance of a cable television system or to provide cable-television service within any of the incorporated areas of St. Augustine, Florida, without a franchise from the city. 
    9-2.2 Franchise (the "franchise"). The franchise granted by grantor and accepted by grantee pursuant to this chapter shall be non-exclusive and shall provide to grantee the right, privilege and authority to construct, operate and maintain a cable TV system in the territorial limits for the term specified in the franchise. A similar grant or grants may be made to competing providers, under proportionately comparable conditions, and in accordance with state and federal law. The franchising procedure shall comply with federal and state law. Federal law shall take precedence in the event of conflict. 
    9-2.3 Grantee authority. Grantee shall have the authority to promulgate such rules, regulations, terms and conditions governing the conduct of its business as shall be reasonably necessary to enable grantee to exercise its rights and to perform its obligations under this article and to assure uninterrupted service to each and all of its customers, however such rules, regulations, terms and conditions shall not be in conflict with the provisions of this chapter and shall be filed with grantor. 
    9-2.4 Franchise application. Any applicant under this chapter shall file ten (10) copies of the application for a new cable television franchise or for the transfer of an existing cable television franchise with grantor's city manager. The application(s) shall be reviewed by grantor and the applicants afforded proper time during a public proceeding before the city commission to explain their application. Grantor may utilize outside professionals who are knowledgeable in the field of cable television for analysis of the applicant's proposals. Additionally, grantor may utilize other expertise within the city government for purposes of making recommendations. The commission may, by resolution, authorize implementation of the CATV Ordinance or resolution adoption procedure for the cable television franchise if the applicant satisfies the criteria herein established and grantor tentatively determines that the grant of application may serve the public convenience, safety and general welfare; such tentative determination to be conclusively evidenced by the scheduling of a public hearing to consider passage of a proposed cable-television franchise, ordinance, and/or resolution(s) concerning the application. 
    9-2.5 Presentations By existing franchisees. Grantor shall, at or before the public hearing on the proposed franchise, ordinance, or resolution, allow all existing grantees an opportunity to submit objections or requests for clarification on an application which affects such existing grantees and shall allow them to be heard and to make public presentations pertaining to such application. 
    9-2.6 Filing fees. 
9-2.6.1 Payment. To compensate grantor for processing and related expenses, each application for a new or geographically-expanded cable television franchise, an extension of an existing franchise, a transfer, or a modification, shall be accompanied by a non-refundable filing fee as follows: 
(a)  For a new franchise $10,000. 
(b)  For a renewal of a franchise $5,000. 
(c)  For a transfer (See section 9-2.7 below). 
(d)  For a modification pursuant to 47 USC § 545, five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) except for rate changes. 
9-2.6.2 Costs to be paid by applicant. In the event such non-refundable filing fee is not sufficient to pay all related costs, the applicant shall pay the balance of such costs to grantor within thirty (30) days of the mailing of an invoice for such balance by grantor to the applicant at its address as listed in its application. Failure to make such payment shall be cause for refusal or revocation of the franchise. 
    9-2.7 Transfer fee. In order that grantor may share in the value that the franchise adds to grantee's operations and in further consideration of grantor's administrative expenses incurred, any sale, transfer, assignment, or lease by grantee of rights under the franchise requiring consent of grantor shall require the payment to grantor of a transfer fee. The transfer fee shall be in amount equal to one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for each remaining year of the franchise term, but not less than four thousand five hundred dollars ($4,500.00). Such transfer fee shall be paid within thirty (30) days after the effective date of sale, transfer, assignment, or lease. Such transfer fee shall not be recovered from the subscribers through rates or by itemized surcharge, or excluded from gross income. 
    9-2.8 Street and right-of-way use not exclusive. For the purpose of constructing, operating and maintaining a system in the territorial limits, grantee, except as specifically required now or in the fixture by grantor, may erect, install, construct, repair, replace, relocate, reconstruct, remove and retain in, on, over, under, upon, across and along the streets within the territorial limits such lines, cables, conductors, ducts, conduits, false manholes, amplifiers, appliances, pedestals, attachments and other property and equipment as are necessary and appurtenant to the operation of the cable system, provided that all applicable permits are applied for and granted, all fees paid, and all codes and ordinances are complied with. The authority to use and occupy the streets and rights-of-way for the purpose set forth herein is not exclusive; grantor reserves the right to grant one or more additional franchises or other authorizations for similar use to any other person(s) at any time. 
    9-2.9 Ownership of cable system, acquisition. 
9-2.9.1 Grantee to own. Grantee shall, at all times during the term of the franchise, be the sole owner of, and have full possessory rights to, all facilities and property, real and personal, of the cable system, whether by ownership, lease, license, or otherwise. Grantee may discard or replace any property, real or personal, so long as grantee continues to satisfy its obligations hereunder. 
9-2.9.2 Sale or transfer of franchise, or change of control of grantee. The franchise or the system hereunder neither shall be transferred nor shall title thereto, either legal or equitable, or any right, interest or property therein, pass to or vest in any entity without full compliance with the procedures set forth in this section. The provisions of this section shall apply to the transfer of all or a majority of grantee's assets, merger (excluding its parent and any affiliated corporation), consolidation, or sale or transfer of stock of grantee or of its parent so as to effect change in control of the system. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent grantee from pledging physical assets of the system to a bona fide lending institution as security and collateral. The franchise itself may not be used for such security or collateral. 
9-2.9.2.1 The parties to the transfer shall make a written request to grantor for its approval of a transfer. Both one-hundred-twenty (120) days' prior notice to grantor, and prior written approval by grantor shall be required for any transfer which changes effective control of grantee or a parent. 
9-2.9.2.2 Grantor shall reply to the parties in writing within one hundred twenty (120) days of the request and shall indicate whether the requested transfer is approved. 
9-2.9.2.3 Grantee shall, within sixty (60) days of transfer, file with grantor a copy of the deed, agreement, lien, lease or other written instrument evidencing such transfer, certified and sworn to as correct by grantee, or its successor. 
9-2.9.2.4 In reviewing a request for transfer, pursuant to section 9-2.9.2.1 above, grantor may inquire into the technical, legal and financial qualifications of the prospective controlling party, and grantee shall assist grantor in so inquiring. Grantor may condition said transfer upon such terms and conditions as it deems reasonably appropriate. Grantor shall not unreasonably withhold its approval. In no event shall a transfer of ownership or control be approved without the new owner becoming a party to the franchise. A new owner (grantee) shall execute a franchise amendment to perfect such ownership as required by grantor. 
9-2.9.2.5 Grantor shall not sell any interest to, or acquire any interest from, any competing video service provider or other cable TV system operating in the territorial limits, during the term of the franchise issued pursuant to this chapter or any extension thereof. 
9-2.9.2.6 Upon approval of the transfer regulated under this section, grantee shall pay to grantor the transfer fee as provided in sections 9-12.6 and 9-12.7 within ten (10) days after the transfer is consummated. 
9-2.9.3 Effect of unauthorized action. Any transfer described in section 9-2.9.2 above that is made without prior consent of grantor shall be null and void and shall be deemed a substantial breach of the franchise. Such action shall be subject to a forfeiture of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day until approved or if not approved, until prior ownership and control is restored. If grantor legally denies consent to any action after it has been taken, grantor may revoke the franchise without further process unless the action is reversed within ninety (90) days by grantee. 
9-2.9.4 Foreclosure. Upon notice of the foreclosure or other judicial sale of the system, grantee shall notify grantor of such notification within ten (10) days. An actual foreclosure or judicial sale shall be treated as a change in control of grantee, and the provisions of this chapter governing the consent to a transfer or change in ownership shall apply without regard to how such transfer or change in ownership occurred. 
9-2.9.5 Receivership or bankruptcy. In the event of the appointment of a receiver or trustee for grantee, whether in receivership, reorganization, bankruptcy, or other such action or proceeding, grantee shall notify grantor within ten (10) days. This shall be treated as a notification that a change in control of grantee has taken place. The term "bankruptcy" as used herein shall include any assignment for the benefit of creditors and/or petition for reorganization under the federal bankruptcy or state insolvency laws, or other similar procedure. 
9-2.9.6 Grantor to assume control. In the event of receivership or bankruptcy as in section 9-2.9.5 above, grantor shall have the right to assume temporary control and management of the cable system by satisfying the creditors and the courts, in order to assure continued acceptable quality of service to subscribers. 
9-2.9.7 Anti-competitive action. Grantor may disapprove any sale, transfer, or change of control that would reduce or tend to reduce competition in the area, such as but not limited to sale of one competitive system or video provider to the other. 
    9-2.10 Police power. Grantee acknowledges that its rights hereunder are subject to grantor's police powers to amend, adopt, and enforce ordinances pertaining to the public health, safety, and morals. Grantor acknowledges that grantee has contractual rights under the franchise agreement and the parties acknowledge that contractual rights and obligations may be modified only by mutual consent. 
    Both parties acknowledge that some rights or interests of grantee may be altered without compensation to grantee by the exercise of police power laws or regulations when necessary in the interests of the public health, safety, welfare and morals, while other rights or interests may be taken only with compensation pursuant to eminent domain provisions under the Constitutions of the United States and the State of Florida. Nothing in this chapter or the franchise agreement issued pursuant hereto shall be construed as a waiver of any such rights by either party. 
    9-2.11 Public works. The rights and privileges granted hereby shall not be in preference or hindrance to the rights of grantor and other lawful government authorities having jurisdiction, to perform or carry out any public works or public improvements. Should the cable system interfere with the construction, maintenance or repair of such public works or improvements, grantee, at its own expense, shall protect and/or relocate the cable system or the applicable part thereof, as directed by grantor or other government authorities having jurisdiction. 
    9-2.12 Extension policy. Subject to the provisions of the franchise granted pursuant to this chapter, grantee shall offer full cable service to all occupants of any areas annexed to the territorial limits with a density of twenty (20) units or more per mile served by aerial plant. Grantee shall offer cable service to all occupants of any area within the annexed territorial limits with a density of twenty-five (25) units (households and establishments) or more per mile served by underground plant. 
    The rights and privileges awarded pursuant to the franchise and this chapter shall relate to and cover the entire territorial limits and any areas annexed thereto (the "annexed areas") during the term of the franchise and extensions, if any. 
    In the event that any annexed areas are built-up areas (areas having a density of twenty (20) or more units per aerial mile or twenty-five (25) or more Units per underground mile), grantee shall provide cable service to such built-up areas within nine (9) months after notification by grantor to do so, provided that if the annexed area is served by another cable operator, grantee shall not be required to provide cable services to that area. 
    Computations of density shall take into account any connecting lines required to serve such areas, if not contiguous to the existing cable distribution plant, as well as any units passed by such connecting lines. 
    9-2.13 Extended service areas. Grantee may utilize any available technologies within the state-of-the-art for the purpose of serving subscribers. Grantee may but shall not be required to provide cable service in annexed areas which do not have a density of twenty (20) units or more per mile aerial or twenty-five (25) units or more per mile underground. The provision of limited cable services in such areas is to be encouraged. 
    9-2.14 Provision of service in territorial limits. Beginning with the effective date of the franchise, subject to the terms hereof and continuing for the term of the franchise and any extension thereto, grantee shall make available upon request of the owner, tenant or lessee of any improved property ("unit") in the territorial limits the full range of cable services available to other subscribers or users of like class, at the same standard charges and rates, and under the terms of this chapter-except for such area as may be described in Exhibit A of the franchise granted pursuant hereto, which shall be treated as an annexed area. 
    9-2.15 Extension of franchise term by grantor. 
9-2.15.1 Revocation; extension. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, grantor may nevertheless extend the term of the franchise beyond the termination or expiration date for such period of time as grantor may specify, not to exceed two (2) years, by giving grantee such notice as is reasonable in the circumstances. In the event of such extension, grantee shall continue to operate the cable system in accordance with all of the provisions of this chapter and the franchise. During any extension of the term, grantor may terminate the franchise as to any area or areas within the franchise territorial limits, effective not less than thirty (30) days from the date of such notice. 
9-2.15.2 Renewal. Upon the expiration of the term for which the franchise is granted, grantor may renew the franchise for an additional term, in accordance with federal law, the Florida Statutes, and the requirements of this chapter. 
    9-2.16 Business office; telephone. 
9-2.16.1 Telephone number. Grantee shall provide a toll-free number for service calls, accessible at no charge from any subscriber location twenty-four (24) hours per day. 
9-2.16.2 Office location(s). Grantee shall provide for an office, located within the territorial limits (City of St. Augustine) and open during normal business hours, where grantee-owned equipment may be dropped off by subscribers or others, and for business transactions. 
    9-2.17 Written notice. All notices, reports, or demands required to be given to grantor and to grantee shall be in writing and shall be deemed to have been given when delivered personally (hand delivered) to the persons designated in the franchise granted pursuant to this chapter, or when seventy-two (72) hours have elapsed after being deposited in the United States mail in a sealed envelope, with registered or certified mail postage prepaid thereon, or on the next business day if sent by express mail or overnight air courier addressed to the party to which notice is being given, as listed in the franchise pursuant to this chapter. Addresses may be changed by either party upon written notice to the other party; certified mail, or hand delivery, return receipt requested. 
    9-2.18 Certification. Grantee, by accepting the franchise, certifies that it has investigated its supply sources; is familiar with the community; has examined the cable system and operations; has reviewed its own financial condition; and has the capacity and resources to carry out its obligations to the community. 
    9-2.19 Consent by grantor. Whenever, under the terms of the franchise or of this chapter, grantor's consent or approval is required, it shall not be unreasonably withheld. This provision, however, shall not necessarily impose upon grantor a "for cause" standard of discretion. 
    9-2.20 Imposition of requirements on grantee; not unreasonable. To the extent that the franchise or this chapter gives grantor or its agents authority: (a) to require tests and/or witnessing of the system, (b) to inspect or audit grantee's books and records relating to the system; (c) to impose on or collect from grantee any fee, penalty or other sum; (d) to require grantee to take or cease any action; or (e) any other right or authority, such authority shall be coordinated by the governing bodies and shall not be used unreasonably or to harass grantee. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-3.0. - Service provisions. 
    9-3.1 Performance. The cable system shall be engineered, installed, equipped, maintained and operated such as to meet FCC Rules Part 76, Subpart K and Technical Standards in Part 8.0, and shall comply with all applicable federal, state, and local codes, rules, regulations and technical standards. 
    9-3.2 Itemized bills. Grantor shall provide all subscribers with itemized monthly bills, listing each tier or level of service and its price, each add-on or markup, and any add-on taxes (such as sales tax), together with the total. Franchise fees may be listed separately and shall be included in gross receipts. 
    9-3.3 Change in channel array. Grantee shall provide thirty (30) days' written advance notice to grantor and subscribers of any changes of channels provided or of tiering. Unless the schedule of such changes is beyond the control of grantee. In such case, grantee shall provide notification and explanation immediately by cable channel and within ten (10) days in writing to grantor and thirty (30) days to subscribers. 
    9-3.4 Rate changes. 
9-3.4.1 Notice. Grantee shall give grantor and all subscribers at least thirty (30) days' notice of any change in subscriber rates. If grantor is certified by the FCC to regulate basic rates, grantor may toll (require additional time from the operator) as provided by FCC Rules, Part 76 Subpart N. 
9-3.4.2 Right to regulate. Grantor reserves the right to regulate rates and services as permitted by state and federal law and FCC regulations. Such rate regulation and administration of rate changes shall follow guidelines established by the Federal Communications Commission and the franchise issued pursuant hereto. 
    9-3.5 Reconnection charge. In the event that cable TV bills are not paid within thirty (30) days, grantee shall have the right to discontinue cable TV service to the customer following thirty (30) days' notice. Such service shall not be restored until after all past-due bills have been paid and reimbursed to grantee, including extra expenses (such as special trips, inspections, disconnecting and reconnecting service, additional clerical expenses, etc.) incurred by grantee on account of any delinquent bills or on account of such subscriber's violation of the contract for cable-TV services. 
    9-3.6 Rate or service discrimination; special classifications. Grantee shall not subject any person or group of persons to any prejudice or disadvantage, preference, or advantage in connection with rates, charges, service, facilities, rules or regulations, except as provided by FCC Rules. 
    Nothing herein shall prohibit the establishment of a graduated scale of rates for classified schedules to which any subscriber within such classification shall be entitled, or the provision of free service to government, institutional, or school buildings, or the provision of free service to employees. Special "Bulk-Bill" rates may be applied to multiple-dwelling units (MDU's). Notwithstanding the foregoing, grantee may negotiate bulk or special rates for businesses, hospitals, nursing homes, multiple dwelling units and other non-single family residential users, and may offer special rates to senior citizens and other capability challenged individuals. 
    Nothing herein shall prohibit grantee from offering special promotions to attract customers if such promotions are offered uniformly and without discrimination throughout the entire territorial limits. Specifically, grantee shall not charge different rates or provide services to subscribers in any area served by one or more competitors. 
    9-3.7 Free basic service. Grantee shall provide basic service without charge to each grantor government building, fire station, police station, library, school or college building, and other grantor-owned or grantor-occupied buildings (excluding housing, buildings, and facilities owned by grantor but not used for government or educational instruction and administrative purposes) within the territorial limits, as requested by grantor. One drop and one converter (if needed) per building shall constitute compliance. Any attached identified structures shall be treated as separate buildings. 
    9-3.8 Emergency power. The cable distribution system shall be equipped with battery-backup power supplies capable of powering the system throughout for a period of not less than two (2) hours, and the headend shall be provided with full emergency-backup power capable of powering the headend continuously. In the event of power outages in the cable-distribution system beyond two (2) hours, grantee shall provide for special auxiliary emergency power as required. 
    9-3.9 Emergency alert system: Emergency Broadcast System. 
9-3.9.1 Emergency Alert. Grantee shall, at grantee's expense, provide and install an emergency alert system for the purpose of permitting designated government officials to provide emergency information and warnings to cable subscribers. The system shall provide for full audio override on all channels. Access to the emergency alert control shall be possible from any telephone by dialing a specific code number. A code-tone-operated relay will limit access to authorized individuals. Emergency notification shall be supplemented with audio and visual transmission on the access and local-origination channel(s). 
9-3.9.2 E.B.S. Grantee shall, at grantee's expense, provide EBS (Emergency Broadcast System) facilities and services in accordance with such rules as may be promulgated therefor by the FCC, and within six (6) months after promulgation of such rules by the FCC. 
    9-3.10 State of the art. Throughout the term of the franchise, grantee shall maintain and upgrade the system and the technical performance of the system so as to keep pace with developments in the state-of-the-art as defined herein. Grantee may on its initiative participate in or undertake experiments, tests, and other activities to determine the state-of-the-art of cable communications technology currently in use. Grantor may require that grantee undertake such tests to the extent grantor and grantee mutually determine that it is economically viable and feasible to do so and provided that such experiments, tests and other activities are technically sound and undertaken in response to a mutually-defined market demand. Grantee shall provide grantor with written reports of the results of all significant tests conducted by or in cooperation with grantee at the request of grantor as described this section. 
    9-3.11 Subscriber antennas; AB switches. Notwithstanding any disconnection of subscribers' existing antennas and downleads to receivers connected to the cable system, the cable system shall be so designed that physical removal of such antennas and downleads will not be required, and so that the subscriber may utilize such antennas at any time in place of the cable system service. An antenna A-B switch may be installed at the option and expense of the subscriber, and shall not noticeably degrade cable system performance. 
    9-3.12 Drops. In areas where the cable distribution system is located underground, Drops to the structure shall be underground, buried to a standard depth of twelve (12) to eighteen (18) inches. In other areas drops may be aerial unless the subscriber elects to pay the cost of underground installation. Insofar as practicable, grantee shall adhere to each subscriber's desire with regard to point of entry of the drop connection into each structure. Insofar as practical, within the subscriber's structure, drop cable runs shall be made as unobtrusively as possible. All drops shall be grounded at the building entry, in accordance with local, NESC, and NEC requirements. 
    9-3.13 Installation time. Within grantor's territorial limits, except as provided in section 9-2.14 herein, service to all subscribers requiring an aerial installation shall be provided within five (5) business days after receipt of the request for service, and service to subscribers requiring an underground installation shall be provided within seven (7) business days after such request, unless later installation is requested or agreed to by the subscriber. Standard installation time shall be specified and published by grantee. 
    9-3.14 Parental guidance control. Grantee shall make available to any subscriber so requesting, at reasonable cost, a "parental guidance control" or "lockout key" which will permit the subscriber to eliminate intelligible audio and video reception of any channels, as provided for and defined by the FCC. Grantee shall notify all subscribers of the availability of such parental-control devices. 
    9-3.15 Complaint policy. Grantee shall promulgate written policy statements, procedures, and schedules for reporting and resolving subscriber complaints and shall finnish a copy thereof to each new subscriber and to grantor, and thereafter to all subscribers at least annually, and to grantor and all subscribers at such time as there is any change in such policy. 
    9-3.16 Complaint services. 
9-3.16.1 Local business office. Grantee shall maintain a local business office or representative which subscribers may telephone during regular business hours and talk to "live" employees without unreasonable delay and without resorting to answering services, recorded messages, added message or toll charges, so that CATV maintenance service shall be promptly available. In addition, provisions shall be made by grantee for receiving and responding to service calls at all other times. As used herein the words "regular business hours" shall be from 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. on Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays and from 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. on Saturdays or some evening hours and/or such other reasonable hours as may be set by grantor by future resolutions of the city commission.
