9-3.16.2 Service technician availability. At least one (1) service technician shall be based in the City of St. Augustine and all service calls shall be responded to within twenty-four (24) hours. 
9-3.16.3 Subscriber awareness of procedures. Grantee shall inform all subscribers of its complaint procedure, including telephone numbers for registering such complaints and request to make all complaints to grantee first. If a complaint is made to grantor and referred from grantor to grantee, grantee shall respond in writing to grantor within five (5) working days concerning the disposition of the complaint. 
    9-3.17 Call record/log of service calls. Grantee shall log all service calls and complaints received, and record all telephone activity. Grantee shall retain all such records for a minimum of twelve (12) months. Such records shall be made available to grantor at any time upon request and five (5) working days' notice. 
    9-3.18 Emergency communications. At least one person in responsible charge of grantee's operations in the territorial limits shall be available by local telephone during such hours as grantee's business office is closed, and the telephone numbers of such persons shall be supplied in advance to the mayor, city manager, the police and fire departments. 
    9-3.19 Reports and records. 
9-3.19.1 Annual report. Within three (3) months of the close of its fiscal year, upon written request of grantor, grantee shall provide to grantor an annual report that includes the following information: 
(a)  A summary of the previous calendar year's activities in development of the system, including but not limited to, services begun or dropped, number of subscribers (including gains and losses), homes passed, and miles of cable distribution plant (fiber and metallic) in service. The summary also shall include a comparison of any construction, including system upgrades during the year, with any projections previously provided to grantor. 
(b)  A certified financial statement, including a statement of income, and where grantee is in a significant construction phase, a statement of sources and applications of funds. The statement shall include notes that specify all significant accounting policies and practices upon which it is based. A summary shall be provided comparing the current year with previous years since the beginning of the franchise. 
(c)  A copy of updated maps depicting the location of all plant where there was construction in the year of the report. 
(d)  A summary of subscriber or consumer complaints, identifying the number and nature of complaints and their disposition. Where complaints involve one or more recurrent system problems, the nature of each problem and what steps have been taken to correct it, shall be identified. When available, more detailed information on complaints shall be submitted upon request of grantor. 
(e)  If grantee is a corporation, a list of officers and members of the board and the local officers and board members of any parent corporation; and where a parent corporation's stock is publicly traded, a copy of its most recent annual report. 
(f)  A list of all partners or known stockholders holding five (5) percent or more ownership interest in grantor and/or any parent corporation; provided, however, when any such entity has fewer than ten (10) persons holding five (5) percent ownership interest, the ten (10) largest such holders. Alternatively, the annual ownership information required by the FCC for cable systems may be supplied. 
(g)  A copy of all of grantee's published rules and regulations applicable to subscribers and users of the cable system. 
(h)  A report on the number of elderly, handicapped, and other subscribers receiving any rate discounts and the amount of the discounts. 
9-3.19.2 Grantee books and records. Grantee must maintain a complete set of books and records available for inspection and audit by grantor upon reasonable notice, for purposes of ascertaining compliance with requirements of this chapter and the franchise agreement. 
    Such inspection and audit shall be upon reasonable notice and during normal business hours and may be undertaken for the limited purpose of ascertaining compliance with requirements of this ordinance and the franchise agreement. 
9-3.19.3 Proprietary interests of grantee. Upon written request by grantee, and to the extent allowed by applicable law, information of a proprietary nature submitted to grantor pursuant to this chapter or the franchise agreement shall not be made available for public inspection if grantor finds that making public the information may cause injury to grantee's business. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-4.0. - System installation conditions. 
    9-4.1 Reservation of grantor's rights in public rights-of-way; easements. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent grantor from constructing, maintaining, repairing or relocating sewers; grading, paving, maintaining, repairing, relocating and/or altering any street; constructing, laying down, repairing, maintaining or relocating any water mains or other facilities; or constructing, maintaining, relocating, or repairing any sidewalk or other public work. Grantee shall, at grantee's expense, move and restore or relocate its plant in time to accommodate such work, and upon thirty (30) days' notice by grantor. All easements and rights-of-way granted to or obtained by franchisees within the territorial limits and/or service areas shall be non-exclusive and fully accessible by and assignable to grantor and its assigns. 
    9-4.2 System construction; maintenance. In the use of grantor's streets and rights-of-way, the following conditions shall apply: 
9-4.2.1 Plans; written notice. Before any construction is commenced, grantee shall submit plans to grantor's building officials and receive a written notice to proceed at least ten (10) days prior to such construction. The building officials shall have the right to inspect all construction or installation work performed by grantee in the streets and to make such periodic inspections as grantor deems necessary to ensure compliance with the terms of the franchise granted pursuant to this chapter and other pertinent provisions of the law. 
9-4.2.2 Wires, cables, amplifiers, etc. All wires, cables, amplifiers and other property shall be constructed and installed in an orderly and workmanlike manner. All cables and wires shall be installed parallel with existing telephone and electric wires wherever possible. Nothing in this article, or any franchise granted hereunder, shall authorize grantee to erect and maintain in the territorial limits new poles where existing poles are servicing the area. Grantee shall obtain permission from grantor before erecting any new poles or underground conduit before grantee seeks to install any lines. All installations shall be underground in those sections of the territorial limits where both telephone and electric utility service are underground at the time of installation, or where subdivision or deed restrictions require utilities to be underground. In sections where either telephone or electric utility facilities are aboveground at the time of installation, grantee may install its service aboveground with the understanding that at such time as those facilities are required to be placed underground by grantor, grantee shall likewise place its services underground without additional cost to the residents of grantor or the remainder of the franchise area: It shall be the policy of grantor that underground installation, even when not required, is preferable to the placing of additional poles. 
(a)  Grantee shall submit to grantor a copy of as-built maps at the completion of construction of the new system. Such maps shall be updated at least once each year thereafter. 
(b)  Grantee shall, in addition to complying with all terms and provisions of this article, comply with all technical standards concerning cable TV promulgated by the Federal Communications Commission. 
9-4.2.3 Reasonable notice of plans for street improvements shall be given to grantee by grantor when paving, resurfacing, or repairs are involved. The notice shall contain the nature and character of the improvements, streets upon which the improvements are to be made, the extent of the improvements, and the work schedule for the project. The notice shall give grantee sufficient reasonable time to make any additions, alterations or repairs to its facilities as are necessary in advance of the actual commencement of the work. Any relocation required by grantor under this paragraph shall be at the expense of grantee. 
9-4.2.4 Vacated, abandoned, closed, discontinued, etc. streets and rights-of-way. If all or part of a street, road, highway, or right-of-way within the territorial limits is vacated, abandoned, closed, reconstructed or discontinued, the rights and privileges contained within this article, with respect to streets, roads or highways, or any part thereof so closed or discontinued, etc., shall automatically cease and grantee shall not be entitled to damages from grantor due to vacating, closing or discontinuance of such street, road or highway, or for any injury to any part of the system in the street or for the removal or relocation of lines and cables. 
9-4.2.5 Building-moving permit. Grantee shall, on the request of any person holding a building moving permit, temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit moving of such building. The expense of such temporary removal, raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the person requesting these services. Grantee shall have the authority to require such payment in advance. Grantee shall be given not less than five (5) business days' advance notice of any move contemplated in order to arrange for temporary wire changes. 
9-4.2.6 Tree trimming. Grantee shall have the responsibility to trim trees upon or overhanging streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public places within the territorial limits so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires and cables of grantee. All trimming is to be done under the explicit prior written notification and approval of grantor's building officials and be at the expense of grantee. 
All trimming shall be performed in a safe and orderly manner and in compliance with the pruning standards of the National Arborists Association, as amended, and any applicable provisions of local codes and ordinances. 
9-4.2.7 Reasonable-care disclaimer. Nothing contained in this section shall relieve any private person, company or corporation from liability arising out of failure to exercise reasonable care to avoid injuring grantee's facilities while performing any work connection with grading, regrading or changing the line of any street or public place or with the construction or reconstruction of any sewer, water, electric or telephone system. 
    9-4.3. Underground; easements. 
9-4.3.1 Underground preferred. In areas having telephone and electric utility lines now or at any time hereafter underground, whether required by ordinance or not, all of grantee's distribution system shall be underground. Underground installation, even if not required, is preferable to the placing of additional poles. In the instance of underground installations made after the effective date of the franchise, drop lines shall be placed at least twelve (12) inches deep and cable distribution lines shall be placed at least twenty-four (24) inches deep. This minimum depth also applies to all replacement drop and distribution lines. Underground cable distribution plant in areas exposed to damage shall be installed in conduit or shall be of armored cable construction. Underwater crossings shall utilize sealed armored cable or sealed cable in conduit, as specified for underwater use. 
9-4.3.2 Private easements. Grantee shall have the responsibility for obtaining easements from property owners, as needed. If grantee is unable to obtain such easements at a reasonable cost and therefore cannot extend its system economically, grantee will be relieved of the extension policy requiring such easements, until such time that such easements can be obtained at a reasonable cost. Grantor shall be named in all easements and shall have the option of sharing same, for purposes not competitive with grantee's business. 
    9-4.4 Installation and construction rules; construction approval. 
9-4.4.1 Construction approval by city engineer; correction of defects. Except for individual service drops, grantee shall not erect any pole, run any line, make any attachment, or commence any construction of any kind without the prior approval of the city engineer. The approval as referenced herein shall be in the form of a permit issued by the city engineer upon approval of (a) layout maps of the system authorized by this franchise showing plant routing, utility company poles to which the system facilities are to be attached and location of all trunk and distribution line amplifiers, (b) true copies of all attachment requests by grantee, and (c) subsequent approval by Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company, and Florida Power and Light Company. Grantor shall have and maintain the right to inspect the construction, operation and maintenance of the system by grantee to ensure the proper performance of the terms of this franchise or any of the rules and regulations as may be from time to time lawfully adopted, grantor may immediately give to grantee thirty (30) days' written notice to correct such violations, and in the event grantee does not make such correction within thirty (30) days from the receipt of such written notice, grantor may make such correction itself and recover the cost of same from grantee. In no event shall grantee create any obstructions or conditions which are or may become dangerous to the traveling public. All work of such kind shall be subject to inspection and approval by grantor in accordance with applicable codes and regulations. 
9-4.4.2 Emergency repairs. In cases of emergency, grantee may make whatever repairs are necessary to maintain the operation of the cable system at required levels provided however that all emergency work shall comply with all applicable ordinances and regulations of grantor, and grantee shall notify grantor of such work immediately upon commencement of the emergency work. Grantee shall be responsible for any damages resulting from temporary repairs. Within two (2) working days of the commencement of the emergency work, grantee shall request any applicable permits for such repairs, in accordance with the rules for such permits. Work shall be subject to inspection and approval by grantor. 
9-4.4.3 Barriers; lighting; traffic control. Any openings or obstructions in streets caused by grantee shall be guarded and protected by grantee and its contractors at all times by placing adequate barriers, fences, boarding or other protective devices, at the sole expense of grantee. During periods of dusk and darkness, protective devices and protected areas shall be designated by warning lights. Grantee shall provide for and pay for traffic control in construction areas as required by local ordinance. 
    9-4.5 Relocations. 
9-4.5.1 Temporary relocation. Grantee's cable distribution plant shall be located, relocated, erected and/or maintained so as: (1) not to interfere with the lives or safety of persons or with any improvements grantor deems proper to make, and of which grantee has received reasonable notice, and (2) not to hinder or obstruct the free use of the streets by the public. Removal of poles and other structures to avoid such interference shall be at grantee's expense. 
Raising or lowering or moving of grantee's plant to permit moving of buildings and other structures and equipment shall be done by grantee within ten (10) business days of previous notice and at mover's expense, subject to receipt of all required permits. 
9-4.5.2 Permanent relocation. If grantor shall elect to alter or change the grade or location of any street, or shall engage in any construction or other public works in, on, or under the streets, grantee, upon at least sixty (60) days' written notice by grantor, shall relocate its cable distribution plant at its own expense, and in each instance shall comply with all ordinances, codes, and regulations of grantor. 
    9-4.6 Installation and construction: compliance with codes. Grantee shall comply with all applicable local, state, and federal rules and regulations now in force or which may be put into force hereafter. Grantee shall comply also with city, state and National Electric and Safety Codes in its installations and operations. The right to change and adopt new rules, regulations, and codes for future construction from time to time is reserved to grantor. Such changes may become effective immediately upon adoption by grantor and notification to grantee, but shall not supersede federal or state codes and regulations. 
    9-4.7 Joint use of grantee facilities; safety rules. Insofar as such work may be done without interfering with the free use and enjoyment of grantee's own facilities, wires and fixtures, and when requested in writing by grantor, grantee shall provide suitable space equivalent to one (1) crossarm (in vertical and horizontal spacing) on each pole erected by grantee, in grantee's riser conduits, and in grantee's control cabinets, equivalent to one (1) duct in each of the conduits constructed by grantee, and if direct burial is used shall provide one (1) grantor cable or tubing, free of charge and for the purpose of carrying wires of grantor's non-competitive data, alarm, signal, radio, or other communications system, provided said wires, facilities, or fixtures are placed and maintained in such a manner as may be reasonably prescribed by grantee, and in no case used to carry electric light or high-voltage power. Whenever its becomes necessary for grantee to move grantor's said wires for grantee's own purposes, such removal shall be at the cost of grantee and under supervision of the director of public works, and such wires shall be promptly replaced by grantee at grantee's expense. 
    9-4.8 Interconnect. Within six (6) months after receipt of written request from grantor and agreement by any neighboring cable operator in a contiguous or adjacent franchise area (territorial limits), grantee shall provide for bidirectional interconnection with such neighboring cable operator. Such interconnection shall be accomplished at reasonable expense to grantee, including design, installation, and all necessary equipment, hardware, and accessories, or shall be shared by grantee and such neighboring cable operator. 
    If reasonable terms of interconnection can not be reached between grantee and such adjacent operator within six (6) months after grantee's original request, then grantor shall be permitted to mediate the terms of the interconnect agreement. 
    9-4.9 Identification. Vehicles, including all trailers and mobile tools owned or leased by grantee and used in the operation, installation, construction, or repair of the cable system shall be identified by name, address, and phone number of grantee. All employees of grantee and of grantee's contractors and subcontractors shall wear identification badges and carry adequate identification as to their names, local business addresses and local business phone numbers. Grantee and its contractors shall clearly identify all of its vehicles, employees, agents, and equipment by decals, badges, signs, and as otherwise appropriate. 
    9-4.10 Restoration: repair. Grantee shall repair promptly and at grantee's expense all damage caused by grantee, its agents, contractors, and subcontractors in the construction, rebuild, upgrade, operation, maintenance, and repair of the cable system and shall restore all property, both public and private, to its original condition, or as nearly so as possible. Such restoration and repair shall be made as soon as practicable after such damage, and in accordance with applicable codes, and not later than ten (10) business days after grantee's receipt of written notification from grantor or the owner of the property so damaged unless otherwise mutually agreed by grantee and grantor or property owner. If any damage involves pavements, sidewalks, driveways, water mains, storm or sanitary sewers, streets, roads, or other public facilities or is deemed by grantor to be a threat to public safety, such damage shall be repaired to grantor's satisfaction commencing within one (1) day after grantee's receipt of written notification from grantor. 
    9-4.11 Obstruction prohibited. Grantee shall prevent the creation of any obstructions or conditions which are or may become dangerous to the public. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-5.0. - Consumer service and repair standards. 
    9-5.1 General. Grantee shall maintain and operate the system and render efficient service in compliance with such rules and regulations as are or may be set forth by the city commission, the State of Florida, and/or the FCC however, grantee shall operate the system so that there will be no interference with television reception, radio reception, telephone communications or other installations which are now or may hereafter be installed or in use by grantor or any persons in the service area. 
    9-5.2 Maintenance and operation. Grantee shall promulgate and adhere to a preventive maintenance policy directed toward maximizing the reliability and maintainability of the cable system with respect to its delivery of cable service to subscribers at or above the performance standards set forth herein. When it is necessary to interrupt cable service for the purpose of making repairs, adjustments, installations or other maintenance activities, grantee shall do so at such times as will cause the least inconvenience to its subscribers, generally between the hours of 11:30 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. the next morning. 
    9-5.3 Office hours and telephone availability. 
9-5.3.1 The cable operator shall maintain a local, toll-free, or collect-call telephone line which shall be available to its subscribers twenty-four (24) hours per day, seven (7) days per week. Office hours and telephone availability shall be provided, as a minimum, in accordance with FCC Rules § 76.309. 
9-5.3.2 Grantee shall maintain an office within the city open to the public during all reasonable business hours for so long as it continues to operate the system. All complaints against the company relating to its performance under the agreement, including but not limited to those concerning quality of service, equipment malfunction and billing disputes, shall be received at the company's office by duly authorized employees. The company shall endeavor to respond and satisfy any complaints within thirty-six (36) hours. 
9-5.3.3 The city manager, or another official duly designated by grantor, shall receive any complaints which have not been satisfied by the company and shall establish procedures for the speedy resolution of such complaints. 
9-5.3.4 Trained cable-operator representatives shall be available to respond to customer telephone inquiries during normal business hours. 
9-5.3.5 After normal business hours, the access line may be answered by a service person or an automated response system, including an answering machine. Inquiries received after normal business hours must be responded to by a trained company representative on the next business day, and must be listed in grantee's service records and logs. 
9-5.3.6 Under normal operating conditions, telephone answer time by a customer representative, including wait time, shall not exceed thirty (30) seconds when the connection is made. If the call needs to be transferred, transfer time shall not exceed thirty (30) seconds. These standards shall be met on no fewer than ninety (90) percent of such occasions under normal operating conditions, measured on a quarterly basis. 
9-5.3.7 Under normal operating conditions, customers shall receive a busy signal response to less than three (3) percent of the total number of calls, over any one-week period. 
    9-5.4 Notice of Repairs. Except in an emergency, grantee shall give affected subscribers at least twenty-four (24) hours' notice of any interruption of cable service for purposes of maintenance or repair. In an emergency, grantee shall give such notice as is reasonable in the circumstances. Notice given on the alphanumeric channels shall be considered sufficient. When fee or more subscribers' service is to be interrupted for repairs for more than three (3) hours, normal scheduled service and repair shall be performed between the hours of 11:30 p.m. and 6:30 a.m. the next morning. 
    9-5.5 Installations, outages and service calls. Under normal operating conditions, each of the following four (4) standards shall be met on no fewer than ninety five (95) percent of such conditions, measured on a quarterly basis: 
9-5.5.1 Standard installation. Standard aerial installation will be performed within seven (7) business days after an order has been placed. Standard underground installation will be performed within ten (10) business days after an order has been placed. "Standard" installations are those that are located within the territorial limits of the City of St. Augustine, except as provided herein section 9-2.14. 
9-5.5.2 Major malfunctions; area outages. Grantee shall commence repairs of any major malfunctions (area outages) within one-half hour after grantee's discovery of such conditions. 
9-5.5.3 Service interruptions. Excluding conditions beyond the control of grantee, grantee shall begin working on service interruptions promptly and in no event later than twenty-four (24) hours after the interruption becomes known to grantee. Grantee must begin actions to correct other service problems the next business day after notification of the service problem. 
9-5.5.4 The "appointment window". Alternatives for installations, service calls, and other installation activities shall be either a specific time or, at maximum, a four-hour time window during normal business hours. 
9-5.5.5 Appointment cancellation. Grantee shall not cancel an appointment with a customer after the close of business on the business day, holiday, or weekend prior to the scheduled appointment. 
9-5.5.6 Service calls cleared. If a cable operator representative is running late for an appointment with a customer and will not be able to keep the appointment as scheduled, the customer will be contacted. The appointment will be rescheduled, as necessary, at a time which is convenient for the customer. Fewer than five (5) percent of such appointments shall be so delayed. 
9-5.5.7 Service calls (repairs) cleared. Seventy (70) percent of all service calls shall be cleared on the same day; ninety (90) percent within three (3) working days. All service calls shall be cleared within five (5) working days unless good and sufficient cause exists and is documented by grantee. Any service call not cleared within five (5) working days shall be reported in writing to grantor or its designated agent by grantee within two (2) working days thereafter. 
9-5.5.8 Service-call ratio as defined in section 9-1.165 shall not exceed two (2) percent or two (2) service calls (truck rolls) per one hundred (100) subscribers, per month, averaged over any three-month period. 
    9-5.6 Communications between grantee and cable subscribers. 
9-5.6.1 Notification to subscribers. 
(a)  Grantee shall provide written information on each of the following areas at the time of installation of services, at least annually to all subscribers, and at any time upon request: 
(1)  Products and services offered; 
(2)  Prices and options for programming services and conditions of subscription to programming and other services; 
(3)  Installation and service maintenance policies; 
(4)  Instructions on how to use the cable service; 
(5)  Channel positions of programming carried on the system; and 
(6)  Billing and complaint procedures, including the address and telephone number of the local franchise authority's cable regulation office. 
(b)  Customers shall be notified of any change in rates, programming services or channel positions as soon as possible through announcements on the cable system and in writing. Notice must be given to subscribers a minimum of thirty (30) days in advance of such changes if the change is within the control of grantee. In addition, grantee shall notify subscribers thirty (30) days in advance of any significant changes in the other information required by the preceding paragraph, unless insufficient time is available to grantee to do so. 
9-5.6.2 Billing. Bills shall be clear, concise and understandable. Bills must be fully itemized, with itemizations including, but not limited to, basic, premium, and event charges, and equipment charges. Bills shall also clearly delineate all activity during the billing period, including optional charges, rebates and credits. In case of a billing dispute, Grantee shall respond to a written complaint from a subscriber within thirty (30) days. 
9-5.6.3 Refunds. Refund checks shall be issued promptly, but no later than either: 
(a)  The customer's next billing cycle following resolution of the request or thirty-one (31) days, whichever is earlier; or 
(b)  Within ten (10) days of the return of the equipment supplied by grantee if service is terminated. 
9-5.6.4 Credits. Credits for service shall be issued no later than the customer's next billing cycle following the determination that a credit is warranted. 
    9-5.7 Reports to grantor. Grantee shall provide written notice detailing resolution of complaints within five (5) business days from written or telephone notification by grantor to grantee. Grantee shall provide service-call and outage reports for time periods up to sixty (60) days to grantor upon request and five (5) business days' notice. 
    9-5.8 Refund for subscriber service interruptions. For any continuous service interruption or loss of service in excess of twenty-four (24) hours (one day) on a calendar basis, grantee shall make a pro-rated refund of such subscriber's regular monthly charge to each subscriber so affected, upon written request of such subscriber. The twenty-four-hour period shall commence when grantee learns of such subscriber outage whether through subscriber telephone, oral, or written notification including notification by grantee's personnel. 
    Such refunds shall be prorated by multiplying the applicable monthly service rate by a fraction whose numerator equals the number of days of the outage and whose denominator equals the number of days in the month of the outage. Grantee shall not be required to grant a refund for a subscriber outage caused by any subscriber. 
    9-5.9 Termination; pro-rated service. In the event a subscriber's service is terminated for any reason, monthly charges for service shall be pro-rated on a daily basis. Where advance payment has been made by a subscriber, the appropriate refund shall be made by grantee to the subscriber within thirty (30) days of such termination or in the next subscriber's billing cycle, unless the amount is less than five dollars ($5.00). Refund shall be made only upon return of grantor's equipment. 
    9-5.10 Disconnection for non-payment. Grantee shall have the right to disconnect a subscriber for failure to pay an overdue account provided that: 
9-5.10.1 Grantee's billing practices and policy statements have set forth the conditions under which the account would be considered overdue and subscriber has not complied therewith; and 
9-5.10.2 Grantee mails written notice of intent to disconnect at least fifteen (15) days prior to the intended disconnection; and 
9-5.10.3 The subscriber account is at least thirty (30) days delinquent computed from the first day of service for which payment was due. 
    9-5.11 Records. Grantee shall maintain records of all service complaints by subscribers, showing the date of receipt of all written complaints and identifying the subscriber, the nature of the complaint, and the date action was taken by grantee in response thereto, together with a description of such action. Such records shall be kept available at grantee's local office for at least one year, for inspection by grantor as it may at any time and from time to time reasonably request, during business hours and upon five (5) days' notice. Grantor shall be advised of complaints which remain unresolved for a period of five (5) working days or more. A monthly log of complaints and resolutions, by category, shall be provided upon request to grantor or its representative by grantee. 
    9-5.12 Precedence. In the event of conflict between this section 9-5.0 of this chapter and § 76.309 of the FCC Rules related to Customer-Service Standards, the requirements of this chapter shall take precedence. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-6.0. - Privacy. 
    Grantee shall comply fully with the letter and spirit of Section 631 of the Cable Act with regard to the right of privacy of any subscriber. If any device or signal associated with the cable system interferes with the right of privacy of any third party, grantee shall terminate any such abuse. 
    9-6.1 Installation of equipment. Grantee shall install no plant on private property without first securing written permission of the owner or tenant in possession of such property or the written permission of the holder of any easement for utility lines or similar purposes, and in accordance with law. Upon request, grantee shall inform owners and tenants of the functions of all equipment installed on private property. 
    9-6.2 Monitoring. Neither grantee nor any of its officers, employees or agents shall tap, monitor or arrange for the tapping or monitoring of any drop, outlet or receiver for any purpose whatsoever other than legitimate technical performance testing of the cable system or the monitoring of subscriber cable service or monitoring to prevent theft of service, without prior written consent of all affected parties. 
    9-6.3 Subscriber lists or information. Grantee shall not sell, disclose, or otherwise make available, or permit the use of, lists of the names or addresses of its subscribers, or any list or other information which identifies subscribers or subscriber viewing habits, to any person or entity for any purpose whatsoever without the consent of each subscriber, all in accordance with and subject to the provisions of the Cable Act and applicable law. This provision shall not prevent grantee from performing such acts as may be necessary for the purpose of service-related activities, including surveys, and grantee promotional/marketing activities. This provision shall not prevent grantee from providing such subscriber information to grantor, in confidence, as required for purposes of auditing franchise fees, in accordance with applicable law. 
    9-6.4 Protection of privacy. Grantee shall not transmit any audio, video or digital signal, including polling channel selections, from any subscriber's premises without first obtaining the written consent of that subscriber. (This provision is not intended to prohibit the use of transmission signals useful only for the control or measurement of signal performance and programming, e.g., status monitoring or reception of premium programming, provided that such information shall not be used except for those basic purposes.) Grantee shall not permit the installation of any special terminal equipment in any subscriber's premises which will permit transmission from subscriber's premises of two-way services utilizing audio, video or digital signals without first obtaining written permission from the subscriber. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-7.0. - Obscenity. 
    The transmission of obscene programming is prohibited. Conviction of any grantee under federal or state or county or city ordinance of transmitting obscene programming will be grounds for revocation of the franchise. 
    Alternatively, and should such obscene video and/or audio programming be permitted under the First Amendment, grantee shall confine such obscene programming to one or more specified channels; provide notice to all subscribers and to grantor of such program; and delete such obscene programming from a subscriber's home within five (5) working days after written request by such subscriber. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-8.0. - Technical requirements. 
    The signal of any broadcast television or radio station retransmitted on the cable system shall be carried without material degradation and with a quality no less than that prescribed by rules of any local, federal, or state regulatory agencies having jurisdiction, and as specified herein. The technical specifications, operation, and performance of the cable system shall conform at all times to the specifications established by any federal or state regulatory agencies having jurisdiction, and existing on the effective date hereof, or to the standards specified below, whichever is of the higher quality. 
    The system shall comply fully with FCC rules, Part 76, Sub-Part K, as amended. Grantee and grantor agree that the following minimum technical standards shall be maintained by grantee's system at all times, over the annual ambient temperature range normally experienced in the area. Notwithstanding the provisions of the Cable Act of 1992, all specifications shall become effective immediately upon completion of rebuild of the system, which will fulfill all FCC requirements and the following requirements as of the last date deadline for compliance with FCC rules, or 1995. 
    9-8.1 Technical standards. The system shall comply with the FCC Technical Standards, Part 76, Sub-Part K, all technical requirements to be effective immediately as of the date of the franchise. Grantee shall perform yearly FCC-mandated testing and shall provide two (2) copies of its test reports to grantor upon request. Grantee's system shall at all times comply with all FCC Technical Standards to become in effect by 1996, but such to be effective immediately. 
    9-8.2 Construction standards. All construction practices shall be in accordance with federal, state, and local statutes, ordinances, and regulations, and in accordance with grantee's construction and installation standards. 
9-8.2.1 All installation of electronic equipment shall be of a permanent nature, durable and installed in accordance with the current provisions of the National Electrical Safety Code (National Bureau of Standards) and National Electrical Code (National Bureau of Fire Underwriters) as amended and as applicable to Cable Television. 
9-8.2.2 Antenna supporting structures shall be designed for proper loading as specified by Electronics Industry Association Specification RS 222E or current version. 
9-8.2.3 Antenna supporting structures shall be painted, lighted, erected and maintained to comply with all applicable rules and regulations of the Federal Aviation Administration and all other applicable federal, state, and local codes and regulations. 
9-8.2.4 Grantee's cable system shall be installed, located, erected, constructed, reconstructed, replaced, removed, repaired, maintained and operated in accordance with good engineering practices. Work shall be performed by experienced maintenance and construction personnel. Grantee shall preserve and protect plants, shrubbery and trees, and any improvements in the tree belts and rights-of-way. Grantee shall not interfere in any manner with the rights of any property owner, or unnecessarily hinder or obstruct pedestrian or vehicular traffic. 
Grantee shall exercise special care in the installation, construction, operation, maintenance, modification, and repair of all portions of the system located within the historical area, as defined by grantor. 
9-8.2.5 Grantee shall exercise reasonable care and shall adhere to industry standards in the construction, operation, maintenance, and repair of the cable television system. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-9.0. - Testing; repairs. 
    9-9.1 Test equipment; proof testing by grantee. Grantee shall provide and keep on hand at all times, or have available within not less than ten (10) business days' notice from grantor, accurately-calibrated test equipment for testing to such technical standards as set forth in Part 7 [section 9-8.0] above and as may be modified by the FCC or other authorized agency in the future, and shall conduct proof tests to said standards as from time to time may be reasonably requested by grantor in order to determine the level of performance of the cable system. Grantor may provide a technical representative to witness and report on such tests, as provided in section 9-9.3 below. 
    9-9.2 Reports. Upon request, grantee shall provide copies to grantor of all testing and evaluation reports as filed with the FCC and any other government agencies. 
    9-9.3 Added proof testing. Should there be extended and continued evidence of substandard performance of the system, proof testing for compliance with technical Standards may be required by grantor, who may, for good cause, retain an independent engineer acceptable to grantee, to conduct technical performance tests of the system in addition to those conducted by grantee, or to witness such tests as performed by grantee. 
    9-9.4 Failure; reimbursement. If the system substantially fails to meet one or more of the technical standards during any grantor-required test, grantee shall reimburse grantor for all related costs and shall investigate and correct the cause of said failure. 
    9-9.5 Time to cure. Grantee shall be given a period of up to sixty (60) days to correct technical-standard deficiencies. Performance testing shall be repeated upon completion of necessary repair or adjustment, and a report of the second test submitted to grantor, all at the expense of grantee. Such testing may be witnessed by grantor's agent, at grantee's expense. 
    9-9.6 Substantial failure; breach. Substantial failure to comply with technical standards or repeated failure to take corrective action in the event of such failures shall constitute a substantial breach of this chapter, and section 9-13.2.1(c) shall apply. 
    9-9.7 Test procedures. Test procedures shall generally follow the guidelines of the NCTA "Recommended Practices for Measurements on Cable Television Systems," subject to FCC rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-10.0. - INSURANCE; BONDING. 
    9-10.1 Insurance coverage. Grantee shall, at its expense, prior to any use of or entry upon grantor's streets or property and at all times during the term of the franchise issued pursuant to this chapter, maintain and provide grantor with suitable evidence of both (1) broad form contractual liability insurance coverage including indemnification obligation set forth here, and (2) comprehensive general public liability insurance coverage including, but not limited to, motor vehicle liability coverage naming grantee, its employees, and affiliates, as insureds and naming grantor, its officers, officials, agents, and employees as additional insureds while acting in the scope of their employment, insuring against on an occurrence basis all claims, loss, cost, damage, expense and liability from loss of life or damage or injury to persons or property arising out of grantee's use of grantor's streets or property. Said policies shall have limits of not less than two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) combined single limit with a four-million-dollar ($4,000,000.00) umbrella for loss of life and injury to one or more persons and for property damage as a result of one incident. 
    9-10.2 Additional indemnification. Grantee shall require substantially identical indemnification and insurance coverages as set forth in sections 9-10.1 and 9-11.0 hereof in favor of grantor, its officials, officers, agents and employees, from any independent contractor or other entity working on its behalf in grantor's rights-of-way. Such coverages shall be in the amount of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) combined single limit with a four-million-dollar ($4,000,000.00) umbrella, naming grantee, grantor, and their officers, agents, and employees as additional insureds. 
    9-10.3 Worker's compensation coverage. Grantee shall also maintain in full force and effect throughout the duration of this franchise sufficient worker's compensation insurance coverage to protect its agents and employees as required by law. 
    9-10.4 Construction bond. Grantee shall post and maintain a construction bond in favor of grantor in the amount of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) by a bonding company licensed to do business in the State of Florida. Such construction bond shall be forfeited in proportion to the cost of the rebuild that remains incomplete, as determined by an independent engineer selected and mutually agreed upon by grantor and grantee, if grantee has not completed such rebuild of the system within the time permitted by the franchise and enabling documents. Such construction bond shall remain in effect until the system rebuild is completed and the system is satisfactorily proof-tested, and accepted by grantor. 
    9-10.5 Performance bond; indemnity. 
9-10.5.1 Performance bond. No later than the date of execution of the franchise or enabling document pursuant to this chapter [Ordinance No. 94-37], grantee shall post and maintain, at its sole cost and expense, a corporate surety bond issued by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Florida and reasonably acceptable to grantor as security for the faithful performance by grantee in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and the franchise issued pursuant hereto. Said bond shall assure grantor of recovery of any and all liability, damages, losses, costs and expenses sustained or suffered by grantor as the result of, without limitation, grantee's failure to properly construct, operate or maintain the cable television system as required under this chapter and the franchise issued pursuant hereto. The total amount of the bond shall be two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) and the bond shall be maintained in favor of grantor. 
9-10.5.2 Cancellation; intention not to renew. It is hereby agreed and understood that this bond may not be canceled or refused renewal until (30) days after receipt by the city commission of the City of St. Augustine by registered mail of two (2) copies of a written notice of such intent to cancel or not renew. 
9-10.5.3 Termination of performance bond. The performance bond shall be maintained for the duration of the franchise and expire by the terms herein no sooner than the expiration of the franchise, provided, however, that the performance bond shall remain in force after expiration in the event of any outstanding substantial breach or dispute as to breach or amount due from grantee. 
    9-10.6 Security deposit. 
9-10.6.1 Cash deposit. Prior to the franchise becoming effective, grantee must post with grantor a cash security deposit in such amount as specified in the franchise agreement to be used as a security fluid to ensure the faithful performance of all provisions of law and the franchise agreement and compliance with all orders, permits, and directions of grantor, and the payment by grantee of any claims, liens or taxes due grantor which arise by reason of the construction, operation or maintenance of the system. The security deposit shall be in such amount as grantor deems necessary, taking into account the effects of inflation, the extent of grantee's operations in the territorial limits and grantee's history of compliance in the territorial limits and other jurisdictions. 
9-10.6.2 Interest. Grantor shall place the security deposit in an interest-bearing account. The interest will accrue to the benefit of grantee, but may not be withdrawn; all interest will be added to, and become part of, the original security fund during the term of the franchise. 
9-10.6.3 Withdrawal. If grantee fails to pay to grantor any fees or taxes due, liquidated damages, damages, or costs or expenses incurred by grantor by reason of any act or default of grantee, or if grantee fails to comply with any provision of the franchise agreement that grantor reasonably determines can be remedied by an expenditure of the security fund, grantor may withdraw that amount with any interest or penalties from the security fund. Upon such withdrawal, grantor shall notify grantee of the amount and date of the withdrawal. 
Grantee may request resolution in accordance with section 9-13.6, or an administrative review within ten (10) days after such withdrawal. Such administrative review shall be held within thirty (30) days thereafter, and a decision shall be rendered within the next ten (10) days. 
9-10.6.4 Restoration. Within thirty (30) days after notice to grantee that an amount has been withdrawn by grantor from the security fund, grantee must deposit a sum of money sufficient to restore the security fund to the original amount. If grantee fails to restore the security fund to the original amount within thirty (30) calendar days, the entire security fund remaining may be forfeited, and/or such failure may be considered a material breach of this chapter and may be used as grounds for revocation of the franchise. 
9-10.6.5 Outstanding or unpaid amounts. Following the revocation and termination of a franchise, grantee is entitled to the return of that portion of the security fund that remains, provided that there is no outstanding default or unpaid amounts due to grantor from grantee. Any such unpaid amounts due grantor shall be withdrawn from the security fund prior to its release. 
9-10.6.6 Rights. The rights reserved to grantor with respect to the security fund are in addition to all other rights of grantor whether reserved by this chapter or authorized by other law, and no action, proceeding or exercise of a right with respect to such security fund will affect any other right grantor may have. 
    9-10.7 Cancellation notice. All grantee bonds, insurance policies and certificates of insurance shall stipulate that the coverages afforded by the policies and bonds shall not be canceled, modified or allowed to expire until after at least thirty (30) days' written notice has been provided to grantor and a receipt of delivery obtained. 
    9-10.8 Evidence of insurance and bonding. By not later than the effective date of the franchise or enabling document thereunder (e.g., letter of intent), grantee shall furnish to grantor current certificates of insurance and bonding, which shall include the named insureds and beneficiaries set forth in sections 9-10.1 and 9-10.2 above. Failure to maintain said insurance shall constitute a substantial breach within the meaning of section 9-13.2.1 below, and shall be grounds for revocation of the franchise. 
    9-10.9 Approval of insurance company by grantor. Insurance coverage shall be in a form and with an insurance company approved by grantor, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. Approval shall be requested at least forty-five (45) days prior to acceptance of the franchise granted pursuant to this chapter. Insurance coverage shall be with a company authorized to do business in the State of Florida. 
    9-10.10 Copies to be filed. Two (2) copies of all bonds shall be filed and maintained with the city commission during the term of any franchise agreement granted hereunder or any renewal thereof. 
    9-10.11 Changes in limits. At the end of each five-year period, grantor shall have the right to require increases in the amounts of insurance and bonds specified above. Any adjustments shall be made by referring to the Consumer Price Index (CPI) or such standards/guidelines as are in existence and in use at the time. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-11.0. - Indemnification. 
    9-11.1 Indemnification. Grantee shall indemnify and hold free and harmless grantor and its officials, officers, agents, and employees from and against any and all damages, loss, cost, or expense. Such shall include reasonable attorneys' and consultants' fees, resulting from any claim, demand, suit, or other action, whether or not reduced to judgment, and for any liability of any nature whatsoever that may arise out of or in connection with or result from the presence of grantee or grantee's agents, successors, employees, contractors, invited parties, or affiliates in their use of, or activities or omissions in, grantor's streets or property. 
    Damages shall include without limitation, liability for damages to persons or property, or wrongful death in connection with the construction, installation, maintenance, operation, repair, or removal of the system or the use of any poles, wires, conduits, and fiber optic equipment or the exercise by grantee of any right or privilege wanted by or under this chapter and the franchise issued pursuant hereto. Damages shall include also any failure by grantee to comply with any law, ordinance, or regulation, or by reason of suit or claim for royalties, lease fees, or infringement of copyrights or patents. 
    FCC Rules and the Communications Act of 1934, as amended, shall apply, to the end of holding officials and local government harmless, particularly in compliance with "The Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992." 
    9-11.2 Grantor defense. Should grantor determine that grantee's prosecution or defense of its case is not in grantor's best interest, grantor may retain separate counsel, at grantee's expense and shall so notify grantee in advance. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-12.0. - Grantee payments to grantor. 
    9-12.1 Franchise fee. Grantee shall pay a franchise fee to grantor as specified in the franchise, and up to the maximum allowed by applicable law. Franchise fees shall be computed semi-annually and semi-annual payment shall be due and payable no later than forty-five (45) days after the end of the period for which payment is intended. Each payment shall be accompanied by a report showing detailed computations and such other relevant data as grantor may reasonably require. Grantor may provide a standard form for use by grantee to compute franchise fees. Such payments shall be deemed compensation for use of grantor's rights-of-way, administration of service complaints, supervision and inspection of equipment and facilities, and administration of the franchise and chapter and shall be in addition to and separate from all federal, state and local taxes. 
    9-12.2 Filing fee. 
9-12.2.1 Initial payment. Each application for a new or renewed cable television franchise shall be accompanied by a non-refundable filing fee in the amount of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). 
9-12.2.2 Full payment. In the event such non-refundable filing fee is not sufficient to pay all such costs, the applicant shall pay the balance of such costs to grantor within thirty (30) days of the mailing of an invoice for such balance by grantor to the applicant at its address as listed on its application. 
    9-12.3 Incidental expenses. Grantee shall also pay all incidental expenses incurred by grantor as defined in this chapter. Neither franchise fees nor incidental expenses are excludable from gross revenues and are a part of grantee's cost of doing business. 
    9-12.4 Capital grant/capital equipment. In consideration of the award of the franchise and as an indication of grantee's interest in helping to fulfill the cable-related needs of the community, grantee shall provide capital equipment for use in connection with the access (PEG) channel(s) as listed in the franchise to be awarded pursuant to this chapter or shall provide an equivalent capital grant to grantor, as defined in the franchise. 
    9-12.5 Transfer fee. In order that grantor may share in the value this franchise adds to franchisee's operations and in further consideration of grantor's administrative expenses incurred, any sale, transfer, assignment, or lease by the franchisee of rights under the franchise requiring consent of grantor shall require the payment to grantor of a transfer fee. The transfer fee shall be in an amount equal to one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for each remaining year of the franchise term, but not less than four thousand five hundred dollars ($4,500.00). The transfer fee shall be paid within thirty (30) days after the date of sale, transfer, assignment, or lease. Such transfer fee shall not be recovered from the subscribers through rates or by itemized surcharge, or excluded from gross income, but shall be a part of the cost of doing business. 
    9-12.6 Conditions of acceptance. Grantor's acceptance of any payment shall not constitute agreement that the payment is in fact the correct amount, and such acceptance of payment shall not constitute a release of any claim grantor may have for further or additional sums payable under the provisions of the franchise or any other claim whatsoever that grantor may have. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-13.0. - Enforcement. 
    9-13.1 Bonds and indemnities. Nothing herein shall be deemed to prevent or impair the right or power of grantor to claim against any bond or indemnity executed or provided for the protection or benefit of grantor. All such bonds and indemnities shall become actionable at grantor's sole discretion upon any of the express conditions therein or upon any substantial breach of this chapter or of the franchise. 
    9-13.2 Forfeiture and termination: liquidated damages. 
9-13.2.1 Substantial breach. In addition to all other rights and powers retained by grantor under this chapter, grantor reserves the right to forfeit and terminate the franchise in the event of an uncured substantial breach of the provisions specified below for the applicable periods specified, and as defined elsewhere herein: 
(a)  Failure to notify grantor of change of ownership or control (thirty (30) days); 
(b)  Failure to provide financial information (thirty (30) days); 
(c)  Failure to satisfy technical requirements regarding system characteristics, or failure to meet technical performance standards as provided herein (thirty (30) days); 
(d)  Failure to provide any service to any person as required by this chapter and the franchise (sixty (60) days); 
(e)  Abandonment of the cable system in whole or in part without prior written consent of grantor (ten (10) days); 
(f)  Failure to provide and maintain insurance, surety and indemnity or failure to notify grantor of expiration of insurance (one (1) day); 
(g)  Failure to comply with the consumer standards as provided in this chapter and the franchise (thirty (30) days); 
(h)  Failure to make any payments as required (ten (10) days); 
(i)  Failure to supply and equip the access channels and other support, and any related services, equipment and facilities (sixty (60) days); 
(j)  Engaging in a course of conduct constituting perpetration of any fraud or deceit upon grantor, any subscriber, or any other user of the system at any time or the entry of a finding of guilt or liability, or a plea of no contest to any criminal charge or civil allegation of fraud against grantee or its parent company or its assigns in any jurisdiction; or upon any violation of or finding of civil liability in any jurisdiction with respect to unlawful discrimination as particularly defined under the laws of the State of Florida or the United States of America. (Effective immediately upon notice.); 
(k)  Taking any material action at any time which requires the approval or consent of grantor without having first obtained such approval or consent (thirty (30) days for corrective action); 
(l)  At any time, making any false entry knowingly in the books or accounts or records of grantee or in any books, records, or documents relied upon by grantor, by grantee, any director, officer or other person holding a controlling interest in grantee, or any affiliated person or employee or agent of grantee acting under the express direction or with the actual consent of grantee, or providing false certification to material conditions as required in this CATV Ordinance or in the franchise issued pursuant hereto; 
(m)  Failure to complete rebuild of the system in the specified time (sixty (60) days); 
(n)  Any written misrepresentation intentionally made by or on behalf of grantee in its proposal for the franchise granted pursuant to this chapter or in connection with the negotiation or renegotiation of or any other modification to the franchise agreement or chapter (immediate action); 
(o)  Failure to reasonably cooperate at any time with any lawful investigation, audit or inquiry conducted by or authorized by grantor (immediate action); 
(p)  Failure to correct deficiencies in the system following tests as provided and/or retests as provided in section 9-9.0 (sixty (60) days); 
(q)  Accumulation of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in liquidated damages over any one-year period, provided, however, that no such liquidated damages shall be deemed to continue during a bona-fide dispute after notice from grantee that grantee will dispute such liquidated damages. Should such dispute(s) be ruled in favor of grantor, however, such liquidated damages shall be deemed to run from the date of such violation. 
9-13.2.2 Liquidated damages. If grantee fails to fulfill any of its obligations under the terms of this chapter or the franchise issued pursuant hereto, grantor may assess grantee and grantee agrees to pay grantor monetary liquidated damages in accordance with the schedule set forth below. The liquidated damages set forth below shall not be the exclusive monetary remedy for the named breaches, and shall not constitute a waiver by grantor of any other right or remedy it may have under this chapter or under applicable law. Any such liquidated damage shall be recoverable from the performance bond, at the option of grantor. 
(a)  Failure to keep business office open during established business hours or to provide emergency service in accordance with section 9-5.0. (One hundred dollars ($100.00) per day.) 
(b)  Failure to comply with the provisions of section 9-2.9.2 change of ownership. (One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day.) 
(c)  Failure to test the system or provide reports thereof as required hereunder and by the FCC. (One hundred dollars ($100.00) per day.) 
(d)  Failure to render payment of franchise fees within the time specified in section 9-14.5 and the franchise. Annual rate of twelve (12) percent, or two (2) percent over prime, whichever is higher, computed daily from time due until paid, plus an initial amount of five (5) percent of amount due, but in no event higher than the maximum amount permitted by law. 
(e)  Failure to comply with provisions of section 9-10.0 Insurance; Bonding. (One hundred dollars ($100.00) per day.) 
(f)  Failure to make a timely filing of annual financial report or maintain open records as required herein. (One hundred dollars ($100.00) per day.) 
(g)  Failure to maintain the technical performance standards required herein and by the FCC. (Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day.) 
(h)  Failure to comply with any other obligation contained in this chapter or future amendments hereto. (One hundred dollars ($100.00) per day.) 
(i)  Failure to build or rebuild the system as provided in the franchise granted pursuant to this chapter. (One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day). 
These liquidated damages shall be in addition to, and not a limitation on, the other provisions of this chapter including forfeiture and termination. Any damages under this part shall be subject to judicial review at the request of grantee. 
    9-13.3 Procedure for revocation of franchise or imposition of liquidated damages. 
9-13.3.1 Notice and opportunity to cure. Should grantor desire to invoke forfeiture of the franchise or imposition of liquidated damages as set forth herein, grantor shall make a written notice by certified or hand-delivered mail upon grantee's general manager at its local office to comply with any provision, rule or determination which it feels grantee has breached. If the breach by grantee is uncured for the period specified in section 9-13.2.1 in the case of forfeitures or ten (10) days in the case of liquidated damages, following such written demand, grantor may revoke the franchise or impose a liquidated damage, as appropriate. 
Should grantee dispute that a breach has occurred, grantee may request grantor to hold a hearing pursuant to section 9-13.3.2. Grantor may, at its option, suspend the time for cure until after final determination is made regarding whether a breach has, in fact, occurred, provided, however, that any liquidated damages or breach shall be deemed to run and be calculated from the date of grantor's original notice under this section in the event grantee shall fail in its effort to dispute that a breach has occurred. Any liquidated damages under this part shall be subject to judicial review at the request of grantee. 
9-13.3.2 Hearing. Should grantor desire to revoke the franchise or impose liquidated damages, and grantee requests a hearing under section 9-13.3.1 above, grantor shall provide grantee an opportunity to appear in a public hearing to present its argument, including the opportunity to offer evidence and question witnesses. Based on the evidence at such hearing, grantor shall determine and set forth in writing whether grantee was in breach of the chapter or franchise and, if so, if grantee has failed to cure or take substantial steps to cure such breach within the allotted time. Any liquidated damages under this part shall be subject to judicial review at the request of grantee. 
9-13.3.3 Computation of liquidated damage. Computation of liquidated damages shall begin on the day notice is received by grantee and shall continue until the breach is cured. 
    9-13.4 Force majeure; waiver of breach or liquidated damage. 
9-13.4.1 Force majeure. Grantee shall not be deemed in breach of this chapter or the franchise for any failure to perform which results from circumstances not under grantee's reasonable control, such as war, civil disturbance, strike, natural catastrophe, or acts of God. Grantee shall not be excused by economic hardship or by misfeasance or malfeasance of its directors, officers, employees, affiliates or parent. 
9-13.4.2 No waiver. Grantee shall not be relieved of its obligations to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter or the franchise by reason of failure or delay of grantor to enforce prompt compliance. Any waiver by grantor of a breach or violation of any provision of this chapter or the franchise shall not operate as or be construed to be a waiver of any subsequent or prior breach. 
    9-13.5 Removal after expiration or revocation; option to purchase. 
9-13.5.1 Removal. At the expiration and non-renewal of the term of the franchise or its revocation, grantor shall have the right to require grantee to remove, at grantee's expense, all or any portion of the system from all streets and public property within the territorial limits. In so removing the system, grantee shall backfill and compact, at its own expense, any excavation that shall be made and shall leave all streets, public property and private property in the same condition as that prevailing prior to grantee's removal of the system, and without affecting, altering or disturbing, in any way, any electric, telephone or utility cables, wires or attachments or other facilities. Grantor shall have the right to inspect and approve the condition of the streets and public property after removal and to require appropriate repair or replacement. Grantee's bond and indemnity shall remain in full force and effect during the entire term of removal. 
9-13.5.2 Disposal. If grantee has failed to commence removal of the system, or such part thereof as was designated, within thirty (30) days after written notice of grantor's demand for removal is given, or if grantee has failed to complete such removal within one (1) year after written notice of grantor's demand for removal is given, grantor shall have the right to cause the system, or such part thereof as grantor shall designate, to be removed at grantee's cost. The cost of removal shall be recoverable from the letter of credit and bond provided for in the franchise and herein, and from grantee directly. 
9-13.5.3 Option to purchase. Notwithstanding any other provisions herein, grantor shall have the option, upon revocation for cause of the franchise or in the event of non-renewal of an expired franchise, to purchase the cable system. If grantor elects to purchase the Cable System, the price shall be determined on the basis of a binding appraisal, rendered by a mutually-selected appraiser, in accordance with § 627 (47 USC 547) of the 1984 Cable Act, as amended. 
    9-13.6 Resolution of disputes. All disputes between grantor and grantee arising out of any franchise granted under this chapter or otherwise in effect at the time of its adoption shall be resolved in the following manner: 
9-13.6.1 Mediation. The parties shall first submit the issues in dispute to a mediator mutually agreed upon by them or appointed by the American Arbitration Association. 
9-13.6.2 Litigation. In the event any issue in dispute remains unresolved after the mediation procedure provided herein, then either party may file an action for relief in the Seventh Judicial Circuit Court in and for St. Johns County, Florida, or the United States District Court for the Middle District of Florida, which shall have exclusive venue over all such unresolved disputes. 
9-13.6.3 Remedies. In addition to any other remedy allowed at law or in equity, grantor shall be allowed recovery of reasonable attorney's fees and expenses of prosecution of its claims or defense if grantor prevails on any one or more of the issues in dispute that are taken to litigation. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-14.0. - Application for franchise or renewal. 
    An application for a CATV franchise or a CATV franchise renewal must be accompanied by a filing fee and must contain the following information, as appropriate: 
    9-14.1 Identification. The name, address and telephone number of the applicant. 
    9-14.2 Description of applicant. A detailed description of the corporate or other business-entity organization of the applicant, including but not limited to the following and to whatever extent required by Grantor. 
9-14.2.1 Staff. The names, residence and business addresses, and phone numbers of all officers, directors, and associates of the applicant. 
9-14.2.2 Ownership. The names, residences, business addresses and phone numbers of all persons having, being entitled to have or control, or controlling one (1) percent or more of the ownership of the applicant; and all parents and affiliates of the applicant, and the respective ownership share of each such person. 
9-14.2.3 Parents, affiliates, etc. The names and addresses and phone numbers of any parents or affiliates or subsidiaries of the applicant, i.e., any other business entities owning or controlling the applicant, in whole or in part, or owned or controlled in whole or in part by the applicant, and a statement of the nature of any such parent or subsidiary business entity, including but not limited to cable television systems, broadcast stations, newspapers, magazines, and/or telephones companies owned or controlled by the applicant, its parent and subsidiaries, and the areas served thereby. 
9-14.2.4 Previous experience. A detailed description of the previous experience of the applicant in providing cable television service and in related or similar fields. 
    9-14.3 Application. 
9-14.3.1 Projections. Detailed pro forma projections over the first ten (10) years of operation of the system under the new or renewed franchise, by year: numbers of subscribers by tier, rates by tier, revenues in detail, expenses in detail, capital expenditures, administrative expenses, depreciation, interest, cash flow, and balance sheet. 
9-14.3.2 Financial statement. Provide a detailed and complete financial statement for the applicant, its parents and/or its subsidiaries. Financial statements shall be prepared by a certified public accountant, for the full fiscal year next preceding the date of the application hereunder, and: 
(a)  If applicable, a letter or other acceptable evidence in writing from a recognized lending institution or funding source, addressed to the applicant and the City of St. Augustine, setting forth the basis for studies performed by such lending institution or funding source, and a clear statement of its intent as a lending institution or funding source to provide whatever capital will be required by the applicant to construct or rebuild and operate the proposed system, or 
(b)  A statement from a certified public account certifying that the applicant has available sufficient free, net and uncommitted cash resources to upgrade or construct and operate the proposed system, and has allocated such funds for such purpose, or 
(c)  A sworn or attested from an authorized company officer, certifying that the applicant has available sufficient free, net and uncommitted cash resources to upgrade or construct and operate the proposed system as proposed, and has allocated such funds for such purpose. 
9-14.3.3 Other franchises; operating systems. A statement identifying, by place and date, any other cable television franchises awarded to the applicant, its parent or subsidiary; the status of such franchises with respect to completion thereof; the cost of completion of such system(s); the amount of applicant's and its parents' or subsidiaries' resources committed to the completion thereof. 
9-14.3.4 System plant description, design data (existing plant). 
(a)  As-Builts: Top Drawings-Maps (detailed drawings not necessary) 
(b)  System Design Parameters 
(c)  List of Equipment-Headend Equipment; antennas; Cable, Fiber, Fittings, Splices, Passives, etc.: Mfr, Make, Model Number 
(d)  Local-Origination Facilities: Make, Model, Mfr 
(e)  Access Facilities: Make, Model, Mfr 
(f)  Test Equipment: Make, Model, Mfr 
(g)  Vehicles, Tools, Support Equipment, Spares, Inventory: Other Physical Plant 
9-14.3.5 System test data. 
(a)  FCC Performance Test Report. 
(b)  FCC CLI Test Report. 
    9-14.4 Operations. A detailed description of the proposed plan of operation of the applicant which shall include but not be limited to the following: 
9-14.4.1 A statement or schedule listing all proposed classifications of rates and charges, including installation charges and service charges, extra service, bad checks, etc.. 
9-14.4.2 A detailed list of channels provided, by tier. 
9-14.4.3 A detailed, informative, and referenced statement describing the existing system operational standards; system technical standards and construction standards which will be used by the applicant. 
9-14.4.4 A detailed description of the technologies to be used, particularly in respect to extension policy and optimum service to all areas, including clear evidence of the feasibility of any planned new technologies. 
9-14.4.5 Consumer-oriented subscriber-service standards. Applicant shall set forth technical, operating, and service standards for the proposed system, which shall meet or exceed FCC requirements and NCTA Standards. 
    9-14.5 Payments. Applicant shall specify the following payments in the application, to be made at the times defined below: 
9-14.5.1 Franchise fees. Amount of franchise-fee rates and payments may be established by grantor at any time in accordance with new or existing applicable law. 
9-14.5.2 Filing fee. (Must accompany application, balance thirty (30) days after invoice): 
(a)  For a new franchise: Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(b)  For a renewal of a franchise: Five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(c)  For a transfer: per year remaining in the term: One thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) or a minimum of four thousand five hundred dollars ($4,500.00). 
(d)  For modification pursuant to 47 USC § 545: Five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
9-14.5.3 Reimbursement of the incidental costs of the ascertainment and franchising process. (Thirty (30) days after invoice;) 
9-14.5.4 Capital equipment and/or grants. List of access equipment, or amount of grant, to be provided to grantor, and details of payment/financial arrangements. 
9-14.5.5 Transfer fee. For any sale, transfer, assignment, or lease by the franchisee of rights under the franchise requiring consent of grantor. (Thirty (30) days after execution of franchise.) 
    9-14.6 Upgrade plans; design data; capital budget. Details of any plans for upgrade/rebuild of existing physical plant: 
(a)  Map; drawing. A detailed map indicating all areas proposed to be served, and a proposed construction time schedule for the complete upgrade or rebuild of the system as necessary to become state-of-the-art and/or to provide for the present and future needs of the community, throughout the entire area to be served. 
a.  A complete set of design parameters and specifications. 
b.  A set of top design drawings (detailed drawings not necessary). 
c.  List of equipment, parts, accessories, and materials to be used - By manufacturer, model number, type, description, specifications. 
d.  Planned construction and test schedule, with milestones. 
    9-14.7 Access channels and facilities. Applications for an initial or renewed franchise shall include proposals for the provision of public, educational, and governmental access channels sufficient to meet community needs as determined by grantor. An applicant shall specify what provision or grants it is willing to make for studio equipment and facilities to be used for local program production by all cable access users. Applicants are encouraged to include proposals for local origination programming by grantee. 
    9-14.8 Other data. Applicant may provide any additional information of possible interest to grantor. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-15.0. - Acceptance of franchise. 
    Grantee shall file its written acceptance of the franchise and/or enabling document granted pursuant hereto, along with exhibits thereto, within twenty (20) business days after the final grant of the franchise or enabling document, respectively. 
(Ord. No. 94-37, § 1, 10-10-94) 
Sec. 9-16.0. - Open books and records. 
    Grantee shall make available on a proprietary basis, upon written request by grantor, complete and accurate books of account, records, maps, plans and other like materials of the company applicable to the ownership and operation of the system. Grantor shall have the right to inspect grantee's operation at intervals and for reasons related to the enforcement, compliance, and administration of this chapter and the franchise and to obtain any applicable information which has not otherwise been provided to grantor. Grantor, if it has reasonable basis to believe such has not been reported fairly or accurately, shall have the right to examine such books and records in detail.
