(b)  Service rendered prior to June 1, 1977, shall be credited to a participant's service account on June 1, 1977, to the extent such service was in force and the basis of retirement benefits on May 31, 1977, in the general employees' pension plan. 
(c)  Service rendered by a participant during a period he was excluded from participation as provided in section 20-103(b)(3) shall be credited to the participant's service account on the effective date of his participation, to the extent such service was in force and the basis of retirement benefits under such other retirement or pension program on the day preceding the effective date of his participation. Service rendered by a participant during any other period he was excluded from participation as provided in section 20-103(b) shall not be credited. 
(d)  A participant who has rendered service after the date he attained age fifty-five (55) years, but prior to the date he becomes a participant in the retirement system, which has not been credited as provided in subsection (b) because he was not a participant during the period, shall have all or a selected portion of such service credited to his service account upon payment of the lump sum amount described in the next sentence to the retirement systems. Payment shall be made within six (6) months of becoming a participant in this retirement system. The lump sum payment shall be equal to the amount of participant contributions he would have made during the period of service claimed plus interest at the rate of three (3) percent a year, compounded yearly, from the date the contribution would have been made to the day of payment. 
(e)  In no case shall service which is the basis of a benefit under any other retirement or pension program, except the federal social security program, be credited a participant under this retirement system. 
(f)  Any participant who was continuously employed by the city from June 1, 1977 through September 30, 2001, and who elected not to participate in the retirement system at any time during the participant's continuous employment, may elect to buy back up to twelve (12) months of credited service, but in no event may such participant buy back more than the number of months needed to attain twenty-five (25) years of credited service. An eligible participant will be credited with the additional months of credited service upon payment to the retirement system of the total amount of participant contributions that would have been due for such service, plus interest at the rate of three (3) percent per annum from the time of the additional credited service purchased to the date of payment. 
(g)  For participants who terminate city employment on or after the effective date of this ordinance, "credited service" shall also include up to three (3) years of active duty in the U.S. armed forces or full-time employment with another governmental entity prior to employment by the city, purchased by the participant in accordance with this subsection; provided the participant has not received and will not receive a benefit from another retirement plan based on such prior employment. Such purchased service may not be used for vesting purposes. An eligible participant may purchase credited service under the system for such prior employment by paying into the fund the full actuarial cost of such credited service, as determined by the plan actuary. Such payment must be made in full prior to separation from city employment. In the event full payment is not made prior to such date, the participant shall receive only the amount of credited service, as determined by the actuary, for which the payment made, excluding interest, is the full actuarial cost. A participant purchasing such additional credited service must also pay the full cost of any actuarial calculations required. Payment for the purchase of credited service pursuant to this paragraph may be made using any one or a combination of the following options: 
(1)  Cash lump sum payment. 
(2)  Installment payments, plus simple interest at the rate of four (4) percent per annum, deducted from the participant's city salary over a period not to exceed five (5) years. 
(3)  Direct transfer or rollover of an eligible rollover distribution from a qualified or eligible plan, in accordance with section 20-146. 
(Code 1964, § 20-138; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 06-06, § 2, 2-13-06) 
Sec. 20-105. - Loss of credited service. 
    A person's credited service shall be forfeited and no longer in force in the event the person's accumulated contributions are withdrawn from the reserve for participant contributions and paid to the person or a beneficiary (including an estate). 
(Code 1964, § 20-139; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-106. - Reinstatement of credited service. 
    A participant may have forfeited credited service restored to his individual service account upon satisfaction of each of the following conditions: 
(1)  The retirement system is paid the total amount of accumulated contributions previously withdrawn plus regular interest from the date(s) of withdrawal to the date(s) of repayment. Repayment shall be made in accordance with such rules as the board shall from time to time prescribe, over a period not to exceed five (5) years. 
(2)  The benefit rate for credited service restored pursuant to this section shall be the benefit rate applicable to the period of the previous service. 
(Code 1964, § 20-140; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 08-27, § 1, 1-12-09) 
Sec. 20-107. - Military service credit. 
    A person who leaves or left city employment to perform "Qualified Military Service" including voluntary or involuntary service in the armed forces of the United States as defined in the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act (USERRA) (P.L. 103-353), as amended from time to time, shall have required periods of active duty credited as city service subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The person is reemployed by the city within ninety (90) days from and after the date of termination of required active duty. 
(2)  The person becomes a participant and pays the retirement system the total amount of accumulated contributions previously withdrawn, if any, plus regular interest from the date(s) of withdrawal to date(s) of repayment. 
(3)  In no case shall more than five (5) years of service be credited on account of all military service. 
    This section is intended to satisfy the minimum requirements of USERRA, as may be amended from time to time. To the extent that this section does not meet the minimum requirements of USERRA, the provisions of USERRA shall govern. The board shall determine the amount of service to be credited a participant under the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1964, § 20-141; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 10-32, § 2, 10-11-10) 
Sec. 20-108. - Normal and reduced early retirement conditions. 
(a)  A person may retire upon satisfaction of each of the following conditions: 
(1)  The person has filed written application or retirement with the board, setting forth the date, not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days subsequent to the execution and filing thereof, retirement is to be effective. 
(2)  The person terminates all city employment prior to the date retirement is to be effective. 
(3)  The person has met an applicable age and service condition for retirement. 
(b)  The age and service conditions for normal retirement are as follows: 
(1)  The person has attained age sixty-five (65) years or older and has five (5) or more years of credited service. 
(2)  The person has attained age sixty (60) years or older and has ten (10) or more years of credited service. 
(3)  The person has attained age fifty-five (55) years, or older and has twenty-five (25) years of credited service. 
Upon normal retirement as provided in this section a person shall be paid a retirement allowance computed according to section 20-110. 
(c)  The age and service conditions for reduced early retirement are that the person has attained age fifty (50) years or older and has ten (10) or more years of credited service but has not satisfied an age and service condition for normal retirement. 
    Upon reduced early retirement as provided in this section a person shall be paid a percentage of a retirement allowance computed according to section 20-110. The percentage shall be one hundred (100) percent reduced by one-half (1/2) of one (1) percent for each month and fraction of a month reduced early retirement precedes the date the person would have satisfied age and service conditions for normal retirement had he continued in city employment; provided, for participants who terminate city employment after attaining age fifty (50) with ten (10) or more years of service on or after the effective date of this section, the percentage shall be one hundred (100) percent reduced by one-fourth (1/4) of one (1) percent for each month and fraction of a month reduced early retirement precedes the date the person would have satisfied the age conditions for normal retirement but based on credited service at the time of termination. 
(Code 1964, § 20-142; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 06-06, § 3, 2-13-06) 
Sec. 20-109. - Vested termination of membership (deferred retirement). 
(a)  A person who ceases to be a participant, for a reason other than retirement or death, on or after satisfaction of an applicable age and credited service condition specified in subsection (b) shall be entitled to retire upon satisfaction of the conditions for normal retirement specified in section 20-108. Upon retirement the person shall be paid a retirement allowance computed according to section 20-110 as the section provided at the time of last termination of participation. 
(b)  The age and credited service conditions for vested termination of participation are ten (10) years of credited service without regard to age. 
(c)  Withdrawal of a person's accumulated contributions and loss of credited service as provided in section 20-105 shall constitute a forfeiture of all rights in and to retirement and the retirement allowance otherwise provided in this section. 
(Code 1964, § 20-144; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-110. - Amount of retirement allowance. 
(a)  A participant who terminates employment before the effective date of this article and retires after June 1, 1977, shall be paid a basic retirement allowance provided in subsection (b) and, if applicable, a temporary retirement allowance provided in subsection (c). 
(b)  The amount of basic retirement allowance shall be equal to the retirant's credited service, to a maximum of thirty-five (35) years, multiplied by two (2) percent of his final average compensation. 
(c)  A temporary supplemental retirement allowance shall be paid the retirant if his date of retirement precedes his sixty-fifth birth date. The amount of temporary supplemental retirement allowance shall be equal to the retirant's credited service, to a maximum of thirty-five (35) years, multiplied by one-half (1/2) of one (1) percent of his final average compensation. The temporary supplemental retirement allowance terminates upon the retirant's attainment of age sixty-five (65) years or his prior death. 
(d)  A participant who terminates employment and retires after the effective date of this article shall be paid a basic retirement allowance equal to the retirant's credited service, to a maximum of thirty-five (35) years, multiplied by two and one-half (21/2) percent of final average compensation. 
(Code 1964, § 20-145; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-111. - Standard form of benefit; retirement allowance to spouse and/or children of deceased participant or retirant. 
(a)  The standard form of benefit for members hired on or after February 1, 2014 and members with less than ten (10) years of credited service on that date shall be a straight life annuity. Prior to retirement such members may elect, in lieu of a straight life annuity, an optional form of payment as provided in section 20-112. 
(b)  Members with ten (10) or more years of credited service on February 1, 2014 may elect, prior to retirement, to receive a standard form of benefit as follows: (1) the member's frozen accrued benefit as of February 1, 2014, payable as a monthly annuity for the member's life, with a continuing benefit to the retirant's eligible spouse and children following the retirant's death in accordance with subsections (c) through (e) of this section; or (2) the member's accrued benefit as of termination of employment payable as a monthly annuity for the member's life, with a continuing benefit to the retirant's eligible spouse or eligible domestic partner and children following the retirant's death computed as follows: 
(1)  If the member is within three and one-half (31/2) years of earliest eligibility for normal retirement on February 1, 2014, a continuing benefit payable to the retirant's eligible spouse or eligible domestic partner and children following the retirant's death in accordance with subsections (c) through (e) of this section. 
(2)  If the member is three and one-half (31/2) years or more, but less than four and one-half (41/2) years from earliest eligibility for normal retirement on February 1, 2014, the continuing benefit to the retirant's eligible spouse or eligible domestic partner and children following the retirant's death shall be computed in accordance with subsections (c) through (e) of this section, but shall be reduced by one (1) percent. If the member elects another optional form of benefit as provided in section 20-112, the benefit shall be reduced by the actuarial equivalent of the straight life annuity value. 
(3)  If the member is four and one-half (41/2) years or more, but less than five and one-half (51/2) years from earliest eligibility for normal retirement on February 1, 2014, the continuing benefit to the retirant's eligible spouse or eligible domestic partner and children following the retirant's death shall be computed in accordance with subsections (c) through (e) of this section, but shall be reduced by two (2) percent. If the member elects another optional form of benefit as provided in section 20-112, the benefit shall be reduced by the actuarial equivalent of the straight life annuity value. 
(4)  If the member is five and one-half (51/2) years or more, but less than six and one-half (61/2) years from earliest eligibility for normal retirement on February 1, 2014, the continuing benefit to the retirant's eligible spouse or eligible domestic partner and children following the retirant's death shall be computed in accordance with subsections (c) through (e) of this section, but shall be reduced by three (3) percent. If the member elects another optional form of benefit as provided in section 20-112, the benefit shall be reduced the actuarial equivalent of the straight life annuity value. 
(5)  If the member is six and one-half (61/2) years or more, but less than seven and one-half (71/2) years from earliest eligibility for normal retirement on February 1, 2014, the continuing benefit to the retirant's eligible spouse or eligible domestic partner and children following the retirant's death shall be computed in accordance with subsections (c) through (e) of this section, but shall be reduced by four (4) percent. If the member elects another optional form of benefit as provided in section 20-112, the benefit shall be reduced by the actuarial equivalent of the straight life annuity value. 
(6)  If the member is seven and one-half (71/2) years or more, but less than eight and one-half (81/2) years from earliest eligibility for normal retirement on February 1, 2014, the continuing benefit to the retirant's eligible spouse or eligible domestic partner and children following the retirant's death shall be computed in accordance with subsections (c) through (e) of this section, but shall be reduced by five (5) percent. If the member elects another optional form of benefit as provided in section 20-112, the benefit shall be reduced by the actuarial equivalent of the straight life annuity value. 
(7)  If the member is eight and one-half (81/2) or more years from earliest eligibility for normal retirement on February 1, 2014, the member's standard form of benefit shall be a straight life annuity; provided that the member may elect another optional form of benefit as provided in section 20-112, which is the actuarial equivalent of the straight life annuity. 
(c)  For members who are active participants on or after February 1, 2014, applicable retirement allowances provided in subsections (d) and (e) shall be paid in the event of the death of a participant who dies while in the employ of the city with five (5) or more years of credited service in force. The credited service requirement of five (5) years shall be waived if the board finds the participant's death to have been the natural and proximate result of causes arising out of and in the course of the participant's actual performance of duty in the employ of the city. The board shall adopt such procedures and make such investigations as it deems necessary to make a determination on the waiver of the five (5) years. Any death benefits applicable to retirees will be paid in accordance with the form annuity in effect at death. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided in subsections (a), (b) and (c), the eligible spouse of the deceased participant or the deceased retirant, if any, and eligible children, if any, shall each be paid a retirement allowance equal to a percentage of the deceased participant's projected retirement allowance or the retirant's actual retirement allowance, as the case may be. The percentage shall be in accordance with the following schedule: 
Percentage Survivors Eligible Spouse or eligible 
Domestic Partner Eligible 
Children (in 
equal shares) Spouse or eligible domestic partner and no children 60 - Spouse or eligible domestic partner and 1 child 60 10 Spouse or eligible domestic partner and 2 or more children 60 20 1 child and no spouse or eligible domestic partner - 40 2 children and no spouse or eligible domestic partner - 50 3 or more children and no spouse or eligible domestic partner - 60  
(1)  An eligible spouse is the person to whom the deceased participant had been married at least one (1) year on the date of his death or the person to whom the deceased retirant was married at the date of his retirement and to whom he had been married at least one (1) year on the date of his death. A spouse's retirement allowance shall terminate upon the death of the spouse. 
(2)  An eligible domestic partner is a person to whom the deceased participant had been the domestic partner to for at least one (1) year on the date of his death or the person to whom the deceased retirant was a domestic partner at the date of his retirement and to whom he had been a domestic partner for at least one (1) year on the date of his death. A spouse's or domestic partner's retirement allowance shall terminate upon the death of the spouse or domestic partner. A domestic partner is defined as a person who is in a committed domestic partnership relationship with a participant, and who: 
a.  Is at least eighteen (18) years old and competent to contract; 
b.  Is not currently in a marriage relationship recognized under Florida law; 
c.  Is not currently a partner in a domestic partnership relationship or a member of civil union with anyone else; 
d.  Is not a blood relative, where one is a direct ascendant or direct descendant of the other (such as a son, daughter, parent, or grandparent), or a sister, brother, aunt, uncle, niece or nephew; 
e.  Consents to the domestic partnership; 
f.  Agrees to be jointly responsible in the support of the domestic partnership; 
g.  Considers himself or herself as being in a committed domestic relationship with the participant, and considers himself or herself to be a member of the immediate family of the participant; and 
h.  Declares in writing that the above requirements are met. 
(3)  An eligible child is a child of the deceased participant or the deceased retirant, which child is both unmarried and under the age of nineteen (19) years (twenty-two (22) years if successfully attending a board-recognized accredited school for at least eight (8) months a year). A child's retirement allowance shall terminate upon his ceasing to be an eligible child or upon his prior death, and the retirement allowance of each remaining eligible child shall be recomputed. 
(e)  A deceased participant's projected retirement allowance shall be computed as provided in section 20-110, based on his final average compensation and credited service at the date of his death. If the deceased participant was under age sixty (60) years on the date of his death, and his credited service is less than twenty (20) years, then and in that event, his projected retirement allowance shall be calculated on the basis of twenty (20) years of credited service. 
(f)  The temporary supplemental retirement allowance portion of the deceased participant's total projected retirement allowance or the deceased retirant's total retirement allowance shall not be considered for the purposes of this section unless the spouse and/or children of the deceased participant or retirant have applied for and been denied monthly benefits under the federal social security program. 
(g)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this plan, if a participant dies on or after January 1, 2007 while performing qualified military service as defined by USERRA, the participant's beneficiaries shall be entitled to any benefits the participant would have been entitled to under this plan had he or she resumed employment and then died while employed. 
(Code 1964, § 20-146; Ord. No. 95-14, § 1, 3-27-95; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 10-32, § 3, 10-11-10; Ord. No. 14-03, § 1, 3-24-14) 
Sec. 20-112. - Optional forms of payment of a retirement allowance. 
(a)  A retiring person may elect to be paid under one (1) of the following optional forms of payment in lieu of the straight life form of payment. The election must be made in writing and filed with the board prior to the date retirement is effective. Payment will be made under the level straight life form of payment if a timely election of an optional form of payment is not made. The amount of retirement allowance under each optional form of payment shall be the actuarial equivalent of the amount of the retirement allowance under the straight life form of payment. 
(b)  Election of an optional form of payment will preclude payment of any automatic retirement allowance to the retirant's eligible spouse and/or children, if any. 
(1)  Form of payment A120-One hundred twenty (120) months certain and life retirement allowance. Under form of payment A120 the retirant shall be paid a reduced retirement allowance for life with the provision that if the retirant's death occurs before one hundred twenty (120) monthly payments have been made the full reduced retirement allowance shall continue to be paid for the remainder of the one hundred twenty (120) months to such person or persons, and in such shares as the retirant shall have designated in writing and filed with the board. If there be no such designated person surviving, the remaining monthly payments shall be computed and paid to the estate of the last survivor among the retirant and the designated person or persons. 
(2)  Form of payment A180-One hundred eighty (180) months certain and life retirement allowance. Under form of payment A180 the retirant shall be paid a reduced retirement allowance for life with the provision that if the retirant's death occurs before one hundred eighty (180) monthly payments have been made the full reduced retirement allowance shall continue to be paid for the remainder of the one hundred eighty (180) months to such person or persons, and in such shares as the retirant shall have designated in writing and filed with the board. If there be no such designated person surviving, the remaining monthly payments shall be commuted and paid to the estate of the last survivor among the retirant and the designated person or persons. 
(3)  Form of payment B50-Fifty (50) percent survivor beneficiary retirement allowance. Under form of payment B50 the retirant shall be paid a reduced retirement allowance for life with the provision that upon his death fifty (50) percent of the reduced pension retirement allowance shall be continued throughout the future lifetime of and paid to such person, having an insurable interest in his life, as the retirant shall have designated in writing and filed with the board. 
(4)  Form of payment B75-Seventy-five (75) percent survivor beneficiary retirement allowance. Under form of payment B75 the retirant shall be paid a reduced retirement allowance for life with the provision that upon his death three-quarters (3/4) of the reduced retirement allowance shall be continued throughout the future lifetime of and paid to such person, having an insurable interest in his life, as the retirant shall have designated in writing and filed with the board. 
(Code 1964, § 20-147; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-113. - Terminal payment. 
    In the event all retirement allowance payments terminate before there has been paid an aggregate amount equal to the retirant's accumulated contributions at the time retirement was effective, the difference, if any, between the retirant's accumulated contributions and the aggregate amount of retirement allowance payments made shall be paid to such person as the retirant shall have designated in writing and filed with the board. If there be no such person surviving the retirant, the difference, if any, shall be paid to the legal representative of the last to survive of the retirant and such designated persons. The provisions of this section shall not apply if the retirant elected payment under form of payment A120 or form of payment A180 provided in section 20-112. 
(Code 1964, § 20-148; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-114. - Disability benefits. 
(a)  A participant with five (5) or more years of credited service who terminates city employment by reason of a disability in the line of duty shall remain a participant during the period for which he is paid disability benefits. He shall be credited with service considered to have been paid compensation, at a rate equal to his final average compensation computed as of his date of termination of city employment, for the period for which he is paid disability benefits. 
(b)  His contributions to the retirement system shall be waived during the period for which he is paid disability benefits. 
(c)  For the sole and exclusive purposes of section 20-111, he shall be considered to have died while in the employ of the city in the event of his death during a period for which he is paid disability benefits. 
(Code 1964, § 20-149; Ord. No. 88-54, § 10, 9-26-88; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-115. - Refund of participant's accumulated contributions. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, a person who ceases to be a participant for any reason except retirement or death, prior to satisfying any of the applicable age and service requirements for normal retirement provided in section 20-108, shall be paid his accumulated contributions upon written request filed with the board. 
(b)  If a person dies and no retirement allowance becomes or will become payable by the retirement system on account of the death, the deceased person's accumulated contributions shall be paid to such person as the deceased person shall have nominated by written designation duly executed and filed with the board. If there be no such designated person surviving the deceased person, the accumulated contributions shall be paid to the deceased person's legal representative. 
(c)  Payment of accumulated contributions as provided in this section may be made in installments according to such rules as the board may from time to time adopt. 
(Code 1964, § 20-151; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-116. - Time of payment. 
(a)  The entire interest of each employee under this plan: 
(1)  Will be distributed to such employee not later than the required beginning date, or 
(2)  Will be distributed, beginning not later than the required beginning date, in accordance with regulations pertaining to such plan, over the life of such employee or over the lives of such employee and a designated beneficiary (or over a period not extending beyond the life expectancy of such employee or the life expectancy of such employee and a designated beneficiary); and further provided that where an employee dies before such employee's entire interest is distributed and if distribution of the employee's interest has begun in accordance with this subsection (2), the remaining portion of such interest will be distributed at least as rapidly as under the method of distributions being used under this subsection (2) as of the date of his death; and provided further that if the employee dies before distribution of the employee's interest has begun in accordance with this subsection (2), the entire interest of the employee will be distributed within five (5) years after the death of such employee; except that 
(3)  If any portion of the employee's interest is payable to (or for the benefit of) a designated beneficiary such portion will be distributed (in accordance with regulations) over the life of such designated beneficiary (or over a period not extending beyond the life expectancy of such beneficiary), and such distributions begin not later than one (1) year after the date of the employee's death or such later date as regulations under the Internal Revenue Code prescribe, then for the purposes of this section the distribution of the entire interest of the employee will be treated as distributed on the date on which such distributions begin; 
(4)  If the designated beneficiary referred to in subsection (3) above is the surviving spouse of the employee, the date on which the distributions are required to begin to the beneficiary shall not be earlier than the date on which the employee would have attained age seventy and one-half (701/2) and if the surviving spouse dies before the distributions to such spouse begin, this subsection (4) shall be applied as if the surviving spouse were the employee. For purposes of this section, the term "required beginning date" and "designated beneficiary" shall have the meanings provided by Section 401(a)(9)(C) and (E) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. 
    For purposes of this section, the life expectancy of an employee and the employee's spouse (other than in the case of a life annuity) may be redetermined but not more frequently than annually. For purposes of this section, any amount paid to a child shall be treated as if it had been paid to the surviving spouse if such amount will become payable to the surviving spouse upon such child reaching majority or other designated event permitted in accordance with Internal Revenue Code Regulations. Any distribution required under the incidental death benefit requirements of this clause shall be treated as a distribution required under this section; anything otherwise contained in other sections of this plan to the contrary notwithstanding. 
(b)  Unless a participant otherwise elects, payment of benefits under any city pension plan to the participant will begin no later than sixty (60) days after the latest of the close of the plan year in which: 
(1)  The date on which the participant attains the earlier of age sixty-five (65) or the normal retirement age specified under the plan; 
(2)  Occurs the tenth anniversary of the year in which the participant commenced participation in the plan; or 
(3)  The participant terminates his service with the city. 
    In the case of a plan which provides for the payment of an early retirement benefit, a participant who satisfied the service requirements for such early retirement benefit, but separated from the service (with any nonforfeitable right to an accrued benefit) before satisfying the age requirement for such early retirement benefit, is entitled upon satisfaction of such age requirement to receive a benefit not less than the benefit to which he would be entitled at the normal retirement age, actuarially, reduced under Internal Revenue Code Regulations; anything otherwise contained in any such pension plan to the contrary notwithstanding. 
(c)  Distribution of a participant's benefit under this Plan must commence no later than April 1 of the calendar year following the later of the calendar year during which the participant attains age seventy and one-half (70 1/2) or the calendar year in which the participant terminates employment with the Employer. 
(Code 1964, § 20-151.1; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 10-32, § 4, 10-11-10) 
Sec. 20-117. - Benefit accruals. 
    Anything in this plan to the contrary, benefit accruals shall not exceed the limits of section 415 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. 
(Code 1964, § 20-151.2; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-118. - Reserve for participant contributions. 
(a)  The reserve for participant contributions shall be the account in which shall be accumulated, at regular interest, the contributions deducted from the compensation of participants and from which shall be made refunds and transfers of accumulated contributions as provided in this article. 
(b)  From and after June 7, 1977, a participant's contributions to the retirement system shall be five (5) percent of his compensation. 
(c)  The person responsible for preparing the city payroll shall cause the contributions provided for in subsection (b) to be deducted from the compensation of each participant on each and every payroll. The deducted contributions shall be paid to the retirement system and shall be credited to the participant's individual accounts in the reserve for participant contributions. Participant contributions shall be made notwithstanding that the minimum compensation provided by law for any participant shall be changed thereby. Every participant shall be deemed to consent and agree to the deductions made and provided herein. Payment of compensation less the deduction shall be a full and complete discharge and acquittance of all claims and demands whatsoever for services rendered by the participant during the period covered by such payment, except as to benefits provided by the retirement system. The person responsible for preparing the city payroll shall certify to the city director of financial services and the board the amount of contribution deducted from the compensation of each participant on each and every payroll. 
(d)  In addition to the contributions deducted from the compensation of a participant, as hereinbefore provided, a participant may deposit in the reserve for participant contributions the amount of repayment permitted by section 20-106, if any. The deposit may be made in a single sum or by an increased rate of contribution approved by the board. 
(e)  The accumulated contributions of a participant shall be transferred from the reserve for participant contributions to the reserve for retirement allowance payments upon retirement. At the expiration of a period of five (5) years from the date a participant without entitlement to a vested termination retirement allowance provided in section 20-109 ceases to be a participant, any balance in the reserve for participant contributions unclaimed by the person or the person's legal representative shall be transferred to the reserve for undistributed investment income. 
(Code 1964, § 20-152; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-119. - Reserve for retirement allowance payments. 
    The reserve for retirement allowance payments shall be the account from which shall be paid all retirement allowances and residual refunds as provided in this article. Whenever the balance in the reserve for retirement allowance payments exceeds the actuarial value of retirement allowances being paid and likely to be paid retirants and beneficiaries (as reported in the annual actuarial valuation), including specifically established reserves, the excess shall be transferred to the reserve for city contributions. 
(Code 1964, § 20-153; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-120. - Reserve for city contribution. 
(a)  The reserve for city contributions shall be the account to which shall be credited contributions made by the city to the retirement system and from which shall be made transfers as provided in this section. 
(b)  Each year following receipt of the report of the annual actuarial valuation, the excess, if any, of the reported actuarial value of retirement allowances being paid and likely to be paid retirants and beneficiaries over the balance in the reserve for retirement allowance payments shall be transferred from the reserve for city contributions to the reserve for retirement allowance payments. 
(c)  The financial objective of this article is to require city contributions to the retirement system each fiscal year which, together with the contributions made by the participants during the fiscal year, shall be sufficient to fully fund the cost of benefits likely to be paid on account of service rendered by participants during the year and finance unfunded costs of benefits likely to be paid on account of service rendered by members prior to the current year over a period of not more than forty (40) years. Such contributions shall be computed by the actuary as level percentages of participant payroll in accordance with generally accepted actuarial principles. The city shall also contribute the anticipated cost of any insurance coverage provided retirants and beneficiaries, to the extent such cost cannot be covered by the unencumbered balance in the reserve for undistributed investment income. The board shall annually certify to the commission the contributions determined according to this section, and the commission shall appropriate and pay to the retirement system the contributions so certified. 
(Code 1964, § 20-154; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-121. - City contribution to employee's contribution. 
    The city shall make, on behalf of each employee member of the employees' pension fund of the city, a contribution of one-fifth ( 1/5 ) of any contribution otherwise required to be made by each such employee to such pension plan, which city contribution shall be in lieu of one-fifth ( 1/5 ) of the employee member contributions otherwise required to be made, so that each employee member will be required to contribute only four-fifths ( 4/5 ) of that specified as employee member contributions under the terms and conditions of such plan; provided, however, that such contributions to be made by the city under the provisions of this section shall not be regarded as employee contributions for purposes of return of contributions to the employee upon termination from service as may otherwise be permissible or required under the provisions of any such plan and provided further that any employee of the city may elect to make full contributions to his pension plan, in which event no contribution will be made by the city under the terms of this section on behalf of such employee and such employee shall be entitled to full return of contributions made by him to the plan upon termination of services. 
(Ord. No. 88-74, § 2, 10-24-88; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-122. - Reserve for undistributed investment income; expenses. 
    The reserve for undistributed investment income shall be the account to which shall be credited all interest, dividends, and other income from the investment of retirement system assets, all gifts and bequests received by the retirement system, all unclaimed accumulated contributions and retirement allowances, all appropriations for administrative expenses, and all other moneys received by the retirement system the disposition of which is not specifically provided. There shall be transferred from the reserve for undistributed investment income all amounts required to credit regular interest to the reserve for participant contributions, and the reserve for retirement allowance payments, and to pay administrative expenses of the retirement system (to the extent moneys are appropriated for this purpose). Whenever the board determines the balance in the reserve for undistributed investment income is more than sufficient to cover current charges to the account, the excess or any part thereof shall be used to provide necessary contingency reserves, to meet special requirements of the other reserve accounts of the retirement system, or transferred to the reserve for city contributions. Whenever the balance in the reserve for undistributed investment income is insufficient to meet the current charges to the account, the amount of the insufficiency shall be transferred from the reserve for city contributions. 
(Code 1964, § 20-155; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-123. - Allowance of regular interest. 
    The board shall at the end of each fiscal year credit regular interest on the individual balances in the reserve for participant contributions at the beginning of the year and on the mean balances in the reserve for city contributions and the reserve for retirement allowance payments. The amounts so credited shall be charged to the reserve for undistributed investment income. 
(Code 1964, § 20-156; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-124. - Investment of retirement system assets. 
(1)  The board shall be the trustees of the moneys and assets of the retirement system, and shall be responsible for investing the assets of the system in accordance with this section. The board shall exercise its duties with respect to the system for the exclusive purpose of providing benefits to members and their beneficiaries and defraying the reasonable expenses of administering the system. The board shall exercise its investment authority with the care, skill, prudence and diligence under the circumstances then prevailing that a prudent person in a like capacity and familiar with such matters would use in the conduct of an enterprise with like character and like aims, and by diversifying the investments of the system so as to reduce the risk of large losses, unless under the circumstances it is clearly prudent not to do so. The board shall have full power to hold, purchase, sell, assign, transfer and dispose of any of the securities and investments in which any of the assets of the system have been invested, as well as the proceeds of such investments and any moneys belonging to the fund, in accordance with this section. The board may employ outside investment counsel to advise the board in the making and disposition of investments. 
(2)  The board shall adopt and periodically update a written investment policy in accordance with F.S. § 112.661, incorporating the following requirements for specific investments: 
(a)  The board may invest in money market instruments, stocks, corporate bonds, bonds or other obligations of the United States of America, either directly or through pooled or commingled funds. 
(b)  The board may make direct investment in bonds, notes, or obligations of any municipality or political subdivision or any agency or authority of the State of Florida, if the obligations are rated investment grade by at least one (1) nationally recognized rating organization. 
(c)  The board may invest up to fifteen (15) percent of its assets in real estate only through participation in commingled funds or insurance company group annuity separate accounts holding diversified real properties. Insurance companies must be licensed to business in the State of Florida and commingled funds and insurance companies must be rated investment grade by at least one nationally recognized rating organization. Any commingled or pooled vehicles used by the board should have investment guidelines that are materially consistent with the guidelines herein. 
(d)  The board may invest up to fifteen (15) percent of its assets in mortgage loan securities secured by real property only through participation in commingled funds or insurance company separate accounts holding diversified mortgage securities. Insurance companies must be licensed to business in the State of Florida and commingled funds and insurance companies must be rated investment grade by at least one (1) nationally recognized rating organization. Any commingled or pooled vehicles used by the board should have investment guidelines that are materially consistent with the guidelines herein. Mortgage securities of commingled funds must be issued by an agency of or enterprise sponsored by the United States Government, including, but not limited to, the Government National Mortgage Association, the Federal National Mortgage Association, and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. 
(e)  The board may invest up to five (5) percent of its assets in stock and corporate bonds of any one (1) issuing company either directly or through pooled or commingled funds. 
(f)  The aggregate investment in stock either directly or through pooled or commingled funds shall not exceed seventy (70) percent (at cost) of the assets of the fund. 
(g)  The average credit quality of the fixed income portfolio shall be rated "A" or higher. No more than fifteen (15) percent of the fixed income portfolio may be rated lower than "BBB". The duration of the fixed income portfolio shall remain within thirty-five (35) percent of the duration of a market index selected by the board. If there is no index selected, the default index shall be the Lehman Aggregate Bond Index. 
(h)  The board may invest up to twenty-five (25) percent of the assets of the fund in corporate obligations and/or securities of a foreign corporation or a foreign commercial entity that are not subject to United States securities laws. United States dollar-denominated securities listed and traded on a United States exchange would not be included in this limitation. 
(i)  Notwithstanding any provision of this section to the contrary, the board shall identify and publicly report any direct or indirect holdings it may have in any scrutinized company, as defined in F.S. § 215.473, and proceed to sell, redeem, divest, or withdraw all publicly traded securities it may have in that company beginning January 1, 2010. The divestiture of any such security must be completed by September 30, 2010. The board and its named officers or investment advisors may not be deemed to have breached their fiduciary duty in any action taken to dispose of any such security, and the board shall have satisfactorily discharged the fiduciary duties of loyalty, prudence, and sole and exclusive benefit to the participants of the pension fund and their beneficiaries if the actions it takes are consistent with the duties imposed by F.S. § 215.473, and the manner of the disposition, if any, is reasonable as to the means chosen. For the purposes of effecting compliance with that section, the pension fund shall designate terror-free plans that allocate their funds among securities not subject to divestiture. No person may bring any civil, criminal, or administrative action against the board of trustees or any employee, officer, director, or advisor of such pension fund based upon the divestiture of any security pursuant to this paragraph. 
(3)  The board shall deposit the assets of the retirement system in a qualified public depository as defined in F.S. § 280.02(26), which depository with regard to such funds and securities shall conform to and be bound by all of the provisions of F.S. ch. 280. 
(Code 1964, § 20-157; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 08-27, § 2, 1-12-09; Ord. No. 10-32, § 5, 10-11-10) 
Sec. 20-125. - Assets not segregated. 
(a)  All assets of the retirement system shall be held for the sole purpose of meeting disbursements for retirement allowances and other payments authorized by the board pursuant to the provisions of this article and shall be used for no other purpose. The description of the various reserves of the system shall be interpreted to refer to the accounting records of the system and not to the segregation of moneys or assets in the reserves of the system. 
(b)  Subsidiary accounts shall be maintained in the reserve for participant contributions reserve for city contributions, and reserve for retirement allowance payments, to reflect the separate equities of the participants. 
(c)  That forfeitures under the provisions of this plan may not be applied to increase the benefits any employee would otherwise receive under the plan; anything otherwise contained herein to the contrary notwithstanding. 
(Code 1964, § 20-158; Ord. No. 89-66, § 3, 10-23-89; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-021) 
Sec. 20-126. - Method of making payments. 
    Payment from moneys of the retirement system shall be made either by the city director of financial services according to charter provisions upon city vouchers or by an insurance company or nationally chartered bank designated by the board. No payment shall be made unless it shall have been previously authorized by a specific or continuing resolution of the board. No authorization of the commission shall be required for the making of such payments. 
(Code 1964, § 20-159; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-127. - Board of trustees-Responsibilities and duties; composition of. 
(a)  The general administration, management and responsibility for the proper operation of the retirement system, and for construing and making effective the provisions of the retirement system are vested in a board of trustees. 
(b)  The board shall consist of the following five (5) persons: 
(1)  Two (2) members appointed by the city commission; 
(2)  Two (2) members elected by the general employees; 
(3)  One (1) member selected by these four (4) members; 
all under the direction and supervision of the city commission. 
(c)  Elections of member trustees shall be held in accordance with rules adopted by the board. 
(Code 1964, § 20-160; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions, etc., generally, § 2-191 et seq. 
Sec. 20-128. - Same-Term of office; oath of office. 
    The regular term of office of a trustee shall be four (4) years. Each trustee shall, before assuming the duties of trustee, qualify by taking an oath of office, to be administered by the city clerk. 
(Code 1964, § 20-161; Ord. No. 92-06, § 3, 3-23-92; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 3-10-03) 
Sec. 20-129. - Same-Vacancy on board; filling of vacancy. 
    A vacancy shall occur on the board of trustees if any participant elected trustee ceases to be a participant, any participant elected trustee fails to attend three (3) consecutive meetings of the board unless in each case excused for cause by the trustees attending the meetings, and any trustee resigns or is removed from office. In the event a vacancy occurs on the board of trustees, the vacancy shall be filled within ninety (90) days for the unexpired term when applicable, in the same manner as the position was previously filled. 
(Code 1964, § 20-162; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-130. - Same-Meetings; quorum; voting; compensation. 
    The board shall hold meetings regularly, at least one (1) in each calendar quarter, and shall designate the time and place of each meeting. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public. The board shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of its proceedings. Three (3) trustees shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the board and at least two (2) concurring votes shall be necessary for a decision by the board. Each trustee shall be entitled to one (1) vote on each question before the board. Trustees shall serve without compensation for their services as trustees but shall be entitled to their expenses actually and necessarily incurred in attending meetings of the board and in performing required duties as trustees. 
(Code 1964, § 20-163; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-131. - Same-Officers; administrative services. 
    The officers and employed services of the retirement system shall be as follows: 
(1)  Chairperson. The board shall annually elect a chairperson and a vice-chairperson from its members. 
(2)  Secretary. The city clerk shall be secretary to the board and the administrative officer of the retirement system. 
(3)  Treasurer. The city director of financial services shall be treasurer of the retirement system. The city director of financial services shall be custodian of the assets of the retirement system except as to such assets as the board may from time to time place in the custody of an insurance company or a nationally chartered bank. 
(4)  Legal advisor. The city attorney shall give advice to said board of trustees in all matters pertaining to their duties in the administration of said general employees' retirement trust fund whenever requested; and he shall represent and defend said board as its attorney in all suits and actions at law or in equity that may be brought against it, and bring all suits and action in its behalf that may be required or determined upon by said board; provided, however, that if the board of trustees so elects, it may employ independent legal counsel at the pension fund's expense for the purposes contained herein, together with such other professional, technical, or other advisers as the board deems necessary. 
(5)  Actuary. The board shall appoint an actuary, who shall be the technical advisor to the board regarding the operation of the retirement system on an actuarial basis and who shall perform such services as are required in connection therewith. The term "actuary" used in this article shall mean a member of the American Academy of Actuaries or a person who had demonstrated an educational background necessary for the practice of actuarial science and has at least five (5) years of relevant actuarial experience; and in either case meets such requirements as the state may from time to time prescribe. A partnership or corporation may be appointed actuary if the duties of actuary are performed by or under the direct supervision of a person who meets the preceding qualifications. 
(6)  Services. The board is authorized and empowered to employ such professional and other services as are required for the proper administration of the retirement system. 
(Code 1964, § 20-164; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-132. - Same-Actuarial data; report to city commission. 
(a)  The board shall keep or cause to be kept, in convenient form, such data as shall be recommended by the actuary as necessary for the operation of the retirement system on an actuarial basis. The board shall keep or cause to be kept, in convenient form, such additional data as is required to properly report the operations of the system. 
(b)  The board shall render a report to the city commission on or before the first day of March of each year showing the fiscal transactions of the retirement system for the year ended the preceding thirtieth day of September, the assets of the retirement system as of the preceding thirtieth of September, and a copy of the most recent actuarial report. 
(Code 1964, § 20-165; Ord. No. 92-06, § 4, 3-23-92; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-133. - Assignments prohibited. 
    The right of a person to a retirement allowance, to the return of accumulated contributions, the retirement allowance itself, any optional benefit, any other right accrued or accruing to any person under the provisions of the retirement system, and any moneys belonging to the retirement system shall not be subject to execution, garnishment, attachment, the operation of bankruptcy or insolvency law, or any other process of law whatsoever, and shall be unassignable, except as is otherwise specifically provided herein. If a participant is covered by a group insurance or prepayment plan participated in by the city, and should he be permitted to, and elect to, continue such coverage as a retirant, he may authorize the board to have deducted from his retirement allowance the payments required of him to continue coverage under such group insurance or prepayment plan. The city shall have the right of setoff for any claim arising from embezzlement by a fraud, or a participant, retirant or beneficiary. 
(Code 1964, § 20-166; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-134. - Right to amend, suspend, terminate. 
    The city expects to continue the retirement system and payment of contributions, but the right to amend or terminate the system is necessarily reserved to the city. However, no such action shall cause any part of the corpus or income of the assets to be used or diverted to purposes other than the exclusive benefit of participants or their beneficiaries and other persons entitled to be paid benefits by the system, nor shall any such action adversely affect benefits already provided by the system or retroactively decrease the accrued benefits of any participant, except that the city may make any amendment it determines necessary or desirable with or without retroactive effect, to comply with the requirements of the Internal Revenue Service; and provided further that in the event of termination of any such pension plan or the complete discontinuance of contributions, the rights of each participant to benefits accrued to the date of termination or complete discontinuance, to the extent then funded, are nonforfeitable; anything otherwise contained in any such amendments to the contrary notwithstanding. 
(Code 1964, § 20-167; Ord. No. 89-66, § 2, 10-23-89; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-135. - Termination allocation, liquidation of fund. 
(a)  Upon termination of the retirement system, each general employee participant's accrued benefits to the date of retirement shall become one hundred (100) percent nonforfeitable to the extent funded. The assets of the retirement system shall be allocated (after provision is made for all expenses of the plan, including the expenses of liquidation) by the payment or provision for the payment of benefits in the following order of preference: 
(1)  To provide for the payment to each participant and nonretired former participant of an amount equal to his accumulated participant contributions; and 
(2)  If any assets remain after complete allocations for the purpose of subsection (1) above, to provide for the continuance of retirement allowances to retirants and beneficiaries, if any; and 
(3)  If any assets remain after complete allocations for the purposes of subsections (1) and (2) above, to provide for the potential rights of participants and former participants entitled to a vested termination retirement allowance on an equitable and nondiscriminatory basis according to generally accepted actuarial principles; and 
(4)  If any assets remain after satisfaction of all liabilities provided for in subsections (1), (2) and (3) above, any excess shall be delivered over and paid to the city. 
(b)  The above allocations may be implemented through the continuance of the existing trust, or through a new trust instrument for that purpose, or through the purchase by the board of insurance company contracts, or by a combination of these media. No participant or other employee shall have the rights or claims on the system or the city beyond the capacity of the assets held by the board to provide the benefits in accordance with the above provisions. 
(c)  If the allocations produce a retirement allowance of less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) a month for any person, the board may pay in lieu of such retirement allowance a lump sum of actuarial equivalent value. 
(Code 1964, § 20-168; Ord. No. 92-06, § 5, 3-23-92; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-136. - Limitation on benefits. 
(a)  Basic limitation. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this system to the contrary, the member contributions paid to, and retirement benefits paid from, the system shall be limited to such extent as may be necessary to conform to the requirements of Code Section 415 for a qualified retirement plan. Before January 1, 1995, a plan member may not receive an annual benefit that exceeds the limits specified in Code Section 415(b), subject to the applicable adjustments in that section. On and after January 1, 1995, a plan member may not receive an annual benefit that exceeds the dollar amount specified in Code Section 415(b)(1)(A) (one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00)), subject to the applicable adjustments in Code Section 415(b) and subject to any additional limits that may be specified in this system. For purposes of this section, "limitation year" shall be the calendar year. 
(b)  Adjustments to basic limitation for form of benefit. If the form of benefit without regard to any benefit increase feature is not a straight life annuity, then the Code Section 415(b) limit applicable at the annuity starting date is reduced to an actuarially equivalent amount (determined using the assumptions specified in Treasury Regulation Section 1.415(b)-1(c)(2)(ii)) that takes into account the death benefits under the form of benefit. 
(c)  Benefits not taken into account. For purposes of this section, the following benefits shall not be taken into account in applying these limits: 
(1)  Any ancillary benefit which is not directly related to retirement income benefits; 
(2)  Any other benefit not required under Section 415(b)(2) of the Code and Regulations thereunder to be taken into account for purposes of the limitation of Code Section 415(b)(1). 
(d)  COLA effect. Effective on and after January 1, 2003, for purposes of applying the limits under Code Section 415(b) (the "limit"), the following will apply: 
(1)  A member's applicable limit will be applied to the member's annual benefit in the member's first calendar year of benefit payments without regard to any automatic cost of living adjustments; 
(2)  Thereafter, in any subsequent calendar year, a member's annual benefit, including any automatic cost of living increases, shall be tested under the then applicable benefit limit including any adjustment to the Code Section 415(b)(1)(A) dollar limit under Code Section 415(d), and the regulations thereunder; but 
(3)  In no event shall a member's benefit payable under the system in any calendar year be greater than the limit applicable at the annuity starting date, as increased in subsequent years pursuant to Code Section 415(d) and the regulations thereunder. 
Unless otherwise specified in the system, for purposes of applying the limits under Code Section 415(b), a member's applicable limit will be applied taking into consideration cost of living increases as required by Section 415(b) of the Code and applicable Treasury Regulations. 
(e)  Other adjustments in limitations. 
(1)  In the event the member's retirement benefits become payable before age sixty-two (62), the limit prescribed by this section shall be reduced in accordance with regulations issued by the Secretary of the Treasury pursuant to the provisions of Code Section 415(b) of the Code, so that such limit (as so reduced) equals an annual straight life benefit (when such retirement income benefit begins) which is equivalent to a one hundred sixty thousand dollar ($160,000.00) annual benefit beginning at age sixty-two (62). 
(2)  In the event the member's benefit is based on at least fifteen (15) years of credited service as a full-time employee of the fire or police department of the city, the adjustments provided for in subsection (e)(1) above shall not apply. 
(3)  The reductions provided for in subsection (e)(1) above shall not be applicable to disability benefits pursuant to section 66-218, or pre-retirement death benefits paid pursuant to section 66-217. 
(4)  In the event the member's retirement benefit becomes payable after age sixty-five (65), for purposes of determining whether this benefit meets the limit set forth in subsection (a) herein, such benefit shall be adjusted so that it is actuarially equivalent to the benefit beginning at age sixty-five (65). This adjustment shall be made in accordance with regulations promulgated by the Secretary of the Treasury or his delegate. 
(f)  Less than ten (10) years of service. The maximum retirement benefits payable under this section to any member who has completed less than ten (10) years of credited service with the city shall be the amount determined under subsection (a) of this section multiplied by a fraction, the numerator of which is the number of the member's years of credited service and the denominator of which is ten (10). The reduction provided by this subsection cannot reduce the maximum benefit below ten (10) percent. The reduction provided for in this subsection shall not be applicable to disability benefits paid pursuant to section 66-218, or pre-retirement death benefits paid pursuant to section 66-217. 
(g)  Participation in other defined benefit plans. The limit of this section with respect to any member who at any time has been a member in any other defined benefit plan as defined in Code Section 414(j) maintained by the city shall apply as if the total benefits payable under all city defined benefit plans in which the member has been a member were payable from one plan. 
(h)  Ten thousand dollar ($10,000) limit. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the retirement benefit payable with respect to a member shall be deemed not to exceed the limit set forth in this section if the benefits payable, with respect to such member under this system and under all other qualified defined benefit pension plans to which the city contributes, do not exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000) for the applicable plan year and for any prior plan year and the city has not any time maintained a qualified defined contribution plan in which the member participated. 
(i)  Reduction of benefits. Reduction of benefits and/or contributions to all plans, where required, shall be accomplished by first reducing the member's benefit under any defined benefit plans in which member participated, such reduction to be made first with respect to the plan in which member most recently accrued benefits and thereafter in such priority as shall be determined by the board and the plan administrator of such other plans, and next, by reducing or allocating excess forfeitures to defined contribution plans in which the member participated, such reduction to be made first with respect to the plan in which member most recently accrued benefits and thereafter in such priority as shall be established by the board and the plan administrator for such other plans provided, however, that necessary reductions may be made in a different manner and priority pursuant to the agreement of the board and the plan administrator of all other plans covering such member. 
(j)  Service credit purchase limits. 
(1)  Effective for permissive service credit contributions made in limitation years beginning after December 31, 1997, if a member makes one or more contributions to purchase permissive service credit under the system, as allowed in sections 66-227 and 66-228, then the requirements of this section will be treated as met only if: 
a.  The requirements of Code Section 415(b) are met, determined by treating the accrued benefit derived from all such contributions as an annual benefit for purposes of Code Section 415(b); or 
b.  The requirements of Code Section 415(c) are met, determined by treating all such contributions as annual additions for purposes of Code Section 415(c). 
c.  For purposes of applying subparagraph (j)(1)a., the system will not fail to meet the reduced limit under Code Section 415(b)(2)(C) solely by reason of this subparagraph c., and for purposes of applying subparagraph (j)(1)b., the system will not fail to meet the percentage limitation under Section 415(c)(1)(B) of the Code solely by reason of this subparagraph c. 
(2)  For purposes of this subsection the term "permissive service credit" means service credit- 
a.  Recognized by the system for purposes of calculating a member's benefit under the plan. 
b.  Which such member has not received under the plan; and 
c.  Which such member may receive only by making a voluntary additional contribution, in an amount determined under the system, which does not exceed the amount necessary to fund the benefit attributable to such service credit. 
Effective for permissive service credit contributions made in limitation years beginning after December 31, 1997, such term may, if otherwise provided by the system, include service credit for periods for which there is no performance of service, and, notwithstanding clause (j)(2)b., may include service credited in order to provide an increased benefit for service credit which a member is receiving under the system. 
(3)  For purposes of applying the limits in this subsection (j), only and for no other purpose, the definition of compensation where applicable will be compensation actually paid or made available during a calendar year, except as noted below and as permitted by Treasury Regulations Section 1.415(c)-2, or successor regulations. Unless another definition of compensation that is permitted by Treasury Regulations Section 1.415(c)-2, or successor regulation, is specified by the system, compensation will be defined as wages within the meaning of Code Section 3401(a) and all other payments of compensation to an employee by an employer for which the employer is required to furnish the employee a written statement under Code Sections 6041(d), 6051(a)(3) and 6052 and will be determined without regard to any rules under Code Section 3401(a) that limit the remuneration included in wages based on the nature or location of the employment or the services performed (such as the exception for agricultural labor in Code Section 3401(a)(2). 
a.  However, for calendar years beginning after December 31, 1997, compensation will also include amounts that would otherwise be included in compensation but for an election under Code Sections 125(a), 402(e)(3), 402(h)(1)(B), 402(k), or 457(b). For calendar years beginning after December 31, 2000, compensation will also include any elective amounts that are not includible in the gross income of the employee by reason of Code Section 132(f)(4). 
b.  For limitation years beginning on and after January 1, 2007, compensation for the calendar year will also include compensation paid by the later of two and one-half (21/2) months after an employee's severance from employment or the end of the calendar year that includes the date of the employee's severance from employment if: 
1.  The payment is regular compensation for services during the employee's regular working hours, or compensation for services outside the employee's regular working hours (such as overtime or shift differential), commissions, bonuses or other similar payments, and, absent a severance from employment, the payments would have been paid to the employee which the employee continued in employment with the employer; or 
2.  The payment is for unused accrued bona fide sick, vacation or other leave that the employee would have been able to use if employment had continued. 
c.  Back pay, within the meaning of Treasury Regulations Section 1.415(c) -2(g)(8), shall be treated as compensation for the limitation year to which the back pay relates to the extent the back pay represents wages and compensation that would otherwise be included under this definition. 
(4)  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, the board may modify a request by a member to make a contribution to the system if the amount of the contribution would exceed the limits provided in Code Section 415 by using the following methods: 
a.  If the law requires a lump sum payment for the purchase of service credit, the board may establish a periodic payment deduction plan for the member to avoid a contribution in excess of the limits under Code Sections 415(c) or 415(n). 
b.  If payment pursuant to subparagraph (j)(4)a. will not avoid a contribution in excess of the limits imposed by Code Section 415(c), the board may either reduce the member's contribution to an amount within the limits of that section or refuse the member's contribution 
(k)  Additional limitation on pension benefits. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary. 
(1)  The normal retirement benefit or pension payable to a retiree who becomes a member of the system and who has not previously participated in such system, on or after January 1, 1980, shall not exceed one hundred (100) percent of his average final compensation. However, nothing contained in this section shall apply to supplemental retirement benefits or to pension increases attributable to cost-of-living increases or adjustments. 
(2)  No member of the system shall be allowed to receive a retirement benefit or pension which is in part or in whole based upon any service with respect to which the member is already receiving, or will receive in the future, a retirement benefit or pension from a different employer's retirement system or plan. This restriction does not apply to social security benefits or federal benefits under Chapter 67, Title 10, U.S. Code. 
(Ord. No. 10-32, § 6, 10-11-10) 
Sec. 20-137. - Worker's compensation and unemployment benefits offset. 
    Should any terminated, disabled or retired participant receive either a worker's compensation wage loss benefit or an unemployment wage loss benefit for the same time period for which that person is entitled to a benefit under this retirement system, the amount of the retirement system benefit shall be reduced. The reduction in the retirement system benefit shall equal in the aggregate the total amount of the worker's compensation and unemployment wage loss benefits received by such person. 
(Code 1964, § 20-170; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-138. - Correction of errors. 
    Should any change in the records result in any participant, retirant or beneficiary receiving from the retirement system more or less than he would have been entitled to receive had the records been correct, the board shall correct such error, and as far as practicable shall adjust the payment in such manner that the actuarial equivalent of the benefit to which the participant, retirant or beneficiary was correctly entitled shall be paid. 
(Code 1964, § 20-171; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-139. - Subrogation. 
    In the event a person becomes entitled to a retirement allowance or other benefit payable by the retirement system as a result of an accident or injury caused by the act of a third party, the city shall be subrogated to the rights of the person against such third party to the extent of the city financed benefits which the retirement system pays or becomes liable to pay. 
(Code 1964, § 20-172; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-140. - Applicability of existing plans. 
    The provisions of this article shall not in any respect amend, modify or repeal any provisions of any city pension plans in existence upon June 1, 1977, or on March 31, 2002. 
(Code 1964, § 20-173; Ord. No. 02-05, § 2, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-141. - Supplemental retirement allowance. 
(a)  A participant who terminates employment with ten (10) or more years of credited service earned after the effective date of this plan, or terminates employment at early or normal retirement age following the effective date of this plan, whose last position with the city was at or above grade 32 and not higher than grade 35, shall receive at normal retirement a supplemental retirement allowance of one-half (1/2) percent of final average compensation for each year of credited service in such grades, up to a maximum of thirty-five (35) years. Such supplement shall be paid under the same terms and conditions as the basic retirement allowance. A participant whose employment in grades 32 through 35 is involuntarily terminated without cause after the effective date of this plan shall receive the supplemental retirement allowance in accordance with this subsection for each year of credited service in such grades, regardless of the number of years of credited service earned after the effective date of this plan. 
(b)  A participant who terminates employment with ten (10) or more years of credited service earned after the effective date of this plan, or terminates employment at early or normal retirement age following the effective date of this plan, whose last position with the city was at or above grade 36, shall receive at normal retirement a supplemental retirement allowance of one (1) percent of final average compensation for each year of credited service in such grades, plus one-half (1/2) percent of final average compensation for each year of credited service in grades 32 through 35, up to a maximum of thirty-five (35) years. Such supplement shall be paid under the same terms and conditions as the basic retirement allowance. A participant whose employment at or above grade 36 is involuntarily terminated without cause after the effective date of this plan shall receive the supplemental retirement allowance in accordance with this subsection for each year of credited service in such grades, regardless of the number of years of credited service earned after the effective date of this plan. 
(c)  A police chief or fire chief who terminates city employment on or after the effective date of this section and who receives normal retirement benefits under the terms of the city police officers or firefighters retirement plan, as applicable, shall receive a supplemental retirement allowance from this retirement system equal to three and one-half (3.5) percent of final average compensation for each year of service as chief, reduced by the participant's benefit under the city police officers or firefighters retirement plan, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 02-05, § 3, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 06-06, § 4, 2-13-06) 
Sec. 20-142. - Pension validity. 
    The board shall have the power to examine into the facts upon which any pension shall heretofore have been granted under any prior or existing law, or shall hereafter be granted or obtained erroneously, fraudulently or illegally for any reason. The board is empowered to purge the pension rolls or correct the pension amount of any person heretofore granted a pension under prior or existing law or any person hereafter granted a pension under this article if the same is found to be erroneous, fraudulent or illegal for any reason; and to reclassify any person who has heretofore under any prior or existing law been or who shall hereafter under this article be erroneously, improperly or illegally classified. Any overpayments or underpayments shall be corrected and paid or repair in a reasonable manner determined by the board. 
(Ord. No. 02-05, § 3, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 20-143. - Conviction and forfeiture; false, misleading or fraudulent statements.
