Chapter 22 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS, PARKS AND MISCELLANEOUS PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Boats, beaches and waterways, Ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166; municipal street system, F.S. §§ 335.01, 335.04; minimum construction standards for streets, roads, etc., F.S. § 336.045. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Excavating; removing materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig into any street, sidewalk, alley or public square within the corporate limits of the city, or to carry away any gravel, sand, shell, turf or earth from any part of any street, sidewalk, alley or public square within the city, except by order or permission of the city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 25-1) 
Sec. 22-2. - Littering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, place, deposit or allow to fall or drain into or on any street, lane or alley, or the sidewalks of any street or lane, or the public places of the city, the peel, rind or covering of any fruit, vegetable or melon, or any garbage, trash, offal, wastepaper, dodger, printed circular, litter sweepings, crustacea or mollusks, including drainage therefrom, or waste of any kind, or to leave thereon or therein an unreasonable time any sink, barrel, box or receptacle for garbage, slop water or waste of any kind, liquid or solid. 
(Code 1964, § 25-3) 
State Law reference- Litter control, F.S. § 403.413. 
Sec. 22-3. - Underground utilities required in historic preservation district. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in herein, "public service companies" shall refer to telephone, cable television and electric utilities serving property within the historic preservation district, defined with Orange Street as the northerly boundary, the intracoastal waterway as the easterly boundary, St. Francis Street as the southerly boundary, and the westerly boundary as follows: Cordova Street northward from St. Francis Street to Bridge Street, westerly on Bridge Street to Granada Street, northward on Granada Street to King Street, eastward on King Street to Cordova Street, thence northward to the northerly boundary. 
(b)  Time limitation on connection. Within six (6) months after the date of availability of underground public service lines, all owners of property served by public service companies shall connect to such underground public service lines in accordance with the tariffs of such companies. 
(c)  All new electrical services or electrical service upgrades installed within the historic preservation district defined herein shall be served underground from the existing public service utilities, whether or not the existing public service lines are installed aboveground or underground. However, in the event that installation of such service is a hardship, an owner may apply to the board of adjustments and appeals for a variance from this section. 
(d)  Penalty for violating section. Any property owner who shall be found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. Each month that such violation shall continue shall be treated as a separate offense. 
(Code 1964, § 25-6; Ord. No. 90-33, § 1, 1-28-91; Ord. No. 96-18, § 1, 4-22-96) 
Sec. 22-4. - Plaza de la Constitucion, city commons: events, protests and counter-protests in the plaza. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Counter-protest means a lawful person or gathering of persons in the plaza or perimeter sidewalk objecting to the protest. 
    Event means a lawful gathering of fifty or more persons in the plaza for the purpose of attending a specific scheduled and permitted program taking place in and around the plaza. 
    Perimeter sidewalk means the sidewalk immediately adjacent to, and encircling, the plaza. 
    Plaza means the area containing grass and landscaping, monuments, a gazebo, a covered market, cannons and other historical objects, and internal walkways of the Plaza de la Constitucion as represented on District No. 5 Official Map of the City of St. Augustine, adopted June 12, 1923, by Ordinance No. 164. 
    Protest means a lawful person or gathering of persons in the plaza or perimeter sidewalk expressing their objection to, or support for, a person, place, thing, or idea. 
(b)  In order to provide for the public, health and safety of all participants in the crowded and constrained boundaries of the plaza, protest and counter-protest participants shall remain on the perimeter sidewalk while event participants occupy the plaza. Protest and counter-protest participants may also be lawfully separated from each other by law enforcement personnel at a designated location in order to maintain the peace in the plaza and perimeter sidewalk. 
(c)  Penalties. Offenses under this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(d)  This section is intended to operate in harmony with all provisions of this Code relating to street artists, as defined in section 22-10, including other sections which are cross-referenced thereto, and is in no way intended to conflict, supersede, or otherwise invalidate any such ordinances or resolutions relating to the same. 
(Ord. No. 18-16, § 1, 11-13-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-16, § 1, adopted November 13, 2018, amended § 22-4 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 22-4, pertained to parks; holding public meetings and derived from § 17-16 of the 1964 Code. 
Sec. 22-5. - Plaza de la Constitucion, city commons: operation of motor vehicles, horses and livestock. 
(a)  Motor vehicles, horses and livestock not permitted. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle, except for authorized government personnel in connection with their official duties, or to allow a horse or other livestock, on any sidewalk or lawn area of the Plaza de la Constitucion or the city commons. 
(b)  Penalties. Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1964, § 17-49.5; Ord. No. 18-16, § 2, 11-13-18) 
Sec. 22-6. - Provision for street artist activity within the Plaza de la Constitucion; establishment of a random lottery for space in the Plaza de la Constitucion for street artist activity; provision for the procedures for said lottery; providing penalties. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Market in the Plaza ("market") means the historic market in the Plaza de la Constitucion, as represented on District No. 5, Official Map of the City of St. Augustine, adopted June 12, 1923, by Ordinance No. 164, as a rectangle at the east end of the plaza, as labeled on the official map. 
(2)  Plaza means the Plaza de la Constitucion, as represented on District No. 5, Official Map of the City of St. Augustine, adopted June 12, 1923, by Ordinance No. 164, excluding the market in the plaza, and the rights-of-way and sidewalks located around the perimeter of the plaza as more specifically described below: 
a.  The right-of-way known as King Street and the sidewalks adjacent to both sides of said right-of-way running from the southwest corner of the intersection of King Street and St. George Street to the southeast corner of the intersection of King Street and Charlotte Street. 
b.  The right-of-way known as Cathedral Place and the sidewalks adjacent to both sides of said right-of-way running from the northwest corner of the intersection of Cathedral Place and St. George Street to the northeast corner of the intersection of Cathedral Place and Charlotte Street. 
c.  The right-of-way known as St. George Street and the sidewalks adjacent to both sides of said right-of-way running from the northwest corner of the intersection of St. George Street and Cathedral Place to the southwest corner of the intersection of St. George Street and King Street. 
d.  The right-of-way known as Charlotte Street and the sidewalks adjacent to both sides of said right-of-way running from the southeast corner of the intersection of Charlotte Street and King Street and the northeast corner of the intersection of Charlotte Street and Cathedral Place. 
(3)  Street artist includes those individuals as defined in section 22-10 of the City Code. 
(b)  Absolute prohibition of vending of certain goods. Notwithstanding any other provision in this ordinance, the following goods and services shall not be offered for sale or donation anywhere in the market in the plaza: Food, beverages, housewares, appliances, sunglasses, auto parts, oils, incense, perfume, lotions, candles and clothing and accessories (including handbags and shoes), jewelry, toys and stuffed animals, flashlights or "glow sticks" and items intended to serve any functional or utilitarian purpose containing no first amendment expressive content. 
(c)  [Unlawful to engage in street artist activity in plaza.] Other than as provided for herein, it is unlawful for any person to engage in any street artist activity in the plaza. 
(d)  Exemption for newspaper vending machines. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sale or offer for sale of newspapers through vending machines of general circulation. For the purposes of this section, "newspapers of general circulation" means a publication published at regular intervals, primarily for the dissemination of news, intelligence and opinions on recent events or newsworthy items of a general character, and reaching all classes of the public. 
(e)  Lottery. The historic market in the Plaza de la Constitucion shall be subdivided into twelve (12) spaces of approximately equal size that have been delineated with pins; six (6) along the north side and six (6) along the south side, excluding a six-foot wide walkway running east/west down the center of the market in the plaza. These twelve (12) spaces shall be available for street artist on a monthly basis. 
(f)  Procedure for lottery; applications. 
(1)  Applications for spaces in the market in the plaza shall be available at the customer service division and shall provide for the following information: Name; address; street artist activity; and printed name and signature. 
(2)  Completed applications must be submitted back to the customer service division by 5:00 p.m. on the 20th day of the month prior to the month the applicant desires to engage in street artist activity in the market in the plaza. In the event that the 20th day of the month falls on a weekend or a holiday, completed applications must be submitted back to the customer service division by 5:00 p.m. on the last day of normal business for the City of St. Augustine before the 20th day of the month prior to the month the applicant desires to engage in street artist activity in the market in the plaza. 
(g)  Procedure for lottery: Drawing for space in the market in the Plaza. 
(1)  On the next business day following the deadline for applications to be received, the city comptroller, or his or her designee, shall randomly draw twelve (12) street artist applications from all applications received. 
(2)  The use of the twelve (12) spots by a permit holder is on a daily, first-come, first-served basis. No street artist shall make efforts to reserve a location; and each permit holder shall abandon a location at the end of his or her working day, including the removal of all personal property. 
(3)  Any unallotted spaces may be assigned by the city comptroller, or his or her designee, on a first come, first serve basis for payment of the administrative processing fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) after the drawing for space in the market in the plaza is complete for any given month. 
(4)  Applicants that are assigned a space in the market in the plaza shall be required to pay an administrative processing fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) within five (5) business days of the drawing and to prominently display a photo ID and permit, provided by the city, identifying the month of the drawing. Spaces assigned via the lottery shall not be transferable and shall only be for use by the applicant with photo ID provided by the city. 
(5)  Upon notification to the customer service division of space not utilized for seven (7) consecutive days, the customer service division shall contact the individual street artist not present and utilizing assigned space for confirmation of intent to abandon the space for the assigned month. If confirmation cannot be made the space will remain assigned as drawn for the month. If the assigned street artist confirms their intent to abandon the space for the month, the customer service division shall contact the next available applicant from the list of applicants received for the given months drawing. Upon payment of the twenty-five dollar ($25.00) administrative fee an id badge and permit will be assigned for use of the abandoned space. 
(h)  Description of street artist activity space. Within the designated area in the market, all activities including equipment and personnel and signage must be confined to the designated space demarcated by the metal pins referenced in subparagraph (e) hereinabove. Street artist shall not obstruct vehicular or pedestrian traffic, entrance to buildings, bicycle racks, handicapped access or vehicular parking, vehicular loading zones, taxi stands or franchised vehicles for hire stands. 
(i)  Penalties. Offenses under this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(j)  Indigency waiver. Street artist as defined in section 22-10 of the City Code seeking relief from payment of fees based upon an inability to pay must apply to the city clerk for a determination of indigent status using the form provided and provide the required information for such determination as required by section 2-79 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 09-26, § 2, 9-14-09; Ord. No. 09-29, § 1, 9-14-09; Ord. No. 17-26, § 1, 10-9-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-26, § 2, adopted September 14, 2009, repealed § 22-6, which pertained to prohibition of sale of merchandise and services on public property within historic preservation zoning districts HP-2 and HP-3 and regulation of sale of merchandise and services on public property outside historic preservation zoning districts HP-2 and HP-3X and derived from Code 1964, § 17-56; Ord. No. 00-09, §§ 1, 2, 3-13-00; Ord. No. 07-23, § 1, 11-13-07. Subsequently, Ord. No. 09-29, § 1, adopted September 14, 2009, added § 22-6 as herein set out. 
Sec. 22-7. - Soliciting, canvassing for commercial purpose on public ways. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use or occupy any street, alley or other public way within the city for the purpose of soliciting or canvassing for a commercial purpose, including the soliciting or extending of invitations for persons to attend sales presentations, sales demonstrations or displays for the sale of either real or personal property. A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 17-56.5) 
Sec. 22-8. - Utility placement permit. 
(a)  Definitions. In this section: 
(1)  Facilities means poles, conduits, wires, cables, electrical conductors, fiber optics, digital technology fixtures, manholes, sewer lines, water lines, and other fixtures intended to be placed within the public right-of-way or in actuality placed within the public right-of-way belonging to a utility. 
(2)  Utility means any utility which is subject to the jurisdiction of the state public service commission except for such utilities which shall have entered into and have in force a current franchise agreement with the city, providing for permission to use public rights-of-way and setting the terms and conditions of such use. 
(b)  No utility shall have the right or privilege to construct, erect, operate, own or maintain in, upon, along, across, above, over or under the streets, alleys, public ways and public places not laid out or dedicated, or any extensions thereof or any additions thereto, in the city any facilities within the corporate limits of the city as it now exists or as it may hereafter be extended or contracted unless or until such utility shall have obtained a permit therefor issued by the city manager or his or her designee upon the terms and conditions hereinafter contained. Each violation of the provisions of this section shall be as punishable as provided by law and shall be enforceable by the municipal code enforcement board with each day of violation being considered a separate violation and each pole, conduit, wire, cable, electrical conductor, manholes, water line, sewer line, or other fixtures being regarded as a separate violation. 
(c)  Upon application by any utility the city manager or his or her designee shall issue a permit to the utility upon the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  The permit shall be nonexclusive and shall be conditioned upon the payment by the utility to the city of the maximum amount permitted to be charged by the city and as allowed by law as a franchise fee for the use of its streets, alleys, public ways and public places for the placement of the fixtures belonging to the utility. If the maximum amount authorized to be charged by the city to the utility for such franchise fee is expressed as a percentage of gross receipts and local service revenues then, in that event, the utility shall pay, upon application for the permit, such percentage and will provide a statement of its gross revenues for the preceding year, sworn to by an authorized official of the utility, in such reasonable form and detail as the city's auditor may from time to time prescribe and sufficient to show the source and method of computation of such gross revenues. The utility shall, in the application, as a condition thereof agree that it will provide within ninety (90) days from the end of the utility's fiscal year a statement of its gross revenues for the period in which the permit is issued and shall pay any deficiency or deficit from that which was previously paid upon application. The utility shall maintain books and records to confirm the dollar amount owed to the city. The city staff or an authorized CPA may examine, as the condition of the issuance of the permit, upon reasonable notice to the utility and during normal business hours, those records located in utility facilities where they are maintained. The records shall not be taken from the utility premises. 
(2)  Permits and revocable licenses required. 
a.  Any person or entity desiring to install, place, construct or replace any improvement in a city public right-of-way shall obtain prior to commencement of any work a permit for such activity issued by the city manager or his or her designee on terms and conditions as defined below. 
b.  Fees for permits shall be determined as allowed by law and by resolution of the city commission. 
c.  No use of or construction in a public right-of-way shall be permitted or licensed if that use or construction creates an obstruction, barrier or safety hazard as defined by generally accepted engineering practices. 
d.  Time limitations. 
1.  In no case shall construction commence on any improvement within any public right-of-way or within any easement owned or controlled by the city before a permit is issued. A permit issued by the city shall be valid for a period of one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of issuance. If a period in excess of one hundred twenty (120) days is required because of the scope of work, approval shall be obtained in advance of the issuance of the permit and the permit validation period shall reflect such extension. A permit shall not be extended more than three (3) times or for more than one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
2.  After issuance of the permit, the permittee shall notify the city public works department a minimum of two (2) business days prior to commencing construction. This notification will allow for scheduling of inspections. If a road closure is required, the permittee shall submit with the permit application a maintenance of traffic (MOT) plan to include all proposed road closures and an expected time duration for each closing. Road closures shall require separate approval by the public works department and a minimum of three (3) business days prior notification before the commencement or construction. Road closures of fewer than fifteen (15) minutes shall not require notification. 
e.  It shall be the duty and responsibility of each applicant for a permit under this article to: 
1.  Make a written application for permit with the public works department on such forms as the city shall prescribe. No work shall commence until the engineer has approved the application and plan and the applicant has paid and provided all fees, deposits and certificates required by this article. The engineer shall review the application and issue a decision or comments for revision and will issue permit providing all conditions of the permit application have been met and all required fees, deposits and certificates from the applicant have been received. 
2.  Include in the application information stating the kind, character and purpose of the proposed excavation or opening and such other information which may be reasonably required to fulfill the requirements of this article. 
3.  Furnish in triplicate and, if desired by the applicant, in electronic format, a detailed plan with dimensions showing the location of the work to be performed under such permit. If approved by the engineer, one copy of such plan shall be returned to the applicant at the time the permit is granted. 
4.  Obtain a permit for each and every project. Notwithstanding this requirement, the utility provider may proceed to perform only such work as required to address emergency situations defined as circumstances creating an out-of-service or imminent out-of-service condition. The applicant must notify the city of such work on the first business day following the commencement of the work and must submit an application for a permit for such work within a time designated by the city manager or his or her designee. 
5.  Save the city, its officers, employees and agents harmless from any and all costs, damages and liabilities which may accrue or be claimed to accrue by reason of any work performed under such permit. To the extent allowed by law, the acceptance of any permit under this article shall constitute such an agreement by the applicant whether such acceptance is expressed or not. 
6.  To the extent allowed by law, pay a permit and engineering review fee and security deposit. Developers of major subdivisions may request to pledge assurances to the city in lieu of cash or check, and the city, in the sole exercise of the city's judgment and discretion, may accept or reject such assurances. 
7.  Furnish a certificate of insurance or self-insurance. 
8.  Keep the original copy of the permit and an approved copy of the plan in the possession of the party actually doing the work, and when required, exhibit such copy to the engineer, duly authorized inspectors or, in the instances of county and state roads, to the respective inspectors representing these authorities. 
9.  Perform the work, in accord with the permit conditions, the regulations established under this article and such further conditions as may be imposed by the engineer. 
f.  Bond. A performance bond, or other financial security, in form, content and execution approved by the city attorney, may be required to ensure financial responsibility for completion of specified work not completed or for repair of damages to the right-of-way or any public property occurring and not repaired in accord with good engineering practices or for events where the work is nonconforming as determined by the public works department. In addition to paying the permit and inspection fees established by resolution of the city commission, a performance bond or other security approved by the city attorney shall be in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a nonrefundable processing fee plus two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) as a retainer refundable within thirty (30) days after completion of specified work. If the work in question exceeds a value of two thousand dollars ($2,000), the bond amount shall be increased by the difference between two thousand dollars ($2,000) and the increased value of the work plus ten (10) percent of that difference. In the alternative, the performance bond may be in the form of a blanket bond approved by the city attorney in form, content and execution and which satisfies the financial protection requirements of this section. If said work remains incomplete after thirty (30) days, the bond will be forfeited. Such forms shall prescribe the manner in which noncompliance with the provisions of a permit or this subchapter shall be remedied and shall provide the necessary financial assurances to remedy any noncompliance. 
(3)  The utility shall continue to be subject to public utility taxes, ad valorem taxes and such other taxes, charges or fees as may be lawfully authorized by the state construction and the general laws of the state. 
(4)  The issuance of the permit shall not restrict the right of the city, which is hereby expressly reserved, to adopt, in addition to the provisions herein contained and existing applicable ordinances, such additional regulations as the city shall find necessary in the exercise of police power, provided that such regulations, by ordinance or otherwise, shall be reasonable, and not in conflict with the rights granted by such permit, and shall not be in conflict with the laws of the state and the lawful regulations of any state agency possessing the power to regulate the activities of the utility. 
(5)  The permit granted by the city to the utility shall not be transferable to another without the city's prior approval. No such sale or transfer shall be effective until the vendee, assignee or lessee has filed with the city an instrument, duly executed, reciting the fact of such sale, assignment or lease; accepting the terms of the permit; and agreeing to perform all the conditions thereof. The city will not unreasonably withhold its consent to the transfer of the permit. 
(6)  Any violation by the utility, its vendee, lessee or successor to the provisions of any permit issued hereunder or any material portions thereof shall be cause for the forfeiture of the permit and all rights thereunder if such violation, failure or default without agreement of the city continues for a period of thirty (30) days after written notice by the city to the utility thereof. 
(7)  The utility shall, at all times during the life of any permit issued pursuant to this section, be subject to all lawful exercise of the police power by the city and such reasonable regulations as the city shall hereafter by resolution or ordinance provide. The rights and privileges granted to the utility pursuant to any such permit shall at all times be subordinate and inferior to the rights of the public in and to the ordinary use of the city streets and rights-of-way and nothing in any permit shall be construed as a surrender by the city of its right and power to use and regulate the use of its streets and rights-of-way. The utility shall obtain the permit provided for in this section before commencing any work requiring a permit and shall obtain such other permits as may be required and shall provide for the following: 
a.  All transmission, distribution, collection, and other structures, lines, conduits, pipes and equipment erected by the utility within the limits of the city shall be so located as to cause minimum interference with the proper use of streets, alleys and other public ways and places, and to cause minimum interference with the rights of reasonable conveyance of property owners who would join any of such streets, alleys, or other public ways and places. 
b.  In case of any disturbance of pavement, sidewalk, driveway or the surfacing or damage to city structures and facilities caused by the utility's operations and activities, the utility shall commence, at its own cost and expense and in the manner approved by the city, replace and restore all paving, sidewalk, driveway or surface of any street or alley disturbed, in as good or better condition as before such work was commenced, and shall maintain the restoration in approved condition for a period of five (5) years. Should the utility fail to commence restoration after seven (7) days' notice, in writing, to such utility by the city, the city may make such repair and restoration and the cost of the same shall be paid by the utility. In the event the utility shall fail to pay for such repair and restoration, no additional permit will be issued while the utility is in default thereof. 
c.  If at any time during the period of any such permit, the city shall lawfully elect to alter, or change the grade of, any street, sidewalk, driveway, alley or other public way, or alter or move any structural facility of the city, the utility, upon reasonable notice by the city, shall remove, relay and relocate its poles, wires, cable, underground conduits, water or sewer lines, manholes or other fixtures at its own expense. 
d.  The utility shall not place poles or other fixtures where the same will interfere with any gas lamp, electric light, water hydrant, water main, or sewage line and all such poles and other fixtures placed in the streets shall be placed at the outer edge of the sidewalk and inside the curbline (or such other place designated by the city) and those placed in alleys shall be placed close to the line of the lot abutting on such alley, and in such a manner as not to interfere with the usual travel on such streets, alleys and public ways. 
e.  Utilities shall, on the request of any person holding a building permit issued by the city, temporarily raise or lower their wires to permit the moving of buildings. The expense of such temporary removal, raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the person requesting the same, and the utility shall have the authority to require such payment in advance. The utility shall be given notice not less than forty-eight (48) hours to arrange for such temporary wire changes. 
f.  As a further condition of the issuance of any permit the utility shall agree to provide the city with records of its underground installation, as built, on sheets provided by the utility within sixty (60) days of the completion of the installation. 
(8)  The permit shall be issued upon the express understanding and agreement by the utility that the utility shall save the city harmless for loss sustained by the city on account of any suit, judgement, execution, claim or demand whatsoever, resulting from the negligence, default or misconduct on the part of the utility, its agents, servants, employees or independent contractors, in the construction, operation or maintenance of its facilities in the area of the permit issued. 
(d)  This section shall not effect or invalidate any valid franchise right of any public service company having an existing franchise with the city. 
(e)  The issuance of a permit pursuant to this section shall not authorize or permit distribution facilities for a utility in competition or providing essentially the same service as that provided by a public service company regulated by the state public service commission which has a valid franchise agreement with the city, it being understood and it being the intent of this section that the operation of a competing system shall require the issuance of a franchise agreement upon the same terms and conditions and under such circumstances as deemed advisable by the city as required for the public service company having a valid franchise agreement with the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-57, §§ 1-4, 1-8-90; Ord. No. 11-19, § 1, 10-10-11) 
Sec. 22-9. - Placement of monuments, plaques and memorials on city property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place a plaque, memorial or monument on any city right-of-way or city owned property, except in conformity with the following requirements: 
(a)  Approval of city commission. No plaque, memorial or monument may be placed upon any city property without the approval of the city commission first obtained. 
(b)  Application. An application for placement of a plaque, memorial or monument shall be filed with the city manager on a form as designated by him which shall require the following information to be provided: 
(i)  A statement of significant historical, cultural or civic contributions to, or acts of patriotism and bravery relating to, the City of St. Augustine. 
(ii)  Agreement by the applicant to pay the cost of construction, placement and any repairs required for the plaque, memorial or monument. 
(c)  Review by city manager. The city manager will review the application and provide his recommendation to the city commission as to the suitability of placement of the plaque, memorial or monument. No plaque, monument or memorial is to be recommended to the city commission by the city manager for placement in the City Commons otherwise known as Plaza de la Constitucion, unless the plaque, monument or memorial commemorates a significant activity or event which occurred prior to February 22, 1821 or unless the plaque, monument or memorial commemorates the service to the city of citizens leading and participating in the civil rights movement in St. Augustine. Absent unusual circumstances, which shall be set forth in the recommendation, any other recommendation shall be for placement of a plaque, meeting uniform standards promulgated by the city manager, on the interior loggia columns of the Alcazar Hotel Building. 
(Ord. No. 92-27, § 1, 1-12-92; Ord. No. 09-14, § 1, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 22-10. - Regulation of street artist. 
(a)  Intent. The City Commission of the City of St. Augustine hereby ratifies, approves and adopts all of the foregoing predicate "Whereas" clauses. The City Commission of the City of St. Augustine finds that the existence in the city of street artists and the street vendors, as hereinafter defined, in the prohibited public area, as hereinafter defined, would interfere with the public health, safety, and welfare of the pedestrian traffic, including residents and tourists by, among other things, attracting audiences which congest the prohibited public area. The city finds that the existence of the street artists and the street vendors in the prohibited public area further would adversely affect the city's interests in the aesthetics incident to the oldest city in the United States and would adversely affect the interest of residents and the regulated, code compliant businesses and museums in the enjoyment of peace and quiet in their homes, businesses and museums. Also, the city finds that the existence of the street artists and street vendors in the prohibited public area would pose a safety risk to the public and passers-by by congestion and clutter in this area of St. Augustine. Therefore, it is the intent of the city to prohibit the street artists from performing in the prohibited public area of the City of St. Augustine and the street vendors from vending in the prohibited public area but to permit them to have access to reasonable alternative avenues of communication throughout the city. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Expressive speech includes by way of example and not limited to, creating visual art and wares such as paintings, drawings, prints, photographs, and sculptures. Expressive speech also includes, by way of example and not limited to, acting, singing, orating, playing musical instruments, performing pantomime, mime, magic, and dance, juggling and performance artistry. To the extent the forgoing list is viewed not as intended to be exemplary guidance but as exclusive, expressive speech also includes other activities recognized by courts as predominantly speech rather than any other purpose. Expressive speech does not include making or selling items which are intended to serve any functional or utilitarian use or purpose, or otherwise contain no first amendment expressive content, even if the item is decorative. 
(2)  Prohibited activity means any activity involving the use of fire, aerosol or spray paint. 
(3)  Prohibited public area means the pedestrian accessed public areas of St. George Street from Cathedral Place north to Orange Street and within fifty (50) feet of that section of St. George Street on the intersecting public lanes, streets or thoroughfares. 
(4)  Street artist means individuals who engage in expressive speech, as defined herein, on the property of the City of St. Augustine. 
(5)  Street vendors means individuals who sell or offer for sale, compensation or donation, or rent or offer for rent, goods, wares, merchandise, food stuffs, refreshments, or other kinds of property or services, on property of the City of St. Augustine. 
(6)  Other public areas means public streets, rights-of-way, sidewalks, parks, playgrounds, and all public ways except those portions of the streets and roadways intended for use by vehicular traffic within the City of St. Augustine. 
(7)  Vending means to sell or offer for sale, compensation or donation, or rent or offer for rent, goods, wares, merchandise, food stuffs, refreshments, or other kinds of property or services. 
(c)  Prohibition. No street artist may perform expressive speech in a prohibited public area. No street vendors may vend in a prohibited public area. No street artist or street vendor may perform a prohibited activity anywhere in the City of St. Augustine. 
(d)  Exceptions. A street artist shall not perform in a manner that interferes with the visibility of any motorist, or at or near intersections or passages in a manner which interferes with the sight distance of any motorist traveling on or entering any thoroughfare in the city. 
(e)  Penalties. Offenses under this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 00-03, § 1, 3-13-00; Ord. No. 00-41, § 1, 11-29-00; Ord. No. 03-08, § 1, 2-24-03; Ord. No. 09-28, § 1, 9-14-09; Ord. No. 17-27, § 1, 10-9-17) 
Sec. 22-11. - Regulation of walking tours utilizing public rights-of-way after sunset. 
(a)  Limits on size; additional tour guides. All walking tours conducted on the public right-of-way after sunset shall consist of no more than twenty-five (25) persons per group, excluding the tour guide. A walking tour conducted on the public right-of-way consisting of more than twenty-five (25) persons shall be divided into more than one group and shall be accompanied by an additional tour guide and shall maintain a sufficient distance between any other group so as not to impede pedestrian traffic and vehicular traffic. 
(b)  Lantern or flashlight required. The licensed tour guide accompanying such group shall carry a lantern or flashlight of sufficient intensity to be seen clearly and shall supervise the members of the tour group in a manner which will ensure that the group will not obstruct the portions of the right-of-way used for vehicular traffic for any reason except to cross the street, and the guide shall not allow members of the group to walk or stand in the vehicular traffic lanes for any other purpose. 
(c)  Exclusion for licensed tour vehicles. The provisions of this section relating to tour sizes shall not apply to groups which are transported on the rights-of-way on licensed tour vehicles and only use the public sidewalks incidental to loading or unloading licensed tour vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 06-15, § 1, 6-23-06) 
Sec. 22-12. - Sleeping, camping, habitation or leaving human waste in public places prohibited. 
(a)  Definition. As used herein, 'homeless' shall refer to an individual or family which has a primary nighttime residence that is: (1) a supervised publicly or privately operated shelter designed to provide temporary living accommodations (including welfare hotels, congregate shelters, and transitional housing for persons with mental illness); (2) an institution that provides a temporary residence for individuals intended to be institutionalized; or (3) a public or private place not designed for, or ordinarily used as, regular sleeping accommodations for human beings. The term does not include any individual imprisoned or otherwise detained. 
(b)  Prohibition on sleeping, camping, habitation or leaving human waste. No person shall sleep, camp or inhabit or deposit or leave any human waste or excrement, including urine and feces, under or on any public street, sidewalk, alleyway, park, plaza or other municipal place or under, on or over any furniture, vehicle, step, curb, fixture, monument, sign, landscaping or any other item or personal property located under, on or over any public street, sidewalk, alleyway, park, plaza or any other public place located within the municipal borders of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. The prohibition on sleeping, camping or habitation shall be effective from the hours of 10:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m. daily. The prohibition on leaving or depositing human waste or excrement shall be effective at all hours of the day or night. The city manager may post signs on public property advising the public of the prohibitions set forth in this subsection (b). 
(c)  Enforcement. This section shall not be enforced against persons defined as homeless unless such homeless persons have access to a public or private facility for their use in safely eliminating their excrement or unless such homeless persons have access to a supervised publicly or privately operated shelter designed to provide temporary living accommodations (including welfare hotels, congregate shelters and transitional housing for persons with mental illness) or an institution which provides a temporary residence for individuals intended to be institutionalized. 
(d)  Penalty for violating section. The penalty for each violation of the provisions of this ordinance shall be as prescribed by section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 07-03, § 1, 3-12-07) 
Sec. 22-13. - Prohibiting the vending and sale of foodstuffs, beverages and refreshments on the public streets, sidewalks, alleyways and rights-of-way of the city. 
(a)  Intent. The City Commission of the City of St. Augustine hereby ratifies, approves and adopts all of the foregoing predicate "Whereas" clauses. The city commission finds that the existence in the city of vendors and sales of foodstuffs, beverages and refreshments on the public streets, sidewalks, alleyways and rights-of-way of the city would interfere with the public health, safety and welfare of pedestrian, vehicular and emergency access traffic, including traffic by residents and tourists, by blocking and congesting the said public streets, sidewalks, alleyways and rights-of-way; would damage the aesthetics of an historically important city and would undermine the commercial life of the city. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Vendors means individuals who sell or offer for sale, compensation or donation, or rent or offer for rent, foodstuffs, beverages or refreshments. 
(2)  Vending or sale means to sell or offer for sale, compensation or donation, or rent or offer for rent, foodstuffs, beverages or refreshments. 
(c)  Prohibition. No vendors may vend and no sales persons may vend or sell foodstuffs, beverages or refreshments on any public street, sidewalk, alleyway or right-of-way anywhere in the City of St. Augustine. 
(d)  Penalties. Offenses under this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 09-30, § 1, 9-14-09) 
Sec. 22-14. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 22-15. - Provision for sale of merchandise and services on public property within the Ponce de Leon Circle and the Anderson Circle; provision for street performer activity within the Ponce de Leon Circle and the Anderson Circle; providing penalties. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Market in the Plaza ("market") means the historic market in the Plaza de la Constitucion, as represented on District No. 5, Official Map of the City of St. Augustine, adopted June 12, 1923, by Ordinance No. 164, as a rectangle at the east end of the plaza, as labeled on the official map. 
    Plaza means the Plaza de la Constitucion west of St. George Street, as represented on District No. 5, Official Map of the City of St. Augustine, adopted June 12, 1923, by Ordinance No. 164 and the rights-of-way and sidewalks located around the perimeter of the plaza. 
    Ponce de Leon Circle means the circular public park property located to the north of the plaza and surrounded by the rights-of-way of King Street, Charlotte Street, Avenida Menendez and Cathedral Place. Ponce de Leon Circle includes the sidewalks and rights-of-way located around the perimeter of the circle. 
    Anderson Circle means the circular public park property located to the north of Ponce de Leon Circle and surrounded by the rights-of-way of Avenida Menendez, Cathedral Place and Charlotte Street and the right-of-way between Charlotte Street and Avenida Menendez. 
    Street performer or street performances includes acting, juggling, singing, playing musical instruments, pantomime, mime, magic, dancing, artistry or the creation of visual art and wares, which includes drawings or paintings applied to paper, cardboard, canvas, cloth or to other similar medium when such art is applied to the medium through the use of brush, pastel, crayon, pencil, spray or other similar object, and the creation, display and/or sale of crafts made by hand or otherwise. 
    Street vendors means individuals who sell or offer for sale, compensation or donation, or rent or offer for rent, goods, wares, merchandise, food stuffs, refreshments, or other kinds of property or services. 
    Vending means to sell or offer for sale, compensation or donation, or rent or offer for rent, goods, wares, merchandise, food stuffs, refreshments, or other kinds of property or services. 
(b)  Prohibition of street vending. It is unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale, compensation or donation, or rent or offer for rent, goods, wares, merchandise, food stuffs, refreshments, or other kinds of property or services upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks, parks and other public places in the Ponce de Leon Circle and the Anderson Circle. Street vending is allowed in the market in the plaza as provided in section 22-6 of this Code. 
(c)  Prohibition of street performing. It is unlawful of any person to engage in any Street Performer activity in the Ponce de Leon Circle and the Anderson Circle. Street performing is allowed in the market in the plaza as provided in section 22-6 of this Code. 
(d)  Exemption for newspaper vending machines. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sale or offer for sale of newspapers through vending machines of general circulation. For the purposes of this section, "newspapers of general circulation" means a publication published at regular intervals, primarily for the dissemination of news, intelligence and opinions on recent events or newsworthy items of a general character, and reaching all classes of the public. 
(e)  Penalties. Offenses under this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 10-03, § 1, 1-25-10) 
Sec. 22-16. - Use of and/or construction in city rights-of-way. 
(a)  Definitions. In this section: 
(1)  Construction means any activity or installation, other than the placement of utilities governed by section 22-8 of this Code, performed within the boundaries of any city right-of-way, including, but not limited to, curb cuts; driveways; excavation activities; installation of pavers, poles, fencing, signage and sidewalks; structures or other improvements; and landscaping activities. 
(2)  Rights-of-way means any opened or unopened city street, roadway or alleyway or any easement or any real property owned by the city. 
(b)  Activities in city rights-of-way without permits. 
(1)  The following construction and/or use activities are prohibited within the boundaries of all city rights-of-way unless permitted in accord with the provisions of this article: 
a.  Installation of mailboxes other than units prescribed by U.S. Postal Service Standards and Florida Department of Transportation Parking and Traffic Design Standards. 
b.  Decorative walls. 
c.  Retaining walls. 
d.  Buildings or structures of any kind. 
e.  Barriers or obstructions of any kind. 
f.  Basketball goals. 
g.  Skateboard ramps. 
h.  Recreational structures of any kind, whether temporary or permanent. 
i.  Fences. 
j.  Swimming pools. 
k.  Parking lots. 
l.  Landscaping of any kind. 
m.  Any other facility, object or item requiring a permanent foundation or which cannot be removed readily. 
n.  Any facility, object or item designed and intended for personal or private use and not for public use. 
o.  Security lights and street lights. 
p.  Driveways, new, modified or replaced. 
q.  Any work, construction activity or item which creates an obstruction, whether permanent or temporary, to the free and complete use of the right-of-way. 
r.  Trenchless construction activities. 
(c)  Permits and revocable licenses required. 
(1)  Any person or entity desiring to install, place, construct or replace any improvement in a city public right-of-way shall obtain prior to commencement of any work a permit for such activity issued by the city manager or his or her designee on terms and conditions as defined below and, in certain instances, the issuance of a revocable license approved by the city commission. 
(2)  Fees for permits and revocable licenses shall be determined by resolution of the city commission. 
(3)  No use of or construction in a public right-of-way shall be permitted or licensed if that use or construction creates an obstruction, barrier or safety hazard as defined by generally accepted engineering practices. 
(4)  All requested uses of or construction in a public right-of-way shall be evaluated for the benefit of said use or construction to the general public or for whether the benefit to and convenience gained by a private property owner conflicts with the benefit to the general public for the use of the right-of-way affected. 
(5)  Revocable licenses are required for all improvements in the public right-of-way which are not accepted for maintenance by the city. Such improvements are for the benefit and pleasure of the property owner. License fees shall be adopted by resolution of the city commission. 
(6)  All revocable license agreements shall include terms established by the city attorney and shall be approved by the city commission upon recommendation of the city manager or his or her designee. 
(7)  The permit applicant shall be the owner or owners of the real property located adjacent to the affected right-of-way or a person designated by affidavit of said owner or owners. 
(8)  Time limitations. 
a.  In no case shall construction commence on any improvement within any public right-of-way or easement before a permit is issued. A permit issued by the city shall be valid for a period of one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of issuance. If a period in excess of one hundred twenty (120) days is required because of the scope of work, approval shall be obtained in advance of the issuance of the permit and the permit validation period shall reflect such extension. A permit shall not be extended more than three (3) times or for more than one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
b.  After issuance of the permit, the permittee shall notify the city public works department a minimum of two (2) business days prior to commencing construction. This notification will allow for scheduling of inspections. If a road closure is required, the permittee shall submit with the permit application a maintenance of traffic (MOT) plan to include all proposed road closures and an expected time duration for each closing. Road closures shall require separate approval by the public works department and a minimum of three (3) business days prior notification before the commencement or construction. Road closures of fewer than fifteen (15) minutes shall not require notification. 
(9)  It shall be the duty and responsibility of each applicant for a permit under this article to: 
a.  Make a written application for permit with the public works department on such forms as the city shall prescribe. No work shall commence until the engineer has approved the application and plan and the applicant has paid and provided all fees, deposits and certificates required by this article. The engineer shall review the application and issue a decision or comments for revision and will issue permit providing all conditions of the permit application have been met and all required fees, deposits and certificates from the applicant have been received. 
b.  Include in the application information stating the kind, character and purpose of the proposed excavation or opening and such other information which may be reasonably required to fulfill the requirements of this article. 
c.  Furnish in triplicate a detail plan with dimensions showing the location of the work to be performed under such permit. If approved by the engineer, one copy of such plan shall be returned to the applicant at the time the permit is granted. 
d.  Obtain a permit for each and every project. 
e.  Agree to save the city, its officers, employees and agents harmless from any and all costs, damages and liabilities which may accrue or be claimed to accrue by reason of any work performed under such permit. The acceptance of any permit under this article shall constitute such an agreement by the applicant whether such acceptance is expressed or not. 
f.  Pay a permit and engineering review fee and security deposit. Developers of major subdivisions may request to pledge assurances to the city in lieu of cash or check, and the city, in the sole exercise of the city's judgment and discretion, may accept or reject such assurances. 
g.  Furnish a certificate of insurance. 
h.  Keep the original copy of the permit and an approved copy of the plan in the possession of the party actually doing the work, and when required, exhibit such copy to the engineer, duly authorized inspectors or, in the instances of county and state roads, to the respective inspectors representing these authorities. 
i.  Agree to perform the work, in accord with the permit conditions, the regulations established under this article and such further conditions as may be imposed by the engineer. 
(10)  Bond. A performance bond, or other financial security, in form, content and execution approved by the city attorney, may be required to protect the city in the event the specified work is incomplete and certificate of occupancy has been requested or when damages to the right-of-way or any public property have occurred and not repaired in accord with good engineering practices or when the work is nonconforming as determined by the public works department. In addition to paying the permit and inspection fees established by resolution of the city commission, a performance bond or other security approved by the city attorney shall be due in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a nonrefundable processing fee plus two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) as a retainer refundable within thirty (30) days after completion of specified work. If the work in question exceeds a value of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), the bond amount shall be increased by the difference plus ten (10) percent of that difference. If said work remains incomplete after thirty (30) days, the bond will be forfeited. Such forms shall prescribe the manner in which noncompliance with the provisions of a permit or this subchapter shall be remedied and shall provide the necessary financial assurances to remedy any noncompliance. 
(Ord. No. 11-18, § 1, 9-26-11) 
Sec. 22-17. - Prohibition of street performances on certain portions of Hypolita Street. 
(a)  Intent. The City Commission of the City of St. Augustine hereby ratifies, approves and adopts all of the foregoing predicate "Whereas" clauses. The City Commission of the City of St. Augustine finds that the existence in the city of street performers, as hereinafter defined, in the prohibited public area, as hereinafter defined, would interfere with the public health, safety and welfare of the pedestrian traffic, including residents and tourists by, among other things, attracting audiences which congest the prohibited public area. The city finds that the existence of the street performers in the prohibited public area further would adversely affect the city's interests in the aesthetics incident to the oldest continuously occupied European settlement in the United States and would adversely affect the interests of residents and the regulated, code compliant businesses and museums in the enjoyment of peace and quiet in their homes, businesses and museums. Also, the city finds that the existence of the street performers in the prohibited public area would pose a safety risk to the public and passers-by by congestion and clutter in this area of St. Augustine. Therefore, it is the intent of the city to prohibit the street performers from performing in the prohibited public area of the City of St. Augustine but to permit them to have access to reasonable alternative avenues of communication throughout the city. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Perform includes acting, singing, playing musical instruments, pantomime, mime, magic, dancing, juggling and the display and/or sale of crafts made by hand or otherwise. 
(2)  Prohibited activity means any activity involving the use of fire, aerosol or spray paint. 
(3)  Prohibited public area means the pedestrian accessed public areas of Hypolita Street from a point fifty (50) feet east of the easterly right-of-way of St. George Street to the westerly right-of-way of Avenida Menendez as extended across the right-of-way known as Hypolita Street. 
(4)  Street performers means individuals who perform, as defined herein, on the streets of the City of St. Augustine. 
(5)  Other public areas means public streets, rights-of-way, sidewalks, parks, playgrounds, and all public ways except those portions of the streets and roadways intended for use by vehicular traffic within the City of St. Augustine. 
(c)  Prohibition. No street performers may perform in a prohibited public area. No street performer may perform a prohibited activity anywhere in the City of St. Augustine. 
(d)  Exceptions. A street performer shall not perform in a manner that interferes with the visibility of any motorist, or at or near intersections or passages in a manner which interferes with the sight distance of any motorist traveling on or entering any thoroughfare in the city. 
(e)  Penalties. Violations under this section shall be penalized as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 12-05, § 1, 3-26-12; Ord. No. 13-16, § 1, 7-8-13, eff. 7-18-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-16, § 1, adopted July 8, 2013, set out provisions intended for use as § 22-18. For purposes of clarity, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as amending § 22-17. 
Sec. 22-18. - Prohibition on sale or offer for sale of goods and services. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Vending means to sell or offer for sale, compensation or donation, or rent or offer for rent, goods, wares, merchandise, food stuffs, refreshments or other kinds of property or services. 
(2)  Vendors means individuals who sell or offer for sale, compensation or donation, or rent or offer for rent, goods, wares, merchandise, food stuffs, refreshments, or other kinds of property or services. 
(b)  Prohibition on vending. No vending shall occur at any time in the public rights-of-way described below: 
(1)  Hypolita Street from a point fifty (50) feet westward of the westerly right-of-way of St. George Street to the easterly right-of-way of Cordova Street. 
(2)  Hypolita Street from a point fifty (50) feet eastward of the easterly right-of-way of St. George Street to the westerly right-of-way of Charlotte Street. 
(3)  Cuna Street from a point fifty (50) feet westward of the westerly right-of-way of St. George Street to the easterly right-of-way of Cordova Street. 
(4)  Cuna Street from a point fifty (50) feet eastward of the easterly right-of-way of St. George Street to the westerly right-of-way of Charlotte Street. 
(5)  Treasury Street from a point fifty (50) feet westward of the westerly right-of-way of St. George Street to the easterly right-of-way of Cordova Street. 
(6)  Treasury Street from a point fifty (50) feet eastward of the easterly right-of-way of St. George Street to the westerly right-of-way of Charlotte Street. 
(7)  Fort Alley from a point fifty (50) feet eastward of the easterly right-of-way of St. George Street to the westerly right-of-way of South Castillo Drive. 
(c)  Exemption for newspaper vending machines. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sale or offer for sale of newspapers through vending machines of general circulation. For the purposes of this section, "newspapers of general circulation" means a publication published at regular intervals, primarily for the dissemination of news, intelligence and opinions on recent events or newsworthy items of a general character, and reaching all classes of the public. 
(d)  Regulatory penalties. Violations under this section shall be penalized as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 12-06, § 1, 3-26-12) 
Sec. 22-19. - Provision for street artist activity at the Historic Downtown Parking Facility East Loggia; establishment of a random lottery for space at the Historic Downtown Parking Facility East Loggia for street artist activity; provision for the procedures for said lottery; providing penalties. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Historic Downtown Parking Facility East Loggia ("East Loggia") means the covered exterior adjacent to the parking garage structure known as the Historic Downtown Parking Facility from the northeast corner of the parking garage structure extending south to the southeast corner of the parking garage structure, as shall be demarcated from time to time by the city manager. 
(2)  Street artist means those individuals as defined in section 22-10 of the City Code. 
(b)  Absolute prohibition of vending of certain goods. Notwithstanding any other provision in this section, the following goods and services shall not be offered for sale or donation anywhere in the East Loggia: Food, beverages, housewares, appliances, sunglasses, auto parts, oils, incense, perfume, lotions, candles and clothing and accessories (including handbags and shoes), jewelry, toys and stuffed animals, flashlights or "glow sticks" and items intended to serve any functional or utilitarian purpose containing no first amendment expressive content. 
(c)  Unlawful to engage in street artist activity other than as defined. Other than as provided for herein, it is unlawful for any person to engage in any street artist activity in the area known as the St. Augustine/St. Johns County Visitor Information Center, the parking facility and grounds surrounding the Visitor Information Center or the promenade in violation of city Resolution No. 2009-38. 
(d)  Lottery. The East Loggia shall be subdivided into twelve (12) spaces of approximately 8' × 10' in size that have been delineated with pins. Five (5) spaces will exist to the north of the pedestrian entrance to the parking garage, seven (7) spaces to the south of the pedestrian entrance to the parking garage. These twelve (12) spaces shall be available for street artists on a monthly basis. 
(e)  Procedure for lottery; applications. 
(1)  Applications for spaces in the East Loggia shall be available at the customer service division and shall provide for the following information: Name; address; street artist activity; and printed name and signature. 
(2)  Completed applications must be submitted back to the customer service division by 5:00 p.m. on the 20th day of the month prior to the month the applicant desires to engage in street artist activity in the East Loggia. In the event that the 20th day of the month falls on a weekend or a holiday, completed applications must be submitted back to the customer service division by 5:00 p.m. on the last day of normal business for the City of St. Augustine before the 20th day of the month prior to the month the applicant desires to engage in street artist activity in the East Loggia. 
(f)  Procedure for lottery: Drawing for space in the East Loggia. 
(1)  On the next business day following the deadline for applications to be received, the city comptroller, or his or her designee, shall randomly draw twelve (12) street artist applications from all applications received. 
(2)  The use of the twelve (12) spots by a permit holder is on a daily, first-come, first-served basis. No street artist shall make efforts to reserve a location; and each permit holder shall abandon a location at the end of his or her working day, including the removal of all personal property. 
(3)  Any unallotted spaces may be assigned by the city comptroller, or his or her designee, on a first come, first serve basis for payment of the administrative processing fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) after the drawing for space in the East Loggia is complete for any given month. 
(4)  Applicants that are assigned a space in the East Loggia shall be required to pay an administrative processing fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) within five (5) business days of the drawing and to prominently display a photo ID and permit, provided by the city, identifying the month of the drawing. Spaces assigned via the lottery shall not be transferable and shall only be for use by the applicant with photo ID provided by the city. 
(5)  Upon notification to the customer service division of space not utilized for seven (7) consecutive days, the customer service division shall contact the individual street artist not present and utilizing assigned space for confirmation of intent to abandon the space for the assigned month. If confirmation cannot be made the space will remain assigned as drawn for the month. If the assigned street artist confirms their intent to abandon the space for the month, the customer service division shall contact the next available applicant from the list of applicants received for the given months drawing. Upon payment of the twenty-five dollar ($25.00) administrative fee an id badge and permit will be assigned for use of the abandoned space. 
(g)  Description of street artist activity space. Within the designated area in the East Loggia, all activities including equipment and personnel and signage must be confined to the designated space demarcated by the metal pins referenced in subparagraph (e) hereinabove. Street artist shall not obstruct vehicular or pedestrian traffic, entrance to buildings, bicycle racks, handicapped access or vehicular parking, vehicular loading zones, taxi stands or franchised vehicles for hire stands. 
(h)  Penalties. Offenses under this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(i)  Indigency waiver. Street artists as defined in section 22-10 of the City Code seeking relief from payment of fees based upon an inability to pay must apply to the city clerk for a determination of indigent status using the form provided and provide the required information for such determination as required by section 2-79 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 17-29, § 1, 10-9-17) 
Secs. 22-20-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 22-31. - Permit required for private construction. 
    No person shall be permitted or authorized to build a sidewalk or foot pavement within the city unless the owner or the agent of the property shall make application to the city manager in writing for authority so to do, and shall have first received the written permission of the city manager so to do; provided, however, that no permission is necessary when the sidewalk is ordered constructed, repaired or aligned according to the provisions of section 22-33. 
(Code 1964, § 25-15) 
Sec. 22-32. - Owners required to construct upon notice. 
    Each owner of real estate within the corporate limits of the city, whenever required by the city commission so to do, shall construct and place a sidewalk or foot pavement in front of his lot, where the same fronts on any traveled street of the city, to the full extent of the frontage of such lot on such traveled street. Owners of lots shall also repair, rebuild or establish the grade on any sidewalk or foot pavements already built whenever required by the city commission and notice given to that effect. Owners of such lots are hereby required in constructing or placing such sidewalks or foot pavements to finish and complete the same with a curb of concrete along the whole length of the sidewalk or foot pavement. 
(Code 1964, § 25-16) 
Sec. 22-33. - Resolution requiring construction; notice to owner. 
    The city commission may by resolution declare that certain specified sidewalks and curbing shall be constructed or repaired, rebuilt or grade established. Upon passage of such resolution, the city manager shall cause written notice of the passage thereof to be served upon the owner or agent of each parcel of land abutting upon such sidewalk, who may be a resident of the city, in the manner provided by law for the service of summons in civil actions. He shall return a copy of the notice with the time and manner of service endorsed thereon, signed by the person serving it, to the city director of financial services, who shall file and preserve such return. For the purpose of such service, if the owner of such property is not a resident of the city, any person charged with the collections of rents or payment of taxes on the property, or having control thereof in any way, shall be regarded as the agent of the owner, and service upon such person shall have the like force and effect as though personal service were made upon the owner thereof. If it appears in any such return, however, that the owner is a nonresident or that neither such owner or agent could be found, one (1) publication of a copy of the resolution in a daily newspaper of general circulation in the city shall be deemed sufficient notice to such owner. 
(Code 1964, § 25-17) 
Sec. 22-34. - Failure of owner to construct after notice-Work to be done by city; report of costs. 
    If sidewalks or curbing are not constructed or repaired within sixty (60) days of the service of the notice provided for in section 22-33, or the publication thereof, the city manager may proceed by direct employment of labor, or by contract, to carry out such construction or repairs at the expense of the owner, as in the case of other improvements, and all such expenses shall be reported by the city manager to the city commission. 
(Code 1964, § 25-18) 
Sec. 22-35. - Same-Assessment of costs; collection; penalty and interest. 
    Upon the report of the expenses of construction of sidewalks under the provisions of section 22-34, the city commission shall thereupon by ordinance assess the costs and expenses thereof upon the owners of all the property bounding and abutting thereon. Such assessment shall be collected in the same manner as other assessments, with a penalty of five (5) percent and interest for failure to pay at the time fixed by the assessment resolution. 
(Code 1964, § 25-19) 
Sec. 22-36. - Same-Lien to be placed upon property. 
    The city shall declare and place a lien upon each piece of property so paved, under the provisions of this article, in the event that the owner of such property shall fail and refuse to pay his assessment. 
(Code 1964, § 25-20) 
Sec. 22-37. - To be built of concrete; specifications. 
    All sidewalks or foot pavements constructed or required to be constructed, and all sidewalks rebuilt or aligned to new grade within the corporate limits of the city, shall be built, erected and repaired of concrete, the mixture of which is contained in a specification on file in the office of the city manager and known and described as concrete mixture for sidewalks. 
(Code 1964, § 25-21) 
Sec. 22-38. - Width and grade. 
    On all streets in the city the sidewalks or foot pavements on each side of each street shall be of such width as may be determined by resolution of the city commission. The grade of all sidewalks or foot pavements in the city shall also be determined by resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 1964, § 25-22) 
Secs. 22-39-22-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING NUMBERING 

Sec. 22-61. - Posting of numbers. 
    Each building in the incorporated area of the city shall have its assigned building number properly displayed in accordance with and conformity to the requirements of this section, whether or not mail is delivered to such building or property. It shall be the duty of the owners and occupants of each building in the incorporated areas of the city to post the assigned building number on the property in conformity with this section as follows: 
(1)  The building number shall be made of a durable weather resistant material and shall be permanently affixed to the building front or to a separate structure such as a mailbox, post, wall, fence or other visible and commonly used area, in such a manner so as to be clearly visible from both directions and legible and without obstruction from the street on which the building fronts. 
(2)  The numerals shall be of a contrasting color with the immediate background of the building or structure on which such numerals are affixed and shall be not less than three (3) inches in height and one-half (1/2) inch in width. 
(Code 1964, § 25-33; Ord. No. 92-18, §§ 1, 2, 8-24-92) 
Sec. 22-62. - Procedure generally. 
    House numbering shall be done in the following manner: 
(a)  East-west streets lying south of Orange Street shall be commenced at the extreme east ends and numbered continuously to the western extremity with the even numbers on the north side and the odd numbers on the south side. East-west streets lying north of Orange Street shall be numbered from San Marcos Avenue in each direction. 
(b)  The numbering of all streets, except Malaga Street, Markland Place and South Castillo Drive, lying west of the Matanzas River or Bay and east of Ponce de Leon Boulevard and running north and south, south of Orange Street shall begin at Orange Street, or at a point near that street and be numbered continuously to the south extremity with the even numbers on the west side and the odd numbers on the east side. All streets running north and south, north of Orange Street, shall be numbered in a similar manner beginning at a point nearest Orange Street. 
(c)  The numbering of all north-south streets lying west of Ponce de Leon Boulevard, including Ponce de Leon Boulevard, and lying south of King Street shall begin at King Street and be numbered continuously to the south extremity with the even numbers on the west side and the odd numbers on the east side. 
(d)  The numbering of all north-south streets lying west of Malaga Street and Ponce de Leon Boulevard, including Malaga Street and Ponce de Leon Boulevard, lying north of King Street shall begin at King Street and be numbered continuously to the north extremity. 
(e)  All north-south streets lying west of Malaga Street crossing King Street shall be designated "South" south of King Street and "North" north of King Street. 
(f)  Castillo Drive lying west of its intersection with San Marco Avenue shall be designated as "West Castillo Drive." Castillo Drive lying to the south of its intersection with San Marco Avenue shall be designated "South Castillo Drive" and numbering in each case shall be from the intersection with San Marcos Avenue. 
(Code 1964, § 25-34; Ord. No. 94-30, § 1, 10-24-94) 
Sec. 22-63. - Allotting of numbers. 
    When subdivisions have been regularly platted and recorded, the numbering shall be made to conform thereto. When no regular subdivision exists, thirty (30) feet shall be assigned to each number in the city. 
(Code 1964, § 25-35) 
Secs. 22-64-22-85. - Reserved.

ARTICLE V. - VACATING AND ABOLISHING STREETS, ALLEYS, ETC. 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-176. - Fee for petition for vacation, abandonment of street, alley or other public way. 
    There is hereby levied and assessed a charge of a nonrefundable fee of four hundred dollars ($400.00) to be paid to the city upon the filing with the city commission of any petition for the vacation or abandonment of any street, alley or other public way. No petition for the vacation or abandonment of any street, alley or other public way will be placed by the city manager on the agenda of the city commission unless and until such fee shall have been paid. 
(Code 1964, § 25-7; Ord. No. 2007-07, § 2, 5-14-07) 
Editor's note- The effective date for this section is May 24, 2007. 
State Law reference- User fees authorized, F.S. § 166.201. 
Sec. 22-177. - Waiting period established for petitions previously denied by the city commission. 
    Whenever the city commission has denied a petition for a vacating or abolishing of a street, alley or right-of-way no further application shall be filed for the same street, alley or right-of-way for a period of one (1) year from the date of such action. In the event that two (2) or more petitions for the same street, alley or right-of-way or any part or all of the same has been denied, no further petition shall be filed for the same property for a period of two (2) years from the date of such action denying the last application filed. 
(Ord. No. 93-09, § 1, 4-12-93) 
Secs. 22-178-22-185. - Reserved.
