(Ord. No. 2013-10, § 1, 4-22-13) 
Sec. 22-333. - Iroquois Avenue. 
    Vacation. That the following described portion of the public street, avenue or road in the City of St. Augustine, Florida, more particularly described as follows: 
All that part of Iroquois Avenue (a 50 foot right-of-way as now established) lying Southeasterly of Block A and Northwesterly of Block B, Seminole Park, Map Book 3, Page 87 of the public records of St. Johns County, Florida and being bounded on the West by the Northeasterly right-of-way line of Cherokee Street (a 40 foot right-of-way as now established), and bounded on the East by the Southwesterly right-of-way line of San Sebastian Boulevard, closed by Resolution Number 1628 as recorded in Deed Book 203, Page 27 of said public records. 
be, and the same is hereby, vacated, discontinued and abandoned and is hereby declared no longer to be a public street, avenue or road of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. All expense incurred for relocation or modification of existing utilities on account of any use put to such property by the owners of the servient estate shall be at the expense of such property owners. 
(Ord. No. 14-12, § 1, 10-27-14) 
Note- Section 5 of Ord. No. 14-12 states, "This ordinance shall become effective upon the approval of the permitting of the bulkhead proposed to be constructed at the eastern end of Iroquois Avenue." 
Sec. 22-334. - Sebastian Avenue. 
    Vacation. That the following described portion of the public street, avenue or road in the City of St. Augustine, Florida, more particularly described as follows: 
All that part of Sebastian Avenue lying west of U.S. Highway #1. 
be, and the same is hereby, vacated, discontinued and abandoned and is hereby declared no longer to be a public street, avenue or road of the City of St. Augustine, Florida, subject to the easements set forth in Section 2 hereof. 
    Easements. There is hereby reserved unto the City of St. Augustine an easement for the installation, maintenance, repair and replacement of utilities and for access for such purposes, over, under and across the portion of Sebastian Avenue that lies parallel to and 10' west of the westerly right-of-way of U.S. Highway #1. 
    The vacation of the above portion of Sebastian Avenue is also subject to the rights of the State of Florida for the use and benefit of the Florida Department of Transportation, formerly known as the State Road Department of Florida, under existing drainage easements, including without limitation, those easements recorded in Deed Book 210, page 401, Deed Book 210, page 548 and Deed Book 211, page 214, all of the public records of St. Johns County, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 15-23, §§ 1, 2, 8-24-15) 
Sec. 22-335. - Moultrie Place. 
    Vacation. That the following described portion of the public street, avenue or road in the City of St. Augustine, Florida, more particularly described as follows: 
    Unopened Moultrie Place lying at the southernmost end of the alleyway (unopened Moultrie Place lying between the southeast end of Block 51, Lot 16 and west side of Block 51, Lot 7, PIN 2215600000) 
be, and the same is hereby vacated, discontinued and abandoned and is hereby declared no longer to be a public street, avenue or road of the City of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 16-24, § 1, 11-3-16) 
Secs. 22-336-22-499. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OUTDOOR CAFES ON AVILES STREET AND ARTILLERY LANE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, adopted October 26, 2015, amended article VI in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article VI, §§ 22-500-22-509, pertained to outdoor cafes on Aviles Street. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Sec. 22-500. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    Café means a use located adjacent to a public sidewalk on Aviles Street and Artillery Lane which is associated with bars and restaurants where food and beverages are prepared, served and sold and are delivered for consumption only in the café service area on Aviles Street or Artillery Lane. 
    Café service area on Artillery Lane means that area of Artillery Lane between Aviles Street on the west and Charlotte Street on the east extending east to include Artillery Lane from Charlotte Street on the west to the right-of-way intersection of Marine Street and Avenida Menendez on the east. The described area encompasses only the pedestrian alley or right-of-way. 
    Café service area on Aviles Street means that area between the easterly boundary of the west sidewalk located on Aviles Street south of King Street and north of Artillery Lane and the easterly boundary of vehicular parking spaces located on the westerly boundary of the right-of-way of Aviles Street south of King Street and north of Artillery Lane. The described area encompasses only the vehicular parking spaces located on the westerly right-of-way of Aviles Street south of King Street and north of Artillery Lane. 
    Café site map means a city-approved map detailing the location of the café service area on Aviles Street and Artillery Lane and of the pedestrian and vehicular pathway as they relate to a café located on Aviles Street and Artillery Lane. The "café site map" shall be available for viewing in the planning and building department. 
    License means the recipient of a sidewalk café use license under the terms and provisions of this article, and as provided for in the license agreement. 
    Sign or signs shall have the same meaning as provided for in section 3-22 of the Code of the City of St. Augustine and any amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, 10-26-15) 
Sec. 22-501. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an outdoor café on any sidewalk or public right-of-way within the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a café in the café service area on Aviles Street or Artillery Lane without obtaining a license as required by this article. Cafés shall only be located in the café service area on Aviles Street or Artillery Lane. 
(b)  The city manager, or his designee, shall have the right to remove, after twenty-four (24) hours' notice, any tables, chairs and other objects on any public right-of-way, sidewalk or property which are used in connection with a café which does not have a valid license. 
(Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, 10-26-15) 
Sec. 22-502. - License fee; renewal fee; and penalties for late payments. 
(a)  The annual license fee for establishing or maintaining a café shall be five dollars ($5.00) per square foot of usable café service area on Aviles Street or Artillery Lane, including the area between the tables and chairs, as determined by the city manager or his designee. 
(b)  The city manager, or his designee, may suspend or prorate the annual license fee in cases of public construction or emergency situations. 
(c)  The license fee shall be paid on or before October 1 and shall cover the time period from October 1 through September 30 of the following calendar year. No license shall be issued for any portion of a year, but any person or entity operating a café for a period beginning after May 1 of any year may obtain a license for the remaining portion of the fiscal year upon payment of one-half of the license fee required by this article. Except as provided in this article, no refund of the fees shall be granted. 
(d)  Late payments for license renewal fees shall accrue interest at the rate of ten (10) percent per annum for the first thirty (30) days. If the license renewal fee is not paid within sixty (60) days after it is due, the license shall terminate automatically. Any continued operation of the café after termination shall be construed as operating a café without a license to use city right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, 10-26-15) 
Sec. 22-503. - License application. 
(a)  A café is characterized by tables and chairs and may be shaded by awnings, canopies or umbrellas if development permits for same have been obtained. Application for a license to use city right-of-way for a café shall include, but not be limited to, the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of applicant; 
(2)  Name and address of the bar or restaurant; 
(3)  A copy of a valid City of St. Augustine business license tax receipt to operate a bar or restaurant fronting the location of the proposed café. The number of chairs proposed for the café must be included in the number of chairs authorized by the business license tax receipt; 
(4)  A copy of a valid use permit for the bar or restaurant fronting the proposed café; 
(5)  A copy of the receipt for payment of all utility connection fees due for the proposed café seating; 
(6)  A copy of a current certificate of insurance in the amounts and categories required by section 22-505 of this article; 
(7)  A drawing (to scale) showing the layout and dimensions of the portion of the café service area on Aviles Street or Artillery Lane proposed for use and of the adjacent private property, public right-of-way and public sidewalk; the proposed location of the café; the size and number of tables, chairs, steps, planters and umbrellas; the location of doorways, trees, parking meters, bus shelters, sidewalk benches, trash receptacles and any other sidewalk obstruction either existing or proposed within the pedestrian area serving the site of the proposed café; 
(8)  Photographs, drawings or manufacturers' brochures fully describing the appearance of all proposed tables, chairs, umbrellas or other objects related to the café; and 
(9)  An affidavit from the owner(s) of the property(ies) fronting the proposed café consenting to the operation of the café at that location. 
(b)  An application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable base application fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(c)  Applications shall be reviewed for compliance with city ordinances and must be approved by the following departments or divisions: Public works, planning and building, heritage tourism, fire, code enforcement and financial services. 
(Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, 10-26-15) 
Sec. 22-504. - Standards, criteria and conditions for license. 
(a)  Cafés on Aviles Street are restricted to the portion of the café service area on Aviles Street frontage directly across from a licensed bar or restaurant located on the west side of Aviles Street to which the license is issued or within the frontage of the building located on the west side of Aviles Street where the licensed bar or restaurant is located, provided that written approval for use as a café is supplied to the city by the building owner. The area of the license may also be extended by a maximum total of fifty (50) feet on either side or on both sides of the licensee's business, subject to the provisions of subsection (b) below. 
(b)  In the event the subject area of the license extends to a portion of the café service area on Aviles Street in front of an adjacent owner's property, the licensee must obtain written permission for use of such area from the adjacent property owner. The revocation or suspension of such permission shall operate to grant the licensee a prorated refund of the annual license fee paid to the City of St. Augustine for the operation of a café but shall not operate to grant the licensee a refund of any other fees paid to the City of St. Augustine for the operation of a café as required by this article. 
(c)  Cafes on Artillery Lane are restricted to the portion of the café service area(s) on Artillery Lane so that a clear three-foot or thirty-six-inch pedestrian walkway shall be maintained through the length of the right-of-way. The café must be associated with a licensed bar or restaurant operating adjacent to the right-of-way of the café service area(s) on Artillery Lane, provided that written approval for use as a café is supplied to the city by the building owner(s). 
(d)  In the event the subject area of the license extends to a portion of the café service area on Artillery Lane in front of an adjacent owner's property, the licensee must obtain written permission for use of such area from the adjacent property owner. The revocation or suspension of such permission shall operate to grant the licensee a prorated refund of the annual license fee paid to the City of St. Augustine for the operation of a café but shall not operate to grant the licensee a refund of any other fees paid to the City of St. Augustine for the operation of a café as required by this article. 
(e)  Licenses shall not be issued where the tables and chairs would be placed within five (5) feet of fire hydrants, alleys or intersections. 
(f)  No tables, chairs, umbrellas or other fixtures shall be allowed within five (5) feet of a pedestrian crosswalk or handicap corner curb cut. 
(g)  A café may serve any alcoholic beverages which they are entitled to serve and sell under that café's state beverage license. No such service shall commence unless the operation of the café has procured all necessary licenses for the sale and service of beer and wine, has provided copies of said licenses to the city manager, or his designee, has acquired insurance covering the sale and service of alcoholic beverages to which the city is named as an additional insured and has provided a copy of said insurance and endorsements naming the city as an additional insured to the city manager or his designee. 
(h)  No outside service or consumption of alcoholic beverages shall be allowed except within the boundaries of the area described in the café license and only during the regular hours of operation of the licensee's business provided such hours of operation do not violate the provisions of this Code establishing the hours for sale, service and consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
(i)  No object shall be allowed around the perimeter of an area occupied by tables and chairs which would have the affect of forming a physical or visual barrier discouraging the use of the tables and chairs or which would have the affect of obstructing the pedestrian use of the sidewalk, alley or the vehicular right-of-way located on Aviles Street or Artillery Lane, except that the city manager, or his designee, may allow the use of planters. 
(j)  Tables, chairs, umbrellas, and other objects incorporated into the use of the café shall be of quality, design, materials, size, elevation and workmanship to ensure the safety and convenience of users and to enhance the visual quality of the urban environment. Design, materials and colors shall be approved by the director of planning and building for appropriateness within the historic district prior to the issuance of the café license. 
(k)  Umbrellas and other decorative material shall be fire-retardant, pressure-treated or manufactured of fire-resistant material. Signs, lettering and images of any type are prohibited on umbrellas, chairs, tables and other permissible fixtures which are located on the public right-of-way. 
(l)  Prior to issuance or renewal of a café license, the city's finance director shall certify that there are no outstanding fines, monies, fees, taxes or other charges owed to the city by the person or entity requesting a café license. A café license will not be issued until all outstanding debts to the city are paid in full. 
(m)  Only one (1) sign shall be allowed per café for every fifty (50) feet of frontage. The location, size, design, materials and color of the sign shall be approved by the director of planning and building prior to the issuance of a café license, and the sign location shall be shown on the permit exhibit. The sign shall not be a sandwich board or A-frame sign. 
(n)  The license issued may be transferred to a new owner only for the location and area listed on the license. The transferred license shall be valid only for the remainder of the period for which it was originally issued. 
(o)  The city manager, or his designee, may require the temporary removal of cafés when street, sidewalk or utility repairs necessitate such action. If such temporary removal exceeds fifteen (15) days, the city manager or his designee shall prorate the remaining license fee for each additional day the café is removed and apply a credit toward the following year's license fee or if requested to do so by the licensee, refund the remaining fee to the licensee. 
(p)  The city manager, or his designee, may cause the immediate removal or relocation of all or part(s) of the café in emergency situations or for safety considerations. 
(q)  The city and its officers and employees shall not be responsible for café fixtures relocated during emergencies, nor shall the city and its officers and employees be responsible for lost business (i.e., meals, drinks or restaurant events) during emergencies. 
(r)  The license shall be specifically limited to the area shown on the "exhibit" attached to and made a part of the license. 
(s)  The licensee shall use positive action to assure that the operation of a café in no way interferes with sidewalk users or limits their free, unobstructed passage. 
(t)  A café license shall be issued only to bars where food is prepared and served and to restaurants. 
(u)  Tables, chairs, umbrellas and other allowable objects provided with a café shall be maintained with a clean and attractive appearance and shall be in good repair at all times. 
(v)  The area covered by the license and the sidewalk and roadway, or alley immediately adjacent to it shall be maintained in a neat and orderly appearance at all times by the licensee, and the area shall be cleared of all debris as needed during the day, again at the close of each business day and as determined by the city manager or his designee. Licensee shall also be responsible to clean the floor surface on which the café is located. 
(w)  No commercial signs shall be permitted except as provided for in this article, and in the license agreement. 
(x)  No tables, chairs or any other parts of cafés shall be attached, chained or in any manner affixed to any tree, post, sign or other fixture, curb or sidewalk in or near the café area. 
(y)  No additional outdoor seating authorized herein shall be used for calculating seating requirements pertaining to the location of, applications for or issuance of a liquor license for any establishment; nor shall the outdoor seating be used as the basis for computing required seating for restaurants and dining rooms or as grounds for claiming exemption from such requirements under the provisions of any city ordinance or state law. 
(z)  No food preparation, fire or fire apparatus shall be allowed on the café service area on Aviles Street or Artillery Lane, the public sidewalk on Aviles Street or Artillery Lane or the public right-of-way on Aviles Street or Artillery Lane, whether or not such area is covered by this license. 
(aa)  Upon the issuance of a "Hurricane Warning" by St. Johns County, the licensee shall forthwith place indoors all tables, chairs and other equipment located on the sidewalk or in the public right-of-way. The issuance of such "Hurricane Warning" shall constitute an emergency situation as referenced herein. 
(bb)  Only the café equipment specifically shown on the approved diagram and not otherwise prohibited shall be allowed in the license area. The estimated chair count per table may vary within the prescribed area provided that the chairs remain within the approved café area. No storage of chairs, tables, dishes, flatware or other café equipment shall be allowed in the license area, in any portion of the public right-of-way or outside the structural confines of the building in which the restaurant is located; however, the licensee may maintain such nonpermanent structures as rolling service stations in the licensed area during hours of operation. 
(cc)  There shall be no live entertainment, amplifiers or speakers placed in the licensed area unless allowed as a special event which shall not exceed two (2) days in length. Conditions such as hours and days of operation and audio levels will be regulated by the office of public affairs, and these conditions may vary during the year. 
(dd)  The licensee shall comply with the following design requirements regarding outdoor seating: Clear knee space under tables: 27? height, 30? width, 19? depth and 34? maximum table height to the top of the table. Alternatively, equivalent accessible seating may be provided. An acceptable example of equivalent seating would be a round table of 36? diameter, 4? stem and base with individual supports. The pedestal and base of the table shall not encroach in the clear floor area. 
(ee)  The licensee shall allow no lighting in the café service area except for lighting on each table which lighting shall have a self-contained power source. 
(ff)  The licensee shall comply with the Florida Accessibility Code for Building Construction. 
(gg)  The licensee shall be responsible for obtaining applicable state permits. 
(Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, 10-26-15) 
Sec. 22-505. - Liability and insurance. 
(a)  The licensee agrees to indemnify, defend, save and hold harmless the city, its officers and employees from any and all claims, liability, lawsuits, damages and causes of action which may arise out of the license or the licensee's activity on the demised premises. 
(b)  The licensee agrees to meet and maintain for the entire license period, at its own expense, the following requirements: 
(1)  Commercial general liability insurance in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence for bodily injury and property damage. The city must be named as an additional insured on the policy, and an endorsement must be issued as part of the policy reflecting compliance with this requirement. 
(2)  Cafés are prohibited from selling or serving alcoholic beverages other than beer and wine and are not required to maintain additional liability insurance for such purpose. 
(3)  Workers' compensation and employers' liability as required by the State of Florida. 
(4)  All policies must be issued by companies authorized to do business in the State of Florida. 
(5)  The city must receive thirty (30) days' written notice prior to any cancellation, nonrenewal or material change in the coverage provided. 
(6)  The licensee must provide and have approved by the city an original certificate of insurance as evidence that the above requirements have been met prior to commencing operations. Failure to comply with these requirements shall cause a suspension or revocation of the license. 
(Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, 10-26-15) 
Sec. 22-506. - Revocation or suspension of license; emergencies. 
(a)  The approval of a café license is conditional at all times. A café license may be revoked or suspended if it is found that: 
(1)  Any necessary business or health permit has been suspended, revoked or canceled. 
(2)  The licensee does not have policies of insurance which are correct and effective in the minimum coverages and amounts described in this article. 
(3)  The licensee exceeds the approved square footage by placing any additional tables, chairs or other equipment beyond the approved area. 
(4)  The licensee has failed to correct violations of this article or conditions of their license agreement within seventy-two (72) hours of receipt of the city manager's, or his designee's, notice of same delivered in writing to the licensee. 
(b)  In the event the licensee fails to remove any tables, chairs and other objects related to the café within seventy-two (72) hours of receipt of the city manager's, or his designee's, final notice of revocation or suspension, the city manager or his designee shall have the right to remove said objects. 
(Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, 10-26-15) 
Sec. 22-507. - Removal and storage fees. 
    If the city removes under any section herein tables, chairs or other objects related to a café, the licensee or café operator shall be responsible for the reasonable expenses incurred by the city for the removal and storage of said objects. The city manager, or his designee, shall promulgate and review, as needed, regulations regarding such storage and the disposition of property under this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, 10-26-15) 
Sec. 22-508. - Enforcement; notice of violation. 
(a)  Code inspectors or law enforcement officers shall issue twenty-four (24) hour warning notices for all nonlife safety violations of this article. Life-safety violations are defined as those conditions which exist involving serious danger to public health, safety or welfare, including violations of the Florida Accessibility Code for Building Construction, in which case the aforesaid notice shall not be required. 
(b)  If a code inspector or law enforcement officer finds a violation of this article, said inspector shall follow the procedures of sections 2-318 through 2-329 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, 10-26-15) 
Sec. 22-509. - Fine for violators. 
    A fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day for each day the violation exists shall be imposed for violators of this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-30, § 1, 10-26-15) 
Chapter 23 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Archaeological preservation, Ch. 6; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 8; housing discrimination, § 16-26 et seq.; planning and development, Ch. 21; trees and landscaping, Ch. 25; zoning, Ch. 28. 
State Law reference- Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166; subdivision regulations required, F.S. § 163.3202(2); adoption of land development regulations, F.S. § 163.3194; platting, F.S. § 177.011 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the Residential Subdivision Regulations of St. Augustine, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. I, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 1, 5-10-93) 
Sec. 23-2. - Definition of terms. 
(a)  The definition of the following terms given in F.S. § 177.031 are incorporated herein by reference: 
(1)  Alley 
(2)  Block 
(3)  Board 
(4)  Cul-de-sac 
(5)  Developer 
(6)  Easement 
(7)  Governing body 
(8)  Improvements 
(9)  Land surveyor 
(10)  Lot 
(11)  Municipality 
(12)  P.R.M. 
(13)  P.C.P. 
(14)  Plat 
(15)  Point of compound curvature 
(16)  Point of curvature 
(17)  Point of reserve curvature 
(18)  Point of tangency 
(19)  Public utility 
(20)  Right-of-way 
(21)  State plane coordinates 
(22)  Street 
(23)  Survey date 
(b)  All other terms used herein, except as the context indicates otherwise, shall have the same meanings and definitions as those provided by section 28-2. 
(c)  Certain words in these regulations are defined for the purpose hereof, as follows: 
    Division of real property, as used in the definition of subdivision, includes division by sale or transfer of land, includes division by survey and includes division by use of a drawing, map or plat. 
    Subdivider means any person who undertakes the subdivision of land. 
    Subdivision means the division of real property in the city into two (2) or more contiguous lots, parcels, tracts, tiers, blocks, sites, units or any other division of land, designated by reference to the number or symbol of the lot, parcel or such units contained in the plat or drawing of such subdivision for the purpose whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership, or if the establishment of a new street is involved, any division of such parcel. The work includes establishment of new rights-of-way and alleys and additions when they result in the division of real property. When appropriate to the context, the word also includes resubdivision and relates to the process of subdividing or to lands or areas subdivided. This shall not apply to gifts or devises within a family unit nor to any approved PUD subdivision as defined in the city's zoning ordinance. The following shall be exempt and not subject to the regulations prescribed by this chapter: 
(1)  The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots in the previously recorded plat is not increased and the resultant lots comply with the standards of this chapter and the zoning code. 
(2)  The division of land into parcels where each and every parcel therein is more than five (5) acres and where such division does not involve the creation, addition, or deletion of, or change in, public or private street lines or public or private easements for ingress and egress, of whatsoever kind. 
(3)  The public acquisition by purchase, acceptance of deed of dedication; or exercise of the right of eminent domain of strips of land for the widening or opening of streets. 
    The word "subdivision" shall and does include the division of real property contained in existing platted lots, regardless of whether or not such division creates less than two (2) additional lots, when the effect of such division is to increase the total number of lots or parcels in the previously recorded plat, or, when the effect is to add, delete, establish, create, change or alter street lines or public or private easements of whatsoever kind within the boundaries of the previously recorded plat. The word subdivision shall not include the vacation of roads pursuant to F.S. § 336.10. 
    The word "subdivision" shall not apply to the division of real property contained in an existing platted lot that is part of a subdivision that was recorded prior to the effective date of the legislation from which this chapter is derived, provided that: 
(1)  No parcel, lot or portion will be created whose lot area is less than one (1) acre. 
(2)  The lots as divided meet the standards set by the city's zoning ordinance. 
(3)  No previously existing lot line is moved, altered or changed. 
(4)  No street lines or public or private easements are created, added, changed or deleted. This shall not apply to the addition of a private driveway. 
This limited exemption shall not effect or alter the zoning ordinances that pertain to the subject property. 
    Title certification means every plat of a subdivision submitted to the city commission must be accompanied by a title opinion of an attorney at law, licensed in the state, or a title insurance company policy confirming that the lands as described and shown on the plat are titled in the name of the person executing the dedication as it is shown on the plat and that the developer has title to the lands. The title opinion or policy shall also show all liens, mortgages and other encumbrances on the land to be platted. 
    Transfer or sale means the change in ownership of either legal title, an equitable interest, or the beneficial interest, of a lot or parcel within a subdivision and includes but is not limited to contracts for sale and agreements for deeds; provided, however, it shall not include any contract for sale that specifically provides in bold print that the sale is contingent upon the recordation of a subdivision plat pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. V, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 23-3. - Application of chapter; conflicts. 
    The regulations set forth in this chapter shall be applicable to all subdivisions of land, as defined herein, in the incorporated areas of the city. In the event of conflict with zoning ordinances in existence on the effective date of the legislation from which this section is derived, the aforesaid zoning ordinances shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. III, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-4. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish procedures and standards for the development and subdivision of real estate within the city, in an effort to, among other things, insure proper legal description, identification, monumentation and recording of real estate boundaries; further, orderly layout and appropriate use of land; provide safe, convenient and economic circulation of vehicular traffic; provide safe and suitable building sites which drain properly and are readily accessible to emergency vehicles; assure proper installation of water and sewer improvements; help conserve and protect the physical, economic and scenic resources of St. Augustine and promote the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. IV, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-5. - Amendments. 
    The city commission may from time to time adopt amendments to the rules and regulations herein in order to effectuate fully the provisions and purposes of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. XV, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-6. - Grandfather clause. 
    This chapter shall not apply to subdivisions that have been approved by the city commission and recorded prior to the effective date of the legislation from which this chapter is derived. This chapter shall not apply to real property located in recorded or unrecorded subdivisions that are in actual existence on the effective date of the legislation from which this chapter is derived provided that such subdivisions meet the following criteria: 
(1)  There has been an actual sale or conveyance of a lot or parcel within such subdivision by the original subdivider to another person or entity prior to the effective date of this chapter. 
(2)  The sale or conveyance referred to in subsection (1) above was not made with the intent to place such subdivision within the exemption created by this grandfather clause. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. XVI, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-7. - Waivers and variations. 
    After a report from the planning agency and appropriate city personnel, the city commission may waive the requirements of these regulations where compliance would be a practical impossibility or would cause unnecessary hardship and/or where the owner proposes an alternative which conforms to the general intent and spirit of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. XI, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-8. - Enforcement, penalties and remedies. 
(a)  Any person who commits an unlawful act as described herein or who shall violate any of the codes, regulations, restrictions and limitations promulgated under the authority of this chapter is guilty of an offense punishable as provided in section 1-8. 
(b)  Any unlawful act or violation of any of the codes, restrictions and limitations promulgated under the provisions of this chapter may be restricted by injunction, including a mandatory injunction, and otherwise abated in any manner provided by law, and such suit or action may be instituted and maintained by the city commission or by any person affected by the violation of any such regulations, restrictions or limitations. 
(c)  A purchaser of land sold in violation of this section may within one (1) year from the date of purchase thereof, be entitled to bring an appropriate action to avoid such sale or to bring action against the seller for any damages which he suffers as a result of the seller's unlawful act, or both. This section specifically authorizes a remedy consisting of setting aside such unlawful sales. This section shall not be construed to limit civil or criminal actions otherwise permitted nor to reduce the time periods allowed by other statutes or laws of limitations. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. XIII, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-9. - Prohibited activity. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for anyone who is the owner or agent of the owner of any subdivided land in the city to transfer, sell, agree to sell or lease any part or portion of such land by reference to, exhibition of or other use of a plat, map or drawing of a subdivision of such land without having submitted a plat of such subdivision to the city commission for approval as required by this chapter and without having recorded the approved subdivision plat in the official records of the county. Penalties for the commission of such unlawful acts shall be provided in section 23-8. It is the specific intent of the city that the adoption of this chapter shall not create any penalty by the city or state for the sole act of negotiating to sell unrecorded subdivision parcels. 
(b)  No street, storm, sewer, water or sanitary facilities in connection with a subdivision shall be laid out, constructed, opened or dedicated for public use and travel, or for the common use of occupants of buildings or lots abutting thereon unless described on a subdivision plat approved and recorded in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. Public utilities may be recorded on a supplemental plat and may be referred to on the subdivision plat. 
(c)  See section 23-1 concerning building construction and building permit restrictions. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. VI, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-10. - Building construction and building restrictions. 
    All lots or parcels of land within a subdivided area shall have access to either a public street which has been accepted by the city commission as shown on a recorded subdivision plat or to a public street which has otherwise received the legal status of a public street or a private street dedicated for the use of such lot or parcel but not accepted for maintenance by the city, but for which appropriate arrangements have been made for maintenance privately. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. XII, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-11. - Bonding. 
(a)  The bonds referred to in this section may be in the form of a certified or cashier's check, irrevocable letter of credit, escrow agreement or surety bond, the terms of which shall be subject to the approval of the city commission. 
(b)  Surety bonds shall be with a bonding company doing business in the state and acceptable to the city commission. 
(c)  The owner shall file a surety bond with the director of financial services at the time the subdivision plat is finally approved by the city commission conditioned upon the faithful performance and completion of all construction, within one (1) year after the date the bond is received and approved by the city commission, of all improvements required under these subdivision regulations enforceable by or payable to the city in a sum at least equal to the cost of constructing the roadway and drainage improvements as estimated by the subdivider's engineer and further conditioned upon the payment of contractors, subcontractors, suppliers and materialmen providing labor or materials for the construction of such improvements. Such a bond shall be hereinafter referred to as a "construction bond." If at the end of one (1) year following receipt and approval of the construction bond by the city commission, the subdivider has not substantially completed the improvements required or requested of and received from the city commission an extension not to exceed one (1) additional year per extension, the city commission may, after notice to the subdivider, hold a hearing and require the subdivider to show cause why the construction permit should not be revoked and why the construction bond should not be forfeited. The subdivider shall have an opportunity to present evidence justifying the delay in completion at the time and place of the hearing so established and at the conclusion of the hearing, the city commission shall determine whether to grant an additional extension of time for the completion or to revoke the construction permit and forfeit the construction bond. In lieu of providing for a construction bond, and upon compliance with all other requirements of this chapter for final subdivision plat approval, the owner may request from the city commission approval for construction of the required roadway and drainage improvements prior to final plat approval. The city commission may, upon application by the owner, approve construction of such improvements provided as follows: 
(1)  Such improvements are completed within one year of approval by the city commission; and 
(2)  The subdivider/owner shall provide an engineer's certificate that all improvements are complete in accordance with city requirements and city staff has inspected such improvements. Upon completion, certification by an engineer and final inspection by the city of all improvements, the city shall approve the final plat for recording and the owner may proceed to sell property within such subdivsion in compliance with this chapter. 
(d)  Upon completion of all required improvements, the subdivider may, after inspection and approval of the city engineer, submit a letter to the city requesting that the city commission release the construction bond or, if aplicable, final plat approval. The request shall be in the city office fourteen (14) days preceding the date that the commission action is requested. Upon receipt of notice of action by the commission, the city shall, in writing, advise the subdivider of the action taken. 
(e)  Where request is made for acceptance of subdivision units or for release of the construction bond, the person seeking such acceptance or release shall first furnish a good and sufficient bond on a bonding company acceptable to the city in the amount of four dollars ($4.00) per running foot of road length contained within the subdivision unit to secure the maintenance of the roads and dedicated improvements. This bond is to be furnished as a guarantee against faulty workmanship, construction and materials. Such bond shall be submitted by the owner to the city commission and shall remain in force for a minimum of one (1) year following date of such release or acceptance, and such warranty bond shall insure the city commission for the maintenance of the dedicated facilities. 
(f)  One (1) year after date of acceptance of the warranty bond by the city commission the owner may submit a request to the city for release of the warranty bond. The city shall again review the subdivision unit in question, for appropriate commission action. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. X, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 98-01, § 1, 1-26-98) 
Secs. 23-12-23-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLAT APPROVAL PROCEDURES 

Sec. 23-36. - Generally. 
    The following procedures for securing subdivision plat approval shall be followed in submitting, reviewing and acting upon all subdivision plats within the city. The subdivider and/or his surveyor, engineer or land planner is encouraged, but not required, to discuss informally his preliminary studies and sketches for any subdivision of land with the city offices listed in section 23-38, as well as those of other offices such as the county health department or county community development department. Many times these discussions may lead to a more complete preliminary plan or plat as hereinafter set forth. During the review process, the subdivider or his agent may be called upon for consultation. Each preliminary plan or plat for a subdivision shall be presented for review prior to detailed development of the plat. This preliminary plan will benefit the subdivider in accordance with the degree of completeness of the plan. Such preliminary plan shall be accompanied by a written statement describing the proposed subdivision. Such preliminary plan and statement shall be reviewed by the city planning and building department, public works department, fire department and police department and shall be submitted to the city planning and zoning board for preliminary approval subject to such revision as may be deemed necessary. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, art. VII, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 2, 5-10-93) 
Sec. 23-37. - Master plan. 
    Where the subdivision of a tract of land is to be carried out in one (1) or more stages, a subdivision master plan of the tentative future lot layout, street system, water system, sewer system and storm drainage system for the entire tract shall be prepared and filed with the planning and building department. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 70.0, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 3, 5-10-93) 
Sec. 23-38. - Preliminary plat. 
(a)  All of the following city departments must approve preliminary plats prior to submitting to the planning and zoning board. A preliminary plat submittal meeting is recommended involving the appropriate city departments and the agent(s) of the developer. 
(1)  Planning and building department. 
(2)  Public works department. 
(3)  City manager. 
(4)  City attorney. 
(5)  City fire department. 
(6)  City police department. 
(b)  The city manager shall receive two (2) copies and each of the remaining offices shall be provided with one (1) legible reproduced copy of the proposed preliminary plat a minimum of three (3) weeks prior to submittal to the planning and zoning board for approval. Should any of these city offices decide that other offices or utility companies need to be involved, they may make necessary contacts and/or request additional reproduced copies for these offices and/or companies. 
(c)  This preliminary plat shall be prepared on sheet sizes of twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches with at least a one-inch margin on three (3) sides with a three-inch margin on the left side of the plat for binding purposes, and shall be in conformance with F.S. § 177.091. 
(d)  The plat will be reviewed by the city offices during the three-week period prior to submittal of the preliminary plat to the city planning and zoning board. The developer or his agent will be contacted during this period of time should any discrepancies be apparent that would affect preliminary approval. However, the reviewing offices' agreement as to acceptability of format and content is not to be construed as assurance of final acceptance by the city. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, §§ 71.0, 71.1, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 4, 5-10-93) 
Sec. 23-39. - Construction drawings. 
    Construction drawings of street, storm, sewer, water or sanitary facilities as appropriate will be reviewed by the city public works director prior to submission of the final plat to the city commission. The developer or his agent will be contacted during that period of time should any discrepancies be apparent in such construction drawings that might affect approval. However, the city public works director's agreement as to the acceptability of such construction drawings is not to be construed as an assurance of final acceptance of the plat by the city. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 71.2, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 5, 5-10-93) 
Sec. 23-40. - Final plat. 
(a)  The final plat approval can only be granted by the city commission in an open public meeting after review and recommendation by the planning and zoning board. 
(b)  The final plat shall be prepared by a currently registered surveyor or engineer of the State of Florida. The submittal must be one (1) original drawing and one (1) copy made in conformance with F.S. § 177.091. The city commission may grant approval of plats with slight variations provided that the variations do not conflict with the requirements of F.S. ch. 177. 
(c)  In addition, a drawing prepared on the same material as the final plat must be submitted for the property appraiser showing only dimensions of lots, rights-of-way and easements. This drawing must be to a scale of one (1) inch equals two hundred (200) feet and the sheet size must be twenty-two (22) inches by thirty-two (32) inches or smaller with a one-half-inch margin all around. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 72.0, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 6, 5-10-93) 
Sec. 23-41. - Required documentation. 
    Prior to recording a plat the following is required: 
(1)  Surveyors or engineers certificates on the plat. 
(2)  Construction plans for roadway design approved by the city. 
(3)  Drainage design plans approved by the city and the county health department. 
(4)  Certification of title or title opinion addressed to and in favor of the city. 
(5)  Dedications by owners on the plat. 
(6)  Dedications by mortgagees and lienors, if applicable, on the plat. 
(7)  Construction bond and/or warranty bonds as required under section 23-11. 
(8)  Signature of approval on the plat from: 
a.  City manager. 
b.  City finance director. 
c.  City attorney. 
d.  Planning and building department. 
e.  City public works director. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 72.1, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 7, 5-10-93) 
Sec. 23-42. - Dedication and adoption. 
    Every plat of a subdivision filed for record must contain a dedication by the developer. The dedication shall be executed by all developers, owners, mortgagees, lienors and other persons having a record interest in the lands subdivided, in the same manner in which deeds are required to be executed. When a tract or parcel of land has been subdivided and a part thereof bearing the dedication executed by the developers or mortgagees having a record interest in the lands subdivided, and the approval of the city commission has been secured and recorded in compliance with this act, all streets, alleys, easements, rights-of-way and public areas shown on such plat, unless otherwise stated, shall be deemed to have been dedicated to the public for the uses and purposes thereon stated. However, nothing herein shall be construed as creating an obligation upon the city commission to perform any act of construction or maintenance within such dedicated areas except wherein the obligation is voluntarily assumed by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 72.2, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-43. - Required fees. 
    An application fee of two hundred seventy-five dollars ($275.00), which shall be non-refundable, shall be paid by the developer prior to submitting for preliminary plan review. In addition, all expenses incurred by the city shall be paid by the developer prior to city commission approval. Additional fees shall be determined at a flat rate per hour as determined by the city manager in accordance with section 2-74 of the Code of the City of St. Augustine. Required fees will include all costs incurred by the city which may include private consultants necessary to complete plan review. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 72.3, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 8, 5-10-93) 
Sec. 23-44. - Final plat approval. 
    Approval of the final plat by the city commission shall be deemed only an acceptance on behalf of the public of the dedication of the streets and other public land as shown upon such plat unless otherwise provided, and shall not be deemed an acceptance for maintenance of the roads, streets, drainage, water and sewer systems and appurtenances installed by the subdivider or developer. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 80.0, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-45. - Suitability of land. 
    The city commission need not approve any subdivision plan and plat unless the land included within the subdivision is suitable for the various purposes proposed in the request for subdivision approval. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 80.1, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-46. - Prerequisites to recordation. 
(a)  Before any plat of a subdivision can be recorded, the owner or developer must comply with F.S. ch. 177. In addition to the requirements of F.S. ch. 177, all existing streets must be paved to city specifications, or paving performance or construction bond posted. 
(b)  Lot size must conform to zoning regulations and ordinances pertaining to the property as currently zoned. 
(c)  The plat must be reviewed and approved by the city public works director, city planning and building department and city planning and zoning board and the city attorney before presenting to the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 80.2, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, §§ 9, 10, 5-10-93) 
Secs. 23-47-23-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-66. - Suitability, conformity of land. 
    The land proposed for a subdivision shall be suitable for development and upon completion of the drainage construction described in the drainage design plans, shall not be subject to flooding, poor drainage, erosion or other conditions detrimental to the health, safety and general welfare of the public. To the fullest extent, subdivisions shall be designed so as to conform to and take advantage of the topographic and other natural features of the land, including the preservation of existing trees and watercourses. All proposed subdivisions shall comply fully with the existing zoning regulations applicable to the land. All roadway and drainage plans and construction shall conform to the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 90.0, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-67. - Data submittal and inspection. 
    The city shall be notified in advance of the beginning of construction on subdivision streets, drainage, sewer and water facilities. Drainage and roadway construction shall be in conformance with the plans submitted under section 23-41. 
(1)  Test reports prepared by a qualified competent, testing laboratory shall be furnished prior to requesting city acceptance of streets for maintenance on the following: 
a.  Florida bearing value tests on subgrade. 
b.  Compaction tests on subgrade and base. 
(2)  The city shall be notified of the completion of the following items of work and shall make an inspection of this work within two (2) working days after notification: 
a.  Storm sewers prior to backfilling (including underdrains). 
b.  Stabilized subgrade. 
c.  Curb and concrete work. 
d.  Roadway base. 
e.  Surface course. 
Should the city be unable to perform the inspection within the two-working-day period, the developer may elect to proceed with construction by providing certification by a registered engineer that work is performed in compliance with the specifications. 
(3)  A qualified city representative will periodically visit the project site to make a visual inspection of the progress of work and to assure compliance with the specifications. 
(4)  The city shall be notified when the project is complete. Upon receiving a written request for final inspection of the completed work, the city shall within two (2) weeks, perform the final inspection and shall notify the developer of the results of the inspection. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.5, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-68. - Lots. 
(a)  Lot arrangement and design shall be such that all lots will provide satisfactory and desirable division for the type of development and use contemplated. Lot sizes shall conform to the city's zoning regulations. 
(b)  Where possible, lot lines shall intersect streets and each other at right angles, and in no case shall a lot have an interior angle of less than sixty (60) degrees, unless approved by the planning and building department. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 90.4, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 11, 5-10-93) 
Sec. 23-69. - Utility and drainage easements. 
    Utility and drainage easements, if any, shall front along public streets and rights-of-way. Drainage easements only may be located along rear or side lot lines, provided that the easement is enclosed with fencing which separates dedicated easements along easement line and provides access gates at each right-of-way intersection fronting a public street. Fencing and gates shall be chain link type with a minimum height of four (4) feet from adjacent grade. Easements shall be a minimum of fifteen (15) feet in width or thirty (30) feet if an open ditch. Where utility and drainage easements are planned adjacent to the subdivision boundary, such easements must lie within the subdivision proper. Where required, front lot easements will be ten (10) feet minimum. Although the use of open ditches and swales is discouraged due to the difficulty involved with maintenance, an acceptable design preventing future congestion and erosion along swale and ditch bottoms and banks may be approved. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 90.5, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 12, 5-10-93) 
Secs. 23-70-23-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREETS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Minimum construction standards for streets, F.S. § 336.045. 

Sec. 23-81. - Access to public streets. 
    Every subdivision shall have adequate access to a publicly maintained road or street dedicated to public use which has been accepted for maintenance by the city, county or state department of transportation. Where a proposed subdivision does not immediately adjoin such a road or street, the subdivider shall provide access from the subdivision to a dedicated road or street in accordance with the requirements set forth within these regulations, or as otherwise may be specified by the city. All lots within a proposed subdivision shall have direct access to a street or road dedicated to public use, or approved private road. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 90.1, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-82. - Street names. 
(a)  New streets shall be appropriately marked at each intersection. New streets which are extensions of existing streets shall bear the name of the existing street. All streets shall be named in the following manner or in a manner acceptable to the city commission: 
Direction Long Short (Less than 
1,000 ft.) East and west Streets Places North and south Avenues Court Diagonal Roads Ways Curving Drives Lanes or circles  
(b)  In no case shall a name for a proposed street duplicate an existing street name, irrespective of whether the street is further described as an avenue, boulevard, drive, way, place or court. The commission reserves the right to approve and/or reject any proposed street name. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 90.2, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-83. - Blocks. 
(a)  Residential blocks shall be not more than one thousand eight hundred (1,800) feet in length. The width of any residential block shall be sufficient to allow two (2) tiers of appropriate depth, except where lots abut directly upon an expressway, major arterial, lake, waterway, or a land use other than residential. In the latter case, consideration shall be given in the subdivision design to the proper buffering of the residential lots. 
(b)  In a block over one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet in length or where otherwise deemed necessary to give pedestrian access to schools, local shopping centers or parks, the city may require right-of-way and pavement for pedestrian ways. Right-of-way for pedestrian ways shall have a minimum width of ten (10) feet. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 90.3, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-84. - Roadway design. 
    All roadway design construction plans submitted to the city for review and approval shall bear the seal and signature of a state-registered professional engineer responsible for the project and shall equal or exceed the following design standards: Roadway sections shall clearly show the type and depth of subgrade, proposed bearing value of subgrade, the thickness and density of the base course and the thickness and type of surface course. Typical cross sections are provided in Exhibits D through E to the legislation from which this chapter is derived. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.0, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-85. - Minimum right-of-way width. 
    Right-of-way shall be as listed below, or of sufficient width to provide for adequate drainage facilities and utilities whichever is greater: The city commission may allow limited lesser width under circumstances wherein the city determines the public interest would be better served by such exception. 
Road Classification R-O-W Width 
(feet) Marginal access 50 Minor street 60 Collector street 80  
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.1, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83)

    The minimum width of street pavement in subdivisions shall be as indicated below:

Sec. 23-87. - Pavement requirements. 
(a)  Stabilized subgrade. The requirements for stabilized subgrade for streets are as follows: 
(1)  Requirements. All roadway subgrades shall have a minimum depth and bearing value, based on the following: 
 Type of 
Development Compacted Stabilized Subgrade Depth Florida Bearing Value (F.B.V.) Residential 6;inch; or more (depending on soil conditions) 40 Industrial, arterial, collector 12;inch; 60  
Where the existing soils to be used in the roadway subgrade have the required bearing value, no additional stabilizing material need be added or mixed in. The width of the stabilized subgrade shall be a minimum of two (2) feet greater than the finished surface course. 
(2)  Stabilizing materials. The stabilizing material, if any is required, shall be high-bearing value soil, sand-clay, limerock, shell or other material approved by the city. 
(3)  Construction. The construction of the stabilized roadbed, including compaction, shall conform to the DOT Standard Specifications, latest edition. 
(4)  Testing. Tests for the subgrade bearing capacity and compaction shall be located no more than five hundred (500) feet apart and shall be staggered to the left, right and on the centerline of the roadway. When, in the judgment of the city, conditions warrant additional testing to assure compliance with the specifications, the developer's engineer will be advised in writing that additional tests will be required and the extent of such additional tests. 
(b)  Base courses. The base courses for streets shall be as follows: 
(1)  Requirements. Subject to the recommendation of the city, base course materials may be either limerock, coquina shell, soil-cement or suitable/local materials, with a minimum thickness and density as follows: 
   Type 
Development Minimum Thickness Minimum Density Residential 6;inch; 95% modified proctor Industrial, arterial, collector 8;inch; 95% modified proctor  
(2)  Materials and construction. The width shall be a minimum of one (1) foot greater than the finished surface course. Limerock and coquina shell shall conform to the DOT Standard Specifications, latest edition, for base course materials, including construction methods. 
Soil-cement bases shall conform to the Portland Cement Association Specifications, latest edition, for materials and construction methods. 
(3)  Prime and tack coats. All bases shall be primed in accordance with the DOT Standard Specifications, latest edition. Tack coat shall not be required on primed bases except on areas which have become excessively dirty and cannot be cleaned, or in areas where the prime has cured and lost all bonding effect. If required, tack coat material and construction methods shall conform to DOT Standard Specifications, latest edition. 
(4)  Testing. Tests for base thickness and compaction shall be located no more than five hundred (500) feet apart and shall be staggered to the left, right and on the centerline of the roadway. When conditions warrant additional testing to assure compliance with the specifications, the developer's engineer will be advised in writing that additional tests will be required and the extent of such additional tests. 
(c)  Surface course for flexible pavements. The surface course for flexible street pavements shall be as follows: 
(1)  Requirements. Surface covers for flexible pavements shall be Type S or Type II asphaltic concrete, and shall meet the following minimum thickness requirements: 
 Type of 
Development Roadway 
Classification Minimum Surface Course Thickness 
(inches) Residential Marginal access 1  Minor street 1  Collector street 11/4 Industrial Marginal access 11/4 Minor street 11/4 Collector street 11/2  
(2)  Materials and construction. Asphaltic concrete Type S or Type II, including prime and tack coats, shall conform to the DOT Standard Specifications, latest edition, for materials and method of construction. 
(d)  Portland cement concrete pavement. The requirements for Portland cement concrete street pavement shall be as follows: 
(1)  Stabilized subgrade thickness requirements. Stabilized subgrade requirements for Portland cement concrete pavements shall be the same as those for flexible pavements. 
(2)  Pavement. Minimum pavement thickness requirements are as follows: 
Type of Development Minimum Thickness 
(inches) Residential 6 Industrial, arterial, collector 8  
(3)  Materials and construction. Portland cement concrete pavement, including joints, shall conform to the DOT Standard Specifications, latest edition, for materials and method of construction. 
(e)  Test results. Contractors must provide certified test results of the degrees of compaction of the subgrade and the base from an independent, qualified test laboratory. 
(f)  Protection against erosion. Grassing and mulching will be included on the subdivision roadside as deemed necessary by the developer to protect his one-year warranty bond against erosion and rivulets caused by surface runoff from the road surface. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.3, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 13, 5-10-93) 
Secs. 23-88-23-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DRAINAGE DESIGN 

Sec. 23-96. - Generally. 
    The drainage design plan for the subdivision shall equal or exceed design standards set forth hereinafter and the policies and procedures established in the Drainage Manual of the Florida Department of Transportation, and the design criteria contained therein. Unstable and highly erosive soil conditions prevalent in the city indicate that design velocity is critical. The maximum allowable velocity shall be in conformance with the values stated in the drainage manual, but not in excess of five (5) feet per second. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.4, 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-97. - Drainage map. 
    The subdivision engineer or surveyor shall include in the construction plans a master drainage map showing all existing and proposed features. The map shall be prepared on a scale not to exceed one (1) inch equals two hundred (200) feet. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.4(1), 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-98. - Roadway ditch gradient. 
(a)  Minimum gradient shall be one-tenth (0.1) percent or the minimum required to provide for the design flow, whichever is greater. 
(b)  Maximum gradients shall be determined from soil characteristics. In unstable and highly erosive soil conditions, the maximum allowable gradient shall be that which will produce allowable velocities consistent with the provisions of the DOT Drainage Manual. 
(c)  Unless otherwise required by the county, the following will be standard ditch protection: 
Ditch Gradient Protection Required Less than 1.0% Grassing and mulching 1.0% - 1.99% Sodding 2.0% - Greater Ditch paving  
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.4(2), 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-99. - Sidedrains for roadway ditches. 
(a)  Placement. Sidedrain pipe shall be placed in the ditch line of the proposed roadway ditch with an invert elevation three-tenths (0.3) of a foot below the proposed ditch grade. 
(b)  Construction details. A schedule showing the size and type sidedrain needed to gain entrance to each subdivision lot shall appear in the subdivision construction plan. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.4(3), 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-100. - Minimum pipe size. 
    The minimum pipe size for culverts shall be as follows: 
Type Culvert Minimum Size Crossdrains 15;inch; or equivalent Sidedrains 15;inch; or equivalent  
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.4(4), 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-101. - Materials. 
    The following pipe materials are acceptable: 
(1)  Reinforced concrete pipe. 
(2)  Corrugated steel pipe and pipe arch, asphalt coated in non-corrosive areas only. 
(3)  Structural plate steel pipe and pipe arch, asphalt coated in non-corrosive areas only. 
(4)  Corrugated clad aluminum pipe and pipe arch in non-corrosive areas only. 
(5)  Polyvinyl chloride and polyethylene. 
Workmanship and pipe materials shall conform to department of transportation specifications, latest edition. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.4(5), 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83; Ord. No. 93-07, § 14, 5-10-93) 
Sec. 23-102. - Length. 
    The maximum length of pipe to be used without an access structure shall be: 
Pipe Size Maximum Length 15;inch; 100;ft; 18;inch; - 36;inch; 400;ft; 42;inch; - Larger At discretion of engineer  
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.4(6), 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Sec. 23-103. - Retention basins. 
    Where a positive outfall is inadequate and revision of the outfall is not practical, the developer may include a retention basin in the drainage system as a means of metering outfall flow. In all cases, the basin shall be located in such a manner as to minimize damage when the design storm is exceeded. As used herein the term "design storm" shall refer to a fifty-year storm. Sufficient drainage right-of-way shall be set aside to allow for egress, ingress and a continuous adequate maintenance berm around the perimeter of the retention basin. 
(Ord. No. 83-9, § 91.4(7), 4-11-83; Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 7-11-83) 
Chapter 24 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law, F.S. ch. 316; powers of local authorities, F.S. §§ 316.006-316.008. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section. The definitions in F.S. ch. 316 apply to this chapter. 
    Curb or curbline. The lateral boundaries of that portion of the street designated for the use of vehicles, whether marked by concrete curbing or curbstones, or not so marked. 
(Code 1964, § 29-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definitions generally, F.S. § 316.003. 
Sec. 24-2. - Public employees to obey traffic regulations. 
(a)  The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the drivers of vehicles upon the highways shall apply to the drivers of all vehicles owned or operated by the United States, this state, or any county, city, town, district or any other political subdivision of the state, subject to such specific exceptions as are set forth in this chapter. 
(b)  Unless specifically made applicable, the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to persons, teams or motor vehicles and other equipment while actually engaged in work upon the surface of a highway, but shall apply to such persons and vehicles when traveling to or from such work. 
(Code 1964, § 29-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 316.072(4). 
Sec. 24-3. - Applicability to animals and animal-drawn vehicles. 
    Every person driving an animal-drawn vehicle upon a roadway is subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter which by their nature can have no application. The provisions of this chapter applicable to pedestrians apply to any person riding or leading an animal upon a roadway or the shoulder thereof. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 316.073. 
Sec. 24-4. - Exemptions to authorized emergency vehicles. 
    The provisions of this chapter regulating the operation, parking and standing of vehicles shall apply to authorized emergency vehicle as defined in this chapter, except that a driver when operating any such vehicle in an emergency, except when otherwise directed by a police officer, may park or stand notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 29-5) 
Sec. 24-5. - Powers and duties of city manager and chief of police relative to traffic generally. 
(a)  The city manager and chief of police of the city, except as otherwise directed by this chapter and except as otherwise directed from time to time by the city commission, shall have power and they are hereby authorized to regulate the operation and parking of vehicles within the corporate limits of the city by the erection or placing of proper signs or markers indicating prohibited or limited parking, restricted speed areas, one-way streets, through or arterial streets, stop streets, U-turns, play streets, school zones, hospital zones, loading and unloading zones, quiet zones and other signs or markers indicating the place and manner of operating or parking vehicles within the corporate limits of the city. The city manager and chief of police shall also have power and they are hereby authorized to designate bus stops and taxicab stands and to erect signs prohibiting the parking of vehicles other than buses and taxicabs in such stands. The city manager and chief of police shall also have power and they are hereby authorized to designate truck routes and to regulate the parking of vehicles of various sizes and weights. The city manager and chief of police shall further have power and they are hereby authorized to cause all such necessary signs or markers to be erected or placed on any street or part of a street when they deem such action necessary. 
(b)  The city manager and chief of police shall also have power and they are hereby authorized to fix the speed limit on streets which are narrow or winding, or where special hazards exist with respect to pedestrians or other traffic or by reason of street conditions. 
(c)  The city manager and chief of police are further empowered and authorized to mark off traffic lanes on streets and parts of streets indicating and directing the flow of traffic, when, in their judgment, such action is necessary. 
(d)  The existence of such signs or markers at any place within the corporate limits of the city shall be prima facie evidence that such signs or markers were erected or placed by and at the direction of the city manager and chief of police and in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(e)  Any person failing or refusing to comply with the directions indicated on any sign or marker erected or placed in accordance with the provisions of this section when so placed or erected shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 29-2) 
Sec. 24-6. - Permits for oversize, overweight, etc., vehicles. 
    The city manager is authorized to issue permits pursuant to F.S. § 316.550 when the same will not endanger the public safety. 
(Code 1964, § 29-133) 
Sec. 24-7. - Operation of certain freight motor vehicles restricted to designated streets.

Sec. 24-9. - Roller skating, skateboarding restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to roller skate, or skateboard, roller blade/in-line skate, or ride a push scooter or bicycle, on the roadway or on any sidewalk which is a part of that portion of St. George Street north of Cathedral Place and south of the City Gates. 
(b)  (1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to skateboard in the Plaza de la Constitution, or the City Commons or on any sidewalk located in any commercial or historically zoned areas. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to do any of the activities described above on, in or upon the Santo Domingo Redoubt or any historic or re-created historic structure or monument. 
(c)  Every person engaged in the business of renting or selling roller skates within the boundaries of the city shall keep posted in a conspicuous place or places in and about his place or places of business typewritten or printed notices in substantial compliance with the form prescribed herein eight-and-one-half-inch by eleven-inch paper or cardboard stock which shall be headed "Warning: $5.00 fine, $15.00 fine" in letters not less than three-quarter-inch high: 
    Warning: Roller skating on any roadway, except while crossing a street on a crosswalk, may constitute a violation of F.S. § 316.2065 and subject the violator to a $5.00 fine. Obstruction of traffic or endangering the safe movement of vehicles or pedestrians may constitute a violation of F.S. § 316.2045 and subject the violator to a $15.00 fine. Skating on St. George north of Cathedral Place constitutes a violation of City Ordinance No. 80-5 and may subject the violator to a $15.00 fine. 
(d)  Violation of subsection (a) or (b) above shall constitute a traffic infraction punishable as provided by F.S. § 318.18(2). Violations of the provisions of subsection (c) hereof shall be punishable as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 29-6.1; Ord. No. 04-04, § 1, 2-23-04) 
Sec. 24-10. - Boarding or alighting from vehicles in motion. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion. 
(Code 1964, § 29-11)

For the purpose of this section, the 'traffic lanes' of the roadway shall be defined as the paved area of the roadway located between the curbs of said highway which are designated for vehicular traffic and the median located between said curbs. The traffic lanes shall not include sidewalks located within the right-of-way.

ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing or parking, F.S. § 316.008(1)(a); stopping, standing and parking generally, F.S. § 316.194 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-31. - Penalties. 
(a)  It shall be a civil infraction for any person to violate any of the sections of this article. 
(b)  All parking ticket citations issued for violations of sections 24-40, 24-42, 24-75, 24-78, 24-79, 24-80 or 24-81 shall require the payment of a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), as may be amended in the future pursuant to section (h) below, within one (1) to fifteen (15) days from the date of issuance of the parking ticket citation. 
(c)  All parking ticket citations issued for violations of sections 24-39, 24-41, 24-45, 24-46 or 24-47 shall require the payment of a fine of thirty-five dollars ($35.00), as may be amended in the future pursuant to section (h) below, within one (1) to fifteen (15) days from the date of issuance of the parking ticket citation. 
(d)  All parking ticket citations issued for violations of section 24-43 shall require the payment of a fine of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), as may be amended in the future pursuant to section (h) below, within one (1) to fifteen (15) days from the date of issuance of the parking ticket citation. 
(e)  In the event the recipient of a parking ticket citation notifies the city finance, management and budget department within fifteen (15) days of the violation of the recipient's intention to contest the parking violation; then and in that event, the infraction shall be transferred to the county court for determination of the alleged civil infraction in accordance with general law and the penalty for such violation shall be as set forth herein.
