Both the amount of land and the type and amount of landscaping required for each bufferyard are designed to ameliorate nuisances between adjacent land uses or between a land use and a public street. These bufferyards have been calculated to insure that they do function as "buffers." 
(e)  Bufferyards required. Bufferyards shall be required to eliminate or reduce potential nuisances, such as dirt, litter, noise, glare, unsightly buildings or parking lots, and to provide spacing to reduce the adverse impacts of noise, odor, danger from fire, and differing intensities of land use. 
(f)  Bufferyards San Marco Avenue Design Standards. Developments that must comply with the San Marco Avenue Design Standards, and which use the residential typology, may locate the required front landscaping bufferyard anywhere between the front building façade and the front property line. The planted area must contain the equivalent front bufferyard planting requirements. 
(g)  Location of required bufferyards. Bufferyards shall be located along the perimeter of the property being developed, abutting the property line. Bufferyards shall not be located on an existing or dedicated public right-of-way. 
(1)  Table of bufferyard requirements. The letter designations contained in this table refer to the specific required bufferyards contained in subsection (f)(3) below. Use of native vegetation shall reduce the required number of plant units by ten (10) percent in those bufferyards where a fence is not required.

(2)  Bufferyard requirements. These requirements are stated in terms of width and the number of trees and shrubs required per one-hundred (100) linear feet of bufferyard. Any of the options illustrated shall satisfy the requirements of this section. The "unit multiplier" is a factor by which the basic number of plant materials required for a given bufferyard is determined for the indicated widths of the required bufferyard. 
(3)  Specific required bufferyards: 
a.  Classification 1: 
Front ..... B 
Side/rear ..... A 
b.  Classification 2: 
Front ..... D 
Side/rear ..... C 
c.  Classification 3: 
Front ..... E 
Side/rear ..... D 
d.  Classification 4: 
Front ..... F 
Side/rear ..... E 
e.  Classification 5: 
Front ..... G 
Side/rear ..... E 
f.  Classification 6: 
Front ..... H 
Side/rear ..... G 
(4)  Parking area requirements. 
a.  Adjacent to public rights-of-way. Bufferyards between parking areas and public rights-of-way shall form a solid opaque mass or screen of landscaping at least twenty-four (24) inches in height upon planting. This bufferyard may be composed of a berm with a maximum height of thirty (30) inches in conjunction with landscaping, with a total height of not less than thirty-six (36) inches in height at installation. A wall or fence of at least thirty-six (36) inches in height, but less than forty-eight (48) inches in height may be used in conjunction with landscaping, with the wall or fence installed adjacent to the parking area and the required landscaping installed between the wall or fence and the property line. When a mass or screen of landscape material is used, it shall obtain opacity within twelve (12) months of planting under normal growing conditions. 
b.  Intersection visibility. Where an accessway intersects a public right-of-way, landscaping shall be used to define the intersection provided, however, that all landscaping within the triangular areas described below shall provide unobstructed cross visibility at a level between two (2) and six (6) feet above the ground. Trees having limbs and foliage extending into this cross visibility area shall be allowed, provided that they are so located so as not to create a traffic hazard. Landscaping, except grass and ground cover, shall not be located closer than three (3) feet from the edge of any accessway pavement. The triangular areas are: 
1.  The areas of property on both sides of an accessway formed by the intersection of each side of the accessway and the public right-of-way pavement line with two (2) sides of each triangle being ten (10) feet in length from the point of intersection and the third side being a line connecting the ends or the other sides. 
2.  The area of property located at a corner formed by the intersection of two (2) or more public rights-of-way with two (2) sides of the triangular areas being measured thirty (30) feet in length along the abutting edges of pavement, from their point of intersection, and the third being a line connecting the ends of the other two (2) lines. 
c.  Adjacent to other properties. Where parking areas are adjacent to surrounding properties, landscaping shall be installed to screen parking areas from adjacent properties. All land between parking areas and the property line shall be screened with a wall or fence, or a combination of a berm, hedge or other landscaping at least forty-eight (48) inches in height at installation which shall form a continuous opaque screen under normal growing conditions. 
d.  Adjacent to residentially zoned properties. Whenever a parking facility containing ten (10) or more spaces is located closer than fifteen (15) feet to a residentially zoned lot, and is not entirely screened visually by intervening structures, a continuous opaque screen at least six (6) feet in height shall be provided along the adjoining property line. This screen shall consist of a solid wall or fence, or a mass of shrubbery at least five (5) feet in height at the time of installation. This screening requirement shall be in addition to any other landscape or bufferyard requirements. 
(5)  Internal landscaping. All parking areas shall have internal landscaping to provide visual and climatic relief from broad expanses of pavement, and to direct and define logical areas for pedestrian and vehicular circulation. 
a.  Within each parking area of five thousand (5,000) square feet or more, there shall be a minimum of five (5) percent of landscaped areas which shall be reasonably distributed within each five thousand (5,000) square feet of parking area so as to be prorated to fulfill the objectives of this article. 
b.  Each separate planting area shall contain at least one (1) tree and a tree shall be planted for each one hundred (100) square feet of internal landscaping. All internal landscaping shall be protected from vehicular encroachment by curbing or wheel stops. All landscape areas shall be a minimum of one hundred (100) square feet, with the least dimension being five (5) feet. 
(6)  Nonresidential uses abutting residential uses. Where nonresidential land uses are proposed abutting existing residential land uses in districts zoned for residential land uses, the bufferyards required for nonresidential uses shall be the next more intensive bufferyard. 
(7)  Buffers between districts. Where an RG-1, RG-2, RGO, RL-1, MU, commercial or industrial district abuts an RS-1 or RS-2 district, without an intervening street or alley, any use which is not permitted or permissible by exception in the RS-1 or RS-2 district shall provide a visual barrier consisting of a solid wall, fence or shrubbery, at least six (6) feet in height, along all side and rear property lines so abutting. 
(Ord. No. 04-17, § 1, 10-25-04; Ord. No. 18-09, § 3, 6-25-18) 
Sec. 25-55. - Plan approval. 
    All applications for use permits or building permits for development shall be accompanied by a site plan which indicates compliance with the requirements of this chapter. Such site plans shall be submitted to the city planning and building division. The site plan shall be drawn to scale normally of not less than one (1) inch equals thirty (30) feet. A different scale may be permitted for good causes shown. Such site plan shall include: 
(1)  All trees to be retained, removed, relocated or planted, by species and dbh., and all shrubs and ground covers to be retained, removed, relocated or planted, by species and size. 
(2)  Existing and proposed planting areas. 
(3)  Existing and proposed parking areas. 
(4)  An irrigation system, including heads, valves, backflow prevention device and pump, that provides one hundred (100) percent coverage. Landscape classifications 1 and 2 may provide, in lieu of an irrigation system, water outlets located to cover an area of no greater than fifty (50) feet radius to provide complete coverage of all landscape areas. 
(5)  Existing and/or proposed structures, sidewalks, pools, fences, walls, exterior mechanical equipment, dumpsters, storm drainage retention areas and other improvements. 
(Ord. No. 04-17, § 1, 10-25-04) 
Sec. 25-56. - Tree removal and replacement. 
(a)  Permits required. It shall be unlawful for any person directly or indirectly to cut down, destroy, remove or effectively destroy by damaging any tree in the city without first obtaining a permit as herein provided. This requirement shall apply to all trees three (3) inches or larger dbh., and to Southern Red Cedar trees (juniperus silicicola) more than two (2) feet tall or having a trunk diameter at a point three (3) inches above ground level of more than one (1) inch. Provided, however, that it shall not be unlawful to remove a tree other than a Southern Red Cedar (juniperus silicicola) which is less than three (3) inches dbh., nor shall any permit be required for the removal of such tree. In addition, it shall not be unlawful to remove an exempt tree or an invasive species and no permit shall be required for the removal of such. 
(b)  Permit applications and application fees. 
(1)  Permits for removal or relocation of trees shall be obtained by making application for permit to the city planning and building division. The application shall indicate the number, species and diameter breast height (dbh.) of each tree to be removed or relocated and the reasons for the removal or relocation. Such applications for permits for removal or relocation of trees shall be accompanied by a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00). Such fees are hereby declared to be necessary for the purpose of processing the application and making the necessary inspection for administration and enforcement of this section. 
(2)  Permits for removal or relocation of trees associated with a site plan for a development shall be obtained by making application for permit for the development to the city planning and building division. The application shall be accompanied by a site plan. When the permit for the development is issued it will include tree removal, relocation and replacement as indicated on the approved site plan for the development. 
(c)  Application review. Upon receipt of a complete application, which may include a site plan for a development, the city planning and building division shall review such application which may include a field check of the site and referral of the application to other departments or agencies as necessary to determine any adverse effect upon the general public welfare, adjacent properties or city services and facilities. 
(1)  The planning and building division may issue a tree removal permit for trees which are not considered preserved trees. 
(2)  To remove a preserved tree anywhere on site, approval shall first be given by the code enforcement, adjustments and appeals board, or by the planning and zoning board, if such approval is related to the review of a site plan. 
(3)  In determining whether or not a permit required by this section should be issued, the city planning and building division shall consider and base all decisions on the following: 
a.  The condition of the tree with respect to disease, insect attack, danger of falling, proximity to existing or proposed structures and interferences with utility services. 
b.  The necessity of removing a tree to construct proposed improvements in order to allow reasonable economic use of the property. 
c.  The relief of the land where the tree is located and the effect removal of the tree would have on erosion, soil moisture retention, diversion, increased or decreased flow of surface waters and the city master drainage plan or similar plan adopted by the city commission. 
d.  The number and density of trees existing in the neighborhood on improved or unimproved property. The planning and building division shall also be guided by the effect removal of a tree would have on property values in the neighborhood where the property is located and on other vegetation in the neighborhood. 
e.  Whether the tree has been designated a preserved tree. 
f.  Impact upon the urban and natural environment, including: 
Ground and surface water stabilization. 
Water quality and aquifer recharge. 
Ecological impacts. 
Noise pollution. 
Air movement. 
Air quality. 
Wildlife habitat. 
g.  The ease with which the property owner or agent can alter or revise the proposed development or improvements to accommodate existing trees, including the tree or trees proposed to be removed. 
(d)  Issuance of permit. The planning and building division shall issue the removal permit unless, upon consideration of the criteria set forth above, the division finds any of the following will result: 
(1)  That the property owner or agent will not be unreasonably affected in shifting the location of the proposed structure, building or improvement, which shift will maintain the existence of the subject trees and still permit construction of such building or improvement on the site. 
(2)  That the property owner or agent will not be unreasonably affected in modifying the design of the proposed structure, building or other improvement, which modification will maintain the existence of the trees proposed to be removed and still permit construction substantially similar to that originally proposed. 
(3)  That the removal of the subject trees will have a substantial adverse impact on the urban and natural environment. 
(4)  That the subject trees are preserved trees and removal must be reviewed by the code enforcement, adjustments and appeals board or the planning and zoning board. 
(e)  Denial of permit. If the planning and building division denies the removal permit it shall set forth with particularity its reasons for such denial in writing. 
(f)  Appeals. When a tree removal permit, including a permit for the removal of a preserved tree not involved with a site plan for new development, has been denied by the planning and building division, the property owner or agent may appeal this decision to the code enforcement, adjustments and appeals board. The code enforcement, adjustments and appeals board shall approve or deny the appeal and may impose conditions as required, such as specific tree species and sizes for the required replacement trees. The board may require more stringent replacement requirements than is required by this chapter. The code enforcement, adjustments and appeals board shall not be empowered to relax the standards and requirements contained herein. If a preserved tree is approved by the board to be removed, a minimum of two (2) shade trees a minimum of ten (10) feet in height shall be used as replacement. The replacement of trees that have been removed after board approval shall be done within thirty (30) days after the tree has been removed. 
(g)  Relocation and replacement. As condition to the granting of a permit, the property owner or agent will be required to relocate the tree being removed or required to replace the tree being removed with a tree somewhere within the site. Native vegetation shall be replaced with native vegetation. Shade trees must be replaced by shade trees. Understory and palm trees may be replaced by any type tree. Replacement shade trees shall be a minimum of ten (10) feet high and understory trees shall be a minimum of ten (10) feet high when planted. Each Southern Red Cedar tree (juniperus silicicola) removed shall be replaced with a minimum of two (2) Southern Red Cedars of such a size and quality as shall be determined by the city building official to be assured of such Southern Red Cedars' continued viability and growth. The property owner or agent shall also be required to replace the relocated or replacement tree should same die within three (3) years from date of planting. 
(h)  Public lands. No tree shall be removed from any public property or public right-of-way except in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(i)  "After the fact" tree removal permits. 
(1)  The application fee shall be as follows: 
a.  One hundred dollars ($100.00) for each tree three (3) inches or more but less than seven (7) inches dbh. 
b.  Two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each tree seven (7) inches or more but less than twelve (12) inches dbh. 
c.  Four hundred dollars ($400.00) for each tree twelve (12) inches or more but less than twenty (20) inches dbh. 
d.  Eight hundred dollars ($800.00) for each tree twenty (20) inches or more dbh. 
(2)  The planning and building director may issue an "after the fact" tree removal permit for trees which are not considered preserved trees, but only after considering the above mentioned factors and the reason why a permit was not obtained prior to the removal. 
(3)  If the planning and building director denies the "after the fact" tree removal permit, he/she shall set forth with particularity the reasons for such denial in writing. When such permit is denied, said denial may be appealed as stated above to the adjustments and appeals board. 
(4)  No "after the fact" tree removal permits shall be issued for the removal of preserved trees. Any such action shall be subject to code enforcement proceedings wherein any explanation or reason for removal without a permit and evidence as to the tree's condition prior to removal may be presented as mitigation. 
(Ord. No. 04-17, § 1, 10-25-04; Ord. No. 09-17, § 1, 5-11-09; Ord. No. 15-09, § 3, 3-19-15) 
Sec. 25-57. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Authority of building official. The city building official shall be the enforcing official for this article. The building official shall: 
(1)  Make such inspections as necessary to carry out the provisions of this article and to initiate appropriate action to bring about compliance with this article. 
(2)  Investigate any complaints or alleged violations of this article. 
(3)  Issue a notice of violation to require compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Certificate of occupancy. No building permit, certificate of occupancy or use permit shall be issued for any development unless such development complies with the provisions herein. 
(c)  Violations and penalties. 
(1)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter may be cited in accordance with sections 2-316 through 2-329 of the Code of the City of St. Augustine, or referred to the municipal code enforcement board for appropriate action. The municipal code enforcement board may impose a fine up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day. Each day that a violation of this chapter continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(2)  In addition to any fine or penalty imposed by citation or the municipal code enforcement board, any person found in violation of this chapter shall replace any tree removed in a manner contrary to this chapter and shall replace such tree or trees under the criteria set forth in section 25-56(g) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 04-17, § 1, 10-25-04; Ord. No. 04-24, § 2, 1-10-05) 
Sec. 25-58. - Variances and conservation overlay zone development review. 
    The city planning and zoning board may grant a variance to the requirements of this article where compliance would be a practical impossibility or would cause unnecessary hardship or where the owner proposes an alternative which conforms to the general intent and spirit of these regulations. When reviewing applications and site plans associated with applications for variances or conservation overlay zone developments or for the removal of significant trees involved with a site plan for new development, the planning and zoning board shall have the authority to locate structures, parking areas and other improvements to retain significant trees when possible and practical. The planning and zoning board shall approve or deny the site plan and may impose conditions as required, such as specific tree species and sizes for the required replacement trees. Under no circumstances may the board deny fair and reasonable use of the property, but the granting of a variance or conservation overlay zone development may be contingent upon retaining significant trees. Procedures for variances and conservation overlay zone development review shall be in accordance with chapter 28. Standards and criteria for conservation overlay zone development review shall be in accordance with chapter 11. 
(Ord. No. 04-17, § 1, 10-25-04; Ord. No. 19-03, § 3, 1-28-19) 
Sec. 25-59. - Appeals. 
    Any person adversely affected by a decision of the planning and building division in the enforcement of or the interpretation of this chapter may appeal such decision to the planning and zoning board within thirty (30) days after the decision of the planning and building division. Appeals shall be in accordance with chapter 28. 
(Ord. No. 04-17, § 1, 10-25-04) 
Sec. 25-60. - Severability. 
    It is the intent of the city commission of the City of St. Augustine, and it is hereby provided, that if any section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase or provision of this division is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not be so construed as to render invalid or unconstitutional the remaining provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 04-17, § 1, 10-25-04) 
Chapter 26 - WATER AND WASTEWATER[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Administration. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, the city manager will administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this chapter. The city manager may delegate any powers or duties to other city personnel. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-2. - Abbreviations. 
    The following abbreviations, when used in this chapter, have the meanings indicated below: 
    AWWA stands for the American Water Works Association. 
    BMP stands for best management practice. 
    COD stands for chemical oxygen demand. 
    CBOD stands for carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand. 
    CFR stands for the Code of Federal Regulations. 
    EPA stands for the U. S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
    gpd stands for gallons per day. 
    mg/l stands for milligrams per liter. 
    mgd stands for million (1,000,000) gallons per day. 
    NAICS stands for North American Industrial Classification System. 
    NPDES stands for the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System. 
    OSHA stands for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. 
    POTW stands for publicly owned treatment works. 
    ppm stands for parts per million (1,000,000). 
    RCRA stands for the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act. 
    SIU stands for significant industrial user. 
    TRC stands for total residual chlorine. 
    TSS stands for total suspended solids. 
    USC stands for United States Code. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 1, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, have the meanings indicated below: 
    Abutting means adjacent or contiguous to or located immediately across from any road, street, right-of-way or easement. 
    Act or the Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC § 1251 et seq. 
    Alternative water system connection fee means any alternative fee calculated by an applicant and approved by the city commission pursuant to this article. 
    Alternative water system connection fee study means a study prepared by an applicant or owner and submitted to the city pursuant to this article. 
    Alternative sewer system connection fee means any alternative fee calculated by an applicant and approved by the city commission pursuant to this article. 
    Alternative sewer system connection fee study means a study prepared by an applicant or owner and submitted to the city pursuant this article. 
    Applicant means the person who individually, or as the authorized representative of an organization or corporation, signs an application for utility service requesting water or sewer service at a specific location for a specific use. 
    Authorized representative of the user means: 
(1)  If the user is a corporation: 
a.  The president, secretary, treasurer, or a vice-president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision-making functions for the corporation; or 
b.  The manager of one (1) or more manufacturing, production, or operation facilities, provided the manager is authorized to make management decisions that govern the operation of the regulated facility including having the explicit or implicit duty of making major capital investment recommendations, and initiate compliance with environmental laws and regulations; can ensure that the necessary systems are established or actions taken to gather complete and accurate information for individual wastewater discharge permit requirements; and where the authority to sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures. 
(2)  If the user is a partnership or sole proprietorship: A general partner or proprietor, respectively. 
(3)  If the user is a federal, state, or local governmental facility: A director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation and performance of the activities of the government facility, or their designee. 
(4)  The individuals described in paragraphs (1) through (3), above, may designate a duly authorized representative if: 
a.  The authorization is in writing; 
b.  The authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company; and 
c.  The authorization is submitted to, and received by, the city. 
    Backflow means a flow of water from the customer's side of the meter into the city water system under conditions where the water pressure on the customer's side of the meter exceeds the pressure in the city water system. 
    Backflow preventer means a mechanical device installed in conjunction with a water meter to prevent a flow of water from the customer's side of the meter into the city water system. 
    Best management practices (BMPs) means schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to implement the prohibitions listed in section 26-78. BMPs include treatment requirements, operating procedures, and practices to control plant site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or waste disposal, or drainage from raw materials storage. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the sewer lateral or public sewer at the property line or other lawful place of disposal. 
    Bypass means the intentional diversion of waste streams from any portion of a user's treatment facility. 
    Carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand (CBOD) means the amount of oxygen expressed in parts per million (1,000,000) necessary to satisfy the oxygen requirements of the carbonaceous fraction of a sample of wastewater incubated for five (5) days at twenty (20) degrees Celsius (20 C) and tested in accordance with standard methods. 
    Categorical industrial user means an industrial user subject to a categorical pretreatment standard or categorical standard. 
    Categorical pretreatment standard means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA in accordance with Sections 307(b) and (c) of the Act (33 USC § 1317) which apply to a specific category of users and which appear in 40 CFR Chapter I, Subchapter N, Parts 405-471. 
    Chemical oxygen demand (COD) means the amount of oxygen required to oxidize all compounds, both organic and inorganic, in water. 
    City means the City of St. Augustine as established by the Charter laws of the City of St. Augustine. 
    City manager means the administrative head of the municipal government as established by the Charter laws of the City of St. Augustine, or designee. 
    City water system means the entire water utility system that services the needs of the customer and which includes a water source, treatment facilities, pumps, transmission and distribution lines, fire hydrants, valves, meters, backflow preventers and all other related appurtenances. 
    City sewer system. See "publicly owned treatment works". 
    Connection charges means specific development charges that must be satisfied in order to receive water or wastewater service. Connection charges include: Collection, transmission and distribution fees; treatment plant fees; tapping fees; backflow preventer fees; hydrant fees; permit fees; asphalt and roadway repair fees; main extension fees; and inspection fees. 
    Control authority means the city. 
    Cross-connection means any physical arrangement whereby the city water system is connected, directly or indirectly, to any other water system, sewer, drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture or other device which may contain contaminated water, sewage or other waste or liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of contaminating the city water system as the result of backflow. By-pass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel or changeable devices and other temporary or permanent devices through which, or because of which, backflow could occur are considered cross-connections. 
    Customer means the person responsible for paying the water, sewer or stormwater billed for service provided at a specific location. 
    Daily maximum means the arithmetic average of all effluent samples for a pollutant collected during a calendar day. 
    Daily maximum limit means the maximum allowable discharge limit of a pollutant during a calendar day. Where daily maximum limits are expressed in units of mass, the daily discharge is the total mass discharged over the course of a day. Where daily maximum limits are expressed in terms of concentration, the daily discharge is the arithmetic average of the pollutant concentration derived from all measurements taken during that day. 
    Deposit means the amount of money placed with the city by each customer as security for payment of the water, sewer or stormwater bill. 
    Development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate. 
    Discharge means the introduction of pollutants into the POTW from any nondomestic source regulated under Section 307(b), (c), or (d) of the Act. 
    Easement means any strip of land created by a subdivider for public or private utilities, drainage, sanitation or other specified uses having limitations, the title to which remains in the name of the property owner subject to the right of use designated in the reservation of the servitude. 
    Effluent means the discharge flow of a treatment facility. 
    Employees means the maximum number of owners, partners, workers, other hired help or volunteers normally present at a commercial or industrial establishment during an eight-hour shift. 
    Existing source means any source of discharge that is not a "new source." 
    Extension means a water or sewer facility constructed to enable the provision of water or sewer service. 
    Flammable means as defined by the city fire regulations. 
    Flow means projected water and/or wastewater use expressed in gallons per day (gpd). 
    Forcemain means a line which carries wastewater under pressure from a pump station. 
    Grab sample means an individual, discrete sample collected at a specific time. A grab sample includes all sub samples or aliquots (e.g. individual containers for specific analytes or analyte groups) and sample fractions (e.g. field sample duplicates or split samples) collected at the same locations within a time not exceeding 15 minutes. 
    Gravity sewer means a non-pressurized wastewater collection line that moves wastewater from one (1) location to another. 
    Industrial pretreatment coordinator means city personnel designated by the city manager to operate and administer the city's industrial pretreatment program. 
    Industrial user means a source of discharge. 
    Influent means the flow arriving at a treatment plant for treatment. 
    Instantaneous maximum allowable discharge limit or instantaneous limit means the maximum concentration of a pollutant allowed to be discharged at any time, determined from the analysis of any discrete or composited sample collected, independent of the industrial flow rate and the duration of the sampling event. 
    Interceptor means any device designed and installed to separate and retain for removal, by automatic or manual means, deleterious, hazardous or undesirable matter from wastewater, while permitting the wastewater to discharge to the POTW. This definition includes grease interceptors and traps, oil and water separators, sand interceptors and traps, and similar devices, whether located inside or outside of a building. 
    Interference means a discharge which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge from another source, interferes with the operation of the POTW, including sewage sludge use or disposal, and which causes a violation of the city's NPDES permit. This definition includes any discharge causing the POTW to be out of compliance with any applicable federal regulations or permits or any other stringent state or local regulations. Such regulations include: Section 405 of the Act; the Solid Waste Disposal Act, including Title II commonly referred to as the RCRA; any state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to Subtitle D of the Solid Waste Disposal Act; the Toxic Substances Control Act; and the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act. 
    Lateral means the connection from a gravity sewer line to a building drain. 
    Local limit means the specific discharge limits developed and enforced by the city upon industrial or commercial facilities to implement the general and specific discharge prohibitions listed in 62-625.400(2), F.A.C. and 40 CFR 403.5(a)(1) and (b). 
    Medical waste means isolation wastes, infectious agents, human blood and blood products, pathological wastes, sharps, body parts, contaminated bedding, surgical wastes, potentially contaminated laboratory wastes, and dialysis wastes. 
    Meter means the measuring device owned and installed by the city on a service line for the purpose of accurately measuring water use by a customer. 
    Metered water means the amount of water delivered to a city water customer as measured by a city water meter; or the amount of water delivered to a city sewer customer as measured by a city water meter, whether or not the sewer customer is served by city water. 
    New source means: 
(1)  A source from which there is, or may be, a discharge, where construction commenced after publication of proposed pretreatment standards under Section 307(c) of the Act which would apply to the source if the standards were thereafter promulgated in accordance with Section 307(c) of the Act, provided that: 
a.  The source is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; or 
b.  The source totally replaces the process or production equipment producing the discharge at an existing source; or 
c.  The production and wastewater generating processes of the source are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether sources are substantially independent, the city manager considers factors such as the extent to which the new source is integrated with the existing source and the extent to which the new source is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source. 
(2)  If construction on a site containing an existing source does not meet the criteria of subsections b. and c. above but otherwise alters, replaces or adds to existing process or production equipment, then such construction is a modification of the existing source and not a new source. 
(3)  Construction of a new source is considered to have commenced if the owner or operator has: 
a.  Begun, or caused to begin, as part of a continuous on-site construction program: 
1.  Any placement, assembly, or installation of facilities or equipment; or 
2.  Significant site preparation work, clearing, excavating, demolition or equipment removal necessary for the placement, assembly or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or 
b.  Entered into a binding contract to purchase facilities or equipment intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase, contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering, and design studies do not constitute a binding contract under this paragraph. 
    Noncontact cooling water means water used for cooling which does not come into direct contact with any raw material, intermediate product, waste product, or finished product. 
    Nonsignificant categorical industrial user means an industrial user that discharges one hundred (100) gallons per day (gpd) or less of total categorical wastewater (excluding sanitary, non-contact cooling and boiler blowdown wastewater, unless specifically included in the pretreatment standard) and: 
a.  Has consistently complied with all applicable categorical pretreatment standards and requirements; 
b.  Annually submits the certification statement required in subsection 62-625.600(17), F.A.C., together with any additional information necessary to support the certification statement; and 
c.  Never discharges any untreated categorical process wastewater. 
    Normal working hours means Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. through 5:00 p.m., except holidays. 
    North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) Code means a classification pursuant to the North American Industrial Classification System Manual issued by the United States Office of Management and Budget. 
    Off-site facilities means water mains and pumps, sewer lines, force mains and lift stations constructed to connect on-site facilities to the nearest point in the existing water or sewer system at which adequate capacity is available to meet the requirements of the new services. 
    On-site facilities means the water mains, services, meters, fire hydrants, sewer lines, force mains, lift stations and pretreatment equipment installed within a development. 
    Oversized facility means a facility designed to be larger than that required to serve a single development, or the extension of a facility a greater length than that required to serve a single development. 
    pH means a measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a solution expressed in standard units. 
    Pass-through means a discharge entering the POTW at a concentration equal to or greater than the effluent concentration, or which is incapable of being adequately treated by the POTW, or which exits the POTW into waters of the United States in quantities or concentrations, which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the city's NPDES permit, including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity or any other legal entity or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. This definition includes all federal, state and local government entities. 
    Plumbing system means the water supply and distribution pipes, fixtures, traps, vents, building drains, building sewers, water treatment equipment and related appurtenances on the customer side of the point of service. 
    Point of service means: 
(1)  In the case of a water service without a backflow preventer, the point where the female pipe thread on the water meter is connected to the customer's service line; 
(2)  In the case of a water service with a backflow preventer, the point where the female pipe thread on the customer leg of the backflow preventer is connected to the customer's service line; and 
(3)  In the case of sewer service, the point where the lateral crosses the customer's property line. 
    Pollutant means any dredged spoils, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, dirt, municipal waste, industrial waste, agricultural waste, and certain characteristics of wastewater (e.g., pH, temperature, TSS, turbidity, color, CBOD, COD, toxicity or odor). 
    Pretreatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater prior to, or in lieu of, introducing such pollutants into the POTW. This reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes; by process changes; or by other means, except by diluting the concentration of the pollutants unless allowed by an applicable pretreatment standard. 
    Pretreatment requirements means any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment imposed on a user other than a pretreatment standard. 
    Pretreatment standards or standards means prohibited discharge standards, categorical pretreatment standards, and local limits. 
    Prohibited discharge standards means absolute prohibitions against the discharge of certain substances. These prohibitions appear in section 26-78 of this Code. 
    Public sewer means a sewer owned by the city, specifically designed, constructed and intended to convey wastewater to the POTW, typically by gravity from manhole to manhole or from manhole to pump station, and to which stormwater and ground water are excluded. 
    Publicly owned treatment works (POTW) means a treatment works as defined by the Act (33 USC § 1292) owned by the city. This definition includes any devices or systems used in the collection, storage, treatment, recycling, and reclamation of sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature and any conveyances, which convey wastewater to a treatment plant. This definition includes public sewers, gravity sewers, manholes, pump stations, force mains, laterals, and all other related appurtenances. 
    Septic tank waste means any sewage from holding tanks, septic tanks, vessels, chemical toilets, campers and trailers. 
    Separator. See "interceptor". 
    Severe property damage means substantial physical damage to property, damage to the treatment facilities causing them to become inoperable, or substantial and permanent loss of natural resources reasonably expected to occur in the absence of a bypass. Severe property damage does not mean economic loss caused by delays in production. 
    Sewage means human excrement, and gray water from showers, dishwashing operations, etc. 
    Significant industrial user (SIU) means: 
(1)  A user subject to categorical pretreatment standards; or 
(2)  A user that: 
a.  Discharges an average of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gpd or more of process wastewater to the POTW (excluding sanitary, noncontact cooling, and boiler blowdown wastewater); 
b.  Contributes a process waste stream which makes up five (5) percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the POTW treatment plant; or 
c.  Is designated as such by the city on the basis that it has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
(3)  The city manager may determine that an industrial user subject to categorical pretreatment standards under Rule 62-625.410, F.A.C., including 40 CFR Chapter 1, Subchapter N, Parts 405 through 471, is a non-significant categorical industrial user. 
(4)  If the city manager finds that a user meeting the criteria in subsection (2) above has no reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement, then the city manager may at any time, on his own initiative or in response to a petition received from a user, and in accordance with procedures in Rule 62-625.500(2)(e), F.A.C., determine that such user should not be considered a significant industrial user. 
    Significant noncompliance means: 
(1)  Chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits defined here as those in which sixty-six (66) percent or more of all of the measurements taken for the same pollutant parameter taken during a six-month period exceed (by any magnitude), a numeric pretreatment standard or requirement, including instantaneous limits; 
(2)  Technical review criteria (TRC) violations defined here as those in which thirty-three (33) percent or more of wastewater measurements taken for each pollutant parameter during a six-month period equal or exceed the product of the numeric pretreatment standard or requirement including instantaneous limits, multiplied by the applicable TRC (TRC equals one and four-tenths (1.4) for CBOD, TSS, total oil and grease and equals one and two-tenths (1.2) for all other pollutants except pH); or 
(3)  Any other violation of a pretreatment standard or requirement (daily maximum, long-term average, instantaneous limit or narrative standard) that the city manager believes has caused, either alone or in combination with other discharges, interference or pass-through (including endangering the health of POTW personnel or the general public); or 
(4)  Any discharge of pollutants that has caused imminent endangerment to the public or to the environment or that has resulted in the city manager's exercise of emergency authority to halt or prevent such a discharge; or 
(5)  Failing to meet, within ninety (90) days after the schedule date, a compliance schedule milestone contained in a wastewater discharge permit or enforcement order for starting construction, completing construction, or attaining final compliance; or 
(6)  Failing to provide, within forty-five (45) days after the due date, required reports, such as baseline monitoring reports, ninety-day compliance reports, periodic self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules; or 
(7)  Failing to accurately report noncompliance; or 
(8)  Any other violation or group of violations, including violation of best management practices, that the city manager determines may adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. 
    Slug load or slug discharge means any discharge at a flow rate or concentration which could cause a violation of the prohibited discharge standards in section 26-78 of this Code. A slug discharge is any discharge of a non-routine, episodic nature, including but not limited to an accidental spill or a non-customary batch discharge, which has a reasonable potential to cause interference or pass through, or in any other way violate the POTW's regulations, local limits or permit conditions. 
    Source means any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is, or may be, a discharge of pollutants. 
    Standard methods means those procedures or methods established by the latest edition of the Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Sewage which is prepared, approved and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Water Environment Federation. 
    Stormwater means any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation, and resulting from such precipitation, including snowmelt. 
    Stub-out means a short section of water or sewer main intended for future use. 
    Total suspended solids (TSS) or suspended solids means the total suspended matter that floats on the surface of or is suspended in water, wastewater or other liquid and which is removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Upset means an exceptional incident in which there is unintentional and temporary noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards because of factors beyond the reasonable control of the industrial user. 
    User means any person, as defined herein, discharging wastewater to the POTW. 
    Wastewater means liquid and water-carried industrial wastes and sewage from residential dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial and manufacturing facilities and institutions, whether treated or untreated, which contribute to the POTW. 
    Wastewater treatment plant means that portion of the POTW designed to provide treatment of municipal sewage and industrial waste. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 03-26, § 1, 9-25-03; Ord. No. 05-08, § 1, 5-23-05; Ord. No. 08-11, § 1, 6-23-08; Ord. No. 11-25, § 2, 10-24-11; Ord. No. 15-25, § 1, 9-28-15) 
Sec. 26-4. - Service area established. 
    The City of St. Augustine service area (hereafter referred to as "service area") is depicted on the service area map. The service area map is on file with the city clerk for the city. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-5. - Authorization to extend city utilities within the service area. 
    The city is authorized and empowered to extend its water and wastewater utilities, wells, mains, manholes, gravity sewers, pump stations, pumps and storage tanks to all areas within the service area. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-6. - Requirement to connect to city water and wastewater when available. 
(a)  Development inside the city limits. All new development within the city limits is required to connect to city water and wastewater service when available. All existing development within the city limits is required to connect to city water and wastewater service within three hundred sixty-five (365) days of when such service becomes available. 
(b)  Development outside the city limits. All new development within the service area is required to connect to city water and wastewater service when available. All existing development within the service area is required to connect to city water and wastewater service when available if and when the existing private water system, wastewater system, well or septic tank, fails. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-7. - Availability of water and wastewater service. 
(a)  Water service for properties inside and outside the city limits. Water service for properties inside and outside the city limits shall be deemed available when a city water main exists in an easement or right-of-way that abuts the property. 
(b)  Wastewater service. Wastewater service for properties inside or outside the city limits shall be deemed available as follows: 
(1)  For a residential subdivision lot, single-family dwelling unit or an establishment with a flow of one thousand (1,000) gpd or less, service is available when a gravity sewer line exists in a public easement or right-of-way that abuts the property line of the lot, dwelling unit or establishment. 
(2)  For an establishment with a flow exceeding one thousand (1,000) gpd, service is available when a gravity sewer main, forcemain or lift station exists in a public easement or right-of-way that abuts the property of the establishment or is within fifty (50) feet of the establishment's property line as accessed via existing easements or rights-of-way. 
(3)  For proposed residential subdivisions with more than fifty (50) lots, for proposed commercial or industrial subdivisions with more than five (5) lots, and for areas zoned or used for industrial or manufacturing, service is available when a sewer system exists within one-fourth (1/4) mile of the development as measured and accessed via existing easements or rights-of-way. 
(4)  For repairs or modifications within areas zoned or used for an industrial or manufacturing use, service is available when a sewer system exists within five hundred (500) feet of an establishment's or dwelling unit's sewer stub-out as measured and accessed via existing easements or rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-8. - Prohibiting utilities of similar character within the service area. 
    No private or public utility is authorized to construct within the service area any system, work, project or utility of similar character to that being operated by the city, unless specifically approved to do so by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-9. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Failure to connect or pay connection charges. If any development within the service area fails to connect as provided for in this chapter, the city has the right to file an action in circuit court to require connection upon showing that service is available as provided in this chapter. If any development within the service area fails to pay connection charges, the city has the right to seek the sums that are due in a court of law. 
(b)  Failure to pay user fees. If any customer in the service area fails to pay user fees, the city has the right to seek the sums that are due in a court of law or to discontinue service until such sums, including penalties established by this chapter, are paid. 
(c)  Other violations. Violations of any provision of this chapter, except as specified in paragraphs (a) and (b) above or elsewhere in this chapter will be addressed as provided by section 1-8 of this Code, chapter 2 of this Code or as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-10. - Severability. 
    If any section, sentence, clause or phrase of this chapter is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, then said holding shall in no way affect the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter. If any part of the service area established by this chapter is held to be invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, then said holding shall in no way affect the validity of the remaining parts of the service area. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Secs. 26-11-26-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICIES AND PROCEDURES 

Sec. 26-26. - Emergency restrictions and service disruptions. 
(a)  Emergencies. In the event that emergency conditions, such as prolonged drought, freezing temperatures or other causes, exist that adversely impact the city water system, the city manager is authorized to shut off or restrict the use of water within the service area as necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare, and the city water system. 
(b)  Taps, extensions and repairs. The city manager has the right to shut off the water from any main upon notice while making taps, extensions and repairs. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-27. - City liability. 
    The city is not liable for any damage resulting from water service disruptions caused by: Bursting or leaking of any water main; shutting off the water for taps, extensions and repairs; or from the accidental failure of the water system for any cause whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-28. - Prohibited practices. 
    It is unlawful for any person to do any of the following: 
(1)  To alter or damage any city water meter; to prevent any city water meter from accurately registering the quantity of water passing through the meter; or to hinder or interfere with the proper action or registration of any such meter. 
(2)  To tamper with, break, alter, uncover, deface, damage or destroy any part of the city water system or POTW. 
(3)  To knowingly use water from any unauthorized connection to the city water system. 
(4)  To wastewater through defective fixtures or plumbing, or to allow water to run continually from any fixture inside or outside a building. 
(5)  To turn water on without making the deposit required to activate the account. 
(6)  To possess a hydrant wrench, valve, meter box, meter, cap or any component part of the city water system without specific authorization from the city manager. 
(7)  To connect any private water system to the city water system without prior authorization from the city manager and prior approval of the appropriate regulatory agencies. 
(8)  To occupy any building connected to the city water system or POTW without first making the deposit required to activate the account. 
(9)  To place or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city service area any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(10)  To discharge to any waterbody in the city service area any sewage or other polluted waters except where suitable treatment has been provided as required by this chapter. 
(11)  To construct, maintain or use any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage inside the city service area except as herein provided. 
(12)  To make, allow or use any cross connection. 
(13)  To connect roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, or any other source of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to the POTW. 
(14)  To connect any appurtenance in any manner to use water without the consent of the city or without the water use being recorded by a city water meter. 
(15)  To tap or make any connection to any part of the city water system or POTW without specific written authorization from the city manager. 
(16)  To connect a private fire hydrant to the city water system. 
(17)  To construct any utility system, intended to be transferred to the city upon completion, without construction plans designed by an engineer registered in the state of Florida and approved in advance in writing by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-29. - Applications for service. 
(a)  Applications required. All persons desiring first-time connection to the city water system or POTW or desiring separation of water or sewer service must submit an application for utility service to the city manager. Additionally, all persons desiring changes to an existing water or sewer connection, such as due to changing the use of an existing building, must submit an application for utility service to the city manager. Such application must be on a form prescribed by the city manager and must contain all the information required for review. 
(b)  Application fees. Review and permitting fees for applications for new service, applications for change in service, applications for line extensions or applications for utility service involving development orders may be adopted by resolution of the city commission. Fees shall apply to all applications for customers inside and outside the city limits. 
(c)  Application requirements. Applications for new service, applications for change in service, applications for line extensions or applications for utility service involving development orders shall be in accordance with the City of St. Augustine Standards and Specifications Design Manual and Details, as amended, and with review and permitting procedures and policies adopted by the city manager. These requirements shall apply to all applications for providing utility service inside and outside the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 11-14, § 1, 9-22-11) 
Sec. 26-30. - Extensions. 
    Water and sewer main extensions must be paid for, designed and constructed as follows: 
(1)  Individual customers. For extensions to serve an individual customer where the extension will enable the city to provide service to other future customers, the customer must pay the flow proportional transmission and distribution (T&D) fee established in this chapter. For extensions to serve an individual customer where the extension will not enable the city to provide service to other future customers, the customer must pay the cost of the extension. The city reserves the right not to construct an extension when it is economically unfeasible to do so. 
(2)  Extensions within a subdivision or development. The entire cost of the water and sewer system within the limits of a subdivision or development must be paid by the developer, except as specifically authorized by the city manager. 
(3)  Extensions to connect the existing city water or sewer system to a subdivision or development. The cost of any extension between that part of the existing water or sewer system with sufficient capacity to provide service to the subdivision or development and the point of connection to the subdivision or development may be shared between the city and the developer. Cost sharing arrangements are made on a case-by-case basis at the discretion of the city manager. 
(4)  Oversized mains. The city reserves the right to require oversized water and sewer mains to serve any development. The city may pay the costs to oversize the mains based on the difference between city estimates of the cost of the oversized mains and the cost of the mains normally required to serve the development. 
(5)  Design. Extensions must be designed by a professional engineer registered in the State of Florida. In the event that the customer's engineer designs the extension, the city manager will review and approve the plans for the extension prior to permitting. 
(6)  Construction. Extensions must be constructed by the city or by a licensed underground utility contractor. Construction must be in accordance with the approved plans. The city manager has the right to inspect extensions during construction to ensure that construction is in accordance with the approved plans. 
(7)  Ownership of extension. Following construction and acceptance by the city, title to the entire extension up to and including the meter, backflow preventer or sewer lateral will be vested in the city. 
(8)  Rights of additional extension. The city manager has the right to add new or additional customers and additional extensions to any city water or sewer main at any time without the permission of any customer contributing to the original extension. 
(9)  Easement required. Prior to constructing any extension in a development and not located in a public right-of-way, the developer must provide a copy of a recorded easement granting the city access to tap, maintain, repair or extend water or sewer lines within or through the development. 
(10)  Payment of flow proportional connection charges. The customer must pay flow proportional connection charges in addition to any main extension costs. The flow proportional connection charges must be paid before service is provided. 
(11)  Utility service agreement required. The city manager reserves the right to require that the developer and the city enter into a written utility service agreement specifying the above terms prior to the construction of any extension. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 03-26, § 2, 9-25-03) 
Sec. 26-31. - System specifications. 
    The city manager has the right to specify the size, type, routing, location and design of all mains, valves, taps, meters, backflow preventers, manholes, gravity sewers, pump stations and any other components being added to the city water system or POTW. Additionally, all components used in the construction, extension and maintenance of the city water system or POTW must be designed and constructed to meet or exceed city standards and specifications. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-32. - Water connections, meters and submetering. 
(a)  Separately owned properties. Separately owned properties will not be supplied with water through a common meter. 
(b)  Water service lines. Water service lines supplying more than one (1) building from a single water meter are prohibited, except when specifically approved by the city manager. 
(c)  Reselling city water or sewer service. Submetering and reselling city water or sewer service by private submetering on the customer side of the city water meter is allowed subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Private meters used for this purpose must be installed, maintained and read at the expense of the customer. 
(2)  Unless specifically approved by the city manager, customers cannot charge or collect from unit owners, tenants or other persons more than the fees and charges billed by the city, plus actual administrative costs. 
(3)  Water and sewer sold to St. Johns County are subject to conditions of a separate interlocal agreement. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-33. - Sewer connections and building sewers. 
(a)  Sewer connection required. Each building must be provided with a separate building sewer with a separate connection to the main. However, in the case where one (1) building stands at the rear of another on a single lot and public sewer is not available and cannot be extended to the rear building, then both buildings may share a common connection at the main. In this case, if a separate water meter serves each building, then sewer service will be billed to each building. 
(b)  Meter required. No person shall discharge wastewater to the POTW unless there is a water meter permitted or installed by the city, accessible to the city meter reader, and located to meter all water entering the premises. 
(c)  Costs of building sewers. The developer must pay all costs related to construction and installation of the building sewer. The developer must indemnify the city from any loss or damage caused directly or indirectly by installation of the building sewer. 
(d)  Design and construction of building sewers. The size, slope, alignment, materials, and construction methods related to the installation and connection of the building sewer must all conform to the requirements of the city building code. A cleanout must be installed at the property line. All excavations for building sewer installations must be adequately guarded with barricades and lights to protect the public from hazard. Public property disturbed in the course of the construction must be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city manager. 
(e)  Location of building sewers. Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In any building in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, wastewater carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(f)  Connection of building sewers to public sewer. Connection of the building sewer to the public sewer must conform to the requirements of the city building code. 
(g)  Maintenance and repair of sewer mains, manholes, laterals and building sewers. In areas where the city provides gravity sewer service, the city provides normal maintenance to the manholes and sewer mains to maintain free flow. 
(1)  For properties connected to the city gravity sewer system, the property owner is responsible for maintaining free flow from the building through the building sewer and sewer lateral to the city sewer main. This includes the connection of the building sewer to the sewer lateral and the removal of obstructions, grease build-ups, clogs, root intrusions or any other types of stoppages in the lateral or building sewer. 
(2)  The property owner shall have a standard cleanout at or near the property line. The cleanout shall be a minimum of four (4) inches in diameter and facing the city sewer main. The cleanout must be at or above ground level and be equipped with a removable threaded cap. The property owner is responsible for knowing the location of this cleanout and for maintaining the cleanout and cap in working order. If no cleanout exists, the property owner must install one prior to the city investigating reports of stoppages in the lateral or building sewer line. 
(3)  In the event of a blockage in the lateral or building sewer line, the property owner must obtain the services of a licensed plumber to investigate the problem. 
(4)  In the event that the blockage cannot be removed by the licensed plumber, the licensed plumber shall contact the city to request a site investigation during normal working hours. 
(5)  If the sewer lateral blockage is caused by structural damage to the sewer lateral owned by the city, as determined by a licensed plumber and field verified by the city at the sewer cleanout, it is the responsibility of the city to repair or replace the lateral without charge to the property owner. 
(6)  If the sewer blockage is not caused by structural damage to the sewer lateral owned by the city, as determined by a licensed plumber and field verified by the city at the sewer cleanout, but is instead the responsibility of the owner lodging the complaint, the city may hold the owner or licensed plumber responsible for all labor and equipment costs associated with the sewer complaint investigation. 
(7)  All city sewer main blockages, including manhole problems, are the responsibility of the city. All repairs to sewer laterals located in the public right-of-way are the responsibility of the city. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 09-31, § 1, 9-17-09) 
Sec. 26-34. - Fire system water service and fire hydrants. 
(a)  Fire system water services. No connections of any kind are allowed to a fire protection service other than those necessary for fire protection. All water used for purposes other than fire protection must be taken from a separate metered tap connected directly to the city main. No person is allowed to use a fire system connection for any purpose other than actually extinguishing a fire. 
(b)  Backflow preventers. All fire system water services must be equipped with a backflow preventer. 
(c)  Enforcement. In the event that any fire system water service customer fails to comply with the requirements of this Code governing such service, the city manager may cut off the water supply. The water supply will remain cut off until the customer has complied with the requirements of this Code governing fire system water service. 
(d)  Public fire hydrants. A public fire hydrant is a fire hydrant meeting all of the following criteria: 
(1)  The hydrant is in the city utility service area and supplied by water via the city water system. 
(2)  The hydrant is installed in a public right-of-way or in a recorded utility easement granting the city access for repairs and maintenance; 
(3)  The hydrant has been either installed by the city or accepted by the city through a bill-of-sale. 
Public hydrants are the maintenance responsibility of the city. 
(e)  Private fire hydrants. A private fire hydrant is a fire hydrant meeting all of the following criteria: 
(1)  The hydrant is in the city utility service area and supplied by water via the city water system. 
(2)  The hydrant is not installed in a public right-of-way or in a recorded utility easement granting the city access for repairs and maintenance; 
(3)  The hydrant has not been installed by the city or accepted by the city through a bill-of-sale. 
Private hydrants are not the maintenance responsibility of the city. The city water customer on whose property a private fire hydrant is located shall be billed monthly for availability of water at a rate established by the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 05-30, § 1, 9-22-05) 
Sec. 26-35. - Backflow prevention. 
(a)  Facilities requiring backflow preventers. No consumer of water from the city water system shall have a cross connection or potential cross connection either inside or outside of any building or buildings without a backflow prevention device being installed to prevent any and all backflow into the public water system. Cross connection is defined in Chapter 62-550.200 F.A.C. 
(b)  Installation and maintenance. Connections to the public water service that require backflow prevention are the responsibility of the customer and shall be installed, tested and maintained by the customer in conformance with Chapter 62-555.360 F.A.C. and American Water Works Association Manual M14 and the City of St. Augustine Cross Connection Control Manual. 
(c)  City reserves right to disconnect water. The city manager has the right to disconnect the water service to any customer where inadequate backflow prevention exists at the service connection. Water service will not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected, and until all penalties and service charges resulting from the disconnection and subsequent reconnection have been paid. Inadequate backflow prevention exists when: 
(1)  A backflow preventer is required but has not been installed; or 
(2)  A required backflow preventer has been removed, tampered with, altered or bypassed; or 
(3)  Any unprotected cross connection exists on the customer's premises; or 
(4)  Any other cross connection exists which may jeopardize public health. 
(d)  Administer and enforce. The city shall have the right to inspect customer facilities to ensure protection of the city water system through backflow prevention, administer and enforce compliance to the cross connection control program, and reporting requirements to regulatory authorities and may exact fees for the administration of this program. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 09-31, § 2, 9-17-09) 
Secs. 26-36-26-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONNECTION CHARGES AND RATES 

Sec. 26-51. - Connection charges. 
(a)  In general. Connection charges, including backflow preventer fees and surcharges, may be established and adjusted from time to time by Resolution of the City Commission passed after public hearing. Charges must be paid prior to service being provided. Except as specifically addressed in subsection (e), below, connection charges run with the property. Customer is responsible for costs associated with making connection to the City utility, including but not limited to, materials, labor, permits, restoration, inspections of the actual connection and line extension as well as flow based fees related to treatment facility, transmission and distribution and collection system capital improvements. 
(b)  Backflow preventer fees. All utility customers who are required to maintain a backflow preventer will be assessed a surcharge for the purpose of administration, compliance and enforcement of the cross connection control regulations. 
(c)  Water and sanitary sewer surcharge areas and fees. 
(1)  The Northwest area forcemain surcharge, intended to cover capital improvements associated with the northwest area forcemain extension, shall be calculated on a gallons per day (gpd) of flow basis. The surcharge fees may be adjusted from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(2)  Upon the request and recommendation of the city manager, the city commission may create additional water and/or sanitary sewer surcharge areas and associated surcharge fees by adoption of a resolution after public hearing at a duly noticed public meeting. The surcharge fees, once adopted, may be adjusted from time to time by resolution of the city commission at a duly noticed public meeting. 
(d)  Consumer Price Index adjustment. All connection charges for water and sewer service provided by this article may be adjusted annually by the city manager with the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index as published by the U.S. Department of Labor, CPI-U Class D south region Class D - no less than 50,000 population, from May 1 of the preceding calendar year until April 30 of the present calendar year. Such adjusted rates shall supersede the rates set forth in this article. 
(1)  The adjusted connection charges will be applied to all "Letters of Availability" dated on or after October 1 of each year or on or after the effective date of the adopting resolution. 
(2)  The percentage change in the Consumer Price Index will be applied to the flow proportional connection charges as follows: 
a.  Multiply the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index from May 1 of the preceding calendar year through April 30 of the present calendar year times the existing flow proportional connection charges. 
b.  Add the product to the existing flow proportional connection charges and round to the nearest cent. 
(e)  Refund of connection charges. Connection charges, as defined herein, paid prior to the installation of facilities to provide service to a property run with the real property benefitted by the services and facilities provided and will be refunded only to the owner of the property at the time of the refund request subject to all of the following conditions: 
(1)  The facilities have not been installed; 
(2)  No flow capacity has been reserved with the Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FDEP), or any such agency exercising jurisdiction over the property benefitted by the services and facilities, and none of the flow capacity has been placed in service for the subject property; 
(3)  Costs incurred by the city related to such facilities are deducted prior to making the refund; 
(4)  The city shall not pay interest on the connection charges refunded; 
(5)  The refund is requested within five (5) years of the date of the original connection charges payment. This subsection (5) shall apply only to connection charges paid on or after October 1, 2012; 
(6)  The burden of proof for having paid connection charges rests with the person or entity seeking refund of the connection charges; 
(7)  The person or entity requesting the refund of the connection charges requests the refund in writing; and 
(8)  The request for refund of connection charges is approved by the city manager. 
(9)  If the property is under foreclosure proceedings or if the city is otherwise placed on notice of pending litigation relating to rights that run with the land, no final determination of a refund shall be executed pending the outcome of the litigation. 
(f)  Lease of increments to base flow rate fee to commercial users providing at least one hundred (100) full time equivalent jobs at the property benefited by the water and sewer service. 
(1)  Authority to lease. The city manager is hereby authorized to lease for a designated term of time as determined by the city manager any increment to the minimum flow based fees created by section 26-51(e) of this Code, as amended from time to time. Such leases shall be made available only to commercial users of water and sewer utility services who create and maintain at least one hundred (100) full time equivalent jobs at the property benefited by the water and sewer service. 
(2)  Calculation of amounts due. The city manager shall employ the following methodology to calculate the amounts due: 
a.  The city shall collect all connection charges described in sections 26-51(b), (c), (d), (e), (f), (g), (h) and (i) of this Code, as applicable and as amended from time to time. 
b.  The city shall collect the lowest flow based fee for non-residential uses as established by section 26-51(e) of this Code, as amended from time to time. 
c.
