The city may lease any increment between the flow based fee for retail sales as provided in section 26-53(a)(17)(a) of this Code, as amended from time to time, and the flow based fee for the nonresidential use of the real property benefiting from the water and sewer service as provided in section 26-53(a) of this Code, as amended from time to time. 
d.  The amount due for the incremental flow based fee lease shall be an amount of not less than two and one-half (21/2) percent of the incremental amount for each year of the lease term. 
(3)  Payment due dates. The first annual lease payment shall be due in advance and simultaneously with the payment of all other fees required by this section 26-51. Subsequent annual lease payments shall be due on the anniversary date of the first such payment. 
(4)  Failure of payment. In the event any annual lease payment becomes delinquent for a period of thirty (30) days after the scheduled payment due date, the city may discontinue water and sewer service to the benefited property and seek relief through any available legal remedies. 
(5)  Written lease agreement. The city and the owner of the benefited property shall memorialize the leasing of the incremental flow based fees by written instrument. The city manager is hereby authorized to execute such written instrument on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; 03-26, § 3, 9-25-03; Ord. No. 04-14, § 1, 9-30-04; Ord. No. 05-30, § 2, 9-22-05; Ord. No. 06-26, § 1, 9-21-06; Ord. No. 08-19, § 1, 9-18-08; Ord. No. 09-31, § 3, 9-17-09; Ord. No. 2009-37, § 1, 10-26-09; Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 9-20-12; Ord. No. 13-28, § 1, 10-14-13) 
Sec. 26-52. - Deferred connection charges. 
    The city manager is authorized to establish a program providing for deferred payment of utility connection charges. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-53. - Water and wastewater flow. 
(a)  Flow for listed uses. Water and wastewater flow are established as follows for the specific uses indicated. Flow for any use not listed will be established for the use listed, which is most closely related to it, as determined by the city manager which shall serve as the final administrative appeal. Flow for properties containing more than one (1) use will be based on the sum of the flows for each of the separate uses. Flow is rounded to the nearest gallon. Flow for commercial or industrial process water and industrial waste are in addition to the flow established for the commercial and industrial uses listed. 
(1)  Airports, bus terminals and train stations: Two hundred fifty (250) gpd per water closet and per urinal. 
(2)  Barber and beauty shops: One hundred (100) gpd per service chair. 
(3)  Bowling alleys: One hundred (100) gpd per lane. 
(4)  Churches: Three (3) gpd per seat, which includes kitchen flow unless meals are prepared on a routine basis, plus five (5) gpd per meal if meals are prepared on a routine basis. 
(5)  Country clubs: Sum of specific uses included (i.e., food operations, lodging, etc.). 
(6)  Dental and medical offices and clinics: Ten (10) gpd per one hundred (100) square feet of gross floor area. 
(7)  Food operations: 
a.  Ordinary restaurants: Fifty (50) gpd per seat with fixed seats; or fifty (50) gpd per fifteen (15) square feet of seating area without fixed seats. 
b.  24-hour restaurants: Seventy-five (75) gpd per seat with fixed seats; or seventy-five (75) gpd per fifteen (15) square feet of seating area without fixed seats. 
c.  Restaurants using single service articles only: Twenty-five (25) gpd per seat with fixed seats; or twenty-five (25) gpd per fifteen (15) square feet of seating area without fixed seats. 
d.  Bars, cocktail lounges, game rooms and nightclubs: Thirty (30) gpd per seat with fixed seats; or thirty (30) gpd per fifteen (15) square feet of seating area without fixed seats. 
e.  Drive-in restaurants: Fifty (50) gpd per car space. 
f.  Carryout restaurants and caterers: Sixty (60) gpd per one hundred (100) square feet of gross floor area. 
g.  Institutional meals: Five (5) gpd per meal. 
h.  Delis, bakeries, meat markets and seafood markets: Fifty (50) gpd per one hundred (100) square feet of gross floor area. 
(8)  Hospitals or surgery centers: Two hundred (200) gpd per bed, plus kitchen flow of five (5) gpd per meal prepared for bed patients, plus twenty-five (25) gpd per cafeteria seat. 
(9)  Laundries, dry cleaners, and self-service laundries: Four hundred (400) gpd per washing machine. 
(10)  Lodging: 
a.  Hotels and motels: One hundred fifty (150) gpd per room, plus four hundred (400) gpd per washing machine if self service laundry facilities are provided. 
b.  Bed and breakfasts, inns and resorts: Two hundred fifty (250) gpd per room, plus four hundred (400) gpd per washing machine if self service laundry facilities are provided. 
(11)  Manufacturing and storage: 
a.  Factories and warehouses: Two hundred fifty (250) gpd per water closet and per urinal 
b.  Mini-warehouses: Twenty (20) gpd per one hundred (100) square feet of office area. 
(12)  Nursing homes: One hundred (100) gpd per bed, plus kitchen flow of five (5) gpd per meal prepared for bed patients, plus twenty-five (25) gpd per cafeteria seat. 
(13)  Offices, office buildings and office parks: Ten (10) gpd per one hundred (100) square feet of gross floor area. 
(14)  Parks, campgrounds, and marinas: 
a.  Parks: Two hundred fifty (250) gpd per water closet and per urinal. 
b.  Marinas: Two hundred fifty (250) gpd per water closet and per urinal; plus fifty (50) gpd per boat slip; plus four hundred (400) gpd per washing machine if self service laundry facilities are provided. 
c.  Campground and recreational vehicle park spaces without water and sewer hookup: Seventy-five (75) gpd per space plus four hundred (400) gpd per washing machine if self service laundry facilities are provided. 
d.  Campground and recreational vehicle park spaces with water and sewer hookup: One hundred (100) gpd per space plus four hundred (400) gpd per washing machine if self service laundry facilities are provided. 
e.  Marinas: Fifty (50) gpd per boat slip. 
(15)  Public institutions other than schools and hospitals: One hundred (100) gpd per person, plus kitchen flow of five (5) gpd per meal prepared. 
(16)  Residential dwelling units: Includes all connections for individually metered dwelling units. Each such dwelling unit represents one equivalent residential connection (ERC) and each ERC represents average daily potable water flow of three hundred (300) gallons per day (gpd) for water and an average daily wastewater flow of two hundred ten (210) gpd per ERC. 
(17)  Retail sales: 
a.  Retail stores (other than convenience stores) and retail shopping centers: Ten (10) gpd per one hundred (100) square feet of gross floor area. 
b.  Convenience stores: Fifty (50) gpd per one hundred (100) square feet of gross floor area, plus flow for food outlet seating if provided as described herein, plus flow for service stations if provided as described herein. 
(18)  Schools and day care establishments: 
a.  Day types: Fifteen (15) gpd per student, plus five (5) gpd per student if showers are provided, plus five (5) gpd per student if cafeteria is provided, plus fifteen (15) gpd per employee. 
b.  Boarding types: Seventy-five (75) gpd per student. 
(19)  Service stations without car washes: Two hundred fifty (250) gpd per water closet and per urinal. 
(20)  Stadiums, racetracks and ballparks: Five (5) gpd per seat. 
(21)  Swimming pools: Two hundred fifty (250) gpd per water closet and per urinal. 
(22)  Theaters, auditoriums, halls and conference centers: 
a.  Theaters (indoor or outdoor), auditoriums, halls and conference centers: Five (5) gpd per seat. 
b.  Drive-in theaters: Ten (10) gpd per parking space. 
(23)  Veterinary clinics, animal boarding, kennels and animal grooming salons: Ten (10) gpd per one hundred (100) square feet of gross floor area, plus twenty (20) gpd per kennel, stall or cage, plus one hundred (100) gpd per animal wash station. 
(24)  Work or construction camps: Fifty (50) gpd per semi-permanent worker. 
(25)  Irrigation systems: Annualized average daily flow based on information provided by the applicant's architect, landscape architect or engineer, subject to approval by the city manager and annual review according to subsection (e) below. 
(26)  Car washes: Annualized average daily flow based on information provided by the applicant's architect or engineer, subject to approval by the city manager and annual review according to subsection (e) below. 
(27)  Process water and industrial waste: Annualized average daily flow based on information provided by the applicant's engineer, subject to approval by the city manager and annual review according to subsection (e) below. 
(28)  Breweries and distilleries: Annualized average daily flow based on information provided by the applicant's engineer, subject to approval by the city manager and annual review according to subsections (e) and (g) below. 
(29)  Gymnasiums, fitness centers and health clubs: Two hundred fifty (250) gpd per water closet, per urinal and per shower stall or shower head. 
(b)  Estimated water or wastewater flow in excess of established flows. In the event that the city manager determines the water or wastewater flow to be in excess of the flow established above based on billing history of similar uses or other data submitted by the applicant's architect, landscape architect or engineer, then the flow proportional connection charges shall be based on the greater flow amount. 
(c)  Changes of use. In the case of changes in use or increases in intensity of use of an existing building which is served by city water and/or sewer, the applicant must pay the flow proportional connection charges established in this chapter based on the difference in flow between the existing use or intensity and the new use or intensity. In the case that the existing flow is not higher than the new flow, the applicant must pay the flow proportional connection charges established in this chapter based on the difference in flow between the highest ever flow and the flow based on the new use or intensity. The burden for documenting the highest ever flow, if the highest flow is not the current flow, rests with the applicant. 
(d)  Demolition and new construction. In the case of a new building to be constructed on the site of a building which was served by city water and/or sewer prior to being demolished, the applicant must pay the flow proportional connection charges established in this chapter based on the increase in flow between the building which was demolished and the new building. The burden for documenting the previous use of the building and the associated flow rests with the applicant. In the event that the previous building was demolished in excess of ten (10) years from the date the new building is built, the connection charges established in this article will be based on the new building. 
(e)  Review of account billing history and flows. The city manager has the right to determine whether or not actual water or wastewater usage is in excess of the flow established above based on the billing history of the account over a twelve-month period. In the event that the actual water or wastewater usage is greater than the flow allocated to the account, then the customer must pay additional flow proportional connection charges based on the difference in flows. 
(f)  Flow determinations based on persons or occupant load. Flow determinations based on persons or occupant load shall be based on the maximum occupancy permitted by the current city building and life safety codes. 
(g)  Estimated water or wastewater flow deficient of established flows. In the event that the city manager determines the long-term impact of water or wastewater flow to the city's utility system to be deficient of the flow established above based on billing history of similar uses or other data submitted by the applicant's architect, landscape architect, engineer or other professional consultant, then the flow proportional connection charges may be based on the lesser flow amount. This provision is intended for specially engineered systems outside of conventional water or wastewater plumbing. 
(h)  Abandoned or inactive service. In the case where utility service to a property has been inactive, abandoned or otherwise unused without payment of service or flow through the service either water or sewer in excess of ten (10) years from the last known paid utility bill, the property is considered abandoned and carries no credit for flow based fees for the property. To re-establish service the application is treated as new service whereby new taps, service line, laterals and payment of the flow proportional connection charges shall be required in accordance with this chapter as if a new property. 
(i)  Alternative fee calculation. 
(1)  In the event an applicant or owner believes that the connection to the water system, the sewer system or both, necessitated by the owner's development justifies a fee that is less than the fee calculated in this article, such applicant or owner may submit a calculation of an alternative water system and/or alternative sewer system connection fee to the city manager pursuant to the provisions of this section. The decision of the city manager shall serve as the final administrative appeal. 
(2)  In the case of new construction, any right to submit an alternative water system connection fee calculation and/or alternative sewer system connection fee calculation shall be deemed to have been waived and expired, and such calculation shall not be considered by the city commission, if not properly and timely made in accordance with this ordinance prior to the issuance of a building permit. 
(3)  In the case of existing buildings, structures or applicable improvements which are required to connect to the potable water system, sewer system or both systems, any right to submit an alternative water system connection fee calculation and/or, alternative sewer system connection fee calculation shall be deemed to have been waived and expired, and such calculation shall not be considered by the city commission, if within thirty (30) calendar days from the effective date of issuance of the "letter of availability" under this article, the owner does not notify the city manager in writing of the owner's intention to submit an alternative water system connection fee calculation and/or alternative sewer system connection fee calculation. 
(4)  Notification and submission of an alternative water and/or wastewater system connection fee calculation. Any owner who wishes to submit an alternative water system connection fee calculation and/or an alternative sewer system connection fee calculation must timely submit to the city manager the applicable calculation along with an administrative review fee of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) for each alternative connection fee. If a combined alternative water and sewer connection fee calculation is submitted, the administrative review fee shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). In order to be deemed timely submitted, all necessary documents and fees must be submitted to the city manager or his/her designee, no later than ninety (90) days from the date of issuance of the "letter of availability". Any late filed submittal shall be deemed to have been waived and expired, and such alternative calculation shall not be considered by the city commission. 
(5)  Upon timely submission of an alternative water system connection fee calculation and/or alternative sewer system connection fee calculation, the basis for it and receipt of the alternative water system connection fee calculation and/or alternative sewer system connection fee calculation, the city manager shall review the alternative water system connection fee calculation and/or the alternative sewer system connection fee calculation and shall make final determination of the alternative fee calculation. 
(6)  The alternative water system connection fee calculation and/or the alternative sewer system connection fee calculation shall be based on data, information or assumptions contained in this article, as amended from time to time, or an alternative water system connection fee study and/or an alternative sewer system connection fee study based upon a calculation prepared by a Florida Professional Engineer who certifies that the flows and corresponding ERCs are reasonable relative to the development. Any such Florida Professional Engineer must include a local study supported by data adequate for the conclusions contained in such study, performed according to a generally accepted methodology and based upon generally accepted standard sources of information relating to facilities planning, cost analysis and demographics. The Florida Professional Engineer must provide competent, substantial evidence that the alternative water system connection fee and/or alternative sewer system connection fee represent an equitable determination of the water and/or sewer flow demand requirements in order to determine the amount of gallons to be allocated to the applicant to determine the number of ERCs and the pro rata share of the cost of capital improvements and additions to the water system and/or sewer system necessitated by the subject development. 
(7)  If during a prior alternative fee calculation process an acceptable alternative water system connection fee study and/or alternative sewer system connection fee study substantially consistent with the criteria required by this article have been accepted by the city manager, and if any such study is determined by the city manager to be then current (no greater than two years old) and applicable, the connection of such previously approved development shall be presumed to be as described in the prior study. In such circumstances, an alternative water system connection fee and/or the alternative sewer system connection fee shall be established reflecting the connection described in the prior study. There shall be a presumption that such a connection study based upon an independent source conducted and accepted by the city manager more than two (2) years earlier is no longer current and not applicable. 
(8)  If the city manager determines that the data, information and assumptions utilized by the applicant to calculate the alternative water system connection fee and/or the alternative sewer system connection fee complies with the requirements of this article and that the alternative water system connection fee and/or the alternative sewer system connection fee were calculated by the use of a generally accepted methodology, then the alternative water system connection fee and/or the alternative sewer system connection fee shall be paid in lieu of the fee set forth in this article. 
(9)  If the city manager determines that the data, information and assumptions utilized by the applicant to calculate the alternative water system connection fee and/or the alternative sewer system connection fee do not comply with the requirements of this article or that the alternative water system connection fee and/or the alternative sewer system connection fee were not calculated by the use of a generally accepted methodology, then the city shall provide to the applicant by certified mail, return receipt requested, written notification within five (5) business dates of such determination, of the rejection of the alternative water system connection fee, the alternative sewer system connection fee or both and the reason or reasons for the rejection. 
(10)  The final decision of the city manager shall be in writing and issued within sixty (60) calendar days receipt of complete and sufficient application per these articles. 
(11)  Any applicant or owner who or which has submitted a proposed alternative water system connection fee and/or alternative sewer system connection fee pursuant to this article and desires the immediate issuance of a building permit shall pay the required fees prior to or at the time of submittal of the proposed alternative fees. Such payment shall be deemed paid under "protest" and shall not be construed as a waiver of any right of review. Any difference between the amount paid and the amount due, as determined by the city manager, shall be refunded to the applicant or owner or paid to the city, as applicable. 
(12)  If an applicant has paid the water and/or sewer connection fees in accordance with an approved alternative water and/or sewer connection fee request, respectively and after connection to the utility the applicant incurs an average daily flow for a connection during an consecutive twelve-month periods in an amount greater than the average daily flow for which the connections fees have been paid, an additional capacity fee shall be assessed for the excess flow based on the connection fee in effect at the time of determination. If the average daily flow during any consecutive three-month period is more than fifteen (15) percent greater than the average daily flow for which connection fees have been paid, an additional connection fee shall be assessed for the excess flow. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 03-26, § 4, 9-25-03; Ord. No. 04-14, § 2, 9-30-04; Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 9-20-12; Ord. No. 15-25, § 1, 9-28-15) 
Sec. 26-54. - Deposits. 
(a)  Deposit required; conditions. Prior to initiating utility service, the city shall, except as otherwise provided herein, require a deposit from all utility service consumers. Application for service by whatever means (written, verbal, telephonic, electronic or otherwise) and the payment of the deposit by the consumer shall constitute the consumer's agreement that the deposit is advance payment for future utility services which may be applied as otherwise provided in this section. 
(1)  Residential service. All residential utility service consumers shall pay a deposit per residential dwelling unit, whether or not each dwelling unit has a separate water meter; except, however, that no deposit for residential utility service shall be required from: 
a.  An existing utility consumer who has an active, residential utility service account with the city, and who has not had a termination of service for nonpayment within the twenty-four (24) months immediately preceding application for new residential utility service; or 
b.  A new residential utility service consumer providing proof of good credit, good credit being defined as: 
1.  No termination of utility service by any provider of such services to the consumer for nonpayment, no returned checks and no delinquent payments within the two (2) years immediately preceding application for new residential utility service and the receipt by the city of evidence of good credit in satisfactory form from another utility; 
2.  Receipt by the city of satisfactory consumer payment history from a reputable credit reporting agency of the city's designation. 
(2)  Nonresidential service. For all nonresidential consumers, the required deposit shall be an amount two (2) times the estimated average monthly combined utility bill of the consumer, as determined by the financial services director or his/her designee. 
(3)  Residential and nonresidential service. All residential and nonresidential consumers without a deposit will be required to pay a utility deposit equal to the amount required by ordinance upon the second notice of disconnect of utility service for nonpayment within a twenty-four-month period. 
(b)  Incremental deposits. An additional deposit shall be required for unsatisfactory payment history, as determined by the financial services director or his/her designee. The amount of such deposit shall be that necessary to yield no more than a total deposit of two (2) times the estimated average monthly combined utility bill of the consumer. Written notice of the additional deposit requirement shall be provided to the consumer by certified mail, return receipt requested, at the address shown on the application for service. The consumer may appeal such requirement in an informal hearing with the financial services director or his/her designee. 
(c)  Interest; unclaimed deposits. Except as provided below, the deposit shall be held by the city until final settlement of the consumer's account, at which time the deposit shall be applied against any utility bill due the city for such service. Any unused balance shall be refunded when the account is settled and closed. All deposits shall earn simple interest, accrued from the date tendered and calculated to the nearest day. Interest shall accrue at a rate of the utility's interest earnings for the period and shall be credited to the consumer annually. In the event any deposit is unclaimed for a period of twelve (12) months after the service is discontinued, such unclaimed deposit and any accrued interest thereon shall be turned over to the state department of banking and finance in accordance with Florida law following thirty (30) days written notice to such consumer mailed to the address shown on the application for service. 
(d)  Refund of deposit; release of other financial assurance. Deposits for residential or nonresidential service shall be credited to the consumer at the end of twenty-four (24) months provided that the consumer has not experienced a termination of service for nonpayment within the previous twenty-four (24) months. 
(e)  Exemptions. The United States of America, the State of Florida, and all political subdivisions, agencies, boards, commissions and instrumentalities thereof are exempt from any deposit requirements under this section. 
(f)  Short-term service. No deposit shall be required for utility service for short-term service, herein defined as service not to exceed seven (7) days, provided the applicant is the owner of the property or the authorized property management agency. 
(g)  Bond in lieu of deposit. If a nonresidential consumer required to make a deposit so elects, he/she may post a surety bond or other financial assurance in lieu of the cash deposit. Such bond or financial assurance shall be issued by a surety authorized to do business in the State of Florida in an amount approved by the financial services director or his/her designee and shall be on a form approved by the city which shall fully protect the city against any loss as a result of any nonpayment of utility bills rendered by the city to the consumer. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 03-15, §§ 1, 2, 6-9-03; Ord. No. 06-26, § 2, 9-21-06; Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 9-20-12) 
Sec. 26-55. - Monthly usage and rates. 
(a)  Usage. The number of gallons of water used is determined by the water meter reading. The number of gallons of sewer used is the same as the number of gallons of water used. However, for an individually metered single-family dwelling unit, no sewer charge will be applied to water billed in excess of ten thousand (10,000) gallons in any single billing period. 
(b)  Rates for customers for water and sewer. Rates are effective beginning October 1 and ending September 30 of each respective fiscal year. Rates shall be established and adjusted from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(c)  Service charge for accounts that are temporarily disconnected. There is a minimum charge for availability of water and sewer service to all accounts that are temporarily disconnected. This service charge must be paid prior to reconnecting service. 
(d)  Notice required to discontinue the use or close account. Customers wishing to temporarily or permanently discontinue the use of water or close the account must notify the city manager. Failure to do so will render the customer liable for the monthly service charges until such notice has been given. 
(e)  Commercial accounts on turn-off list. Customers with commercial accounts on the turn-off list for non-payment will be called when the account appears on the turn-off list. However, an individual customer will not be called more than three (3) times over the duration of the account. Following the third such call, the city manager will send the customer, via certified mail-return receipt, a notice stating that the customer will not receive any future courtesy phone call and that the account will be turned off when it appears on the turn-off list. 
(f)  Consumer Price Index adjustment . All rates for water and sewer service provided by this article may be adjusted annually by the city manager with the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index as published by the U.S. Department of Labor, CPI-U Class D south region Class D - nonmet less than 50,000 population, from May 1 of the preceding calendar year until April 30 of the present calendar year. Such adjusted rates shall supersede the rates set forth in this article. 
(1)  The adjusted rate will be applied to all billings dated on or after October 1 of each year. 
(2)  The percentage change in the Consumer Price Index will be applied to the rates as follows: 
a.  Multiply the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index from May 1 of the preceding calendar year through April 30 of the present calendar year times the existing rates. 
b.  Add the product to the existing rates and round to the nearest cent. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 03-25, § 1, 9-25-03; Ord. No. 04-14, § 3, 9-30-04; Ord. No. 05-30, § 3, 9-22-05; Ord. No. 06-26, § 3, 9-21-06; Ord. No. 08-19, § 2, 9-18-08; Ord. No. 09-31, § 4, 9-17-09; Ord. No. 10-27, § 1, 9-23-10; Ord. No. 11-14, § 2, 9-22-11; Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 9-20-12) 
Sec. 26-56. - Billing. 
(a)  Monthly bill. Charges established by this chapter are billed and collected for the billing period as established by this chapter. Such charges are due and payable on the bill date shown on the bill. The customer must pay all charges at the same time. 
(b)  Unpaid charges. In the event that any charges remain due and unpaid on or after the due date stated on such bill which date will be twenty-five (25) days after the bill date, a delinquent (late) fee of one and one-half (1.5) percent of the outstanding balance or five dollars ($5.00), whichever is greater, shall be charged to the customer. If any bill remains due and unpaid on and after the due date stated on the bill issued to the customer for the next billing cycle, the account may be placed on the turn-off list. Any account on the turn-off list is subject to disconnection. If disconnected, the water service will not be restored until all charges and penalties due have been paid. 
(c)  Refund of deposits. No deposits made with the city by any customer will be refunded unless all charges and penalties have been paid in full. However, if charges and penalties total less than one dollar ($1.00), no bill will be rendered. Likewise, no deposits will be refunded in an amount less than one dollar ($1.00), except upon the customer's written request. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 10-27, § 2, 9-23-10; Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 9-20-12) 
Sec. 26-57. - Miscellaneous service charges. 
(a)  Service charges. Service charges related to miscellaneous services rendered may be adjusted from time to time and are established and adjusted by Resolution of the city commission after public hearing. 
(b)  Requests for meter tests. All requests for meter tests must be made on a form supplied by the city manager and must be signed by the customer. 
(c)  Adjustments resulting from meter tests. In the event that a water meter test indicates that the meter is producing a customer overcharge, an adjustment will be made to bills of the account in question for the past three (3) months to the degree that they exceed the bills for the same three (3) months of the prior year. In the event that the account has no prior year history, the three-month adjustment will be the percentage that the degree of error of the meter exceeds two (2) percent of AWWA specifications. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 03-15, § 3, 6-9-03; Ord. No. 03-26, § 5, 9-25-03; Ord. No. 06-10, § 1, 4-10-06; Ord. No. 12-13, § 1, 9-20-12) 
Sec. 26-58. - Discontinuing service for non-use. 
    The city manager may discontinue water and sewer service to any customer for non-use. The city manager will only restore services to such a customer following the payment of all applicable charges and penalties. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-59. - Property owner liability. 
    In the event that a customer fails to pay the charges established by this chapter, the property owner becomes liable and responsible for the payment of such charges. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-60. - Relief from sewer service charges. 
(a)  Conditions for requesting relief. A sewer customer may seek relief from sewer service charges in the following cases. 
(1)  In the event that the customer anticipates significant water use of a non-recurring nature where the water will not enter the POTW, the request for relief must be submitted in writing to the city manager not less than three (3) days prior to such water use. The request for relief must clearly indicate that the proposed water use is not wasteful or unreasonable. Such uses may include, but are not limited to, filling swimming pools and pressure washing. Such uses specifically do not include irrigation, gardening and car washing. 
(2)  In the event that the customer has experienced significant water leakage on the customer's side of the water meter and that the water did not enter the POTW, the request for relief must be submitted in writing to the city manager not more than three (3) days following discovery of the leak. The request for relief must include either: 
a.  A statement from a master plumber, certified by the State of Florida or licensed by the city or St. Johns County, that a sewer customer has experienced material water leakage on the customer's side of the water meter; or 
b.  A customer's receipt for materials or labor related to repairing the leak. 
(3)  In the event that the customer has experienced vandalism resulting in significant water leakage on the customer's side of the water meter and that the water did not enter the POTW, the request for relief must be submitted in writing to the city manager not more than three (3) days following the discovery of the vandalism and must be accompanied by a copy of the police report related to the vandalism. 
(4)  The city manager shall determine whether or not the customer's water use or leakage is significant. 
(b)  Conditions for granting relief. In the cases established in subsection (a) above, the city manager is authorized to adjust the sewer service charges as follows. 
(1)  The period of time of the adjustment must be requested in writing by the customer and be approved by the city manager. 
(2)  In the event that the customer's account has been active for twelve (12) months or more, the adjustment will equal the average sewer service charge for the account for the previous twelve (12) months. 
(3)  In the event that the customer's account has been active for more than three (3) months, but fewer than twelve (12) months, the adjustment will equal the average sewer service charge for the life of the account. 
(4)  In the event that the customer's account has been active for less than three (3) months, the sewer service charge will be reduced by fifteen (15) percent. 
(5)  In no case will the adjustment result in a sewer service charge below the minimum service charge established by this chapter. 
(6)  Customer sewer charges will not be adjusted more than one (1) time in any twelve-month period, except in the case of a leak discovered by a master plumber pursuant to subsection (a)(2) above, or in the case of vandalism pursuant to subsection (a)(3) above. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-61. - Care and share account. 
(a)  Care and share account established. There is in the general ledger a special account known as the 'care and share account'. The purpose of this account is to provide a means for city utility customers to contribute money to help indigent city utility customers pay their monthly utility bills. The city manager shall transfer to this account monthly an amount equal to the sums of the amounts designated to the account by customers under subsection (c) below. Funds on deposit in the care and share account are deemed appropriated for each fiscal year as they are collected but remain available for disbursement as designated without fiscal year limitation. 
(b)  A not-for-profit agency selected by the city commission, shall review applications for expenditures from the care and share account. The not-for-profit agency shall apply the standards and procedures adopted by the city manager or his or her designee for reviewing applications from customers who desire to have their water, sewer or garbage bills paid out of the care and share account. The not-for-profit agency may issue a voucher to the customer to be redeemed at the city's financial services department for complete or partial payment of the customer's unpaid utility bill. When a voucher is presented, the city manager may pay the customer's water, sewer and garbage bill to the extent that funds are available in the account. The city reserves the right to audit all documentation and accounts submitted by the not-for-profit agency and customer for issuance of vouchers pursuant to this section. 
(c)  Customer contribution voluntary. City utility customers may authorize the city manager to add a sum, voluntarily designated and paid by the customer, to the care and share account. The city manager shall provide a method for designating contributions to the care and share account on the customer's monthly utility bill. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 14-19, § 1, 10-27-14) 
Secs. 26-62-26-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WASTEWATER PRETREATMENT 

Sec. 26-76. - Purpose and policy. 
    This article sets forth uniform requirements for users of the publicly owned treatment works (POTW) for the city and enables the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33 United States Code 1251 et seq.), the general pretreatment regulations (40 CFR 403), and Chapter 62-625, F.A.C., Pretreatment Requirements for Existing and New Sources of Pollution. 
    This article applies to all users of the POTW. It authorizes the issuance of wastewater discharge permits; provides for monitoring, compliance, and enforcement activities; requires user reporting; and provides for the setting of fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the program established herein. 
    The objectives of this article are: 
(1)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW that will interfere with its operation; 
(2)  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW that will pass through the POTW, inadequately treated, into receiving waters, or will otherwise be incompatible with the POTW; 
(3)  To protect both POTW personnel who may be affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment and the general public; 
(4)  To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of operation, maintenance, and improvement of the POTW; and 
(5)  To enable the city to comply with its national pollutant discharge elimination system permit conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements, and any other federal or state laws to which the POTW is subject. 
(6)  To promote reuse and recycling of industrial wastewater and residuals from the POTW. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 05-08, § 2, 5-23-05) 
Sec. 26-77. - Approval authority. 
    The Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FDEP) is the approval authority. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-78. - Prohibited discharge standards. 
(a)  General prohibitions. No user shall introduce or cause to be introduced into the POTW any pollutant or wastewater which causes pass-through or interference. These prohibitions apply to all users of the POTW whether or not they are subject to categorical pretreatment standards or any other national, state or local pretreatment standards or requirements. 
(b)  Specific prohibitions. No user is allowed to introduce or cause to be introduced into the POTW the following pollutants, substances or wastewater: 
(1)  Pollutants which create a fire or explosive hazard in the POTW including, but not limited to, waste streams with a closed-cup flash point of less than one hundred forty (140) degrees F (sixty (60) C) using the test methods specified in 40 CFR 261.21; 
(2)  Wastewater having a pH less than five (5.0) or more than nine (9.0) or otherwise causing corrosive structural damage to the POTW or equipment; 
(3)  Solid or viscous substances in amounts which may obstruct the flow in the POTW resulting in interference, but in no case solids greater than two (2) inches in any dimension; 
(4)  Pollutants, including oxygen-demanding pollutants (CBOD, etc.), released in a discharge at a flow rate and/or pollutant concentration, which, either singly or by interaction with other pollutants, will cause interference with the POTW; 
(5)  Wastewater having a temperature greater than one hundred fifty (150) degrees F (sixty-five and one-half (65.5) C) which will inhibit biological activity in the treatment plant resulting in interference, but in no case wastewater which causes the temperature at the introduction into the treatment plant to exceed one hundred four (104) degrees F (forty (40) C); 
(6)  Petroleum oil, non-biodegradable cutting oil, or products of mineral oil origin in amounts that will cause interference or pass-through; 
(7)  Pollutants which result in the presence of toxic gases, vapors, or fumes within the POTW in a quantity that may cause acute worker health and safety problems; 
(8)  Hauled waste or pollutants, except at discharge points specifically designated by the city manager according to section 26-84 of this Code; 
(9)  Noxious or malodorous liquids, gases, solids, or other wastewater which, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, are sufficient to create a public nuisance or a hazard to life, or to prevent entry into the sewers for maintenance or repair; 
(10)  Wastewater imparting color that cannot be removed by the treatment process, including dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions; 
(11)  Wastewater containing radioactive wastes or isotopes, except in compliance with applicable federal or state regulations; 
(12)  Stormwater, surface water, ground water, artesian well water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, swimming pool drainage, condensate, de-ionized water, non-contact cooling water, and wastewater, unless specifically authorized by the city manager; 
(13)  Sludge, screenings, or other residues from the pretreatment of industrial wastes; 
(14)  Medical wastes, except as specifically authorized by the city manager in a wastewater discharge permit; 
(15)  Wastewater that, alone or in conjunction with other sources, causes the POTW effluent to fail a toxicity test; 
(16)  Detergents, surface-active agents, or other substances that may cause excessive foaming in the POTW; 
(17)  Fats, oils, or greases of animal or vegetable origin in concentrations greater than the established local limit, or any grease trap or grease interceptor waste; 
(18)  Hazardous wastes as defined in 40 CFR 261. 
(c)  Processing and storage restrictions. No user shall process or store pollutants, substances or wastewater prohibited by this article in such a manner that they could enter the POTW. 
(d)  Notification of the discharge of hazardous waste. Any user who commences the discharge of hazardous waste must notify the city manager, the EPA regional waste management division director, and the Florida Department of Environmental Protection hazardous waste and pretreatment authorities, in writing, of any discharge into the POTW of a substance which, if otherwise disposed of, would be a hazardous waste under 40 CFR Part 261. Such notification must include the name of the hazardous waste as set forth in 40 CFR Part 261, the EPA hazardous waste number, and the type of discharge (continuous, batch, or other). If the user discharges more than one hundred (100) kilograms of such waste per calendar month to the POTW, the notification must also contain the following information to the extent such information is known and readily available to the user: An identification of the hazardous constituents contained in the wastes, an estimation of the mass and concentration of such constituents in the waste stream discharged during that calendar month, and an estimate of the mass of constituents in the waste stream expected to be discharged during the following twelve (12) months. All notifications must take place within one hundred and eighty (180) days after the discharge commences. Any notification under this subsection need be submitted only once for each hazardous waste discharged. However, notifications of changed conditions must be submitted as required by section 26-100 of this Code. The notification requirement in this section does not apply to pollutants already reported by users subject to categorical pretreatment standards under the self-monitoring requirements of this chapter. 
(e)  Exemptions. Users are exempt from the requirements of subsection (d) above during a calendar month in which they discharge no more than fifteen (15) kilograms of hazardous wastes, unless the wastes are acute hazardous wastes as specified in 40 CFR 261.30(d) and 261.33(e). Discharge of more than fifteen (15) kilograms of non-acute hazardous wastes in a calendar month, or of any quantity of acute hazardous wastes as specified in 40 CFR 261.30(d) and 261.33(e), requires a one-time notification. Following the one-time notification, users discharging more than these quantities of any hazardous waste are not required to additionally notify the city manager. 
(f)  Impact of new regulations. In the case of any new regulation under section 3001 of RCRA identifying additional characteristics of hazardous waste or listing any additional substance as a hazardous waste, the user must notify the city manager, the EPA regional waste management waste division director, and state hazardous waste authorities of the discharge of such substance within ninety (90) days of the effective date of the new regulation. 
(g)  Reduction of hazardous wastes. In the case of any notification made under this section, the user must certify that it has a program in place to reduce the volume and toxicity of hazardous wastes generated to the degree the user has determined it to be economically practical. 
(h)  Rights of discharge limited. This section does not create a right to discharge any substance not otherwise permitted to be discharged by this Code, by any wastewater discharge permit issued hereunder, or by any applicable federal or state law. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 3, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-79. - National Categorical Pretreatment Standards. 
    The categorical pretreatment standards found in 40 CFR Chapter I, Subchapter N, Parts 405-471, are hereby incorporated. 
(1)  Where a categorical pretreatment standard is expressed only in terms of either the mass or the concentration of a pollutant in wastewater, the city manager may impose equivalent concentration or mass limits in accordance with Rule 62-625.410(4), F.A.C. 
(2)  When wastewater subject to a categorical pretreatment standard is mixed with wastewater not regulated by the same standard, the city manager shall impose an alternate limit using the combined waste stream formula in Rule 62-625.410(6), F.A.C. 
(3)  A user may obtain a variance from a categorical pretreatment standard if the user can prove, pursuant to the procedural and substantive provisions in Rule 62-625.700, F.A.C., that factors relating to its discharge are fundamentally different from the factors considered by EPA when developing the categorical pretreatment standard. 
(4)  A user may obtain a net gross adjustment to a categorical standard according to Rule 62-625.820, F.A.C. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 05-08, § 3, 5-23-05; Ord. No. 08-11, § 2, 6-23-08; Ord. No. 11-25, § 4, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-80. - Local limits and right of revision. 
(a)  Local limits. The city hereby adopts the standards and requirements established by the applicable parts of Title 40, Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 400-699) in industrial user permits. As appropriate, local limits governing discharges to the POTW through industrial user permits will be developed by the city and approved by Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FDEP). The local limits governing discharges to the POTW effective on November 4, 2011 are hereby adopted, ratified and implemented into the City Code by reference. The city manager is granted the authority to make amendments to said local limits as the city manager finds necessary. 
(b)  No person shall discharge wastewater containing pollutants in excess of the local limits for those pollutants which limits have been established for the City of St. Augustine's WWTP using standard procedures, calculations and methods acceptable to the FDEP to protect against pass through, interference, protection of WWTP employees and adverse affects on wastewater residuals disposal. No industrial user shall discharge process waste streams or unregulated waste streams or shall dilute waste streams in excess of the concentrations set forth by the city manager. Local limits shall be included as permit conditions and attached to each SIU wastewater permit issued. 
(c)  The established local limits are subject to change and shall be modified as needed based on regulatory requirements and standards, WWTP operation, performance and processes, the industrial user base, potable water quality and domestic wastewater characteristics. Modifications to the established local limits must be reviewed and approved by FDEP prior to implementation. Implementation shall be effective thirty (30) days from notice of acceptance of the modified limits by FDEP. Permitted SIUs shall also be issued an addendum to their wastewater discharge permit containing the new local limits. 
(d)  The established local limits apply at the point where the wastewater is discharged to the POTW. All concentrations for metallic substances are for total metal unless indicated otherwise. At his or her discretion, the city manager may impose mass limitations in addition to or in place of the concentration-based limitations. 
(e)  The city manager may develop best management practices (BMPs), by ordinance or in individual wastewater discharge permits, to implement local limits and the requirements of section 26-78. 
(f)  Right of revision. The city reserves the right to establish, by ordinance or in wastewater discharge permits, more stringent standards or requirements than those specifically established by 40 CFR or Chapter 62-625 FAC on discharges to the POTW. 
(g)  A copy of the approved local limits is available upon request at the following location: City of St. Augustine City Hall, 75 King Street, St. Augustine, Florida 32084. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 5, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-81. - Pretreatment measures and facilities. 
(a)  User responsibility. Users must provide wastewater pretreatment necessary to comply with this chapter and must comply with all categorical pretreatment standards, local limits, and prohibitions established by this Code within the time limit specified by EPA, the state or the city manager, whichever is more stringent. The user must provide, operate, and maintain any facilities required to meet the requirements of this Code, at the user's expense. The user must submit detailed plans and operating procedures of such facilities to the city manager. The city manager will review and approve such plans and operating procedures in writing before such facilities are constructed. The review of such plans and operating procedures in no way relieves the user from the responsibility of modifying such facilities as necessary to produce a discharge meeting the requirements of this chapter. 
(b)  Dilution. Increasing the use of process water, or in any way attempting to dilute a discharge, as a partial or complete substitute for adequate pretreatment, to achieve compliance with a discharge limitation unless specifically authorized by an applicable pretreatment standard or requirement is prohibited. The city manager may impose mass limits on users who are using dilution to meet applicable pretreatment standards or requirements, or in other cases when the imposition of mass limitations is appropriate. 
(c)  Discharge restrictions authorized. The city manager may require users to restrict their discharge during peak flow periods, to discharge certain wastewater only into specific sewers, to relocate and/or consolidate points of discharge, and/or to separate sewage waste streams from industrial waste streams. The city manager may also require a user to take any other action necessary to protect the POTW and determine the user's compliance with the requirements of this chapter. 
(d)  Flow equalization. The city manager may require any user to install and maintain, on the user's property and at the user's expense, a suitable storage and flow control facility to ensure equalization of flow. The city manager may issue a wastewater discharge permit solely for flow equalization. 
(e)  Combustible gas detection. The city manager is authorized to require users with the potential to discharge flammable substances to install and maintain a combustible gas detection meter meeting OSHA standards. 
(f)  Interceptors. The city manager is authorized to require users likely to discharge grease, oil or sand to the POTW to install interceptors. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-82. - Interceptors. 
(a)  Users required to install interceptors. Interceptors, as defined in this Code, must be installed as follows prior to any certificate of occupancy being issued: 
(1)  For any new source, as defined by this Code, likely to discharge oil, grease or sand to the POTW; 
(2)  For any new facility or use likely to discharge oil, grease or sand to the POTW; 
(3)  For any existing facility or use that has been expanded or renovated, resulting in the addition of facilities or uses likely to discharge oil, grease or sand to the POTW, where such facilities or uses did not previously exist; 
(4)  For any existing facility or use that the city manager determines contributes oil, grease or sand to the POTW in quantities sufficient to cause line stoppages or necessitate increased maintenance on the collection system; and/or 
(5)  For renovation or expansion of any facility or use contributing or likely to contribute oil, grease or sand to the POTW, where such renovation or expansion requires a plumbing permit from the city. 
(6)  Sources, uses and facilities considered likely to discharge oil, grease or sand to the POTW include: Restaurants, hotel kitchens, hospitals, school kitchens, bars, factory cafeterias, clubs, service stations, repair garages, factories producing oily or flammable wastes, car washes, commercial laundries and dry cleaners, bottling plants, and slaughtering houses. 
(b)  Program manual. The Fats, Oils and Grease Program Manual promulgated by the city manager, as amended from time to time, is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as part of this section. Copies of the Fats, Oils and Grease Program Manual shall be available upon request. 
(c)  Specifications and installation. Interceptors shall be designed and installed in accordance with the Fats, Oils and Grease Program Manual solely at the user's expense. Plans and specifications for interceptors shall be submitted to the city for approval prior to installation. 
(d)  Cleaning and maintenance. Interceptors shall be cleaned, maintained and repaired in accordance with requirements of the Fats, Oils and Grease Program Manual solely by the user and solely at the user's expense. Users shall maintain an on-site record log of all cleaning and maintenance activities for a minimum of three years. 
(e)  Inspections. The city shall conduct inspections on all facilities with interceptors at a frequency based on the size of the device. Inspections are conducted to ensure compliance with the requirements of the Fats, Oils and Grease Program Manual and to ensure adherence to proper cleaning and maintenance schedules as established by the program manual. 
(f)  Adoption, incorporation and amendment of the City of St. Augustine Fats, Oils and Grease Program Manual. The City of St. Augustine Fats, Oils and Grease Program Manual dated [November 4, 2011] is hereby adopted, ratified and implemented by reference into the City Code. The city manager is granted the authority to make amendments to said City of St. Augustine Fats, Oils and Grease Program Manual as the city manager finds necessary. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 6, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-83. - Accidental discharge and slug control plans. 
    At least once every two (2) years, the city manager will evaluate whether each significant industrial user needs to develop and implement an accidental discharge and slug control plan. The city manager may require any user to develop and implement an accidental discharge and slug control plan. Such a plan must be reviewed and approved by the city manager and must include, at a minimum, the following: 
(1)  Description of discharge practices, including non-routine batch discharges; 
(2)  Description of stored chemicals; 
(3)  Procedures for immediately notifying the city manager of any accidental or slug discharge as required by section 26-101 of this Code; and 
(4)  Procedures to prevent adverse impact from any accidental or slug discharge. Such procedures include, but are not limited to: Inspecting and maintaining storage areas, handling and transfer of materials, loading and unloading operations, control of plant site stormwater runoff, worker training, containment structures or equipment, containing toxic organic pollutants and solvents, and/or measures and equipment for emergency response. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-84. - Hauled waste. 
(a)  Septic tank waste. Septic tank waste may only be introduced into the POTW at locations and times designated by the city manager. Such waste must not violate section 26-78 of this Code or any other requirements established by the city. The city manager may require septic tank waste haulers to obtain wastewater discharge permits. 
(b)  Wastewater discharge permits required. The city manager requires generators and haulers of industrial waste to obtain wastewater discharge permits. The city manager may prohibit the disposal of hauled industrial waste in the POTW. The discharge of hauled industrial waste is subject to all other requirements of this chapter. 
(c)  Discharge of hauled industrial waste. Industrial waste haulers must not discharge loads at locations other than those specified by the city manager. The city manager must give prior consent to any discharge of hauled industrial waste. The city manager is authorized to collect samples of each load to ensure compliance with applicable standards. The city manager is authorized to require industrial waste generators and haulers to provide a waste analysis of any load prior to discharge. 
(d)  Record keeping. Industrial waste haulers must provide a waste tracking form for every load of waste hauled. This form must include, at a minimum, the name and address of the industrial waste hauler, permit number, truck identification, name and address of each source of the hauled waste, volume and characteristics of the waste. The form must identify the type of industry generating the waste, known or suspected waste constituents, and whether or not any wastes are RCRA hazardous wastes. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-85. - Wastewater analysis. 
    The city manager may require a user to submit information concerning the nature and characteristics of its wastewater. When so requested, the user must submit the requested information within sixty (60) days of the date of the request. The city manager is authorized to prepare a form for this purpose and may periodically require users to update the information submitted. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-86. - Wastewater discharge permits and renewals. 
(a)  Permits for significant industrial users. Significant industrial users must not discharge wastewater to the POTW prior to obtaining a wastewater discharge permit from the city manager. 
(b)  Permits for other users. The city manager may require users other than significant industrial users to obtain wastewater discharge permits to implement the requirements of this chapter. 
(c)  Violations. Any violation of the conditions of a wastewater discharge permit is a violation of this chapter and subjects the wastewater discharge permit holder to the sanctions set forth in this chapter. Obtaining a wastewater discharge permit does not relieve the permit holder of the obligation to comply with federal and state pretreatment standards and requirements or with any other requirements of federal, state and local law. 
(d)  Permits for existing connections. Any user required to obtain a wastewater discharge permit, who was discharging wastewater to the POTW prior to August 2, 2001, and who wishes to continue such discharges in the future, must submit an application for a wastewater discharge permit according to section 26-87 of this Code. Such user must not cause or allow discharges to the POTW to continue more than sixty (60) days after August 2, 2001, except according to a wastewater discharge permit issued by the city manager. 
(e)  Permits for new connections. Any user required to obtain a wastewater discharge permit must obtain such permit prior to beginning such discharge. The user must submit an application for this wastewater discharge permit according to section 26-87 of this chapter at least sixty (60) days prior to the date upon which any discharge will begin. 
(f)  Application fee. The city charges an application fee for each wastewater discharge permit application and each wastewater discharge permit renewal. The application fee must accompany each application. 
(g)  Incomplete applications. Incomplete or inaccurate applications will not be processed and will be returned to the user for revision. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-87. - Information required on wastewater discharge permit applications, renewals and monitoring reports. 
    Users required to obtain wastewater discharge permits must submit an application for such permit to the city manager. All applications for wastewater discharge permits, renewals and monitoring reports must contain the following information on a form approved by the city manager: 
(1)  Identifying information. Name and address of the facility, including the name of the operator and the name of the owner. 
(2)  Environmental permits. A list of any environmental control permits held by or for the facility. 
(3)  Description of operations. Description of the nature, average rate of production, and North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) codes of the operations carried out by the user. This description should include a schematic process diagram indicating points of discharge to the POTW from regulated processes. 
(4)  Flow measurement. Measured average daily flow and maximum daily flow, in gpd, of discharges to the POTW from regulated process streams, and from other streams when necessary to allow use of the combined waste stream formula set out in 40 CFR 403.6(e). 
(5)  Pollutant measurement. 
a.  Categorical pretreatment standards applicable to each regulated process and any new categorically regulated processes for existing sources. 
b.  Results of sampling and analysis identifying the nature, concentration and/or mass of regulated pollutants in the discharge from each regulated process. 
c.  Instantaneous, daily maximum or long-term average concentrations, or mass must be reported. 
d.  The samples shall be representative of daily operations and analyzed as required by section 26-102 of this Code. Where compliance with a BMP or pollution prevention alternative is required, the user shall submit documentation as required by the city manager or the applicable standard to determine compliance with the standard. 
e.  Sampling must be performed in accordance with procedures set out in section 26-96 of this Code. 
(6)  Description of potential discharges. Description of activities, facilities, and plant processes on the premises, including a list of all raw materials and chemicals used or stored at the facility which are, or could accidentally or intentionally be, discharged to the POTW. 
(7)  Employees and hours of operation. Number and type of employees, proposed or actual hours of operation. 
(8)  Description of products and processes. Each product produced by type, amount, process or processes, and rate of production. 
(9)  Raw materials processed. Type and amount of raw materials processed (average and maximum per day). 
(10)  Plans. Site plans, floor plans, mechanical and plumbing plans, and details indicating all sewers, floor drains, and appurtenances by size, location, and elevation, and all points of discharge. 
(11)  Time and duration of discharges. 
(12)  Location. The location for monitoring all wastes covered by the permit. 
(13)  Other information. Any other information the city manager deems necessary to evaluate the wastewater discharge permit application. 
(14)  Certification. A statement, signed by an authorized representative of the user indicating whether pretreatment standards are being met on a consistent basis, and if not, whether additional pretreatment is required to meet pretreatment standards and requirements. 
(15)  Signatures and certification. 
a.  All wastewater discharge permit applications, renewals and monitoring reports must be signed by an authorized representative of the user and contain the following certification statement: 
"I certify under penalty of law that this document and all attachments were prepared under my direction or supervision according to a system designed to assure that qualified personnel properly gather and evaluate the information submitted. Based on my inquiry of the person or persons who manage the system, or those persons directly responsible for gathering the information, the information submitted is, to the best of my knowledge and belief, true, accurate, and complete. I am aware that there are significant penalties for submitting false information, including the possibility of fine and imprisonment for knowing violations." 
b.  If the designation of an authorized representative is no longer accurate because a different individual or position has responsibility for the overall operation of the facility or overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, a new written authorization satisfying the requirements of this section must be submitted to the city manager prior to or together with any reports to be signed by the authorized representative. 
c.  A facility determined to be a non-significant categorical user by the city manager pursuant to section 26-3 of this Code must annually submit the following certification statement signed by an authorized representative. This certification must accompany any alternative report required by the city manager: 
"Based on my inquiry of the person or persons directly responsible for managing compliance with the categorical pretreatment standards under 40 CFR [specify applicable national pretreatment standard parts(s)], I certify that, to the best of my knowledge and belief that during the period from [month, day, year] to [month, day, year]: 
(a)  The facility described as [industrial user name] met the definition of a non-significant categorical industrial user as described in paragraph 62-625.200(25)(c), F.A.C.; 
(b)  The facility complied with all applicable pretreatment standards and requirements during this reported period; and 
(c)  The facility never discharged more than one hundred (100) gallons of total categorical wastewater on any given day during this reporting period. This compliance certification is based upon the following information: [documentation of basis to continue exemption]." 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 7, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-88. - Wastewater discharge permit decisions. 
    The city manager reviews each permit application and accompanying data furnished by the user. Within forty-five (45) days of receiving a complete wastewater discharge permit application, the city manager will either issue the wastewater discharge permit or deny the application. The city manager may deny any application for a wastewater discharge permit. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-89. - Duration of permit. 
    Wastewater discharge permits are issued for a period not to exceed five (5) years and include a specific issue date and a specific expiration date. A wastewater discharge permit may be issued for a period less than five (5) years at the discretion of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-90. - Contents and conditions of permit. 
(a)  General conditions. A wastewater discharge permit includes conditions deemed reasonably necessary by the city manager to prevent pass-through or interference, protect the water quality of receiving streams, protect worker health and safety, facilitate sludge management and disposal, and prevent damage to the POTW. 
(b)  Required conditions. Wastewater discharge permits contain: 
(1)  A statement indicating permit duration not to exceed five (5) years, a specific issue date and a specific expiration date; 
(2)  A statement that the wastewater discharge permit is nontransferable without prior notification to the city manager according to section 26-92 of this Code, and provisions for furnishing the new owner or operator with a copy of the existing wastewater discharge permit; 
(3)  Effluent limits, including best management practices, based on applicable pretreatment standards 
(4)  Self-monitoring, sampling, reporting, notification, and record keeping requirements, including identification of the pollutants to be monitored, sampling types, sampling locations and sampling frequency based on the applicable general pretreatment standards in Chapter 62-625, F.A.C., categorical pretreatment standards, local limits, and federal, state and local law; and 
(5)  Statement of applicable civil and criminal penalties which may be imposed for violating pretreatment standards and requirements, or compliance schedules. Such schedules shall not extend the compliance date beyond applicable state or federal deadlines. 
(6)  Requirements to control slug discharges in accordance with Chapter 62-625.500(2)(b)6, F.A.C., if determined by the city manager to be necessary. 
(c)  Other conditions. Wastewater discharge permits may also contain the following conditions: 
(1)  Limits on the average and/or maximum rate of discharge, time of discharge, and/or requirements for flow regulation and equalization; 
(2)  Requirements to install pretreatment technology, pollution control, or to construct appropriate containment devices, designed to reduce, eliminate, or prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW; 
(3)  Requirements to develop and implement spill control plans or other special conditions including management practices necessary to prevent accidental, unanticipated, or non-routine discharges; 
(4)  Requirements to develop and implement waste minimization plans to reduce the amount of pollutants discharged to the POTW; 
(5)  The schedule of user charges and fees for managing wastewater discharged to the POTW; 
(6)  Requirements to install and maintain inspection and sampling facilities and equipment; 
(7)  A statement that compliance with the wastewater discharge permit does not relieve the permit holder of responsibility for complying with all applicable federal and state pretreatment standards, including those which become effective during the term of the wastewater discharge permit; and 
(8)  Other conditions deemed appropriate by the city manager to ensure compliance with this chapter, and with state and federal laws, rules, and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 8, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-91. - Appeals. 
(a)  The city manager may provide public notice of the issue of a wastewater discharge permit. Any person, including the user, may petition the city manager to reconsider the terms of the wastewater discharge permit within thirty (30) days of notice that the permit has been issued. 
(b)  Failure to submit a timely petition for reconsideration shall be deemed a waiver of the administrative appeal. 
(c)  The wastewater discharge permit shall remain in effect pending the appeal. 
(d)  If the city manager fails to act within thirty (30) days of receiving a petition for reconsideration, the request for reconsideration shall be deemed to be denied. Decisions not to reconsider a wastewater discharge permit, not to issue a wastewater discharge permit, or not to modify a wastewater discharge permit shall be considered final administrative actions for purposes of judicial review. 
(e)  Aggrieved persons seeking judicial review of the final administrative wastewater discharge permit decision must do so by filing a complaint with the Circuit Court of Appeals. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 15-01, § 1, 1-25-16) 
Sec. 26-92. - Permit modification, transfer and renewal. 
(a)  Permit modification. The city manager may modify a wastewater discharge permit for good cause, including, but not limited to, the following reasons: 
(1)  To incorporate any new or revised federal, state, or local pretreatment standards or requirements; 
(2)  To address significant alterations or additions to the user's operations, processes, or wastewater volume or character since the date the wastewater discharge permit was issued; 
(3)  In response to changes to the POTW that require either a temporary or permanent reduction or elimination of the permitted discharge; 
(4)  In response to information indicating that the permitted discharge poses a threat to the POTW, city personnel, or the receiving waters; 
(5)  In response to user violations of any wastewater discharge permit conditions; 
(6)  In response to user misrepresentations or failure to fully disclose all relevant facts in either the wastewater discharge permit application or in any required report; 
(7)  As a result of a revision of, or a grant of variance from, categorical pretreatment standards pursuant to 40 CFR 403.13; 
(8)  To correct typographical or other errors in the wastewater discharge permit; or 
(9)  To transfer the wastewater discharge permit to a new owner or operator. 
(b)  Permit transfer. Wastewater discharge permits may be transferred to a new owner or operator only if the permit holder gives at least forty-five (45) days advance notice to the city manager and the city manager approves the wastewater discharge permit transfer. If the permit holder fails to provide proper advance notice of a proposed transfer, the wastewater discharge permit becomes void as of the date of facility transfer. The advance notice must include a written certification by the new owner or operator which: 
(1)  States that the new owner and/or operator has no immediate intent to change the facility's operations and processes: 
(2)  Identifies the specific date on which the transfer is to occur; and 
(3)  Acknowledges full responsibility for complying with the conditions of the existing wastewater discharge permit. 
(c)  Permit renewal. A user with an expiring wastewater discharge permit must apply for wastewater discharge permit renewal by submitting a complete permit application, according to section 26-87 of this Code, a minimum of one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the expiration of the existing wastewater discharge permit. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-93. - Revoking and voiding permits. 
(a)  Revoking a permit. The city manager may revoke a wastewater discharge permit for good cause including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Failing to notify the city manager of significant changes to the wastewater prior to the changed discharge; 
(2)  Failing to provide prior notification to the city manager of changed conditions pursuant to section 26-100 of this Code; 
(3)  Misrepresenting facts or failing to fully disclose all relevant facts in a wastewater discharge permit application; 
(4)  Falsifying self-monitoring reports; 
(5)  Tampering with monitoring equipment; 
(6)  Refusing to allow the city manager timely access to the facility premises and records; 
(7)  Failing to meet effluent limitations; 
(8)  Failing to pay fines; 
(9)  Failing to pay sewer charges; 
(10)  Failing to meet compliance schedules; 
(11)  Failing to submit a complete monitoring report or wastewater discharge permit application; 
(12)  Failing to notify the city manager in advance of the transfer of business ownership of a permitted facility; or 
(13)  Violating any provision of this chapter, any condition of a wastewater discharge permit, any condition of any order issued pursuant to this chapter, or any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
(b)  Voiding a permit. Wastewater discharge permits become void upon cessation of operations or transfer of business ownership according to section 26-92 of this Code. A wastewater discharge permit issued to a user becomes void upon the issuance of a new wastewater discharge permit to that user. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-94. - Wastewater received from other local governments. 
(a)  Interlocal agreement required. If another local government or a user located within another local government contributes wastewater to the POTW continually for a minimum of one hundred twenty (120) consecutive days, the city shall enter into an interlocal agreement with the contributing local government. 
(b)  Information required. Prior to entering into the interlocal agreement required by subsection (a) above, the contributing local government must provide the following information: 
(1)  A description of the quality and volume of wastewater discharged to the POTW by the contributing local government; 
(2)  An inventory of all users located within the contributing local government that are discharging to the POTW; and 
(3)  Other information the city manager deems necessary. 
(c)  Conditions of interlocal agreement. Any interlocal agreement required by subsection (a) above, must contain the following conditions: 
(1)  A requirement for the contributing local government to adopt a sewer use ordinance which is at least as stringent as this chapter and local limits which are at least as stringent as those established by section 26-80 of this Code. The requirement must specify that such ordinance and local limits must be revised as necessary to reflect changes made to the City Code; 
(2)  A requirement for the contributing local government to submit a revised user inventory on at least an annual basis;
