(3)  A provision specifying which pretreatment implementation activities, including wastewater discharge permitting, inspection, sampling, and enforcement, will be conducted by the contributing local government; which of these activities will be conducted by the city manager; and which of these activities will be conducted jointly by the contributing local government and the city manager; 
(4)  A requirement that the contributing local government provide the city manager with access to all information that the contributing local government obtains as part of its pretreatment activities; 
(5)  Limits on the nature, quality, and volume of the contributing local government's wastewater at the point where it discharges to the POTW; 
(6)  Requirements for monitoring the contributing local government's discharge; 
(7)  A provision ensuring the city manager access to the facilities of users located within the contributing local government's jurisdictional boundaries for the purpose of inspection, sampling, and any other duties deemed necessary by the city manager; and 
(8)  A provision specifying remedies available for breach of the terms of the interlocal agreement. 
(d)  Enforcement of pretreatment standards. The city has the right to take legal action to enforce the contributing local government's sewer ordinance, or to impose and enforce city POTW pretreatment standards and requirements directly against noncompliant users in the event that the contributing local government is unable or unwilling to take such action. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-95. - Pretreatment charges, surcharges and fees. 
(a)  Pretreatment fees. Fees related to the city's pretreatment program are hereby established as follows. These fees relate solely to the city's pretreatment program and are separate from all other fees, charges, fines, and penalties chargeable by the city. Pretreatment charges, surcharges and fees are non-refundable. 
(1)  Application for wastewater discharge permit or renewal: Five hundred dollars ($500.00); 
(2)  Annual permit maintenance fee (includes monitoring, inspecting, sampling, analysis, and reviewing monitoring reports): Five hundred dollars ($500.00); 
(3)  Reviewing and responding to accidental discharge procedures and construction: Actual cost; 
(4)  Application to appeal the issue of a wastewater discharge permit or renewal: Five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(b)  Surcharge for exceeding established limits. An industrial discharge with concentrations of specified pollutants in excess of established limits, which can be treated by conventional processes but at higher cost will be surcharged as follows: 
(1)  Wastewater with a CBOD concentration in excess of two hundred fifty (250) mg/l: Seventy-four cents ($0.74) per pound of CBOD. 
(2)  Wastewater with total SS concentration in excess of two hundred fifty (250) mg/l: Ninety-eight cents ($0.98) per pound of total SS. 
(3)  Wastewater with a COD concentration exceeding that of the CBOD concentration multiplied by one and sixty-seven one hundredths (1.67): Forty-seven cents ($0.47) per pound of COD in excess of permitted limits for COD. 
(4)  These surcharges are in addition to any other established rates. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-96. - Baseline monitoring reports. 
(a)  Reports from existing users. Existing categorical users currently discharging to the POTW, or scheduled to discharge to the POTW, must submit a report to the city manager containing the information listed in paragraph (e) below. This report must be submitted within one hundred eighty (180) days after the effective date of a categorical pretreatment standard or the final administrative decision on a category determination under Rule 62-625.410(2)(d), F.A.C., whichever is later. 
(b)  Reports from new users. New sources and sources that become categorical users following the promulgation of an applicable categorical standard must submit a report to the city manager containing the information listed in paragraph (e) below. The report must be submitted at least ninety (90) days prior to commencement of the discharge. A new source shall report the method of pretreatment it intends to use to meet applicable categorical standards. A new source also shall give estimates of its anticipated flow and quantity of pollutants to be discharged. 
(c)  Reports from nonpermitted users. The city manager may require users who are not required to obtain a wastewater discharge permit to provide reports to the city manager. 
(d)  Timing of reports. Written reports will be considered submitted on the date postmarked. Written reports transmitted by other means will be considered submitted on the date received by the city manager. 
(e)  Information required on monitoring reports. Users described above shall submit the information set forth below. 
(1)  All information in section 26-87(1) through (4). 
(2)  Measurements of pollutants. 
a.  The user shall provide the information required in section 26-87(5)a. through (5)d.; 
b.  The user shall take a minimum of one representative sample to compile that data necessary to comply with the requirements of this paragraph; 
c.  Samples should be taken immediately downstream from pretreatment facilities if such exist or immediately downstream from the regulated process if no pretreatment exists. If other wastewaters are mixed with the regulated wastewater prior to pretreatment the user should measure the flows and concentrations necessary to allow use of the combined wastestream formula in 62-625.410(6), F.A.C. to evaluate compliance with the pretreatment standards. Where an alternate concentration or mass limit has been calculated in accordance with 62-625.410(6), F.A.C. this adjusted limit along with supporting data shall be submitted to the city; 
d.  Sampling and analysis shall be performed in accordance with section 26-102; 
e.  The city manager may allow the submission of a baseline report which used only historical data so long as the data provides information sufficient to determine the need for industrial pretreatment measures; 
f.  The baseline report shall indicate the time, date and place of sampling and methods of analysis, and shall certify that such sampling and analysis is representative of normal work cycles and expected pollutant discharges to the POTW. 
(3)  Compliance certification. A statement, reviewed by the user's authorized representative as defined in section 26-3 and certified by a qualified professional, indicating whether pretreatment standards are being met on a consistent basis, and, if not, whether additional operation and maintenance and/or additional pretreatment is required to meet the pretreatment standards and requirements. 
(4)  Compliance schedule. If additional pretreatment and/or operation and maintenance will be required to meet the pretreatment standards, the shortest schedule by which the user will provide such additional pretreatment and/or operation and maintenance requirements must be provided. The completion date in this schedule shall not be later than the compliance date established for the pretreatment standard. A compliance schedule pursuant to this section must meet the requirements set out in section 26-97 of this Code. 
(5)  Signature and report certification. All baseline monitoring reports must be certified in accordance with section 26-87(15) of this Code and signed by an authorized representative as defined in section 26-3. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 05-08, § 4, 5-23-05; Ord. No. 11-25, § 9, 10-25-11) 
Sec. 26-97. - Compliance schedule progress reports. 
(a)  Compliance schedule. If additional pretreatment is required to meet pretreatment standards, the user must implement the shortest schedule by which to provide such additional pretreatment. The completion date in this schedule must not be later than the compliance date established for the applicable pretreatment standard. The city manager reviews and approves the compliance schedule prior to implementation. 
(b)  Milestone dates and progress increments. The compliance schedule must list milestone dates which establish progress increments for commencing and completing major events leading to constructing and operating additional pretreatment required to meet applicable pretreatment standards. Such major events include, but are not limited to, hiring an engineer, completing preliminary and final plans, executing contracts for major components, commencing and completing construction, commencing routine operations, and achieving final compliance. No increment referred to in this paragraph shall exceed nine (9) months. 
(c)  Progress reports. The user must submit a progress report to the city manager no later than fourteen (14) days following each milestone date in the schedule. The progress report must include, at a minimum, whether or not major events were completed on schedule, the reason for any delay, and if appropriate, the steps being taken to return to the established schedule. In no event shall more than nine (9) months elapse between such progress reports to the city manager. 
(d)  Reports on compliance with categorical pretreatment standard deadline. Within ninety (90) days following the date for final compliance with applicable pretreatment standards, or in the case of a new source, following commencement of the introduction of wastewater into the POTW, any user subject to such pretreatment standards and requirements shall submit to the city manager a report containing the information described in sections 26-87(4) and (5) and 26-96(e)(2) of this Code. For users subject to equivalent mass or concentration limits established in accordance with the procedures in section 26-79, this report shall contain a reasonable measure of the user's long-term production rate. For all other users subject to categorical pretreatment standards expressed in terms or allowable pollutant discharge per unit of production (or other method of operation), this report shall include the user's actual production during the appropriate sampling period. All compliance reports must be signed and certified in accordance with section 26-87(15). All sampling will be done in conformance with section 26-102. 
(e)  Termination of service. Nothing in this section prohibits the city manager from terminating service to the user in the event that the POTW fails to meet its permit limits during the period of user noncompliance. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 10, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-98. - Categorical pretreatment standard compliance reports. 
    Any user subject to pretreatment standards and requirements must submit a monitoring report to the city manager within sixty (60) days following the date for final compliance with applicable categorical pretreatment standards. Any user considered to be a new source subject to pretreatment standards and requirements must submit a monitoring report to the city manager following commencement of the introduction of wastewater into the POTW. For users subject to equivalent mass or concentration limits established in 40 CFR 403.6(c), this report must contain a reasonable measure of the user's long-term production rate. For all other users subject to categorical pretreatment standards expressed in terms of allowable pollutant discharge per unit of production (or other measure of operation), this report must include the user's actual production during the sampling period. Reports must include the information required by section 26-87 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-99. - Periodic compliance reports. 
(a)  All significant industrial users, except a nonsignificant categorical industrial user, must submit reports indicating the nature and concentration of pollutants in their discharge limited by pretreatment standards and the measured or estimated average and maximum daily flows for the reporting period. In cases where the pretreatment standard requires compliance with a best management practice or pollution prevention alternative, the user must submit documentation required by the city manager or the pretreatment standard necessary to determine the compliance status of the user. Reports must be submitted at a frequency determined by the city manager, but in no case less than twice per year (June and December). All periodic compliance reports must be signed and certified in accordance with section 26-87 of this Code. 
(b)  All wastewater samples must be representative of the user's discharge. Wastewater monitoring and flow measurement facilities must be properly operated, kept clean and maintained in good working order at all times. Failing to keep monitoring facilities in good working order is not grounds for the user to claim that sample results are unrepresentative of the user's discharge. 
(c)  If a user subject to the reporting requirements in this section monitors any pollutant more frequently than required by the city manager, and using the procedures prescribed in section 26-102 of this Code, the user must include the results of this monitoring in the report. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 11, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-100. - Reports of changed conditions. 
    Users must notify the city manager of any planned significant changes to the user's operations or system that might alter the nature, quality, or volume of the user's wastewater discharge at least ninety (90) days before the change. Significant changes include, but are not limited to, flow increases of twenty (20) percent or greater and the discharge of any previously unreported pollutants. 
(1)  The city manager may require the user to submit information necessary to evaluate the proposed changed conditions and may require the user to submit a wastewater discharge permit application. 
(2)  The city manager may issue a wastewater discharge permit or modify an existing wastewater discharge permit in response to changed conditions or anticipated changed conditions. 
(3)  Modifying an existing wastewater discharge permit may require advance approval from EPA. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-101. - Reports of discharges causing potential problems. 
(a)  Initial notification. In the case of any discharge that may cause potential problems for the POTW, the user must immediately telephone and notify the city manager of the incident. Such discharges include, but are not limited to, accidental discharges, discharges of a nonroutine or episodic nature, non-customary batch discharges, and a slug discharge or slug load. Notification must include the location of the discharge, type of waste, concentration and volume, if known, and corrective actions taken by the user. 
(b)  Written notification. Within five (5) working days following such discharge, the user must submit a detailed written report describing the cause(s) of the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent similar future occurrences. Notification does not relieve the user of any expense, loss, damage, or other liability, which the user incurs as a result of damage to the POTW or natural resources or of any other damage to persons or property, nor does notification relieve the user of any fines, penalties, or other liability imposed pursuant to this chapter. 
(c)  Posting notification procedures required. The user must permanently post a notice on the user's bulletin board, or other prominent place, advising employees whom to call in the event of a discharge described in subsection (a) above. The user must ensure that all employees who may cause such a discharge to occur are advised of emergency notification procedures. 
(d)  Notification of changes. Significant industrial users are required to notify the city manager immediately of any changes at its facility affecting the potential for a slug discharge. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 12, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-102. - Sampling and analysis requirements. 
(a)  Sample collection. Samples collected to satisfy reporting requirements must be based on data obtained through appropriate sampling and analysis performed during the period covered by the report, based on data that is representative of conditions occurring during the reporting period. 
(b)  Sampling and analysis techniques. Sampling and analytical method requirements must comply with 40 CFR Part 136, paragraph 62-625.600(1)(e), F.A.C., Chapter 62-160, F.A.C., and the Department of Environmental Protection Standard Operating Procedures for Field Activities, DEP-SOP-001/01 (DEP-SOP-001, FS2400, Wastewater Sampling). If 40 CFR Part 136 does not contain sampling or analytical techniques for the pollutant in question, or where EPA determines that the Part 136 sampling and analytical techniques are inappropriate for the pollutant in question, the sampling organization, with the approval of the industrial user and control authority, shall identify and propose a method for use in accordance with Rule 62-160.220, F.A.C. 
(c)  Flow proportional sampling. Except as specified by subsections (d) and (f) below, twenty-four-hour composite samples must be obtained using flow proportional collection techniques. In the event flow proportional sampling is not feasible, the city manager may authorize time proportional sampling or a minimum of four (4) grab samples where the user demonstrates that these techniques will provide a representative sample of the effluent being discharged. Using protocols (including appropriate preservation) specified in Chapter 62-160, F.A.C., and DEP-SOP-001/01, multiple grab samples collected during a twenty-four-hour period may be composited prior to analysis as follows: for cyanide, total phenols, and sulfides the samples may be composited in the laboratory or in the field; for volatile organics and oil and grease, the samples may be composited in the laboratory. Composite samples for other parameters unaffected by the compositing procedures as documented in approved DEP sampling procedures and laboratory methodologies may be authorized by the city manager, as appropriate. Additionally, the city manager may require grab samples to show compliance with instantaneous limits. 
(d)  Grab collection sampling. Samples for oil and grease, temperature, pH, cyanide, total phenols, sulfides, and volatile organic compounds must be obtained using grab collection techniques. 
(e)  Oil and grease samples. Oil and grease samples shall be collected in accordance with paragraphs (c) and (d) above unless the sampling location or point cannot be physically accessed to perform a direct collection of a grab sample. In these instances, the sample shall be pumped from the sampling location or point into the sample container using a peristaltic-type pump. All pump tubing used for sample collection must be new or pre-cleaned and must be changed between sample containers and sample points. The pump tubing shall not be pre-rinsed or flushed with sample prior to collection of the sample. The report of analysis shall indicate that a peristaltic pump was used to collect the oil and grease sample. 
(f)  For sampling required in support of baseline monitoring and ninety-day compliance reports required in sections 26-96 and 26-97, a minimum of four (4) grab samples must be used for pH, cyanide, total phenols, oil and grease, sulfide and volatile organic compounds for facilities for which historical sampling data do not exist; for facilities for which historical sampling data are available, the city manager may authorize a lower minimum. For the reports required by section 26-99, the industrial user is required to collect the number of grab samples necessary to assess and assure compliance by with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 13, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-103. - Record keeping. 
    Users subject to the reporting requirements of this chapter must retain, and make available for inspection and copying, all records and information related to monitoring activities required by this ordinance, any additional records of information obtained pursuant to monitoring activities undertaken by the user independent of such requirements, and documentation associated with best management practices established under section 26-80. Records must include the date, exact place, method, and time of sampling; the name(s) of the person(s) taking the samples; the dates analyses were performed; name(s) of the person(s) performing the analyses; the analytical techniques or methods used; and the results of such analyses. These records must remain available for a period of at least five (5) years. This period shall be automatically extended for the duration of any litigation concerning the user or the city, or where the city manager has specifically notified the user of a longer retention period. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 14, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-104. - Right of entry for inspection and sampling. 
    The city manager has the right to enter the premises of any user to determine whether the user is complying with the provisions of this chapter, any wastewater discharge permit or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement. Users are required to allow the city manager ready access to all parts of the user's premises for inspection, sampling, examining and copying records, and performing any other duties specified by this chapter. 
(1)  Where a user's security system requires identification and clearance of persons before entering the premises, the user is required to make all necessary arrangements to allow the city manager, upon presenting suitable identification, to enter the premises without delay to administer and enforce this chapter. 
(2)  The city manager has the right to install sampling or monitoring equipment on the user's premises. 
(3)  The city manager may require the user to install sampling or monitoring equipment. The user, at the user's expense, must maintain all sampling and monitoring equipment in safe and proper operating condition at all times. All devices used to measure wastewater flow and quality must be certified as required by the manufacturer, but not less than annually, and must be calibrated prior to use to ensure accuracy. 
(4)  At the written or verbal request of the city manager, the user must promptly remove any temporary or permanent obstructions preventing safe and easy access to the premises for inspection or sampling. The user cannot thereafter replace any such obstructions. The user must bear the costs of removing such obstructions. 
(5)  Unreasonable delays in allowing the city manager access to the user's premises are a violation of this chapter. 
(6)  In the event that the city manager is refused access to a user's premises, or any part thereof, as part of administering or enforcing this chapter, the city manager may seek a search warrant from a court of competent jurisdiction to allow access. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-105. - Confidential information. 
    The city manager shall generally make information and data related to a user obtained by enforcing and implementing this chapter available to the public without restriction. However, the user may request that certain information and data not be made available to the public because it would divulge trade secrets protected under state law. If the user so requests, and is able to demonstrate to the city manager that the release of such information and data would divulge trade secrets protected under state law, then the portions of a report which might disclose trade secrets will not be made available to the public. The user must make such a request, in writing, at the time the information or data is submitted. Such information or data will be made available upon request to governmental agencies for uses related to the NPDES program or pretreatment program and in enforcement proceedings involving the person furnishing the information or data. Wastewater constituents and characteristics and other effluent data defined by 40 CFR 2.302 are not recognized as confidential information and are available to the public without restriction. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-106. - Publication of users in significant noncompliance. 
    The city manager will publish annually, in the largest daily newspaper published in the city where the POTW is located, a list of users who were in significant noncompliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements during the previous twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02) 
Sec. 26-107. - Notice of violation, repeat sampling and reporting. 
    If sampling performed by a user indicates a violation, the user must notify the city manager within twenty-four (24) hours of becoming aware of the violation. The user must repeat the sampling and analysis and submit the results of the report analysis to the city manager within fourteen (14) calendar days after becoming aware of the violation. Where the city has performed the sampling and analysis in lieu of the industrial user, the city must perform the repeat sampling and analysis unless it notifies the user of the violation and requires the user to perform the repeat analysis. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 15, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-108. - Violations and enforcement. 
    If a user violates any provision of this chapter, any condition of a wastewater discharge permit, any condition of any order issued pursuant to this chapter, any pretreatment standard or requirement, or willfully or negligently introduces any substance into the POTW which causes personal injury or property damage, then the city manager may take against the user all or any, in any combination, in any order, of the listed enforcement actions. Taking a single enforcement action does not bar against, nor is a prerequisite for, taking other enforcement action against the user. 
(1)  Notice of violation. The city manager may issue the user a written notice of violation. Within ten (10) calendar days of receiving the notice of violation, the user must submit to the city manager: An explanation for the violation; a plan for correcting the violation; and a plan to prevent future violations, including specific required actions. Submitting this plan does not relieve the user of liability for any violations occurring either before or after receiving the notice of violation. 
(2)  Consent orders. The city manager may enter into a consent order, assurances of voluntary compliance, or other similar document establishing an agreement with any noncompliant user. Such documents must include specific action to be taken by the user to correct the violation within a specific time period. Such documents have the same force and effect as the compliance orders and cease and desist orders issued pursuant to this Code and are judicially enforceable. 
(3)  Show cause hearing. The city manager may order the user to appear before the city manager and show cause why a proposed enforcement action should not be taken. Notice will be served on the user specifying the time and place for the meeting, the proposed enforcement action, the reasons for such action, and a request that the user show cause why the proposed enforcement action should not be taken. The notice of the meeting will be served personally or by certified mail return receipt at least ten (10) calendar days prior to the hearing. Such notice may be served on any authorized representative of the user. 
(4)  Compliance orders. The city manager may order the noncompliant user to come into compliance within a specified time. If the user does not come into compliance within the specified time, then sewer service may be discontinued unless adequate treatment facilities, devices, or other related appurtenances are installed and properly operated. Compliance orders may also establish other requirements, including additional self-monitoring and management practices designed to minimize the amount of pollutants discharged to the POTW. A compliance order does not extend the deadline for compliance established for a pretreatment standard or requirement. A compliance order does not relieve the user of liability for any violation. 
(5)  Cease and desist orders. The city manager may order the user to cease and desist all violations, and direct the user to: 
a.  Immediately comply with all requirements; and 
b.  Take necessary corrective or preventive action to properly address an existing or threatened violation, including halting operations and/or terminating the discharge. 
(6)  Administrative fines and liens. The city manager may fine a noncompliant user an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per day. Such fines are assessed on a per-violation, per-day basis. In the case of monthly or other long-term average discharge limits, fines will be assessed for each day during the period of violation. Unpaid fines, after ninety (90) calendar days, may be recorded as a lien against the user's property. 
(7)  Emergency suspensions. The city manager may order a user to immediately suspend its discharge when an actual or threatened discharge reasonably appears to cause imminent or substantial endangerment to the health or welfare of persons, interfere with the operation of the POTW and/or its effluent discharge limitations, or endanger the environment. If the user fails to immediately comply with the suspension order, the city manager may disconnect or plug the user's sewer service. A noncompliant user responsible, in whole or in part, for any discharge causing imminent endangerment, must submit a detailed written statement to the city manager prior to the date of any show cause or termination hearing, describing the causes of the harmful discharge and the measures taken to prevent any future occurrence. 
(8)  Termination of discharge. The city manager may terminate the discharge of any user who does any of the following. The city manager will notify such user a maximum of twenty-four (24) hours in advance of the termination. 
a.  Violates wastewater discharge permit conditions; 
b.  Fails to accurately report wastewater constituents and discharge characteristics; 
c.  Fails to report significant changes in operations or wastewater volume, constituents, and characteristics prior to discharge; 
d.  Refuses to allow the city manager reasonable access to the user's premises for inspection, monitoring, or sampling; or 
e.  Violates the pretreatment standards established by this Code. 
(9)  Injunctive relief. The city manager may petition any court of competent jurisdiction to issue a temporary or permanent injunction, as appropriate, which restrains or compels the specific performance of the wastewater discharge permit, order, or other requirement imposed by this chapter on activities of the user. The city manager may also seek other action appropriate for legal and/or equitable relief, including a requirement for the user to conduct environmental remediation. 
(10)  Civil penalties. The city manager may file suit in any court of competent jurisdiction to impose a minimum civil penalty of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation, per day. Penalties shall accrue for each day during the period of the violation. The city may recover reasonable attorneys' fees, court costs, and other expenses associated with enforcement activities, including sampling and monitoring expenses, and the cost of any actual damages incurred by the city. 
(11)  Criminal prosecution. The city manager may file criminal charges in any court of competent jurisdiction against the noncompliant user. The user shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a minimum fine of one thousand ($1,000.00) dollars per violation per day, or imprisonment for not more than sixty (60) calendar days, or both. In the case of a user who willfully or negligently introduces any substance into the POTW causing personal injury or property damage, this penalty shall be in addition to any other action for personal injury or property damage available under state law. 
(12)  Disconnecting water supply and sewer service. The city manager may disconnect the water service and/or sewer service to the noncompliant user. Service will be restored, at the user's expense, only after the user demonstrates the ability to comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 02-04, § 5, 3-11-02; Ord. No. 11-25, § 16, 10-24-11) 
Sec. 26-109. - Upset, affirmative defense and bypass. 
(a)  [Upset.] An upset does not constitute noncompliance to the extent caused by operational error, improperly designed treatment facilities, inadequate treatment facilities, lack of preventative maintenance or careless or improper operation. 
(b)  Effect of an upset. An upset shall constitute an affirmative defense to an action brought for noncompliance with the categorical pretreatment standards if the requirements of subsection (c) below are met. 
(c)  Conditions necessary for a demonstration of upset. An industrial user who wishes to establish the affirmative defense of an upset shall demonstrate, through properly signed, contemporaneous operating logs, or other relevant evidence that: 
(1)  An upset occurred and the industrial user can identify the cause of the upset; 
(2)  The industrial user's facility was, at the time of the upset, being properly operated; and 
(3)  The industrial user has orally submitted the following information to the control authority within twenty-four (24) hours of becoming aware of the upset, with a written submission to be provided within five (5) days: 
a.  A description of the discharge and cause of noncompliance; 
b.  The period of noncompliance, including exact dates and times or, if not corrected, the anticipated time the noncompliance is expected to continue; and 
c.  Steps being taken or planned to reduce, eliminate and prevent recurrence of noncompliance. 
(d)  Industrial user responsibility in case of an upset. The industrial user shall control production of all discharges to the extent necessary to maintain compliance with categorical pretreatment standards upon reduction, loss, or failure of its treatment facility until the facility is restored or an alternative method of treatment is provided. This requirement applies in the situation where, among other things, the primary source of power of the treatment facility is reduced, lost or fails. 
(e)  Affirmative defense. A user has an affirmative defense to enforcement action brought against it for violating section 26-78 of this Code if the user can prove that it did not know, or have reason to know, that its discharge, alone or in conjunction with discharges from other sources, would cause pass-through or interference in the POTW, and that either: 
(1)  A local limit exists for each pollutant discharged, and the user was in compliance with each local limit directly prior to, and during, the pass-through or interference; or 
(2)  No local limit exists, but the discharge did not change substantially in nature or constituents from the user's prior discharge when the city was regularly in compliance with its NPDES permit, and in the case of interference, was in compliance with applicable sludge use or disposal requirements. 
(f)  Bypass not violating applicable pretreatment standards or requirements. An industrial user may allow any bypass to occur which does not cause pretreatment standards or the requirements to be violated, but only if it is for essential maintenance to assure efficient operation. These bypasses are not subject to the provision of (g), (h) and (i) below. 
(g)  Notice in the event of anticipated bypass. If a user knows in advance of the need for a bypass, the user must notify the city manager at least ten (10) calendar days before the date of the bypass. If the industrial user does not know of the need for a bypass ten days prior to the bypass then the industrial user shall notify the city manager immediately upon knowledge of the need for a bypass. 
(h)  Notice in the event of an unanticipated bypass. A user must submit oral notice to the city manager of any unanticipated bypass that exceeds applicable pretreatment standards within twenty-four (24) hours of the time the user becomes aware of the bypass. The user must follow up with written notification to the city manager within five (5) calendar days of the date the user became aware of the bypass. The written notification must contain: A description of the bypass and its cause; the duration of the bypass, including exact dates and times, and, if the bypass has not been corrected, how long it is expected to continue; and steps taken or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent recurrence of the bypass. 
(i)  Prohibition of bypass. Bypass is prohibited, and the control authority shall take enforcement against an individual for a bypass, unless: 
(1)  Bypass was unavoidable to prevent loss of life, personal injury, or severe property damage; 
(2)  There were no feasible alternatives to the bypass, such as the use of auxiliary treatment facilities, retention of untreated wastes, or maintenance during normal periods of equipment downtime. This condition is not satisfied if adequate back-up equipment should have been installed in the exercise of reasonable engineering judgment to prevent a bypass which occurred during normal periods of equipment downtime or preventative maintenance; and 
(3)  The user submitted notices as required in this paragraph. 
(j)  Anticipated bypass approval. The city manager shall approve an anticipated bypass, after considering its adverse effects, if the city manager determines that it will meet the three conditions listed in paragraph (i) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 08-11, § 3, 6-23-08; Ord. No. 11-25, § 17, 10-24-11; Ord. No. 16-01, § 2, 1-25-16) 
ARTICLE V. - WATER CONSERVATION THROUGH LANDSCAPE IRRIGATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Landscaping, § 25-51 et seq. 

Sec. 26-110. - Intent and purpose. 
    This article implements procedures which promote water conservation through the more efficient use of landscape irrigation. 
(Ord. No. 09-15, § 1, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 26-111. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivatives shall have the meanings given below. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense shall include the future tense, words used in the plural form shall include the singular form and words used in the singular form shall include the plural form. 
    Address means the house number of a physical location of a specific property. The term includes "rural route" numbers but excludes post office box numbers. If a lot number in a mobile home park or similar community is used by the U.S. Postal Service to determine a delivery location, the lot number shall be the property's address. An "even numbered address" means an address ending in the numbers 0, 2 ,4, 6, 8 or the letters A-M. An "odd numbered address" means an address ending in the numbers 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 or the letters N-Z. 
    District means the St. Johns River Water Management District. 
    Landscape irrigation means the outside watering of plants in a landscape such as shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, ground covers, plants, vines, gardens and other such flora situated in such diverse locations as residential areas, cemeteries, public, commercial and industrial establishments and public medians and rights-of-way. Landscape irrigation does not include golf course greens, tees, fairways, primary roughs and vegetation associated with intensive recreational areas such as, but not limited to, playgrounds and football, baseball and soccer fields. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Nonresidential landscape irrigation means the irrigation of landscape not included within the definition of residential landscape irrigation, such as that associated with public, commercial and industrial property, including commercial or transient housing units, hotel and motel units and public medians and rights-of-way. 
    Residential landscape irrigation means the irrigation of landscape associated with any housing unit having sanitary and kitchen facilities designed to accommodate one (1) or more residents, including multiple housing units and mobile homes. 
(Ord. No. 09-15, § 1, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 26-112. - Landscape irrigation schedule. 
(a)  When Daylight Savings Time is in effect, landscape irrigation shall occur only in accordance with the following irrigation schedule: 
(1)  Landscape irrigation at odd numbered addresses or at properties with no addresses may occur only on Wednesday and Saturday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
(2)  Landscape irrigation at even numbered addresses may occur only on Thursday and Sunday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
(3)  Nonresidential landscape irrigation may only occur on Tuesday and Friday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
(4)  No more than three-fourth-inch of water may be applied per irrigation zone on each day irrigation occurs and in no event shall irrigation occur for more than one (1) hour per irrigation zone on each day irrigation occurs. 
(b)  When Eastern Standard Time is in effect, landscape irrigation shall occur only in accordance with the following irrigation schedule: 
(1)  Landscape irrigation at odd numbered addresses or at properties with no addresses may occur only on Saturday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
(2)  Landscape irrigation at even numbered addresses may only occur on Sunday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. daily; and 
(3)  Nonresidential landscape irrigation may occur on Tuesday and shall not occur between 10:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.; and 
(4)  No more than three-fourth-inch of water may be applied per irrigation zone on each day that irrigation occurs, and in no event shall irrigation occur for more than one (1) hour per irrigation zone on each day that irrigation occurs. 
(c)  All landscape irrigation shall be limited in amount to only that necessary to meet landscape needs. 
(Ord. No. 09-15, § 1, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 26-113. - Exceptions to landscape irrigation schedules. 
    Landscape irrigation shall be subject to the following irrigation schedule exceptions: 
(1)  Irrigation using a micro-spray, micro-jet, drip or bubbler irrigation system is allowed anytime. 
(2)  Irrigation of new landscape is allowed at any time of day on any day for the initial thirty (30) days and every other day for the next thirty (30) days for a total of one sixty-day period, provided that the irrigation is limited to the minimum amount necessary for such landscape establishment. 
(3)  Watering in of chemicals, including insecticides, pesticides, fertilizers, fungicides and herbicides when required by law, the manufacturer's product application instructions or best management practices is allowed anytime within twenty-four (24) hours of application of the chemicals. Watering in of chemicals shall not exceed one-fourth-inch of water per application except as otherwise required by law, the manufacturer's product application instructions or best management practices. 
(4)  Irrigation systems may operate anytime for maintenance and repair purposes not to exceed twenty (20) minutes per hour per zone. 
(5)  Irrigation using a hand-held hose equipped with an automatic shut-off nozzle is allowed anytime. 
(6)  Discharge of water from a water-to-air air-conditioning unit or other water-dependent cooling system is not limited. 
(7)  The use of water from a reclaimed water system is allowed anytime. For the purpose of this paragraph, a reclaimed water system includes systems for which the primary water source is reclaimed water and which may or may not be supplemented from another water source during peak demand periods. 
(8)  The use of recycled water from wet detention treatment ponds for irrigation is allowed anytime provided the ponds are not augmented from any ground or off-site surface water or public supply sources. 
(Ord. No. 09-15, § 1, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 26-114. - Additional requirement. 
    Any person who irrigates landscape with an automatic lawn sprinkler system installed after May 1, 1991 shall install, maintain and operate a rain sensor device or switch which overrides the irrigation system when adequate rainfall has occurred. 
(Ord. No. 09-15, § 1, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 26-115. - Variance from specific day of the week limitations. 
    The city commission may grant variances to these landscape irrigation schedule provisions under the following conditions: 
(1)  The specified day or days for irrigation would lead to unreasonable or unfair results in particular instances, provided that the applicant demonstrates with particularity that compliance with the scheduled day or days will result in a substantial economic, health or other hardship on the applicant requesting the variance or those served by the applicant. Where a contiguous property is divided into different zones, a variance may be granted hereunder so that each zone may be irrigated on different days than other zones of the property. However, no single zone may be irrigated more than two (2) days a week during Daylight Savings Time and not more than one (1) day a week during Eastern Standard Time. 
(2)  All users or customers requesting a variance as set forth above shall file with the city manager a petition for variance but shall conform to the greatest possible extent to the provisions of this ordinance until such variance is granted. 
(3)  A petition for variance shall be in writing and contain, at a minimum, the following: 
a.  The petitioner's name and address. 
b.  A detailed statement of the facts which the petitioner believes and demonstrates that the request qualifies for variance. 
c.  A description of the variance desired. 
d.  The period of time for which the variance is sought, including the reasons and facts in support thereof. 
e.  Other relevant information the petitioner believes supports his/her petition for variance. 
(4)  Variances granted under the provisions of this section shall be issued in writing. 
(Ord. No. 09-15, § 1, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 26-116. - Application of ordinance. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to each person located within the City of St. Augustine. 
(Ord. No. 09-15, § 1, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 26-117. - Enforcement officials. 
    This article may be enforced by the city manager, his authorized representative(s), the City of St. Augustine Police Department and any law enforcement officer of the state. 
(Ord. No. 09-15, § 1, 4-27-09) 
Sec. 26-118. - Penalties. 
(a)  Violation of any provision of this article shall be subject to the following penalties: 
First violation: Written warning. 
Second violation: Fifty dollars ($50.00). 
Subsequent violations: Fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(b)  Each day in violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. Enforcement officials shall provide violators with no more than one (1) written warning. In addition to the civil sanctions contained herein, the city may take any other appropriate legal action, including, but not limited to, injunctive action to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 09-15, § 1, 4-27-09) 
Chapter 27 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxation and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17; guides, § 17-121 et seq. 
State Law reference- Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 27-1-27-22. - Reserved. 
Sec. 27-23. - Definitions. 
(a)  For hire passenger transportation vehicle means any motorized or non-motorized vehicle, when used for transporting persons for compensation; let or rented to another for consideration; offered for rent or hire as a means of transportation for compensation; advertised in a newspaper or generally held out as being for rent or hire; used in connection with a travel bureau; or offered or used to provide transportation for persons solicited through personal contact or advertised on a "share-expense" basis. 
(b)  Low speed vehicle means any four-wheeled vehicle whose top speed is greater than twenty (20) miles per hour but not greater than twenty-five (25) miles per hour. Low-speed vehicles must comply with the safety standards in 49 C.F.R. s. 571.500 and s. 316.2122 as may be amended. 
(c)  Pedicab means either: 
(1)  A bicycle that has two (2), three (3) or more wheels, that transports, or is capable of transporting, passengers on seats attached to the bicycle, that is operated by an individual and that is used for transporting passengers for monetary consideration; or 
(2)  A bicycle with that has a single unarticulated frame, that pulls a sidecar or similar device that transports, or is capable of transporting, passengers on seats attached to the sidecar or similar device, that is operated by an individual, and that is used for transporting passengers for monetary consideration. 
(d)  Taxicab means any motor vehicle for hire, other than horse-drawn carriage, trailer train, low speed vehicle or pedicab, used for the transportation of passengers for hire, or offered for hire to the public for transportation. 
(Ord. No. 16-10, § 1, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-24. - Applicability. 
    All operations of for hire passenger transportation vehicles business or services rendered pursuant hereto shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 16-10, § 1, 9-22-16; Ord. No. 17-33, § 1, 11-13-17) 
Sec. 27-25. - Penalty and enforcement. 
    Violation of any provision of this article shall be punishable as provided in section 1-8 or code enforcement pursuant chapter 2, article VI of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 16-10, § 1, 9-22-16; Ord. No. 17-33, § 2, 11-13-17) 
ARTICLE II. - VEHICLE DRIVERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 27-26. - To remain with vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, operator or driver of any for hire passenger transportation vehicle, or driver of any horse-drawn vehicle for hire, to leave or absent himself for a greater distance than ten (10) feet from such for hire passenger transportation vehicle or horse-drawn vehicle, of which he has charge as driver, while such for hire passenger transportation vehicle or horse-drawn vehicle is parked or standing along the side of the curb of any public street within the city; provided, however, that such driver may assist passengers for hire in loading or unloading their hand baggage to and from such for hire passenger transportation vehicle or horse-drawn vehicle for hire. This section shall be construed to govern the persons named herein only while conducting their business as a vehicle for hire. 
(Code 1964, § 28-1; Ord. No. 16-10, § 2, 9-22-16; Ord. No. 17-33, § 3, 11-13-17) 
Cross reference- Guides, § 17-73(67). 
Sec. 27-27. - Drivers for hire to be photographed. 
    It shall be the duty of all drivers of for hire passenger transportation vehicles including, but not limited to taxicabs, pedicabs, low speed vehicles, horse-drawn vehicles, trailer trains or other vehicles used for sightseeing, to be photographed by the city manager or his designee. Duplicates of such photograph shall be retained by the city and shall appear on the identification badge issued pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1964, § 28-3; Ord. No. 96-16, § 1, 4-22-96; Ord. No. 16-10, § 2, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-28. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 96-16, § 2, adopted April 22, 1996, repealed former § 27-28, relative to furnishing cards to the police department, which derived from Code 1964, § 28-5. 
Sec. 27-29. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 96-16, § 3, adopted April 22, 1996, repealed former § 27-29, relative to the police furnishing cards as receipt for fingerprinting, which derived from Code 1964, § 28-4. 
Sec. 27-30. - For hire driver's appearance and credentials. 
    Every for hire driver shall be clean and neat in appearance and shall, while on duty, wear the identification badge issued by the city bearing the inscription, "Licensed for Hire Driver," the license year, the official St. Augustine photograph of the driver and the seal of the City of St. Augustine. Said badge shall be worn in plain view at all times while engaged in activities licensed under this section. 
(Code 1964, § 28-12; Ord. No. 96-16, § 4, 4-22-96; Ord. No. 16-10, § 2, 9-22-16) 
Secs. 27-31-27-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION 

Sec. 27-46. - Required examination; issuance of permit; data concerning convictions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate a for hire passenger transportation vehicle including, but not limited to, taxicabs, pedicabs, low speed vehicles, horse-drawn vehicles, trailer trains, or other vehicles used for sightseeing in the city, until such person has taken an examination to show a satisfactory knowledge of the principal streets of the city and all main thoroughfares leading out of the city, as well as a thorough knowledge of all the provisions of this Code and other ordinances relative to traffic regulations. Such examination shall be conducted by the city manager or his designee. Any person desiring to take such examination shall furnish a sworn written statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance. The city manager shall have the right to deny a permit under this section if it is determined that an applicant has been convicted of a felony or a criminal traffic offense as described in section 27-51 of this article. The applicant shall have the right to appeal such decision to the city commission within thirty (30) days, which shall hold a hearing at the next available city commission meeting and upon notice to the applicant, to determine whether to issue a permit to an applicant denied a permit due to such conviction. When such person shall comply with the provisions of this section and show satisfactory evidence of his qualifications as provided by this section, the city manager or his designee shall issue a permit and identification badge as provided within this article upon payment of the required fees. 
(Code 1964, § 28-6; Ord. No. 96-16, § 5, 4-22-96; Ord. No. 16-10, § 2, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-47. - Notice of change of address, etc., required. 
    Any driver or operator registered under the provisions of this article is required to promptly notify the city manager of any change of his residence, place of employment or change of the vehicle which he is driving. 
(Code 1964, § 28-7; Ord. No. 96-16, § 6, 4-22-96) 
Sec. 27-48. - Records to be kept. 
    It shall be the duty of the city manager or his or her designee to keep a record of all the data required by section 27-46. 
(Code 1964, § 28-8; Ord. No. 96-16, § 7, 4-22-96; Ord. No. 16-10, § 2, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-49. - Permit to be on annual basis. 
    Any person to whom a permit and identification badge have been issued under the provisions of this article shall be entitled to such permit and identification badge from year to year upon payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) upon initial issuance and ten dollars ($10.00) for each year renewed thereafter, plus any occupational license fee as required by section 17-73 of this Code and a fee, as established by the city manager, to cover the city's cost in administering examinations, performing criminal records searches and issuing badges required by this chapter; provided, however, that such person shall fully comply with the provisions of this article and such other ordinances, rules and regulations as shall be enacted or adopted from time to time by the city; and provided further that the city commission, for good cause shown, may at any time revoke such permit and identification badge. 
(Code 1964, § 28-10; Ord. No. 96-16, § 8, 4-22-96) 
Sec. 27-50. - Revocation of permit. 
    If any person licensed under this article shall commit an infraction punishable as provided in F.S. § 316.655, as amended, or violate any of the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city pertaining to automobiles or traffic, and on a third conviction thereof, his permit for operating such vehicle may be revoked by the city commission upon notice and hearing upon findings of fact which indicate violation of this article, and it shall thereafter be unlawful for him to operate such vehicle in the city. 
(Code 1964, § 28-9; Ord. No. 96-16, § 9, 4-22-96; Ord. No. 16-10, § 2, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-51. - Criminal traffic offenses. 
    Upon acquiring a license under this article, any person convicted of a violation of a criminal traffic offense, including s. 316.027, s. 316.061, s. 316.067, s. 316.072, s. 316.192, s. 316.193, s. 316.1935 or s. 316.2045(2), Florida Statutes, shall automatically have his permit revoked for a minimum period of one (1) year. Such revocation may be appealed to the city commission. The city commission may, upon notice and hearing, permanently revoke the permit of any person convicted as provided herein. 
(Code 1964, § 28-11; Ord. No. 96-16, § 10, 4-22-96) 
Secs. 27-52-27-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MOTOR VEHICLES FOR HIRE 

Sec. 27-71. - Liability insurance-Required; amount; form; conditions; approval, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, operator, agent, lessee or driver of any for hire passenger transportation vehicle, to drive or operate the same, or permit the same to be driven or operated, on the public streets of this city, unless such owner, operator, agent, lessee, chauffeur or driver shall have first procured and filed with the city director of financial services, at all times while such vehicle is being driven or operated, a liability insurance policy issued by a reliable and responsible insurance company authorized to write liability insurance and to do business in the state in amounts of not less than the amounts required by F.S. § 324.032, or any amendment thereto. As of October 1, 2006, the requirements are as follows: One hundred twenty-five thousand dollars ($125,000.00) for one (1) person injured or killed, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for all property damaged or destroyed in any one (1) accident, and two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for more than one (1) person injured or killed in any one (1) accident, covering each motor-driven passenger vehicle owned, operated, driven or controlled by such owner, operator, agent, lessee or driver. 
(b)  The policy required by this section may be in the form of a separate policy for each vehicle or may be in the form of a fleet policy covering all vehicles operated by such owner, operator, agent, lessee, chauffeur or driver. In the latter event, such policy shall provide insurance on each vehicle in amounts of not less than the amounts required by F.S. § 324.032, or any amendment thereto. As of October 1, 2006, the requirements are as follows: One hundred twenty-five thousand dollars ($125,000.00) for one (1) person injured or killed, and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for all property damaged or destroyed in any one (1) accident, and not less than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for more than one (1) person injured or killed in any one (1) accident. 
(c)  Such policy or policies shall cover: 
(1)  All sums which the insured shall become obligated to pay by reason of the liability imposed upon the insured by law for damages, including damages for care and loss of services, because of bodily injury, including death at any time resulting therefrom, sustained by any person, caused by accident and arising out of the ownership, maintenance, operation or use of such vehicle. 
(2)  All sums which the insured shall become obligated to pay by reason of the liability imposed upon the insured by law for damages because of injury to or destruction of property, including the loss of use thereof, caused by accident and arising out of the ownership, maintenance, operation or use of such vehicle. Such policy or policies shall include an endorsement to the effect that the same cannot be altered, modified or cancelled for any cause without notice being served upon the city director of financial services at least fifteen (15) days prior to the date of such alteration, modification or cancellation. 
(d)  Such policy or policies shall be in the generally accepted form in use in this state by liability insurance companies for such public and property damage liability insurance policies, and shall, among other things, provide that the insolvency or bankruptcy of the insured shall not relieve the insurer from the payment of damages for injuries or death sustained, or loss occasioned, within the provisions of the policy. All such policies, before becoming effective, under this article, shall be approved by the city manager as to sufficiency and the city attorney as to form. 
(Code 1964, § 28-22; Ord. No. 07-22, § 1, 12-10-07; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-72. - Same-Prerequisite to issuance of license. 
    No city license for the operation of any for hire passenger transportation vehicle shall be issued until the insurance policy shall have been filed and approved as provided for in section 27-71. 
(Code 1964, § 28-23; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-73. - Same-Effect of lapse, expiration or termination. 
    If at any time during the effective period of any city license issued for the operation of any for hire passenger transportation vehicle the licensee suffers or allows the policy required by section 27-71 to lapse or to become ineffective, or if the insurer thereof becomes unable financially to respond to the obligation thereof, or such policy is suffered or allowed to expire or terminate in whole or in part, then at the same time the license of such licensee to drive or operate such vehicle shall ipso facto become null and void. 
(Code 1964, § 28-24; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-74. - Congested areas-To be designated by resolution, etc. 
    The city commission shall, by resolution, from time to time, as in its judgment public necessity, safety or convenience may require, create, define and declare any areas within the city as "congested areas." When such areas are so created and designated, all of the provisions in this article for or relating to congested areas shall be applicable and enforceable as to the congested areas created hereunder. Any congested area may be enlarged, restricted, changed, relocated or abolished by the city commission, by resolution, as in its judgment public necessity, safety or convenience may require. All such resolutions shall be published once before they shall become effective. 
(Code 1964, § 28-25) 
Sec. 27-75. - Same-Vehicles to use "taxi" stands. 
    Every taxicab, upon entering any congested area created under this article, shall proceed directly to an unoccupied "taxi" stand and shall enter and remain upon such stand until employed by a passenger or until such vehicle is otherwise ready to leave the congested area. 
(Code 1964, § 28-26; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-76. - Rates and charges-To be fixed by resolution. 
    The city commission shall by resolution, from time to time, fix and establish reasonable rates and charges for the transportation of persons and their baggage within the city in for hire passenger transportation vehicles, and also in the same manner, amend, alter, change or abolish same. All such resolutions shall be published at least once before they shall become effective. 
(Code 1964, § 28-27; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-77. - Same-Exceeding amounts fixed. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator or driver of any for hire passenger transportation vehicle to charge or demand of any customer any sum of money in excess of the rates or charges fixed and established by the city commission under the provisions of section 27-76. 
(Code 1964, § 28-28; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-78. - Same-Cruising and solicitation of passengers. 
(a)  Cruising or driving on the public streets within any congested area created under section 27-74 soliciting prospective passengers for hire is hereby prohibited. No driver or other person shall stop or park any for hire passenger transportation vehicle for hire on any street or highway of the city within any such congested area for the purpose of soliciting passengers, except at such places designated as "for-hire" or "taxi" stands. No driver of any such vehicle shall solicit any patron to board such vehicle at any public place within any such congested area except at the curb within the boundaries of a "for-hire" or "taxi" stand. No driver of such vehicle shall, within any such congested area, while such vehicle is not upon a "for-hire" or "taxi" stand, by word, sign or other signal, solicit any person to become a passenger in such vehicle; provided, that no restriction contained herein shall prohibit any such vehicle from proceeding to any designated place: 
(1)  To pick up any patron who has, prior to the beginning of that journey, by telephone or other communication, requested such vehicle to meet such patron at such designated place; or 
(2)  To deliver any patron to his requested destination; provided further, that no such vehicle shall load or unload passengers with any such congested area except at the curb of the street. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any for hire passenger transportation vehicle to park or solicit business on the streets of the city within any such congested area except as hereinabove provided. 
(Code 1964, § 28-29; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-79. - Refusal to pay legal fare. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare, whether it is fixed by the city commission or a lesser amount agreed to between the parties, for the use of for hire passenger transportation vehicles. 
(Code 1964, § 28-30; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-80. - Cards showing schedule of rates, photograph and name of operator, etc., to be posted in vehicle. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner, operator, agent, lessee, chauffeur or driver of any for hire passenger transportation vehicle to procure from the city director of financial services suitable cards, which shall be in a form prescribed by the city manager, and shall show the schedule of the rates and charges for the transportation services furnished by the operator of the vehicle; a photograph of the driver of such vehicle and his name, address and city license number; and also, the name and address of the owner of such vehicle. 
(b)  Such cards shall be posted in a conspicuous place within such vehicle while it is in use as a for hire passenger transportation vehicle, so that it may be clearly visible to all passengers in such vehicle. 
(Code 1964, § 28-31; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-81. - Signs or markings required on vehicles. 
    Every for hire passenger transportation vehicle in the city, while on the street, shall have placed thereon a sign, or painted thereon in letters at least three (3) inches in height, and plainly visible and distinguishable from the vehicle, the company name, phone number, and unique vehicle number. The company name and phone number will be on both sides of the vehicle. The unique number will be displayed on the front, back and both sides of the vehicle. In addition, the unique number will be displayed on the dashboard and back of the front passenger seat of the vehicle and shall be clearly visible from the rear compartment of the vehicle. 
(Code 1964, § 28-32; Ord. No. 94-05, § 1, 2-28-94; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-82. - Owner to register vehicle with police. 
    Every owner of a for hire passenger transportation vehicle in the city shall register such vehicle used for hire with the police department annually, on January first of each year. 
(Code 1964, § 28-33; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-83. - Equipment and safety requirements. 
    Every for hire passenger transportation vehicle under this article shall be at all times in good order and repair in a clean condition and well ventilated when in operation, so as to render safe, adequate and proper service, and so as not to be a menace to the safety of the patron of the vehicle or general public. 
    Every for hire passenger transportation vehicle shall comply with the equipment and safety standards of this sub-section as applicable by type: 
(a)  Taxicab. 
(1)  Taxicabs shall meet the following equipment and safety standards annually: 
(i)  The windshield and all side and rear windows shall provide clear visibility and operate according to the manufacturer's specifications. The windshield and all windows shall possess no breakage, cracks or pits that impair visibility or hinder the safety of passengers. All window cranks/power window switches shall be complete, intact and functioning. Windows on vehicles for hire shall not be covered by, or treated with a material which would cause the vehicle to be in violation of F.S. §§ 316.2951-316.2956, as may be amended. 
(ii)  All standard manufacturer's interior equipment shall be complete, intact and functioning; including, but not limited to interior lights, dashboard, trim, gear shifts and head rests. Vehicle interiors must not contain loose objects and must be clean, sanitary, and free of broken seats/protruding sharp edges or torn or damaged upholstery, headliner, or floor coverings. The vehicle's interior must be free of offensive odors. The floor board shall be free of rust and holes. Trunks and luggage compartments must be kept clean and free of debris. 
(iii)  All doors must have operating handles, which allow opening from both the inside and outside, and door hinges and latches must function properly. Door locks must be operable by passengers at all times. Door seals and gaskets must be intact/operating and prevent water, odor and fumes from entering the vehicle from outside. All door panels must be intact to prevent accidental injuries on door and window mechanisms. 
(iv)  Seat belts shall be available for all passengers (according to manufacturer's specifications and state law). Seat belts shall be in operating condition, easily accessible, clean and free of grease and other objectionable substances. 
(v)  All vehicles shall be equipped with a fully functioning heating and air conditioning system. The vehicle shall be equipped with a fully functioning windshield defrost or defogging system. 
(vi)  All vehicles shall be equipped with a light capable of illuminating the interior of the vehicle, controlled by the operation of the doors, or manually controlled by the driver. 
(vii)  The transportation of children shall be in accordance with F.S. § 316.613, as may be amended. 
(viii)  Those vehicles and operations, which are subject to the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), shall comply with the applicable provisions of said Act. 
(ix)  The vehicle's body, fenders, doors, trim, grill and paint must be free from cracks, breaks, rust, and body damage that detracts from the overall appearance of the vehicle or could result in harm or injury to the passenger or his/her personal belongings. 
(x)  The vehicle must be equipped with safe tires of the same size. No recaps shall be used. Maximum allowable tread wear shall be where tread is level with the wear bar, or two-thirty-seconds-inch when measured at three (3) random places in the tire tread. The tires shall be inflated to manufacturer's specifications and free of cuts, cracks, bulges, or exposed belts. 
(xi)  Windshield wipers must be operational according to the manufacturer's specifications. Wiper blades shall be in such a condition as to make firm contact with the windshield when operational, and shall not be torn or worn. 
(xii)  Reflectors and lenses shall not be cracked or missing and must be the correct color and properly positioned. 
(xiii)  Low and high beam headlights, turn signals, brake, tail and reverse lights shall be operable as required by state law. Each vehicle shall have a white light on the vehicle to illuminate the rear license plate so that it is clearly visible. 
(xiv)  Steering mechanisms shall not be worn or jammed, nor shall there be more than two inches play to the left or right of center, measured at the steering wheel rim with the front wheels in a straight-ahead position. Power steering units shall not have visible signs of fluid leakage. 
(xv)  The vehicle suspension shall function as designed by the manufacturer. 
(xvi)  The vehicle shall be equipped with an operating horn with the actuating button mounted in the location designated by the vehicle manufacturer and operated in the manner designed and assembled by the vehicle manufacturer. 
(xvii)  Each vehicle shall contain an operating parking brake and a primary brake system which acts on all four (4) vehicle wheels. There shall be no visible leaks in the brake line, hoses, wheel cylinders or any part of the brake system and no frayed cables. Brake linings and/or disc pads, when measured at the thinnest point shall not be less than one-sixteenth ( 1/16 ) of an inch and firmly attached to the brake shoe or disc. Disc brake rotors and brake drums shall be of a size and type appropriate for the vehicle, with no cracks or other damage which change or impair the functional surface. All primary brake systems shall demonstrate a reasonable total braking force when conducting a rolling stop. 
(xviii)  There shall be no leakage of exhaust gas from the exhaust manifold, muffler or any other point in the exhaust system as determined through a visual and audible inspection. The tail pipe shall discharge exhaust from the rear of the vehicle according to manufacturer specifications. 
(xix)  Belts shall show no signs of excessive wear and be free of cracks and frays. Hoses shall be firm and in good condition, free of leaks and cracks. 
(xx)  All fluid levels shall be maintained according to manufacturer's specifications. 
(xxi)  Vehicles are required to have manufacturer specified spare tires and tire changing equipment, unless all wheels are equipped with a "run flat tire" system. 
(xxii)  Vehicles must be equipped with functioning speedometer and odometer. 
(xxiii)  Vehicles must receive routine maintenance according to the manufacturer's recommendations pertaining to service intervals. A record of such routine maintenance must be maintained and is subject to inspection by the division. 
(xxiv)  Businesses must ensure that each vehicle or driver has a means of communicating to a central dispatch or to emergency agencies with a two-way radio and/or cellular mobile telephone. 
(xxv)  Failure to comply with the provisions of this section and applicable sections of F.S. ch. 316, as may be amended, may result in denial of a permit(s), revocation or suspension of the permit(s), a denial of renewal of such permits, issuance of a civil citation, a misdemeanor conviction or other such remedies available to the division by law. 
(b)  Pedicab. 
(1)  Each pedicab must be equipped with the following, all of which shall be operational: 
(i)  A headlight capable of projecting a beam of light for a distance of five hundred (500) feet. 
(ii)  A taillight red in color and plainly visible from a distance of six hundred (600) feet to the rear of the pedicab. 
(iii)  A schedule of fare rates. 
(iv)  A signal bell or other warning device (except a siren, which is prohibited). 
(c)  Low speed vehicle. 
(1)  A low-speed vehicle must be equipped with headlamps, stop lamps, turn signal lamps, taillamps, reflex reflectors, parking brakes, rearview mirrors, windshields, seat belts, and vehicle identification numbers. 
(Code 1964, § 28-34; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-84. - Periodic inspection. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, operator, agent, lessee or driver of any for hire passenger transportation vehicle, to drive or operate the same, or permit the same to be driven or operated within the jurisdictional limits of the City of St. Augustine without current valid numbered medallion issued by the city displayed as required in section 27-84(e) below. 
(b)  Prior to receiving a medallion, each taxicab shall be inspected by an ASE certified mechanic that the vehicle is in compliance with the equipment and safety requirements as listed in section 27-83(a)(1)-(25) on a form provided by city fleet management. The applicant must provide to the city's fleet management the signed checklist from an ASE certified mechanic that the vehicle is safe prior to receiving their initial medallion. 
(c)  Each year prior to city renewing the medallion, each taxicab shall be inspected by an ASE certified mechanic that the vehicle is in compliance with a safety checklist as provided by city fleet management. The applicant must provide to the city's fleet management the signed checklist from an ASE certified mechanic that the vehicle is safe prior to receiving their renewed medallion. 
(d)  The owner of all other for hire passenger transportation vehicles shall, at least annually, subject the vehicle to a complete and thorough inspection by the city's fleet maintenance staff in accordance with the equipment and safety standards as listed for the vehicle type in subsection 27-83. 
(e)  If upon inspection the vehicle is found to comply with the requirements of section 27-83 and there is a current regulatory license on file for the vehicle, then a numbered medallion will be issued. This medallion will be fixed to the outside left rear of the vehicle, in plain view from the rear of the vehicle. A vehicle may be inspected and found to comply with requirements; however, if there is no current regulatory license on file, a numbered medallion will not be issued until a current regulatory license is obtained. 
(Code 1964, § 28-35; Ord. No. 92-12, § 1, 5-11-92; Ord. No. 07-18, § 1, 10-22-07; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16; Ord. No. 17-33, § 4, 11-13-17) 
Sec. 27-85. - Suspension and revocation of vehicle medallion. 
    The chief of police is given full power to suspend a medallion if he determines that the operation of a vehicle for hire would cause imminent danger to the public's safety. The suspension shall be effective immediately upon notice to the owner. The motor vehicle may not be returned to serve until it has been inspected and found to comply with section 27-83. 
(Code 1964, § 28-36) 
Sec. 27-86. - Inspection fee. 
(a)  Medallions issued are valid from October 1st through September 30th of each year. All for hire passenger transportation vehicles must be inspected annually as provided in section 27-84 and the annual fee will be as set by the city manager pursuant to section 2-74. 
(b)  The fee for reinspecting a vehicle that has been determined unsafe by the chief of police will be as set by the city manager pursuant to section 2-74. 
(c)  The annual fee collected under this article is a fee paid for the purpose of examination and inspection of vehicles for hire and the administration of this article. Such fees are declared to be regulatory fees in addition to and not in lieu of the occupational license taxes imposed. 
(Code 1964, § 28-37; Ord. No. 92-12, § 2, 5-11-92; Ord. No. 16-10, § 3, 9-22-16) 
Sec. 27-87. - Presumption of operation.
